[Story]: Keystone Park: Part 1 - Living in Fear
I"ve never been one for the spooky and strange stuff that people with paranoia always talk about. You will never see me standing on the side of an argument where someone is saying their house is bugged or someone is living in their attic. Even if that is the case, I don"t really give a damn. If someone has bugged the house, come and get me if what I"m saying is that bad. And if some random person is living in the walls or ceiling, more power to them as long as they don"t bother me.
But when you have someone like Fin, a complete psychopath trying to destroy our lives, you have to stay on guard 24/7. I gave birth to him, and I know the evil he is capable of. No one but me knows the magnitude of the crazy we are dealing with. When you"re a mother, some things are best left unspoken, but when you know, you know. And lately, I"ve been feeling like someone is constantly watching. Even before he went to jail, I never felt this way.

*** Text between my boyfriend and I ***

Me - Is it annoying as hell? Absolutely. But I"ve never had these feelings and vibes except for the last week or two. When you know, you just know, and whatever this feeling is about, it"s got to do with our privacy. I"m paranoid about him 24/7 because I know if he is in an "I don"t give a fuck" mindset, he will come up in here and do whatever he pleases. No matter who is here, if he lives or dies, jail or prison, when he wants something, he gets it. The cost is never too much for him. I promise you that.

My boyfriend

"I checked in a few places under the house. I didn't hear or see anything right then but I definitely heard that noise when we were outside. The cat kept running around real weird too"
My boyfriend- "I know what you mean. Last night I felt like something was trying to tell me something. And guess what fell from above and floated right in front of me when I squatted down to look under the house…. A feather"

Me- "I mean he could have did all kinds of stuff. He could have a 2 way radio under there to just creep us out. And with as much stuff as old man Frye prob has I"m sure it wouldn"t be hard for umm to get his hands on something to do just that. Unbeknownst to Glenn of course. He wouldn"t condone it. "

My boyfriend "I have felt like somebody has been sneaking up to the building and trying to look in it and shit for about the same amount of time. Like since he got out. We gotta get away from him and from here"

Me "Last night after I heard the weird shit I was sitting in here and I had just opened back up the floor vent. Cause it was getting hot again. Well about 7-8 mins later I felt like I was gonna pass the fuck out and wasn"t gonna be able to control myself doing so. Like not a sleepy pass out. More like a dizzy going under anesthesia kind of feeling it was really weird. I turned on the fan and the feeling subsided. But I was a little weirded out by that

I remember the early signs, the little things that hinted at the chaos to come. The temper tantrums that grew more violent, the unsettling calmness in his eyes when he got what he wanted. As a mother, you always hope that your child will find their way, that the love and guidance you offer will steer them towards a better path. But with Fin, that hope faded quickly. His defiance turned into something darker, something that made me fear for my safety and the safety of those around me.

The incidents started small—missing money, broken items, and unexplained absences. I would confront him, but his responses were always cold and calculating, as if he enjoyed the turmoil he was creating. The breaking point came when he began threatening us openly, making it clear that he would stop at nothing to get what he wanted. The police were no help; they could only do so much without concrete evidence, and Fin was smart enough to cover his tracks.

Living in Keystone Park, our once peaceful home has turned into a fortress. We"ve installed security cameras, changed locks, and even considered moving. But Fin knows us too well. He knows our routines, our weaknesses, and he exploits them with ruthless precision. Every knock on the door, every unfamiliar sound, sends a jolt of fear through me. I find myself constantly looking over my shoulder, wondering if today is the day he decides to make his next move.

Friends and family offer support, but they can"t truly understand the depth of this nightmare. They see Fin as the troubled young man who lost his way, not the monster I see in my nightmares. It"s a lonely battle, fighting to protect the ones you love from someone you once cherished. The guilt is overwhelming—wondering if there was something I could have done differently, if there was a way to save him before he turned into this.

Fin"s unpredictability is what scares me the most. One moment, he could be charming and persuasive, convincing everyone that he"s changed. The next, he could be plotting our downfall, calculating his next move with chilling precision. It"s a game of cat and mouse, and I"m constantly on edge, waiting for the other shoe to drop.

In the past week, the feeling of being watched has intensified. It"s as if Fin is everywhere and nowhere at once, his presence lingering in the shadows. I"ve tried to dismiss it as paranoia, but deep down, I know it"s real. This isn"t just a mother"s fear—it"s a gut feeling, an instinct honed by years of living with a predator. Fin is watching, waiting for the perfect moment to strike, and all I can do is try to stay one step ahead.

The nights are the worst. I lie awake, listening to every creak and groan of the house, imagining him slipping through the darkness. Sleep offers no respite; my dreams are plagued by visions of his twisted smile, his eyes glinting with malice. Each day is a struggle to maintain some semblance of normalcy, to pretend that everything is okay when it"s far from it.

This is our life now, a constant battle for survival against someone who was once a part of us. Fin may be my son, but he"s also my greatest enemy, and the stakes are higher than ever. This is just the beginning of our story, the first chapter in a long and harrowing journey through Keystone Park. Stay tuned as I continue to share our struggle, our fear, and our fight to reclaim our lives from the clutches of a nightmare."

### The Weight of Guilt

Fin was always a difficult child, but it was the combination of his intelligence and a lack of empathy that truly set him apart. As a mother, I felt a crushing sense of responsibility, as if I had somehow failed to guide him down the right path. I remember the countless nights spent wondering what I could have done differently, what words I could have said or actions I could have taken to steer him away from the darkness that was consuming him. The more I tried to reach him, the more he pushed me away, his cold, calculating eyes betraying a lack of emotion that was both frightening and tragic.

I recall one particularly harrowing incident when Fin was just a teenager. He had come home late, his face bruised and swollen, claiming he had been in a fight. My initial instinct was to comfort him, to ask if he was okay, but as I looked at his injuries, a chilling suspicion took hold. I confronted him, demanding to know the truth. He denied everything, his eyes vacant and unresponsive. It was only later, after speaking to some of his friends, that I discovered he had been involved in a violent altercation at school, one that left another boy severely injured. The guilt I carried from that moment forward was almost unbearable. Had I been more attentive, more vigilant, could I have prevented that incident? The answer, always, was no.

Fin's descent into criminality was gradual, almost imperceptible at first. At first, it was small thefts—money here, a valuable item there. Each time, I tried to reason with him, to explain the consequences of his actions. But his responses were always the same: a shrug, a smirk, as if he found the whole situation amusing. It wasn't until he started threatening us, making it clear that he would stop at nothing to get what he wanted, that I realized the full extent of his dangerous potential. The more I tried to protect my family, the more aggressive he became, turning our home into a battleground.

I remember the day the police finally took him into custody. It was a relief, a moment of peace that I hadn't felt in years. But it was also a bittersweet victory, one that came at a high cost. Fin's imprisonment was a reminder of my failures as a mother, a constant reminder that I had not only failed to protect him but had also failed to protect those around him. The relief was short-lived; as soon as he was locked up, the fear of what he might do next began to set in. I knew that, no matter how long he remained in jail, the danger he posed would never truly disappear. He was always just one step ahead, always one move away from striking again.

The guilt has been a constant companion, haunting me in the quiet moments of the night and seeping into my everyday life. I wonder if there was a way to save him, if there was a different path he could have taken. But the truth is, I was powerless against the darkness that consumed him. All I could do was try to protect those around me from his wrath. And now, as I live in constant fear of his next move, I am left to wonder if I will ever find peace, if I will ever be able to move past the guilt that weighs me down.

### The Unsettling Visions

The past week has been a living nightmare, filled with visions that seemed almost surreal. Each night, as I try to fall asleep, my mind is plagued by images of Fin's cold, calculating eyes staring down at me. I see him lurking in the shadows, his presence a constant, looming threat. The walls of our home seem to close in on me, as if they too are aware of the danger he poses. The creaking floorboards, the distant sounds of traffic outside, all seem to whisper his name, reminding me that he is never truly gone.

Last night, the nightmares reached a new level of terror. I was sitting in the living room, trying to unwind after a long day, when I heard a faint whisper. At first, I dismissed it as the wind or my imagination, but the voice grew louder, clearer. "Mom," it said, "I'm coming for you." My heart raced as I turned around, searching the room for its source. But there was nothing—no one there. I shook my head, trying to dispel the fear that had taken hold of me, but the voice continued, more insistent, more haunting. "Mom, you can't hide from me. I'll find you."

I bolted up from the couch, my heart pounding in my chest. I grabbed a flashlight and began to search every corner of the room, every shadow, every nook and cranny. But there was nothing. The house was empty, silent, except for the echo of that dreaded voice. I sat back down, trying to catch my breath, but the fear lingered, like a dark cloud hanging over me.

The dreams don't just haunt me at night; they follow me into the waking hours as well. During the day, I find myself constantly on edge, hyper-aware of my surroundings. The simplest noises set me on edge, causing me to jump and look around as if expecting Fin to appear out of thin air. I've started avoiding certain rooms in the house, rooms that seem to hold more than just memories but also a sense of his lingering presence.

One particular day, while cleaning the attic, I found an old box that had been tucked away in the corner. As I reached for it, I felt a sudden chill run down my spine. I hesitated, my hand hovering in the air as if I expected the box to spring to life and attack me. When I finally opened it, I discovered a collection of old letters and photographs, remnants of a life that seemed so distant and yet so painfully close. As I sifted through the items, I couldn't shake the feeling that Fin was watching me, that he was lurking somewhere in the shadows, waiting for his chance to strike.

The fear has become so consuming that it's starting to affect my daily life. I can't sleep properly, my nights filled with restless tossing and turning. My appetite has diminished, and I find myself losing track of time, lost in the spiraling thoughts of his potential return. I've even started to question my own sanity, wondering if the fear has finally driven me over the edge. But deep down, I know it's not just fear; it's a primal instinct, a mother's intuition that tells me Fin is still out there, watching, waiting.

The isolation that comes with this fear is perhaps the worst part. I can't share my nightmares with anyone, not even my closest friends or family. They would think I was losing my mind, and to some extent, they might be right. But the truth is, I'm not just scared; I'm terrified. Fin is a part of me, a part of my past, and the thought of him coming back, of him causing more harm, is something I can't bear to contemplate.

In the quiet moments, when the house is silent and the world outside seems distant, I find myself talking to Fin, trying to reason with him, to convince him that we can find a way to coexist. But the words feel hollow, as if they are just a faint whisper in the vast expanse of his malevolent intentions. I'm left with the sinking feeling that no matter what I do, no matter how much I try to protect myself and those I love, Fin will always be one step ahead, always looming in the shadows, ready to strike at the most unexpected moment.

### The Struggle for Normalcy

Living in this constant state of fear has taken a heavy toll on my mental and emotional well-being. Each day is a battle to maintain a semblance of normalcy, to pretend that everything is fine when it's far from it. The weight of Fin's potential return hangs over me like a dark cloud, making even the simplest tasks feel insurmountable. I find myself on edge, hyper-aware of every sound, every movement, every shadow that might signal his presence.

I've become a master of disguising my true feelings, putting on a brave face for the sake of my family. But behind closed doors, the facade falls away, revealing the terrified woman who is desperately trying to hold everything together. My mind is a whirlpool of anxiety and fear, constantly replaying the worst-case scenarios and wondering if today is the day Fin will make his move. 

The fear has also taken a toll on my relationships. My friends and family mean well, but their inability to understand the full extent of my nightmare only adds to my sense of isolation. They offer support and advice, but it's never enough to quell the deep-seated fear that gnaws at me day and night. I've started to withdraw from social activities, preferring the solitude of my own company to the judgmental eyes of those who don't understand the true horror I face.

My family, too, is not immune to the effects of this fear. My husband, Glenn, has noticed the change in me, the way I jump at every noise, the way I avoid certain rooms in the house. He tries to be understanding, but the look of concern in his eyes only reminds me of the shared burden we both carry. Our once close-knit family dynamic has become strained, each of us struggling to cope with the weight of Fin's potential return.

The fear has also affected my ability to function on a daily basis. Simple tasks that used to be second nature now require immense effort and concentration. I find myself unable to focus, my mind constantly wandering to the thoughts of Fin's possible return. The fear has seeped into every aspect of my life, making it almost impossible to find a moment of peace or tranquility.

In the quiet moments, when the house is silent and the world outside seems distant, I find myself talking to Fin, trying to reason with him, to convince him that we can find a way to coexist. But the words feel hollow, as if they are just a faint whisper in the vast expanse of his malevolent intentions. I'm left with the sinking feeling that no matter what I do, no matter how much I try to protect myself and those I love, Fin will always be one step ahead, always lurking in the shadows, ready to strike at the most unexpected moment.

They would think I was losing my mind, and to some extent, they might be right. But the truth is, I'm not just scared; I'm terrified. Fin is a part of me, a part of my past, and the thought of him coming back, of him causing more harm, is something I can't bear to contemplate.

But the words feel hollow, as if they are just a faint whisper in the vast expanse of his malevolent intentions. I'm left with the sinking feeling that no matter what I do, no matter how much I try to protect myself and those I love, Fin will always be one step ahead, always lurking in the shadows, ready to strike at the most unexpected moment.

### The Decision to Leave

The fear has reached a breaking point, and I realize that staying in Keystone Park is no longer an option. The constant dread, the sense of being watched, the nightmares that follow me into the waking hours—it's all becoming too much. I know that if we stay, the danger will only grow, and the risk to my family will become unbearable. I have to take action, and the only way to ensure our safety is to leave.

The decision to move is not an easy one. Keystone Park has been our home for years, a place filled with memories—both good and bad. But the thought of Fin's potential return, of him causing more harm, outweighs any attachment I have to this place. I know that leaving means starting over, that it will be difficult and perhaps even painful, but it's a risk I'm willing to take for the sake of my family's safety.

I start by researching potential new homes, looking for places that offer a fresh start, a clean slate. I want somewhere remote, far enough away from Keystone Park that Fin would have a hard time finding us. The process is overwhelming, filled with endless options and uncertainties. Each new place comes with its own set of pros and cons, and the thought of uprooting our lives weighs heavily on me.

I confide in Glenn, sharing my fears and my decision to move. His initial reaction is one of disbelief, as if he can't believe that the nightmare has reached a point where we have to leave our home. But as I explain the reasons behind my decision, he begins to understand the gravity of the situation. He agrees that moving is the best course of action, even if it means leaving behind everything we've built here.

The process of packing up our lives is exhausting and emotional. Each item we pack holds a memory, a piece of our past that we're leaving behind. The attic, filled with boxes and mementos, becomes a shrine to our time in Keystone Park, a place where I mourn the loss of our home while also looking forward to the promise of a new beginning.

As the moving day approaches, I feel a mix of emotions—fear, anticipation, and a glimmer of hope. I'm scared of what might happen if Fin finds us, of the dangers that lie ahead, but I'm also hopeful that we can finally find a place of safety and peace. The fear has been a constant shadow over our lives, but now, for the first time in years, I feel a sense of possibility, a chance to start anew.

Leaving Keystone Park is not just a physical move; it's a mental and emotional journey. It's a step towards reclaiming our lives from the grip of fear and uncertainty. It's a reminder that sometimes, in order to protect those we love, we must be willing to take a leap of faith, to leave behind the familiar and embrace the unknown. And so, with heavy hearts but with hope in our minds, we prepare to leave Keystone Park behind, ready to face whatever challenges lie ahead in our search for a new home, a new life.

### The Journey Begins

The day we left Keystone Park was a blur of emotions—excitement, fear, and a profound sense of loss. The moving truck was loaded to the brim with our belongings, each item carefully packed and labeled. As we stood at the edge of our driveway, the reality of leaving hit us hard. Tears welled up in my eyes as I looked back at the house, a place filled with memories—both happy and haunting. It was both a home and a prison, a place of safety and a constant reminder of the danger that loomed over us.

Glenn put his arm around me, his presence a comforting anchor in the storm of emotions. "We'll make a new life," he whispered, his voice filled with resolve. His words provided a small but vital source of comfort, reminding me that this move was not just about escaping fear but also about finding a place where we could finally be safe and happy.

The drive to our new home was long and exhausting, punctuated by moments of quiet reflection and sporadic conversations. The landscape outside the window changed from the familiar streets of Keystone Park to the unfamiliar roads of a new town. Each mile we traveled brought us closer to the promise of a fresh start, yet it also heightened the anxiety of the unknown.

As we pulled into the driveway of our new home, a small, cozy house nestled in a quiet neighborhood, a wave of mixed emotions washed over me. There was a sense of relief that we were finally here, away from the shadows of Fin's potential return, but also a pang of sadness for the life we were leaving behind. The house was clean and modern, a stark contrast to the older, more rustic home we had in Keystone Park. It was a blank canvas, ready to be filled with new memories and a sense of normalcy.

We began the process of unpacking, each box a step towards building a new life. The kids ran around the empty rooms, their excitement palpable as they explored every nook and cranny. Glenn and I worked tirelessly, organizing furniture, setting up the kitchen, and making the house feel like home. Each task was a reminder that we were taking control of our lives, building a future free from the fear that had haunted us for so long.

Despite the exhaustion, there were moments of joy and laughter as we settled into our new surroundings. The neighbors were friendly, welcoming us with smiles and waves. The kids made new friends quickly, their excitement about the move turning to a sense of belonging. For the first time in years, I felt a sense of hope, a belief that we could finally find peace and happiness.

But the fear never truly left me. Every now and then, a shadow would cross my mind, a fleeting thought of Fin's face, his cold, calculating eyes. I would shake it off, reminding myself that we were safe now, that this was our new beginning. Yet, the fear lingered, a constant undercurrent in the river of our new life.

As the days turned into weeks, the new home began to feel more like a haven. The familiar sounds of laughter and the hum of daily life filled the rooms, creating a sense of normalcy that had been absent for so long. We started to build new routines, new traditions, and each day brought us closer to the life we had hoped for.

And so, we continue to navigate this new chapter, balancing the hope for a peaceful future with the lingering fear of what might come. The journey is far from over, but for the first time in years, I feel a sense of possibility, a belief that we can finally find the safety and happiness we've been searching for. This is just the beginning of our story, a new chapter in the fight for a life free from the shadows of fear.

[Story]: After the destruction of an energy world at the hands of Jacques Marcus, He decides to go to a hub-world on the other side of the system to recuperate and gear up for his next battle. Little does he know, the next battle is not far behind.


Jacques arrives on a planet that looks similar to Earth in every way except it's bigger. The city he lands in is the capital of the world named Solis City. He finds a map of the city at the port dock where his ship the Raging Phoenix is at. He makes his way to an Armory that"s close to the dock. He enters the ramshackle building and talks to the wild looking shopkeeper. The shopkeeper says "Welcome to Pinpoint, the highest rated gun shop among tourists."

Jacques responds as he looks around the shop. "I highly doubt that."

"Well rude guy, anything you in the market for? My name"s Keith by the by, what"s yours stranger?"

"Jacques and I"m looking for a new rifle, preferably any pre-voyage relics."

"Holy hell pre-voyage!? You're looking for some real strange stuff, but lucky for you I'm selling a pristine relic, called the Kalashnikov AK47."

Jacques" eyes sparked and he walked over shaking the rickety wooden floorboards with each step. As Jacques is examining the gun Keith takes notice of something and asks. "You're a big guy, what cybernetics are you rocking?"

Jacques switches his gaze to the short stocky man and as his demeanor changes, a fear starts to fill Keith. Jacques responds "None, I'm all natural. I can't have that damn federation knowing anything about me."

Keith gathers his resolve and responds "That"s a fair answer plus you look good for no enhancements."

"Why thank you man. How much for the relic?"

"The asking price is 30,000 credits."

"I'll give you 100,000 credits if you give me the gun, don't do any paperwork or ask any more questions."

"With all due respect Mr. Jacques, I highly doubt you have that much on your person."

The white, ring-like device on his back begins to glow and a bag manifests and floats into his hand. He drops the bag and subsequently some of the credits fall out. "Now the gun please, unless you need more?"

A stunned Keith responds " Naw this is plenty. Take the gun I'll say it fell off the truck."

Jacques chuckles a bit and says "Thanks."

He then takes the gun, as he is further examining the weapon the ring on his back starts to glow. After a few short minutes the gun floats up into the air, flies straight into the device and disappears. He exits the store and notices a swath of people rushing to an area of the city in electric anticipation. In his curiosity he follows the ecstatic and unruly crowd. Following them for a few blocks he notices advertisements for a summit that is occurring that day. He makes the assumption that is where they are going.

One hour later

The summit starts and a group of people dressed in colorful costumes and capes are giving a speech. Jacques is happy and filled with hope seeing a new rise of heroes. A new era of heroes trying to stop the tyranny of the Galactic Federation just as he is. The Crusaders of The Cosmos. A new dawn in his eyes. Then, one sentence said by MKUltria sinks his entire being into a raging inferno. She said "We, with the support of the Galactic Federation, can bring peace and prosperity across the sector, And hopefully the entire multiverse." Jacques is furious. His mind is descending into a swirling torrent of anger, sadness, and confusion. "Why do they support them now? Why would they make a superhero team? Is this just to taunt me? To put me off my edge? Why, oh why did they have to die? Why did they kill my family if they would go back and do this?"

Then it dawns on him. He must kill them. No one can truly be a hero under the heel of the Galactic Federation. They will just be used for a revenue boost for the federation. They will hurt or even kill people if they are run by the federation. Jacques makes his way to the stage. One of the heroes, NightHawk, looks directly at him and starts to signal the rest of the heroes. Another hero, Bombastia says "Hey you, scary looking guy in the mountain camo pants and black shirt. Are you Jacques Marcus, The Monster?"

Jacques gets on stage and says "Yeah."

Bombastia steps closer to Jacques while showing off his ability, making explosive fireballs in his hands, and says. " Who do you think you are coming to this planet, no to this sector? With all the blood you've spilled didn't you think we'd kill you on sight."

Jacques gets closer to Bombastia and responds. "Do you really think I'm gonna let a guy dressed in orange tights and a cape even lay a hand on me?"

NightHawk lunges over and says "I've already sent a distress call. The other crusaders are on their way."

MKUltria rushes over to the side of the stage next to Bombastia and says "We need to kill you Jacques. You are a pure manifestation of evil. Please understand. In order to secure a better tomorrow. We need to kill you."

Bombastia lunges at Jacques while putting a fireball in his face and says. "Yeah, so be a good boy and die already."

Jacques picks him up by the neck and chuckles. He cracks Bombastia's neck and says. "Don't worry. He's not dead yet, just paralyzed. I want him to be in complete despair before he dies y'know. Like the true villain you say I am."

He then crushes Bombastia's head and throws his corpse in the crowd of horrified people. As the people all run away and hide, Jacques says. "You said you need to kill me to secure a better tomorrow? That's too bad. None of you will live to see it.""

### The Capital of Solis City

Jacques Marcus descended from his ship, the Raging Phoenix, onto the expansive soil of Solis City. The planet, larger than Earth in every conceivable manner, had an almost eerie familiarity. Towering skyscrapers, verdant parks, and bustling streets stretched as far as the eye could see, mirroring the urban sprawl of his home world but on a grander scale. The air was thick with a mix of industrial emissions and natural flora, creating a unique scent that was both alien and comforting.

Solis City, the capital of this colossal world, was a marvel of architectural ingenuity and cultural diversity. Neon lights flickered above the crowded streets, casting vibrant hues on the bustling populace below. The city was a vibrant mosaic of different cultures, each represented by their unique architecture, food stalls, and marketplaces. It was a place where the old and the new coexisted, blending ancient traditions with futuristic innovations.

Jacques made his way to the port dock where the Raging Phoenix was moored. The docks were a hive of activity, with ships of all shapes and sizes coming and going. He found a small booth near the entrance where a holographic map of the city floated in mid-air. After a brief interaction with the holographic attendant, Jacques downloaded the map into his neural interface. The map showed various landmarks and locations, including the Armory he had been searching for.

With the map in hand, Jacques began his journey through the sprawling city. He navigated through narrow alleyways and wide boulevards, passing by street vendors and merchants hawking their wares. The people of Solis City were diverse and lively, their expressions ranging from curiosity to indifference as they observed the unfamiliar figure clad in rugged mountain camo.

After what felt like hours, Jacques finally arrived at the Armory. The building was a ramshackle structure, its exterior weathered and scarred by time and countless battles. However, the moment he stepped inside, the atmosphere changed. The air was filled with the familiar scent of oil and metal, and the walls were lined with rows of weapons, each gleaming under the dim lighting.

A short, stocky man with a wild beard and a piercing gaze approached him. "Welcome to Pinpoint, the highest rated gun shop among tourists," he announced with a confident smirk. "I'm Keith, the shopkeeper. How can I help you?"

Jacques scanned the room, his eyes immediately drawn to a particular corner where a variety of relics from past voyages were displayed. He turned to Keith, his voice low and intense. "I'm looking for a new rifle, preferably any pre-voyage relics. Do you have anything that fits the bill?"

Keith's eyes lit up as he led Jacques deeper into the Armory, pointing out various weapons with a practiced hand. "Well, stranger, you've come to the right place. We've got a real gem here—a pristine relic called the Kalashnikov AK47. It's a piece of history, and it's yours if you want it."

Jacques' interest piqued, he followed Keith, their footsteps echoing through the narrow corridors of the Armory. As they reached a secluded section, Keith pulled out the AK47 and handed it to Jacques. The weapon felt heavy in his hands, its weight and balance a testament to its robust design. He examined it closely, appreciating the craftsmanship and the history it carried.

"Is this the one?" Jacques asked, his voice steady but with a hint of urgency.

### The Revelation

As Jacques continued to examine the AK47, a sudden realization struck him. The weapon, though old and battle-worn, seemed to resonate with a part of him he hadn't felt in years. It was as if it had been waiting for him, calling to him from the depths of time. He felt a strange connection to the relic, as if it held the memories and experiences of countless soldiers who had wielded it before him.

"Keith," Jacques said, his voice breaking the silence of the armory. "Tell me more about this rifle. Where did you get it?"

Keith, still processing the large sum of credits Jacques had produced, looked up momentarily confused. "This? It's an old relic, a Kalashnikov AK47 from a pre-voyage era. I found it in a hidden stash on an abandoned ship. It's a rare find, especially in such good condition."

Jacques' eyes narrowed, his mind racing. "An abandoned ship? And you just happened to stumble upon it?"

Keith shrugged. "Yes, it was a long time ago. I didn't think much of it at the time, but I knew it had value. I've been selling it here hoping to find the right buyer."

Jacques' grip tightened around the rifle. "This isn't just any rifle," he said, his voice low and intense. "It's more than just a weapon. It's a piece of my past, a link to a time when I was still fighting for something bigger than myself."

Keith studied Jacques, trying to understand the emotion behind his words. "I see. But why are you so attached to it? It's just a relic."

Jacques looked at Keith, his eyes filled with a mix of nostalgia and sorrow. "Because it reminds me of who I used to be, before everything changed. Before I became what they call 'The Monster.' This rifle was part of my journey, part of the battles I fought, the lives I saved... and the lives I took."

Keith felt a pang of empathy for the man standing before him. "I'm sorry, Mr. Marcus. I had no idea."

"It's okay," Jacques said, his voice softening. "But I need this weapon. It's not just about the firepower; it's about the memories and the connections it holds. It's a piece of my soul."

And as he walked through the bustling streets of Solis City, he couldn't shake the feeling that his next fight was already on the horizon.

### The Crowd's Rush

As Jacques emerged from the Armory, the vibrant energy of Solis City enveloped him once more. The bustling streets were filled with people, their faces lit up by the vibrant neon lights overhead. But it wasn't the everyday hustle and bustle that caught his attention; it was the palpable excitement in the air, a sense of urgency that seemed to ripple through the crowd.

A group of people, moving with a purpose and a fervor that was almost contagious, caught Jacques' eye. They were rushing towards a particular area of the city, their expressions filled with anticipation and electric excitement. Intrigued, Jacques decided to follow them, his curiosity piqued.

He navigated through the throngs of people, weaving his way through the narrow streets and bustling marketplaces. The crowd grew denser as he got closer to the designated area, and soon, he found himself at the heart of a massive gathering. A grand stage had been set up in the center of the square, surrounded by a sea of people eager to witness whatever was about to unfold.

Advertisements for the event were plastered on every available surface, proclaiming it as a "Summit of Heroes." Jacques could see people in colorful costumes and capes, their faces painted with the symbols of various factions and causes. It was a gathering of those who fought against the Galactic Federation, those who dreamed of a better tomorrow.

As Jacques watched from the periphery, a group of speakers took the stage, their voices amplified by the sound systems. They spoke of hope, of resistance, and of the power of unity. The crowd roared with approval, their voices merging into a single, resounding chorus of optimism and determination.

Jacques felt a surge of hope and inspiration himself, his anger and sorrow momentarily eclipsed by the collective spirit of the gathering. He had found a new purpose, a new reason to fight. But as the speakers continued, their words took a darker turn, and Jacques' hope began to waver.

One speaker, a woman with a powerful presence and a commanding voice, stepped forward. "We stand here today as the Crusaders of the Cosmos," she declared. "United by our shared goal of ending the tyranny of the Galactic Federation. Together, we can bring peace and prosperity across the sector, and perhaps even the entire multiverse."

The crowd erupted in cheers, but Jacques felt a cold wave of realization wash over him. The words of the speaker resonated deeply, and he couldn't shake the feeling that something was off. He watched as the crowd's excitement turned to fervor, their chants and cheers growing louder and more intense.

As the speaker continued, Jacques' mind raced. What was it about this gathering that felt so wrong? Why were these people rallying under the banner of the Galactic Federation, the very entity they claimed to be fighting against?

The answer came to him in a sudden, blinding flash of clarity. The Galactic Federation was using these people, using their hope and determination to maintain their grip on power. They were being manipulated, their efforts being redirected for the Federation's benefit. And the Crusaders of the Cosmos, with their newfound unity and strength, were nothing more than pawns in a game they didn't even realize they were playing.

Jacques felt a surge of anger and despair. How could he stand by and let this continue? How could he allow the Galactic Federation to exploit these innocent people for their own gain?

His mind made up, Jacques stepped forward, ready to confront the speakers and expose the truth. But before he could take a single step, a new thought entered his mind. He needed to gather more information. He needed to understand the full extent of the Galactic Federation's manipulation before he could take any action.

With a heavy heart, Jacques turned away from the crowd and retreated into the shadows, his resolve stronger than ever. He would find a way to stop the Galactic Federation, even if it meant going against the very people he had come to believe in.

### The Summit Unveiled

Jacques found a secluded spot near the edge of the crowd, where he could observe the proceedings without drawing attention to himself. The stage was filled with individuals dressed in elaborate costumes and capes, each symbolizing a different cause or faction. They moved with a sense of purpose and camaraderie, their faces glowing with the light of a shared vision.

The speakers took turns addressing the crowd, each one exuding a mix of passion and authority. Their words were powerful, filled with rhetoric that promised a brighter future and the end of oppression. The crowd responded with wild enthusiasm, their cheers echoing through the square and filling Jacques with a sense of foreboding.

It was then that MKUltria stepped onto the stage. Dressed in a shimmering silver suit adorned with intricate holographic patterns, she exuded an aura of confidence and strength. Her eyes, glowing with an inner light, locked onto the audience, capturing their attention.

"We, the Crusaders of the Cosmos," she began, her voice resonating with authority and conviction, "stand united against the tyranny of the Galactic Federation. We are the hope of the galaxy, the beacon of freedom for those who suffer under their heel. With the support of the Galactic Federation, we can bring peace and prosperity across the sector, and hopefully, the entire multiverse."

The crowd erupted in cheers, their excitement reaching a fever pitch. But Jacques felt a chill run down his spine. The words of MKUltria were a betrayal, a cruel twist of the knife that twisted his heart. The Galactic Federation, the very entity they claimed to be fighting against, was now using them as pawns in their grand scheme.

His mind swirled with anger and confusion. How could they support the very system they claimed to be opposing? Was this some twisted attempt to taunt him, to drive him further into madness? He thought of the sacrifices he had made, the lives he had lost, and the battles he had fought. And now, here they were, embracing the very thing he had dedicated his life to opposing.

"Why?" Jacques whispered to himself, his voice barely audible over the din of the crowd. "Why would they do this? Why would they turn on their own people?"

The weight of his questions pressed down on him, his heart heavy with the burden of unanswered doubts. He had believed in the power of unity, in the idea that together, they could overcome any adversity. But now, it seemed that unity had been twisted into a tool of manipulation, used to further the Galactic Federation's agenda.

As the speeches continued, Jacques' resolve hardened. He couldn't stand by and let this continue. He had to expose the truth, to show the people the reality of their situation. He had to disrupt this facade of unity and reveal the true face of the Galactic Federation.

Jacques stepped back into the shadows, his mind racing with plans and strategies. He would find a way to infiltrate this group, to expose their true allegiance and rally the people against the Galactic Federation. He would not allow them to use hope as a weapon against those who truly deserved it.

His heart burned with a newfound determination, Jacques Marcus was ready to face whatever challenges lay ahead. The battle was just beginning, and he was determined to be the one to turn the tide.

### The Battle Unfolds

Jacques Marcus stood in the shadows, his mind a whirlwind of thoughts and emotions. He had seen the truth, and now it was his duty to act. The lies and manipulations of the Galactic Federation could not be allowed to stand. He had to expose them, to bring their deception to light and rally the people against their oppressive regime.

With a deep breath, Jacques stepped out from his hiding spot and made his way towards the stage. The crowd parted before him, their eyes wide with surprise and fear. The Crusaders of the Cosmos, who moments ago had been filled with hope and unity, now looked upon him with suspicion and hostility.

As Jacques reached the base of the stage, Bombastia, one of the heroes, stepped forward. Dressed in an orange suit adorned with explosive symbols, his face was a mask of anger and determination. "Who do you think you are, coming to this planet, no to this sector?" he shouted, his voice echoing through the square. "With all the blood you've spilled, didn't you think we'd kill you on sight?"

Jacques stood his ground, his eyes locked onto Bombastia's. "I'm Jacques Marcus," he said, his voice steady and unyielding. "And I'm here to expose the truth. You're being used, manipulated by the Galactic Federation. They're using you to maintain their power, and you're nothing more than pawns in their game."

Bombastia's eyes flashed with rage. "Don't you dare speak to us like that! We're heroes, fighting for a better tomorrow!"

Jacques took a step closer, his presence overwhelming. "A better tomorrow under the Galactic Federation? You're deluding yourselves. They will exploit you, use you, and ultimately betray you. And I won't stand for it."

NightHawk, another hero, lunged forward, his wings outstretched and glowing with energy. "Enough, Jacques! You're a monster, a killer. We can't let you破坏 everything we've built."

Jacques didn't flinch. He knew the accusations were true, but he also knew that the path he was on was the only one that mattered. "I may be a monster, but I fight for what's right. And what's right is to expose the lies of the Galactic Federation."

MKUltria rushed to the side of the stage, her voice cutting through the chaos. "We need to kill you, Jacques. You are a pure manifestation of evil. Please understand. In order to secure a better tomorrow, we need to eliminate you."

Jacques' eyes narrowed, his resolve solidifying. "You think killing me will secure a better tomorrow? You're wrong. All it will do is pave the way for more oppression and deceit. And I won't let that happen."

Bombastia raised his hands, sparks of energy crackling between his fingers. "Then die already, Jacques. This ends now!"

Jacques didn't wait for the explosion. He lunged forward, his movements swift and deadly. He grabbed Bombastia by the neck, lifting him off the ground with ease. The crowd gasped, their cheers turning into horrified whispers as they watched the scene unfold.

"You won't kill me," Jacques said, his voice a low growl. "Not today. And you won't live to see a better tomorrow under the Galactic Federation."

He tightened his grip around Bombastia's neck, the man's struggles growing weaker with each passing second. As Bombastia's eyes widened in fear and despair, Jacques let out a chilling laugh. "You wanted to be a hero? You're nothing but a pawn. And you'll die like one."

With a final, crushing squeeze, Jacques snapped Bombastia's neck. The man's body went limp, and he crashed to the ground with a thud. The crowd recoiled in horror, their cheers replaced by screams of shock and fear.

Jacques didn't stop there. He turned to NightHawk, who had launched himself into the air, preparing to attack. "You too, NightHawk," he said, his voice cold and merciless. "You'll all die if you continue to support the Galactic Federation."

NightHawk roared, his wings flapping with ferocious energy. He descended upon Jacques, aiming to catch him off guard. But Jacques was ready. He dodged NightHawk's attack with ease, countering with a swift blow that sent the hero crashing into the stage.

The stage collapsed under NightHawk's weight, sparks flying and debris raining down. Jacques stood tall, his eyes filled with a mix of anger and determination. He had exposed the truth, and now he would fight to protect it.

As the remaining heroes scrambled to their feet, Jacques knew this was only the beginning. The battle was far from over, and he was ready to face whatever challenges lay ahead.

### The Final Confrontation

Jacques stood amidst the chaos, his eyes scanning the disoriented heroes who had gathered around the stage. The once vibrant square was now a scene of fear and confusion, with people scrambling to avoid the falling debris. NightHawk, recovering from his fall, landed gracefully on the ground and faced Jacques, his eyes blazing with a mix of anger and determination.

"You think you can stop us, monster?" NightHawk shouted, his voice filled with defiance. "You're wrong. The Crusaders of the Cosmos will not be stopped!"

Jacques took a step forward, his eyes locked onto NightHawk. "You're wrong," he said, his voice cold and unwavering. "You're nothing but pawns in the Galactic Federation's game. And I will not let you destroy what little hope there is left."

NightHawk launched himself at Jacques, his wings flaring out and energy crackling around him. Jacques sidestepped the attack, his movements fluid and precise. He grabbed NightHawk's wrist, twisting it with a force that sent the hero to the ground. NightHawk cried out in pain, his energy dissipating as he struggled to regain control.

MKUltria rushed to NightHawk's side, her expression a mix of concern and determination. "We can't let him do this," she shouted, her voice filled with urgency. "We need to stop him before he ruins everything!"

Jacques turned to face her, his eyes filled with a mix of sorrow and resolve. "You're fighting for the wrong cause, MKUltria. The Galactic Federation will never bring peace or prosperity. They will only use you to further their own agenda."

MKUltria's eyes flashed with anger. "You're wrong, Jacques. We're fighting for a better tomorrow, for a future where everyone can live in peace."

Jacques shook his head, his voice breaking. "You're deluding yourselves. The only peace you'll find under the Galactic Federation is one where you're powerless and oppressed."

Before MKUltria could respond, Bombastia's body began to twitch and convulse. The crowd watched in horror as the once-dead hero seemed to come back to life. His eyes rolled back in his head, and his body erupted in a series of violent spasms. The crowd screamed in terror, their fear spreading like wildfire.

Jacques looked at the scene before him, his heart heavy with the weight of his choices. He knew that continuing this battle would only lead to more bloodshed and more loss. But he also knew that he couldn't stand by and let the Galactic Federation continue to manipulate and exploit these people.

"I'm done fighting," Jacques said, his voice breaking. "I won't be part of this anymore. You can either join me and fight for true freedom, or continue to support the Galactic Federation and face the consequences."

The crowd fell silent, their eyes wide with shock and uncertainty. Some began to whisper among themselves, debating the validity of Jacques' words. Others looked to the leaders of the Crusaders, waiting for their guidance.

MKUltria took a step forward, her expression a mix of confusion and determination. "What do we do, NightHawk? Should we follow this man or continue to fight against the Galactic Federation?"

NightHawk hesitated, his eyes filled with doubt. "I don't know," he admitted. "But I think we should at least consider what he's saying."

Jacques nodded, his eyes scanning the crowd. "Come with me, and we'll find a way to fight for true freedom. Or stay here and continue to be pawns in the Galactic Federation's game."

The crowd remained silent, their eyes reflecting the uncertainty and fear that had gripped them. It was a moment of truth, a moment where they had to decide what side they would stand on.

And as the seconds ticked by, Jacques knew that the future of the galaxy depended on the choices they would make in that moment.

[Story]: Chapter One


Title unsure

Sam pulled his phone out of his pocket and hurriedly went to check his email inbox.

"Come one, come on."

He thought as he waited for it to load.

"Yes! There it is!" He murmured to himself.

He quickly opened what he had been waiting for. It was a job interview for a forklift operator. Sure, the wage was low but Sam whether he realized it or not really needed this. He'd just gotten out of rehab and the halfway house he was staying in required that he have some form of legal employment. Sam knew that if he could just get an interview, he could get the job and be back on his way to proving to everyone that he was finally a changed man.

He put his phone back into his pocket, grabbed his keys and left his room. The halfway house was an old brownstone in downtown Portland. Sam had been told that he had found a "good one" though the state of the home made him never want to find out what a "bad one" looked like. The old worn floorboards creaked with every step. As he made his way down the narrow and steep steps he was hit with the damp rotting smell of the street coming through the now open front door.

It was Mr. Hawthorne the home caretaker. He had just come in with a handful of mail. Mr. Hawthorne was a kindly old man of about 70. He had thick grey hair that he always kept trimmed neatly. He was a person that you couldn't imagine being younger as if he had somehow always looked this way. Stuck in his old age, as if he were meant to be there.

"Nothing for you today Samuel." He said plainly. "Where are ya off to?" He asked.

"A job interview!" Sam said excitedly and with an air of pride.

"Excellent, excellent Samuel." Said Mr. Hawthorne pleasantly. "Let me know how it goes! And best of luck!"

Sam padded Mr. Hawthorne in his shoulder as he passed him in the entryway "Thanks, Mr. Hawthorne and I will!" He said happily.

Sam stepped out into the street. It had just finished raining and the damp smell of a decaying city filled his lungs. This reminded Sam of where he was from. Not because of the smell of the city but because every time he stepped outside he was reminded that he didn't belong there. Sam was raised on a small farm in Montana. How he ended up here brought him great shame. But, he was heading to a place to hopefully help him right all of his wrongs.

He walked down the block and turned the corner. There sat his 1999 Honda Civic. For starters no one had smashed the window so he was already in the positive. He unlocked the door and hopped inside.

"Alright you old son of a bitch, come on now." He thought as he pushed in the clutch and turned the ignition. The cars engine sputtered, spat and rolled its way to life.

Sam smiled a sense that this was all going o work out suddenly washed over him. The old Honda rarely started on the first try! He put it into gear and started down the road. A road he hoped would lead him out of this city and perhaps back home.

CHAPTER TWO

Arrival

Sam was relieved that the warehouse was far from the city proper and out in the suburbs of Portland. Anytime he was able to escape the city he felt a weight lifted off of his shoulders. He pulled into the massive parking lot of the warehouse and headed for the door on its southern corner where the e-mail had told him his interview would be at. The parking lot seemed eerily empty but it was a Sunday. The woman who wrote the email explained to him that she was only able to schedule his interview for that time because of some logistical issues.

He found a spot near the doorway that read "new hires" above it. Sam grabbed his phone and wallet and headed inside. As he entered the lobby he saw rows of empty chairs and a front desk that was currently empty. Sam walked up to the desk tentatively. The lobby looked like any large doctors office waiting room. The harsh artificial lights, the smell of cheap carpet slightly put him on edge. He stood at the desk for a moment before he finally uttered a tentative "Hello?" His voice seemed to echo around the great space and down the long hallway behind the desk.

Just before he was about to toss out another meek "hello?" A kindly woman appeared through a cracked door behind the reception area.

"Coming!" She said anxiously!

"Sorry, sorry, I wasn't supposed to be here this morning! My name is Christine! I had to cover for a colleague who called in sick! I'm a bit behind! You must be Samuel! You're the only one scheduled for an interview today! Here, take this packet and fill it out. When you're finished bring it back up and I'll let Mr. McMaster know you're here!" She said with much haste.

She handed Sam the packet on a clip board with a pen and directed him to take a seat at any of the empty chairs behind him. Sam sat down and started filling the packet out. It was all normal job interview stuff. But this presented a problem for Sam as he had just left rehab. Sam didn't have any references aside from Mr. Hawthorn. Sure, he could put down some old friends from the service but he didn't know their numbers anymore. So, he just put down Mr. Hawthorne for now. If they had any questions about it he figured he could answer them during the actual interview. Sam figured that the less they knew about him the better his chances would be of getting the job. After all this wasn't NASA they just wanted someone to drive a forklift around a warehouse.

He handed the packet back to Christine who was ostensibly busy answering emails on her computer. She smiled and said "let me get this to the supervisor! He'll have you back in just a moment!"

"Thank you!" Sam said and he went back and sat down waiting anxiously. "What if they ask about my past? They surely will." He thought. "What should I tell them? The truth? No, that's not gonna work. Maybe a half truth." Before he could finish his thought Christine stood up and said "Sam! He'll see you now!"

Chapter Three

Rabbit hole

Sam was led into a back room in the middle of a hallway that had to of been 100 yards long. Christine opened the door to a small bland grey office that Mr. McMasters was sitting in. He appeared to be fast at work typing. Sam took in the room. Small, grey, bland and very cookie cutter. Not a distinguishing feature in it. No personal pictures, nothing. Very utilitarian. Very impersonal. The only thing that caught Sam's eye was a fancy machine in the corner that appeared to be some type of water dispenser. Complete with glass cups and napkins on a table near it.

"Please please Sit." Said Mr. McMaster his voice booming and commanding. As he stood he stretched his hand out toward Sam. Mr. McMaster was a commandingly large man. At least six foot four and 250 pounds. Despite his size and deep voice he appeared very friendly and almost child-like.

Sam shook his hand and was immediately intimidated by Mr. McMasters massive hands and grip strength. Sam squeezed his hand firmly but could tell that McMaster was holding back considerably. They both sat.

"Samuel, nice to meet you! I'm Gregory McMaster, please just call me Greg. I'm so glad you could make it in today. We really need someone in that spot and I think you're gonna work out."

Sam was already feeling relieved. Oddly before he could get a word out Greg said "hey, saw ya looking at the water machine we have there in the corner. Pretty cool looking right?" He said with a smile on his face.

"This is one of our CEO's inventions believe it or not. See, this thing makes its own 'spring water' fresh as the Rockies man! You won't believe it! Here let me grab you a glass!"

"I'm alright" Sam said calmly

"No, no I insist I have my manager hell to get me one of these in my office!"

"Okay, sure sure" said Sam with his hand outreached taking the now full glass from Greg's massive hand.

Sam took a tentative sip. He was almost taken back, it really did taste like spring water! "Hey! You weren't kidding!" He said surprisingly!

"I love this thing man" Greg said as he leaned against the machine analyzing it. "She's something else huh?"

"Sure is.." Said Sam but the words coming out of his mouth felt funny. Must be his nerves he thought. Sam looked up quickly trying to calm himself down but the room seemed to roll and shift. "Hey, uhh what did you'd say was in this?" He murmured to the spinning room. Then, total blackness.

Chapter Four

Waking up at the bottom.

The first thing Sam realized as he floated back into consciousness was the acute feeling of his head throbbing. Then, as his sense slowly began to warm up from there cold slumber he realized he was laying down and that he was comfortable. For a moment he just laid there before a sudden and quick blast of consciousness asked him "hey, where are we?" His eyes shot open only to be closed reflexively by a blinding light above his head. He raised his hands to cover his eyes and slowly sat up. As his vision adjusted to the brightness of the room he looked around. He was laying on a hospital bed. The room appeared to be solid concrete with a sloping drain in the middle. One large door was directly in the center of the far wall. It was heavy and metallic with a small slit at the top. Sam's confusion began to give way to abject panic as he peered around the room.

He jumped out of the bed, and ran over to the large door. He banged loudly and yelled "Hey! Hello!" Suddenly the room light switched from a harsh white to a dark and powerful red. A voice echoed around the concrete walls.

"Please step away from the door." It said robotically. "Assistance is on the way.""

Chapter Five

Panic and Revelation

Sam's heart pounded in his chest as he stood frozen in front of the door. The red light was disorienting, and he could feel a chill running down his spine. "What the hell is going on?" he muttered to himself, his voice trembling. The robotic voice had only served to deepen his confusion and anxiety.

Just as he was about to try the door again, the sound of footsteps echoed through the room. Moments later, the door creaked open, revealing a nurse in a white uniform. She wore a surgical mask and protective gear, giving the room an even more unsettling atmosphere.

"Mr. Samuelson?" she asked, her voice soft but firm.

Sam nodded, his eyes wide with fear. "Yes, that's me. What happened? Where am I?"

The nurse stepped inside, cautiously closing the door behind her. "You were brought in by an ambulance a few hours ago. You were found unconscious in a warehouse parking lot, and you've been in and out of consciousness since then."

Sam's mind raced. The warehouse interview, the glass of water, the blinding light... It all came rushing back to him. "What did they give me? What happened to me?" he demanded, his voice rising.

The nurse took a step back, looking visibly uncomfortable. "We ran some tests, but nothing showed up. It's as if you just passed out. But," she hesitated, "there's something... off about you. Your eyes, your speech... it's like you're not entirely yourself."

Sam's stomach sank. He knew there was something wrong, but he couldn't understand what it was. "I don't understand. Why would they give me something? Why would I pass out like that?" He paced back and forth, trying to make sense of it all.

The nurse shook her head, looking genuinely sorry for him. "I don't know, Mr. Samuelson. But I'll do everything I can to help you figure it out. For now, just try to rest. We'll run more tests and see if we can find the cause."

Sam nodded, feeling exhausted both physically and mentally. As he lay back down in the hospital bed, he couldn't help but think about the strange encounter with Mr. McMaster and the water machine. He had no idea what had happened to him, but he knew one thing for sure: he needed to find out.

Chapter Six

Unraveling the Mystery

As the days passed, Sam's condition improved. The constant headaches and disorientation eventually subsided, and he was finally able to focus on the task at hand: figuring out what had happened to him. He spent hours reminiscing about the day of his interview, trying to pinpoint any possible clue that could explain his strange experience.

One evening, while flipping through the packet of information he had filled out before the interview, Sam noticed something strange. In the section where he was supposed to list his references, someone had written "Mr. Hawthorne" three times. He had only written it once. It was as if someone had filled out the rest of the form for him.

Sam's suspicions grew. Was this connected to the mysterious water machine and Mr. McMaster's odd behavior? He decided to pay Mr. Hawthorne a visit to see if he could find any answers.

When Sam arrived at the halfway house, Mr. Hawthorne was in the backyard, tending to his garden. Sam approached cautiously, not wanting to alarm the old man.

"Mr. Hawthorne, I need your help," Sam said, his voice trembling with anxiety.

The old man looked up from his gardening and smiled. "Samuel, my boy, what's troubling you?"

Sam took a deep breath before explaining everything that had happened, from the interview to the hospital visit. As he spoke, Mr. Hawthorne's face grew more and more concerned.

"I've heard rumors about this warehouse and its owner," Mr. Hawthorne said quietly. "They've been involved in some... questionable activities. But I had no idea they would go to such lengths."

Sam's heart raced. He knew he had to find out the truth. "What do I do now, Mr. Hawthorne? How do I find out who's behind this?"

The old man sighed, running a hand through his grey hair. "You need to be careful, Samuel. But you must find out the truth. Go to the police, tell them everything you know. They'll be able to help you."

Sam nodded, feeling a sense of determination wash over him. He had no choice but to face his fears and uncover the truth. With Mr. Hawthorne's guidance, he would find out who was behind this and why they had targeted him.

Chapter Seven

Exposing the Truth

Sam knew he had to be cautious. He couldn't just walk into the police station and blurt out his story; he needed to gather more information first. He spent days researching the warehouse and its owner, Gregory McMaster. What he discovered was shocking.

It turns out that Gregory McMaster was not just a businessman; he was also a notorious criminal with a long list of convictions for fraud, extortion, and even murder. The warehouse was a front for his illegal activities, and Sam had been chosen as a pawn in one of his schemes.

Armed with this information, Sam finally went to the police. He told them everything he knew, including the strange encounter with Mr. McMaster and the water machine. The officers were skeptical at first, but as Sam presented the evidence he had gathered, their expressions shifted from doubt to disbelief.

The police launched an investigation into Gregory McMaster and the warehouse. They discovered that Sam had been drugged during the interview and that the water machine was a device designed to administer the drug directly into a person's system.

As the investigation progressed, Gregory McMaster was arrested. Sam was cleared of any wrongdoing and even received a letter of recommendation from the police for his bravery in coming forward.

Sam's journey had been long and difficult, but he had finally found the truth and exposed the evil that had been lurking in the shadows. He was grateful for Mr. Hawthorne's guidance and support throughout the entire ordeal.

In the end, Sam decided to leave the city behind and return to his Montana roots. He hoped that by starting anew, he could finally leave his past behind and find the peace and happiness he had been searching for.

[Story]: The golden rays of early morning shone into the shelter, landing on the boy's eyes. This stirred him from sleep and through instinct, he immediately clutched at his chest, making sure it was still there. A small pouch tied to a cord draped around his neck, the reason he embarked on this journey. He crawled from the hovel of branches and dead leaves into the forest. The trees were beginning to shed, and the ground was damp. The dense woods turning light brown. The boy set out to look for food.


Silent and slow, the boy explored the forested basin, bow in hand. There were no signs of anything larger than himself there. No trails, no droppings, nothing that might provide the boy with a meal that would last longer than a few days. Birds would do. So, the boy continued, his gaze focused on the forest canopy. While terrain, weather and people might have changed throughout his journey, hunger was the only certainty.

Some time later, the boy managed to shoot down two scrawny cranes and had them tied around his waist. He spied a swan resting at the banks of the river. It was far, but his father taught him to shoot well. The boy focused, drew in a breath, and loosed the arrow. It grazed the swan's neck, and struck a rock behind it, flint tip shattering. The swan began twitching on the gravel bank, the indirect strike broke its neck. Before the boy approached the dying bird, he noticed a rustling in the bushes next to it. He stopped and waited. A wild dog emerged, just as cautious as the boy, and slowly padded towards the swan. The boy could see its ribs clearly through the dogs matted fur, its shoulder blades threatening to break through its skin. He let the dog take his kill.

It was raining heavily. The boy decided to make camp inside a deadfall at the banks of the river. The boy sat soaked and shivering next to his fire. As he dried, he dreamt of warmer lands, and of the place he received his gift.

The sun steadily grew warmer. The lands changing from a lush green to dry grass and eventually to dust and cracked rock. The people also changed. They spoke in a language strange to the boy, guiding him with vague gestures and garbled tongues. He stumbled through the desert, trailing behind his guides, accumulating other ragged followers as they went. Then he saw it. Just along the shimmering horizon was a blot of green atop a hill. A beacon in the desert calling out to lost pilgrims seeking to gain its knowledge.

As the weary group approached the high perched temple, the dry winds carried the stench of rotting flesh. Bodies lay strewn on the sand, swarmed by countless vultures. Their decaying flesh being ripped from the bone by great hooked beaks, their bones to be returned in time to that sacred place atop the hill. Like the wilderness surrounding it, the temple's rites embodied all aspects of life; With death being a necessity for birth and growth.

The boy plunged his face into the natural spring at the gates of the temple, wetting his parched throat and blistered face. A plant grew around the spring, and it grew like no other plant the boy had ever seen. Lines were dug into the earth, allowing water to flow through impossibly straight rows of tall grass. He knew that this was the reason he was sent here.

The days grew longer and longer, with more and more travellers arriving at the oasis. The boy was sitting in the large camp of strangers and the sun had reached its highest point of the year when they were summoned into the temple.

The boy surveyed the cavernous hall, perplexed. A juxtaposition of the natural and artificial. The large room was composed of straight lines and sharp angles, yet etched into the stone was lifelike depictions of the desert fauna; Foxes chasing rabbits, herds of wild horses running along the walls of the room, and in the centre a mighty pillar carrying the image of a large vulture, its magnificent wings spread, scythe beak turned to the side on full display.

The ceremony began with the beating of drums echoing off the high walls. A large stone basin was brought before the audience. With elegant movements, the temple's residents poured soil into the basin. A human bone was ground up, the bleached white powder scattered onto the soil. They produced seeds from small pouches hung around their necks and buried it in the basin's loose mixture. Next, they poured that life giving water from the spring onto the soil and began to dance around the room. The boy's eyes traced their swirling and noticed the moon carvings on the walls. Waxing and waning stone circles. This dance was the passage of time. Each lap of the hall representing months. All while the seed waited in damp soil.

The boy and his fellow travellers were ushered out of the hall and were led to the spring with the strange grass. The grass was cut from the ground and beaten against a flat rock releasing its grain, the stalks being cast aside. The grain was ground down, mixed with water, and baked over a fire. The audience feasted on this new food, along with all manner of desert beasts and a thick liquid that made the boy feel dizzy. The boy hadn't feasted so much in his entire life. But food wasn't the gift he had come all this way to receive, at least not in this form. When it was time for them to leave the temple, each group of travellers were presented with a small pouch much like those the dancers wore. The families rejoiced at receiving this benevolent gift, the boy received his gift alone.

The land was dusted with frost, cold winds funnelled through the mountain pass biting at the boy's skin. Occasionally he would glance behind him, spotting the same wild dog watching from behind a rock or quickly running out of sight. It had been trailing behind him ever since he had shot down that swan.

The boy paused for a moment, then quickly ducked down behind a mound of loose stone. There was a clearing in the woods below, and noises. Speech. A group began to enter the clearing. A band of young men, around the boys age, carrying spears and clubs, wearing the skins of great beasts. He had heard of such people from some of the pilgrims in the desert. Boys sent out into the wilderness, tasked with killing a creature stronger than them, wearing its skin, and returning as men. The boy could hear them from far up the mountain ridge. No doubt the animals in that forest did too. The rear of the line finally emerged into the clearing. They were dragging along women bound at the wrist. Stripped bare, some younger than the boy, some with hair beginning to grey. Most had distended bellies hanging from skeletal frames wholly unsuited for the burden of pregnancy. The boy waited; Still frozen in place long after the party had disappeared back into the treeline. When he could only hear the natural sounds of the forest once more, he rose to his feet and looked up at a path further up the mountain. The wide eyes of the dog stared back at him, waiting for the boy to move ahead so that it too could stand up and continue its journey.

As time passed, the land grew a thick coating of snow. Food was even harder to come by now, yet with each kill he would leave a small pile of refuse some way away from his camp. It would always be gone by the next morning. He didn't see the dog much. It was a careful companion, and rightfully so. The boy had noticed the dog's belly swelling over time; It would have pups any day now.

Amongst the snowcapped trees the boy found a glacial lake. Shimmering blue reflecting the cloudless winter sky above it. He would be able to fish here, possibly enough to last him the remainder of the journey. He didn't know how close he was. He thought he recognised the land surrounding him, yet the drifting snow made him uncertain. He made camp in a small cove along the lakeshore, weaving basket shaped traps and leaving a pile of slightly damp wood for a fire later.

The boy paced along the water, dropping traps where forest streams fed the lake. While he waited, he chipped at the edges of his knife, dull stone flaking off to reveal a hidden sharp edge. The traps hadn't caught as many as he'd hoped, but it'd keep him fed, and that was enough. After gutting the fish with his newly renovated knife and draping them over the smoky fire to dry, he walked a little bit further down the shore and left a pile of offal. He placed a whole fish at the top, for the pups.

Back at the camp he stripped down, leaving the small pouch tucked in a crevice for safekeeping. It was a while since he bathed, but it wasn't raining now, and he had a fire to dry off next to. He made his way back to the edge of the water and looked down, gazing at his reflection in the water. It revealed someone unrecognisable to the boy, pale goose pimpled skin stretched over a wiry frame, more bone than muscle. Hair also began to sprout on his upper lip, this journey had changed him.

He tread the freezing water until his feet began to go numb and the sun began to set. As he emerged from the lake, he noticed that the pile of guts was left untouched. No matter, it would be gone by tomorrow. With shaky steps he went back to the camp, barricading the entrance with stones and fallen branches to keep the heat in. He sat next to the fire clutching the gift around his neck, hoping he would see his family again soon.

A sharp gust of wind entered the cove, waking the boy up. Through sleep blurred eyes he saw figures standing over him. He shot up, spun to the entrance, and saw them clearly. The pelt hunters. The eldest stood before him, a cloak of thick sandy coloured fur slung over his shoulder, grinning with teeth that were beginning to brown. An unseen blow struck the side of the boy"s head, and he went back to sleep."
