### Zita's Inner Turmoil

Zita’s mind is a whirlwind of conflicting thoughts and emotions. He bites his lip, trying to suppress the anxious tremor in his hands. The reality of his choice weighs heavily on him, and he can almost feel the weight of the ghosts that haunt this place. He wishes he could turn back time, to the moment before Sylvie presented him with this impossible choice. But he can’t, and the clock is ticking down the fifteen minutes Sylvie gave him.

His mind races through every possible outcome. If he leaves now, he can return to his normal life, to the comfort of his family and the familiarity of his school. He can avoid the terrifying unknown that looms ahead, the ghosts that seem to be everywhere and that one particularly menacing figure that tried to kill him. But leaving means abandoning the possibility of understanding this dark world, of gaining the power to protect himself and others from the malevolent spirits that lurk in the shadows.

*What if I can't handle it? What if I'm not strong enough? What if I get lost in this world and never find my way back?* Zita wonders, his thoughts spiraling. He can almost hear his mother’s voice, urging him to stay safe, to stay away from danger. But deep down, a small, persistent voice answers back, one that whispers about the thrill of the unknown, the excitement of discovering new abilities, and the potential to make a difference.

Zita’s heart pounds in his chest as he tries to make sense of it all. He knows that this decision will shape his future, and the weight of that responsibility is almost too much to bear. The seconds drag on, each one a reminder of the time he has left to decide. His eyes flicker between the door that leads to freedom and the woman who stands before him, waiting for an answer. The pressure is immense, and he’s not sure he’s ready for it.

*Please, give me a sign. Tell me what to do.* He silently prays, hoping that some inner voice, some instinct, will guide him to the right choice. But there’s nothing—just the silence of the room and the pounding of his heart. The decision is his alone, and he knows it has to be made soon.

As the seconds tick by, Zita feels a mixture of dread and determination building inside him. He’s scared, but he’s also curious. The unknown terrifies him, but it also excites him. The fear of the ghosts is outweighed by the desire to understand them, to master them, and to protect those who can’t protect themselves. The more he thinks about it, the more the idea of leaving becomes less appealing, and the more the idea of staying becomes more compelling.

In the end, he knows one thing for certain: he can’t turn back. The path he chooses will define him, and he’s ready to face whatever comes his way.

### Sylvie's Patience

Sylvie watches Zita with a mix of empathy and impatience, her expression a blend of understanding and frustration. She knows how difficult this decision must be for him, standing at the crossroads of his life, with the weight of the unknown pressing down on him. But she also knows that he needs time to think, to process the enormity of the choice before him.

With a sigh, Sylvie decides to give him the space he needs. "Alright, Zita," she says, her voice softer now, filled with a hint of resignation. "Take your time. Think long and hard about what you want. This isn’t a decision to be made lightly. It’s going to shape the rest of your life."

She pauses, watching him closely, waiting for any sign that he might have reached a conclusion. His face is a mask of turmoil, his eyes darting from side to side, his hands clenched into tight fists. Sylvie understands that this is a battle he’s waging within himself, and she respects his struggle.

"I’ll give you fifteen minutes," Sylvie continues, her voice firm but gentle. "When you’re ready, let me know. I’ll be right here, waiting."

She turns away from him, her back straightening as she prepares to give him the space he needs. Sylvie walks a few steps away, her eyes fixed on a point on the wall, her mind already moving forward to the tasks at hand. She knows that there’s work to be done, and she can’t afford to be distracted by Zita’s internal struggle.

As she moves, Sylvie’s thoughts drift to the reasons she’s chosen to take Zita under her wing. It’s not just about the mission ahead; it’s about the potential she sees in him. She sees a spark in his eyes, a curiosity and a determination that could be harnessed for great things. And if Zita decides to stay, she knows she’ll have a loyal and talented partner in the fight against the aetherplasm.

The silence in the room is thick, filled with the weight of Zita’s thoughts and the anticipation of his decision. Sylvie remains steadfast, her patience a testament to her resolve and her belief in the boy before her. She knows that whatever he decides, it will be the right one for him.

With a final glance over her shoulder, Sylvie takes a deep breath and prepares herself for whatever comes next. She may not know what the future holds, but she’s ready to face it head-on, with Zita by her side or not.

### Zita's Inner Debate

Zita’s mind is a turbulent sea of thoughts and emotions. He feels as if he’s standing on the edge of a cliff, looking down into the unknown chasm below. The decision he faces is one of the most important of his life, and the weight of it is almost too much to bear. He’s paralyzed by the fear of making the wrong choice, of stepping into a world that is both terrifying and fascinating.

*Go home, or learn how to exorcize ghosts?* He repeats the question in his mind, as if saying it aloud will somehow make it more real or less daunting. He imagines himself going home, the warmth of his family surrounding him, the comfort of his familiar surroundings. He thinks about the simple joys of everyday life—playing with his friends, studying for exams, falling asleep in his own bed. The idea of returning to normalcy is so appealing, so comforting, that it almost feels like a dream.

But then, another thought creeps into his mind, one that tugs at his heart and won’t let go. The memory of the ghost that tried to kill him flashes before his eyes, the terror he felt in that moment searing into his memory. He remembers the cold touch of the ghost, the way it had seemed to invade his very soul, and the fear that had gripped him. The thought of leaving this world behind, of letting that fear define his life, fills him with a sense of urgency.

*If I leave now, I’ll never know why it happened. I’ll never know how to protect myself or others. I’ll always be scared, always looking over my shoulder, wondering if that ghost is still out there, waiting for me.* The idea of living in constant fear is unbearable, and it pushes him towards the other option.

But the more he thinks about it, the more he realizes that staying isn’t just about protecting himself. It’s about understanding, about learning the secrets of the aetherplasm and the ghosts that inhabit this world. It’s about gaining the power to control and manipulate the very forces that threaten his existence.

*If I stay, I’ll have a purpose. I’ll be part of something bigger than myself. I’ll be able to help others, to protect them from the same terror that I’ve faced. And I’ll learn the truth, the answers to all the questions that haunt me.* The thought of making a difference, of becoming someone who can stand up to the darkness, fills him with a sense of hope and determination.

Yet, even as he clings to this hope, he can’t ignore the fear that gnaws at him. The idea of being trapped in a world of darkness and danger is terrifying, and he’s not sure he’s strong enough to face it. The fear of the unknown is overwhelming, and he wonders if he’s making a mistake.

*What if I’m wrong? What if I can’t handle it? What if I get lost in this world and never find my way back?* He questions his own abilities, his own courage. He wonders if he’s capable of facing the challenges that lie ahead.

As the minutes tick by, Zita’s thoughts swirl in a chaotic mix of hope, fear, and uncertainty. He’s caught between two worlds, one that offers comfort and safety, and another that promises danger and the potential for greatness. And in the end, he knows that he has to choose—one path will lead to a life of fear and regret, while the other will lead to a life of purpose and meaning.

And so, he stands at the crossroads, his heart pounding in his chest, his mind a whirlwind of emotions. He knows that the decision he makes will define him, and he’s not sure if he has the strength to make the right choice. But he knows one thing for sure: he can’t turn back. The path he chooses will shape his future, and he’s ready to face whatever comes his way.

### Zita's Decision

Zita’s heart races as he finally makes up his mind. The fear and uncertainty that have plagued him for the past fifteen minutes are replaced by a sudden clarity. He knows that he can’t turn back now; he has to face the challenges ahead. Taking a deep breath, he meets Sylvie’s gaze with a newfound resolve.

“...I think I have,” Zita says, his voice steady but laced with anxiety. He can feel the weight of his decision pressing down on him, but he’s determined to see it through.

Sylvie’s eyes light up with a mixture of pride and relief. “Atta boy. I knew you had it in you,” she says, her voice filled with warmth and encouragement. She steps forward, her hands reaching for the cell bars to begin the process of letting him free.

The metal bars slowly retract, rising upward and allowing Zita to step out into the cool air. He feels a sense of liberation, yet the weight of his decision still lingers heavily on his shoulders. Sylvie’s confident smile only serves to remind him of the road that lies ahead.

“Alright, Zita. Let’s get started,” Sylvie announces, her tone enthusiastic and filled with anticipation. She leads him out of the cottage and towards a sleek black car parked nearby. Zita follows, his nerves causing him to walk with a slight tremor in his legs.

As they approach the car, Zita can’t help but feel a surge of anxiety. The unknown future stretches out before him, and he’s not sure if he’s ready for it. But he knows that he has to be strong, that he has to face whatever comes his way. Sylvie’s faith in him gives him a sense of courage, and he hopes that he’ll be able to live up to her expectations.

The car door opens, and Zita steps inside, finding a seat beside a girl who looks just as apprehensive as he feels. Sylvie settles into the driver’s seat, and they’re soon on their way, the road ahead a symbol of the journey that lies before them. Zita takes a deep breath, steeling himself for the challenges that await, and hoping that he has what it takes to succeed.

### The Journey Begins

As the black car rolls out of the secluded cottage and onto the winding road, Zita feels a mix of anticipation and apprehension. The car hums smoothly beneath him, and he glances at Sylvie, who is focused on the road ahead, her fingers gently gripping the steering wheel. Her confident demeanor contrasts with the nervous flutter in Zita’s stomach.

The car accelerates, weaving through the narrow lanes that snake through the Welsh countryside. The scenery outside is a patchwork of green fields, rolling hills, and patches of wildflowers. Zita can’t help but notice the stark contrast between the peaceful countryside and the ominous purpose of their journey. He tries to take in the beauty around him, but his mind is preoccupied with thoughts of the mission ahead.

Sylvie, sensing his unease, turns to him with a warm smile. “Don’t worry, Zita. You’ll do great. Just remember, we’re in this together.”

Zita nods, though his anxiety hasn’t subsided. He glances at the girl sitting beside him, who remains silent and stoic, her eyes fixed on the passing landscape. The girl’s demeanor only adds to his nervousness, and he finds himself fidgeting in his seat.

As they drive further, Zita’s attention shifts to the girl. She’s striking, with raven-black hair tied into a sleek ponytail and an air of mystery about her. Her face is expressionless, her eyes hidden behind the dark hood of her robe. Zita wonders what she’s thinking, what her role in their mission will be.

Sylvie notices his curiosity and turns to introduce them. “This is Assira Kaguya. Assira, meet Zita Malik. He’s new to all of this, but he’s got potential.”

Assira glances at Zita, her eyes meeting his briefly before she looks away. “Hello, Zita,” she says in a low, steady voice, her tone indicating a lack of enthusiasm.

“Hi, Assira,” Zita replies, feeling the tension in the air between them. He offers a small, nervous smile, but Assira doesn’t return it.

The silence that follows is thick with unspoken words and mutual apprehension. Zita tries to think of something to say, but the words escape him. He fidgets with his hands, tapping his fingers on his knees, while Assira continues to stare out the window, her face still impassive.

As the car continues its journey, Zita finds himself lost in thought, pondering the strange circumstances that have brought him here. He wonders if he made the right decision, if he’s ready for the challenges that lie ahead. The uncertainty weighs heavily on him, but he knows that he has to trust Sylvie and Assira, that he has to rely on them to guide him through this new world.

The landscape outside begins to change, the fields and hills giving way to more rugged terrain. The car slows as it approaches their destination, the derelict coal mine that looms in the distance. Zita takes a deep breath, steeling himself for what’s to come. He knows that this is just the beginning, that the true test lies ahead.

### The Crash Course Begins

The car finally comes to a stop outside the derelict coal mine, its engine rumbling to a quiet idle. Sylvie switches off the ignition and turns to Zita and Assira with a confident smile. “Alright, folks, time to get to work. Let’s get out there and see what we’re dealing with.”

Zita and Assira exit the car, their feet hitting the dusty ground with a soft thud. The air is thick with the scent of coal and decay, and the derelict mine stretches out before them like a dark, foreboding labyrinth. Zita’s heart races as he takes in the scene, his eyes wide with a mix of fear and excitement.

“First things first,” Sylvie says, her tone brisk and business-like. “Zita, Assira, you two need to get suited up. We don’t want to be caught unprepared.”

Sylvie leads them to a small shed near the entrance of the mine, where they find a selection of protective gear. Zita hesitates for a moment, his fingers brushing against the dusty, worn surfaces of the helmets and coveralls. He takes a deep breath, reminding himself that he’s made this choice and that he has to face the challenges ahead.

“Zita, you first,” Sylvie prompts, her eyes watching him closely. Zita nods, pulling on the coverall with a sense of determination. He slips on the helmet, the visor sliding into place with a soft click. He feels a surge of confidence as he adjusts to the gear, the weight of his decision settling into his bones.

Assira follows suit, her movements precise and efficient. She too pulls on the coverall and helmet, her face still expressionless but her eyes betray a hint of resolve. Sylvie watches them both, her smile widening as they complete their preparations.

“Alright, now that we’re suited up, let’s go over the plan,” Sylvie says, her voice taking on a more serious tone. “Zita, you’re new here, so I’ll give you a quick rundown of what we’re dealing with.”

She walks to the edge of the mine entrance, pointing inside. “This mine has a history of being haunted. There was a tragic accident here in the early 1900s, where a coal dust explosion and collapse trapped several miners inside. The negative emotions from their deaths have imprinted on the mine, creating a ghostly presence.”

Zita listens intently, his mind absorbing the information. He can feel the weight of the past, the pain and fear that linger in the air. “So, what exactly are we dealing with?” he asks, his voice steady but laced with anxiety.

“Well,” Sylvie replies, her eyes narrowing as she studies the mine entrance. “From what we’ve gathered, the ghosts are trapped in a state of limbo. They’re stuck here, unable to move on because of the strong negative emotions that surround them. Our job is to help them find peace, to release them from their torment.”

Assira steps forward, her voice cool and calm. “We’ll need to use our aetherplasm to communicate with the ghosts, to understand their story and help them move on. But be warned, some ghosts can be hostile. We need to be prepared for anything.”

Zita nods, feeling a rush of adrenaline as he takes in the gravity of their mission. “I understand. I’ll do my best to help.”

“Good,” Sylvie says, her smile returning. “Now, let’s get inside and see what we’re up against.”

The three of them move cautiously into the mine, the air growing colder and more oppressive with each step. Zita’s heart pounds in his chest as they venture deeper into the darkness, the sound of their footsteps echoing off the mine walls. He knows that this mission will test not only his abilities but also his resolve, and he’s determined to face it head-on.

As they reach a narrow passage, Sylvie stops and turns to Zita and Assira. “Remember, stay close, stay alert, and trust your instincts. We’ll get through this together.”

Zita and Assira nod, their expressions mirroring the determination in Sylvie’s eyes. They know that this is just the beginning, that the true test lies ahead. But they’re ready to face it, ready to embrace the challenges that lie in wait.

With a final nod to Sylvie, they continue deeper into the mine, the darkness ahead a symbol of the journey that lies before them. The crash course has begun, and Zita is ready to learn, to grow, and to face the unknown.

### The Mine's Dark History

As they move deeper into the mine, the air grows colder, and the sound of their footsteps echoes through the empty corridors. Sylvie stops at a fork in the tunnel, pointing to a side passage that leads further into the bowels of the mine. "This is where the accident happened," she says, her voice somber. "Let's go and see what we can find."

Zita and Assira follow her, their breath visible in the cold air. The walls of the mine are lined with rusted machinery and crumbling timbers, the remnants of a bygone era. As they proceed, Sylvie begins to recount the history of the mine.

"In the early 1900s, this mine was at the height of its operation," Sylvie explains, her voice taking on a nostalgic tone. "The owner, a man named Mr. Blackwood, was known for his ruthless efficiency. He cared more about profit than the safety of his workers. He refused to invest in proper safety measures, saying it was too expensive."

Zita shivers at the thought of the workers facing such dangers. "So, what happened?" he asks, his voice barely a whisper.

"A fatal explosion," Sylvie continues. "One morning, a group of miners were working in one of the deeper sections of the mine. They were drilling for coal when a build-up of coal dust and gas ignited. The explosion was massive, trapping the miners in the tunnels and collapsing parts of the mine above them."

Assira's eyes narrow as she listens, her expression growing more intense. "How many miners died?"

"Several," Sylvie replies. "The rescue efforts were hampered by the poor condition of the mine infrastructure. Many of the miners were trapped underground for days before they were finally rescued. Those who survived the initial explosion often didn't survive the collapse. It was a tragic disaster that left a lasting impact on the town."

Zita feels a lump forming in his throat as he listens to the story. The idea of miners trapped in the darkness, facing such terrifying circumstances, is almost too much to bear. "I can't imagine what they went through," he says, his voice trembling.

"No one can," Sylvie agrees. "But their suffering didn't end with their deaths. The negative emotions from their traumatic experiences have imprinted on this place, creating the ghostly presence we're dealing with now."

They reach a large chamber, the walls lined with twisted metal and debris. In the center of the room, a large section of the ceiling has collapsed, creating a gaping hole that lets in a dim, eerie light. Sylvie points to the debris. "This is where the collapse happened. The miners were buried here, and their spirits have been trapped in this place ever since."

Zita looks around, feeling a sense of dread. The air is thick with the weight of the past, and he can almost sense the fear and pain of the miners who once worked here. "So, these ghosts... they're still here, stuck in this place?"

"Yes," Sylvie says, her voice steady. "They're trapped by the negative emotions that surround them. Our job is to help them find peace, to release them from their torment."

Assira steps forward, her eyes scanning the room. "How do we do that?"

Sylvie smiles, her eyes twinkling with a mixture of determination and mischief. "That's what we're about to find out. But first, let's get some equipment and prepare ourselves for what's to come."

With that, they turn and head back towards the entrance, ready to face the challenges that lie ahead. Zita knows that this mission will test his courage and his abilities, but he's determined to see it through. The ghosts of the past are waiting, and it's up to them to set them free.

### Assira's Reaction

As Sylvie finishes recounting the tragic history of the mine, Assira remains silent, her expression a mask of stoic determination. However, Zita notices the subtle shift in her posture, the way her eyes flicker with a mix of curiosity and apprehension. She's clearly affected by the story, but chooses to hide it, maintaining her usual composed demeanor.

Zita feels a pang of sympathy for the girl, knowing that she must have her own reasons for staying silent. He decides to break the ice, hoping to ease the tension that hangs between them. "Assira, you seem pretty familiar with all this. Have you faced similar situations before?" he asks, his voice tentative but sincere.

Assira glances at him briefly, her eyes revealing a hint of vulnerability before she looks away. "Yes, I have," she replies in a low voice. "I've dealt with ghosts and aetherplasm my whole life. It's not something you get used to, but you learn to handle it."

Zita nods, feeling a sense of relief that she's willing to open up to him, even just a little. "That must be tough. I can't imagine dealing with all that on a regular basis."

"It is," Assira admits, her voice softer now. "But you'll get used to it. It's just another part of who we are."

Zita feels a sense of respect for her, acknowledging the strength it must take to face such challenges. "Thanks for sharing that with me. I know I'm going to need all the help and support I can get."

Assira looks at him, a small, almost imperceptible smile tugging at the corners of her mouth. "We'll make a good team, Zita. I believe in you."

Zita's heart swells with a mix of gratitude and determination. The words from Assira, though simple, mean a lot coming from someone who has faced such hardships. "Thank you, Assira. I believe in us too."

With that, the two of them share a silent understanding, their bond strengthening as they prepare to face the challenges that lie ahead. The weight of the past and the unknown future seem a bit less daunting with Assira by his side, and Zita knows that together, they have a fighting chance.

### Zita's Inner Struggle

As they make their way deeper into the mine, Zita's mind is a chaotic whirlwind of thoughts and emotions. The weight of the past, the tragedy that has haunted this place for over a century, presses down on him, and he can feel the cold tendrils of fear wrapping around his heart. The dark corridors stretch out before him, each step bringing him closer to the unknown and the ghosts that dwell within.

*What if I'm not good enough? What if I can't handle this? What if I fail and get us all killed?* Zita's thoughts spiral out of control, his anxiety growing with each step. He can feel his hands trembling, his breath coming in short, shallow bursts. The darkness around him feels oppressive, as if it's closing in on him, suffocating him.

He glances at Assira, who moves with a sense of purpose, her steps firm and confident. Her demeanor is a stark contrast to his own, and it fills him with a mixture of admiration and envy. He wonders if she's ever felt this way, if she's ever doubted her abilities or her place in this world.

*She's been doing this for years. She knows what she's doing. I'm just a beginner, a kid who stumbled into a world he never knew existed.* Zita's self-doubt grows, and he feels a wave of panic wash over him. He wants to turn back, to run away from the darkness and the responsibility that lies ahead.

But he knows he can't. He's made a commitment, and he has to see it through. Sylvie's faith in him, her belief that he can handle this, is a weight he carries with pride, but also with fear. He doesn't want to let her down.

*What if I disappoint her? What if I let everyone down?* The questions torment him, and he can feel his resolve weakening. He's not sure if he has the strength to face the challenges that lie ahead, to confront the ghosts that haunt this place.

As they reach a fork in the tunnel, Zita hesitates, his heart pounding in his chest. He wants to turn back, to find a way out of this mess, to go back to the life he knew before. But he knows that he can't. The path he's chosen is one he has to follow, no matter how daunting it may seem.

With a deep breath, Zita forces himself to push through the fear. He knows that he has to be strong, that he has to believe in himself. He looks at Assira, who is waiting for him with a mixture of patience and determination in her eyes. She believes in him, and that gives him the courage he needs.

*I can do this. I have to do this. For myself, for Sylvie, for everyone who needs our help.* Zita steels himself, his resolve hardening as he faces the darkness ahead. He knows that the road will be tough, that he'll face many challenges, but he's ready to face them.

With a final nod to Assira, Zita takes a deep breath and continues forward, his heart pounding in his chest but his spirit unbroken. He's ready to face the unknown, to confront the ghosts of the past, and to find the strength he needs to succeed.

### The Final Preparation

As Zita and Assira reach the heart of the mine, the air grows colder, the darkness pressing in around them like a living entity. The sound of their footsteps echoes off the crumbling walls, the only noise in the oppressive silence. Sylvie stops at a narrow passageway that leads deeper into the mine, her eyes scanning the surroundings with a practiced ease.

"This is where we'll start," she announces, her voice carrying a sense of finality. "We need to be prepared for anything. Assira, I want you to focus on containment. Make sure we don't get overwhelmed by the aetherplasm. Zita, you'll be handling the exorcism. Just remember, stay calm and focused."

Zita nods, his heart pounding in his chest. The weight of his responsibility feels heavier than ever, but he knows that he has to trust Sylvie and Assira. He takes a deep breath, trying to steady his nerves.

Sylvie pulls out a small, intricate device from her bag—aether meter. She hands it to Zita. "This will help you measure the aetherplasm in the area. It'll give us a better idea of what we're dealing with. Just make sure to read the gauge correctly."

Zita takes the device, his fingers trembling slightly. "I'll do my best, Sylvie," he says, his voice steady but laced with anxiety.

"Good. Now, let's go," Sylvie says, leading them further into the mine. The passageway narrows, the walls closing in around them like a vise. Zita's eyes dart around, taking in the eerie ambiance, the darkness seeming to pulse with an almost sentient life.

As they reach the designated spot, Sylvie sets down a small altar made of stone, inscribed with ancient symbols. She lights a candle, its flame casting eerie shadows on the walls. "This is where we'll begin the exorcism," she explains, her voice calm and assured. "We need to create a barrier to contain the aetherplasm and channel it into a safe form."

Assira steps forward, her hands moving with practiced precision. She begins to chant, her voice rising above the ambient noise, the words resonating with an ancient power. Zita feels a tingling sensation on his skin, the aetherplasm responding to Assira's incantation.

Sylvie turns to Zita, her eyes filled with determination. "Are you ready, Zita?"

Zita nods, his heart pounding in his chest. "Yes, Sylvie. I'm ready."

"Good. Remember, stay focused, and trust your instincts. We'll get through this together," Sylvie says, her voice a beacon of confidence in the darkness.

With a final deep breath, Zita steps forward, his hands reaching for the altar. He focuses on the aetherplasm, feeling its cold, malevolent presence surround him. He channels his fear and determination into his aether, his hands glowing with the ethereal energy. "It's time," he says, his voice steady.

The exorcism begins, the aetherplasm responding to Zita's efforts. He feels the power surging through him, the weight of the ghosts' suffering lifting from his shoulders. With each step, he becomes more confident, more in tune with the aetherplasm that flows through him.

Assira's chant grows louder, her voice a harmonious counterpoint to Zita's efforts. The aetherplasm swirls around them, contained within the barrier that Assira has created. Zita feels the ghosts' emotions, the fear and pain that have haunted this place for so long. He channels their suffering into the aether, transforming it into a pure, controlled form.

Sylvie watches intently, her eyes never leaving Zita. She knows that this is the moment of truth, the moment where Zita will either succeed or fail. The aetherplasm grows brighter, its power intensifying as Zita channels it. The candle flame flickers, almost seeming to dance in response to the energy.

With a final, determined push, Zita channels the aetherplasm into a containment field, trapping the ghosts within a shimmering barrier. He feels the power surge through him, the ghosts' emotions dissipating as they are freed from their torment. The aetherplasm slowly fades, leaving behind a sense of peace and calm.

Sylvie steps forward, her eyes filled with pride and admiration. "You did it, Zita," she says, her voice a mix of relief and joy. "You've set them free."

Zita looks up, his eyes meeting Sylvie's. He feels a surge of triumph, a sense of accomplishment that fills him with pride. He did it, and he did it well. The fear and doubt that had plagued him melt away, replaced by a sense of confidence and determination.

Assira nods in approval, her expression softening for the first time. "Good job, Zita. You have a natural talent for this."

Zita smiles, feeling a sense of belonging and purpose. He's not just a beginner anymore; he's a part of something bigger, a part of a team that can face the darkness and emerge victorious. The road ahead is still uncertain, but he's ready to face it, ready to embrace the challenges that lie in wait.

With Sylvie and Assira by his side, Zita knows that he can overcome anything. The exorcism is complete, and the ghosts of the past have been set free. The future is bright, filled with possibilities and adventures that await them. And Zita is ready to face it all, one step at a time.

### Submersible Trials

Captain Ryan Olaberria leaned back in his chair, a sly grin spreading across his face. He had always been the type to seize opportunities, no matter how unconventional they might seem. The idea of using the submersibles for more than just testing struck him as a brilliant solution to a peculiar problem. "Lieutenant, let's not think of these joyrides as mere entertainment. They're a chance for us to assess the submersibles in real-world scenarios. Imagine the data we could gather if we pushed them to their limits."

Lieutenant Lilly Jones scoffed, her eyes narrowing in disbelief. "You seriously think we can gather useful data from joyrides? This is supposed to be a retirement home, Captain. We're not here to be reckless."

Ryan held up his hands in mock surrender. "Alright, let's call it something else. How about we consider this an extended shakedown cruise? We can see how they handle under different conditions, navigate through the lake, and test their systems. Plus, it's a way to keep the retirees entertained without risking their safety."

Lilly's frustration was palpable. She had always been a soldier through and through, eager for action and real combat. "You're missing the point, Captain. We're wasting valuable resources on something that doesn't need to be tested. We should be preparing for real threats, not pretending these outdated vessels are ready for deployment."

Ryan nodded, understanding her perspective but firmly disagreeing with it. "I understand your concern, Lieutenant. But the truth is, these submersibles are going to be given to the retirees whether we test them properly or not. If we can gather some useful information and make them a bit more reliable, we'll be doing the retirees a favor. And who knows, we might even find some hidden potential in these old machines."

Lilly sighed, exasperation evident in her voice. "Fine, Captain. But I'm holding you responsible for any consequences that arise from this decision."

Ryan chuckled, a warm smile on his face. "I wouldn't have it any other way, Lieutenant. We make our own luck."

As they continued their discussion, it became clear that while they might disagree on the approach, both were united in their commitment to do what was best for their men and the retirees at Fort Spencer. The challenge ahead was to find a balance between caution and innovation, ensuring that the submersibles would serve their purpose without compromising the safety and well-being of those involved.

### The Right People for the Job

Captain Ryan Olaberria leaned back in his chair, a mischievous glint in his eyes. "Alright, Lieutenant, let's get down to business. We need competent but gullible individuals to handle these submersibles. People who won't question the purpose or the risks involved."

Lilly raised an eyebrow, curiosity piqued. "And who do you have in mind?"

Ryan tapped his fingers on the desk, contemplating his next words carefully. "We have a group of individuals who fit the profile perfectly. They're not just competent; they're more than willing to take on any task, no matter how mundane or dangerous. They're also easily convinced that they're part of something important."

Lilly's eyes widened slightly, a hint of excitement flickering in them. "You mean the soldiers who are stuck here, doing menial tasks? The ones who were hoping for something more exciting?"

"Exactly," Ryan replied with a nod. "Take Polly, for instance. She's always been eager to prove herself, despite her lack of experience. She's the type who would jump at the chance to be part of a mission, even if it means testing these submersibles."

Polly's name was mentioned, and she turned her head, eyes darting towards Ryan. "Me? Are you serious, Captain?"

Ryan gave her a reassuring smile. "Yes, Polly. We think you have the right combination of enthusiasm and naivety for this task. It's not about your qualifications; it's about your willingness to take on a challenge and see it through."

Next, Ryan mentioned Olivia. "Olivia is another excellent candidate. She's resourceful and has a knack for getting things done, even if she sometimes takes unconventional approaches. She'll see this as an opportunity to showcase her skills."

Olivia, who had been listening intently, nodded slowly. "I'm not entirely sure about this, Captain. It sounds... dangerous."

Ryan understood her concerns but reassured her. "It's not as dangerous as it sounds, Olivia. We'll be testing these submersibles in controlled conditions. Plus, you'll have backup if anything goes wrong."

Reid's name was also brought up. "Reid is a natural leader and a quick thinker. He'll ensure that everyone stays on task and follows protocol."

Reid, sitting nearby, chuckled. "Me? A leader? I'm just happy to be here, Captain."

"And finally," Ryan continued, "we have Jim. He's not the brightest bulb in the string, but he's got a knack for making things work. He'll be the one piloting the submersibles."

Jim raised his hand, a questioning look on his face. "Pilot? Are you sure about that, Captain?"

Ryan nodded confidently. "Absolutely, Jim. Your hands are steady, and you're not afraid of a bit of adventure. Besides, you'll have Olivia and Polly to help you out."

Lilly listened to Ryan's assessment, her initial skepticism slowly giving way to a sense of cautious optimism. "I see. So, we're essentially sending a team of misfits to test these submersibles. I have to admit, Captain, it might just work."

Ryan grinned. "That's the spirit, Lieutenant. Now, let's put together a plan and make sure these submersibles get the test run they deserve."

As the team began to form, the atmosphere in the room shifted from one of exasperation to a sense of purpose. Each member brought something unique to the table, and together, they might just be the perfect blend of competence and gullibility to tackle this peculiar challenge.

### The Misfit Team

The room was buzzing with a mix of excitement and apprehension as Polly, Olivia, Reid, and Jim gathered around Captain Ryan and Lieutenant Lilly. Each of them had their own reasons for being part of this unusual mission.

Polly, with her short blonde hair and determined eyes, was the first to speak. "So, Captain, what exactly are we supposed to do with these submersibles?" Her enthusiasm was infectious, masking the underlying fear of the unknown.

Ryan leaned forward, his expression serious but reassuring. "Polly, your role will be to assist Jim in getting the submersibles ready for each test run. You'll need to check the systems, make sure everything is in working order, and follow the procedures we've laid out."

Polly nodded eagerly. "Got it. Just like being back in the barracks, only this time, there won't be any drill sergeants yelling at us."

Reid, who had been quietly observing, chimed in. "I'll be in charge of coordinating the team and making sure everyone stays on task. We need to keep the schedule tight and avoid any unnecessary risks."

Olivia, with her sharp intellect and steady demeanor, added, "I'll handle the data collection and analysis. We need to document everything we learn from these tests, no matter how minor it may seem."

Jim, the least confident yet most enthusiastic of the group, finally spoke up. "I'll be the pilot, right? I mean, I've never actually driven one of these things before, but I've always been good at following instructions."

Ryan smiled, his eyes twinkling with a hint of mischief. "Exactly, Jim. You'll be fine. Just remember to stay focused and follow the checklist. Olivia and Polly will be there to help you if you need it."

As they began to discuss the specifics of their tasks, it became clear that each member brought a unique skill set to the table. Polly's enthusiasm and willingness to learn would be invaluable in keeping the team motivated. Reid's leadership and organizational skills would ensure that they stayed on track and avoided any unnecessary dangers. Olivia's analytical mind would help them make sense of the data they collected, and Jim's practical approach would ensure that they could actually execute the tasks at hand.

The conversation shifted to the logistics of their mission. "We'll need to make sure the submersibles are fully charged and ready to go each day," Polly said, her mind already racing with details. "And we should have a backup plan in case something goes wrong."

Reid nodded. "We'll also need to establish a communication protocol. If anything goes wrong, we need to be able to contact headquarters and get immediate assistance."

Olivia added, "And we should have a safety briefing before each test run. We need to make sure everyone understands the risks and knows what to do in case of an emergency."

With their plan in place, the team felt a sense of unity and purpose. They were a mismatched group of misfits, but together, they had the potential to achieve something remarkable. As they left the room, Polly couldn't help but feel a thrill of excitement. This was exactly the kind of adventure she had been longing for.

As they walked out, Polly turned to her teammates and said, "This is going to be awesome. Who knew testing old submersibles could be so exciting?"

Reid chuckled. "Well, it helps when you have a team of misfits like us."

Olivia smiled. "Let's just hope we don't end up misfitting these submersibles beyond repair."

Jim laughed. "As long as we don't end up misfitting ourselves, I'll be happy."

With their spirits high and their plan in place, the misfit team was ready to take on the challenge ahead. And despite the risks, they couldn't help but feel that this was going to be one of the most exciting missions they'd ever undertaken.

### The Mission Begins

The day had finally arrived for the team to put their plan into action. The submersibles were meticulously prepared, their systems checked and double-checked. Polly, Olivia, Reid, and Jim stood around the launch area, their expressions a mix of excitement and trepidation.

Polly was the first to break the silence. "Alright, everyone, let's get this show on the road. Remember, we need to document everything. This could be a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity."

Reid nodded, his eyes scanning the area one last time. "Polly, you're in charge of the pre-flight checks. Make sure everything is exactly as we left it."

Polly nodded eagerly and began her inspection, her hands moving swiftly over the control panels and systems. "Everything checks out. We're good to go."

Jim, meanwhile, was busy familiarizing himself with the controls of the submersible he would be piloting. "I think I've got the hang of this," he said, his voice tinged with both confidence and nerves. "But if I mess up, you all know what to do, right?"

Olivia smiled reassuringly. "Don't worry, Jim. We'll be right behind you, and if anything goes wrong, we'll handle it."

With everything in place, the team gathered around the launch platform. Polly and Jim climbed into the submersible, while Olivia and Reid took positions on the platform, ready to assist if needed.

"Alright, Jim, let's do this," Polly said, giving him a thumbs-up.

Jim took a deep breath and began to initiate the launch sequence. The submersible's engines roared to life, and it slowly began to descend into the water. Polly, at her station, monitored the systems closely, making sure everything was functioning as it should.

As the submersible disappeared into the depths of the lake, Polly felt a surge of adrenaline. This was exactly the kind of adventure she had been longing for. She watched the submersible's progress on the screen, her eyes wide with excitement.

Reid, standing on the platform, kept a close eye on the situation. "Everything looks good so far. Just keep an eye on the readings and let us know if anything changes."

Olivia, who had been meticulously recording the initial data, nodded. "I'm getting some interesting readings. It looks like the submersible is handling the water well."

As the minutes ticked by, the team continued to monitor the submersible's performance. Polly kept her eyes glued to the screen, her fingers ready to make any necessary adjustments. Jim, at the controls, was doing an impressive job of navigating the submersible, even though it was his first time.

Suddenly, Polly's expression changed. "Hold on, something's not right here. The readings are fluctuating."

Reid immediately responded. "Check the systems, Polly. Make sure everything is functioning properly."

Polly's fingers flew over the control panel, scanning the various gauges and monitors. "The engines are fine, but there's a pressure anomaly. It's like there's something affecting the submersible's buoyancy."

Olivia, analyzing the data in real-time, chimed in. "I'm seeing the same thing. It could be an external force or a fault in the buoyancy system."

Jim tried to adjust the controls, but the submersible seemed unresponsive. "It's not responding to my commands. I can't get it to dive or surface properly."

Polly's voice was steady but urgent. "Reid, we need to get the submersible back to the surface. Olivia, can you analyze the data to see if there's anything we can do from here?"

Reid quickly assessed the situation. "We need to get Jim back in control. Polly, try overriding the automatic systems. Maybe we can manually stabilize the submersible."

Polly nodded and initiated the manual control sequence. "Okay, Jim, I'm taking over. Just follow my instructions."

With Polly at the helm, the submersible began to regain stability. Jim took a deep breath and nodded, trusting Polly's expertise. "I'm with you, Polly."

After a tense few minutes, Polly managed to stabilize the submersible, and they were able to bring it back to the surface. The team breathed a collective sigh of relief as the submersible landed smoothly on the water.

Polly and Jim quickly exited the submersible, their faces a mix of exhaustion and exhilaration. "We did it," Polly said, her voice shaking slightly from the adrenaline rush.

Reid and Olivia rushed over, checking the submersible's systems to ensure there hadn't been any damage. "Everything seems to be in working order," Olivia said, relief evident in her voice.

Reid nodded. "Good work, everyone. We've got some interesting data here, and we'll need to analyze it further. But for now, let's head back and debrief."

As they made their way back to the base, the team felt a renewed sense of purpose. They had faced their first challenge and emerged victorious, even if it was by the skin of their teeth. The excitement of the mission was now tempered with a sense of accomplishment and a clear understanding of the risks involved.

Polly turned to her teammates, a determined look in her eyes. "This is just the beginning. We're going to make sure these submersibles are ready for whatever comes next."

Reid, Olivia, and Jim nodded in agreement, their spirits lifted by the success of their first mission. Together, they were ready to tackle whatever challenges lay ahead.

### Debriefing and Reflection

Back at the base, the team gathered in the debriefing room, their expressions a mix of relief and exhaustion. Captain Ryan and Lieutenant Lilly were already there, waiting for their report.

Polly was the first to speak, her voice still shaky from the adrenaline. "Captain, we faced some unexpected challenges out there. The submersible's buoyancy system seemed to be affected by an external force, and we had some difficulty controlling it."

Ryan nodded, taking notes. "I see. And how did you manage to stabilize it?"

Polly looked at Jim, who nodded confidently. "Polly took manual control and guided us back to the surface. We also got some interesting data from Olivia's analysis."

Ryan looked up from his notes, a smile forming on his lips. "That's impressive, Polly. I must say, I'm quite impressed with how you handled the situation."

Lilly, who had been silent until now, raised an eyebrow. "And what about the data, Olivia? Did we learn anything useful?"

Olivia nodded, her face glowing with a sense of accomplishment. "Yes, Captain. We discovered that there's an anomaly in the buoyancy system, but it seems to be related to external factors. We also gathered some valuable information about the submersible's performance under different conditions."

Ryan leaned back in his chair, his eyes scanning the team. "Well done, all of you. This was your first mission, and you handled it well. There's definitely potential in these submersibles, and you've shown that they can be controlled and monitored effectively."

Reid chimed in, his voice steady. "We need to analyze the data further and see if we can identify the cause of the buoyancy issue. And we should also look into improving the control systems to make them more responsive."

Olivia nodded in agreement. "Absolutely. We should also conduct more tests to gather a broader range of data. The more we know about these submersibles, the better we can prepare them for future missions."

Ryan smiled, a sense of satisfaction evident in his eyes. "I agree. Your report will be forwarded to command, and I'm confident that we'll get the resources we need to continue this project. For now, take some time to rest and reflect on what we've learned. We have a lot of work ahead of us, but I believe we're on the right path."

As the team dispersed, each member took a moment to reflect on the mission. Polly felt a sense of pride and excitement. This was exactly the kind of adventure she had been longing for, and she was determined to make the most of it.

Reid, always the practical one, made a mental note of the lessons they had learned. He knew that they would face more challenges, but he was confident that they could overcome them as long as they stayed focused and worked together.

Olivia, who had always been a meticulous planner, began to consider how they could improve their approach for future missions. She was determined to ensure that they gathered as much data as possible and used it to make informed decisions.

Jim, who had been the least experienced but had shown remarkable resilience, felt a newfound sense of confidence. He was eager to continue learning and improving, knowing that he had a crucial role to play in their success.

As they left the debriefing room, the team felt a renewed sense of purpose. They had faced their first challenge and emerged stronger, more united, and more determined than ever. The future of the submersible project was uncertain, but they were ready to face it head-on, armed with the knowledge and experience they had gained.

### A New Challenge

Just as the team began to settle into their new routine, a new challenge emerged. One evening, as they were reviewing the data from their latest tests, Polly noticed a strange pattern in the readings. The fluctuations in the submersible's buoyancy seemed to be linked to an unexpected frequency in the water's temperature changes.

Polly quickly brought her findings to the attention of the team. "Guys, I think we've found something interesting. The buoyancy anomalies are linked to changes in water temperature. It's like the submersible is responding to thermal currents in the lake."

Reid leaned in, his eyes narrowing as he studied the data. "That could explain the fluctuations we've been seeing. If the submersible's buoyancy system is sensitive to temperature changes, it could explain why it's been acting up."

Olivia nodded, her analytical mind already working through the implications. "And if we can understand and predict these thermal currents, we might be able to stabilize the submersible more effectively. This could be a breakthrough for our testing."

Jim, always eager to contribute, added, "So, what do we do now? We need to figure out how to use this information to our advantage."

Ryan, who had been quietly observing, finally spoke up. "We need to conduct more tests, but this time, we focus on the thermal currents. We need to map out the temperature patterns in the lake and see how they affect the submersible's buoyancy."

Polly's eyes lit up with excitement. "That's a great idea, Captain. We can use the submersible to monitor the temperature changes in real-time and gather more data."

Reid nodded, his mind already racing with ideas. "And we should also consider using additional sensors to gather more detailed information. The more data we have, the better we can understand the thermal currents and how they interact with the submersible."

Olivia added, "We should also look into the submersible's buoyancy system and see if there's a way to adjust it to better handle these temperature changes. Maybe we can find a way to make it more resilient."

With their plan in place, the team set to work. They spent the next few days conducting extensive tests, mapping out the thermal currents in the lake and gathering as much data as possible. Each test was more challenging than the last, but the team was undeterred. They knew that the more they learned, the closer they would get to solving the mystery of the submersible's buoyancy issues.

As they continued their research, Polly couldn't help but feel a sense of pride. This was the kind of adventure she had been longing for, a challenge that tested their skills and pushed them to their limits. And despite the risks, she was more determined than ever to see it through.

The team worked tirelessly, their focus unwavering. They knew that the success of the submersible project hinged on their ability to overcome this new challenge. And as they gathered more data and made new discoveries, they felt increasingly confident that they were on the right path.

One evening, as they were reviewing their latest findings, Polly turned to her teammates and said, "We're getting closer. We just need to keep pushing forward, no matter what."

Reid nodded, a determined look on his face. "We won't stop until we find a solution."

Olivia smiled, her eyes filled with determination. "Together, we can do this."

Jim, ever the optimist, added, "And we'll have a blast doing it."

With their spirits high and their determination unwavering, the team was ready to face whatever challenges lay ahead. They knew that this journey was far from over, but they were confident that they had what it took to succeed. And as they prepared for their next round of tests, they felt a sense of excitement and anticipation. This was just the beginning, and they were ready to take on whatever came their way.

[Story]: -Simon


-Simon!

-SIMON!

I shook awake. I"d fallen asleep in class.. again. My teacher, Miss Lawrence, was looking at me with slight exasperation. Her red locks bobbed slightly as she shook her head left to right, sighing slightly she continued the lecture, talking about old engineering feats, underground tunnels and the sort. I heard a few snickers around me from my class-mates. It"s easy to take sleep for granted when you get plenty of it, a fact I"ve become very aware of the last two weeks.

-.. I want those assignments on my desk by Monday

She said

-And make sure you all get enough rest

She finished, with a pointed look at me. I took it in stride, it"s not like it"s my fault I hardly get any sleep..

-Hey, Simon!

Fred, school boxing star and all around good-guy, yelled behind me as I was getting my bag out of my locker.

-You gotta stop dozing off like that, you"re gonna get shit if it keeps up

-Yeah, yeah, I know..

-What"s up, anyways? You got a new girl you haven"t told me about, keeping you up at night?

He asked with a coy smile. I gave him a sly grin

-Nah man, that sounds like a good problem to have..

I scratched my neck and looked down at my feet

-It"s a bit embarrassing actually..

He looked looked slightly concerned

-What is? You know you can tell me anything, still haven"t told a soul about the-

He scanned the surroundings quickly, making sure no one was in earshot

-"undearwear incident" in second grade

He loved to bring up that example whenever he wanted to prove his reliability, which is unnecessary since it has never been in question during all the years I"ve known him.

-It"s night terrors

I said

-But it"s more than that. I think they"re over, but then they"re not.. I wake from a nightmare, drenched in sweat, heart racing, trying to calm myself down. Memories of the dream fading, and I see shadows out of the corner of my eye, moving away from me. I try and focus on them, and they fade into the background.

Fred looks quizzical for a moment, then he asks

-Is it like sleep paralysis? I"ve never had it, but I"ve heard some really freaky stories..

-Nah, it"s not that. I"ve had them a lot as a kid, you probably heard most of those stories from me.. No, this is different. I can move while its going on, and I don"t feel the dread I"ve come to associated with sleep paralysis. It"s freaky still, but in another way. I feel hollow whenever I wake up, like I"m missing something. It lasts all the way up to around lunch.

Even in the light of day, the topic was getting on my nerves. Fred seemed to sense I was uncomfortable with digging too deep into this at the moment

-Sounds rough

He said

-Nothing a bit of practice won"t solve. See you there?

He asked, slapping my arm

-You bet

I slapped his arm back

A few hours, and several bruises later, I was sitting out in my garden on the green grass, birds chirping in the background, late spring wind fanning my face and hair.

-Watcha" doing?

My annoying sister, Sarah, chirped up.

-Meditating. Same as yesterday. And the day before that.

She loved to find new ways to annoy me, currently it was asking questions she already knew the answer to, but that in itself isn"t good enough. She needs to know I know she knows the answer.

-Watcha" doing that for?

-To get away from you, scram!

I snapped at her, giving her an evil look.

She scrambled away, giggling all the way.

Meditation, I"d started doing it a while ago, when I was still fantasizing about the idea of becoming a pro-boxer, looking for any edge I could eek out in order to compete with Fred. It was supposed to increase focus in the ring. I bet it does wonders, but I gave up on it on too soon to figure. Now, now I"m doing it out of desperation. Maybe my night terrors were because of a worried mind? Meditation calms the mind, so maybe it"ll cure this problem?

I felt a buzz in my pocket, it"s a text from Alyssa in the group chat

-You guys ready?

She asked

-Shit is it now?!?

Fred responded

-I"ll bring snacks

Henri chimed in, always prepared for pretty much any situation, no matter how unlikely

-Yeah, usual spot in 15?

I typed

Alyssa, one year older than the rest of us, senior in highschool, had a bit of an obsession with the occult. Well, obsession is a bit harsh, but she"s fascinated by it, reading up on stuff, buying tarot cards, crystals and herbs used in different rituals. She found some fortune-teller/medium on craigslist, and she badgered the rest of us to join her on her expedition there.

Approximately 15 minutes later I approached the diner/convince store named Shop"N"Stop, Fred and Henri already waiting by the rundown, faded exterior of the place who couldn"t make its mind up about what it was. The shop is alright, got the necessities at a reasonable price, the diner on the other hand.. only one I know who haven"t been running to the toilet for a week after eating there is Alyssa, and it"s hardly fair to count her since she"s some kind of freak of nature when it comes to dodging sickness, and most bad things now that I think about it.

-Where"s our heroine, dragging us out at this ungodly hour to do God knows what, with forces and powers beyond our comprehension to witness, let alone understand?

I waxed poetically at the two in greeting. Henri chuckles and adjusts his glasses, while Fred smiles and looks behind me

-T"was three hours before midnight, sun"s last rays still sparkling. Hardly an ungodly hour

A playful voice behind me, coming closer, said. I turn around and see her, auburn hair playing lightly in the slight wind, eyes glimmering a greyish green in the afromentioned sun, set over the barely visible freckles dotting her nose and visible cheekbones.

Yeah, she"s a real looker, and I"m well aware of that. She"s the standard I judge other beauties by, and it"s anything but a fair standard. My feelings towards her is more like that of a sister, only she"s less annoying, knowing someone since kindergarten kinda does that. There"s days I"ve wondered, even fantasized about the two of us, once her blooming beauty was becoming apparent even to me. But I"d make it weird if I made a move, and she sees me as a brother as well, she"s said it in the past..

-Considering our mission this evening, anything after noon is an ungodly hour

Henri, the only staunch atheist and unbeliever in anything paranormal, intoned. Despite his scepticism, he"s the most easily scared of the bunch.

-Wouldn"t be you if you weren"t the last one here

I smiled at Alyssa

Fred came up to us and put his arms around our shoulders

-Alright birdies, let"s get a move on. I"ve got a pizza with my name on it at home. It"s very impatient, can"t wait to see the insides of my stomach

We got a move on, going towards the older parts of town, the Shop"N"Stop marking the end of the newer, better maintained parts of town.

Henri glanced around nervously

-So where"d you say you found this guy? Or woman? Or whatever?

He asked

-Woman

Alyssa responded, giving him a quick smile

-Found her on craigslist, she"s a bit expensive but I think it"s worth it. I"ve only tried cheap mediums so far, and the price really reflected the quality of their work

She huffed, looking slightly annoyed, then she turned to the group and beamed towards us

-Good thing I got you guys to share the fee with

Henri huffed incredulously

-You mean you got us to badger until we finally agree to do what you want?

Fred looked to Henri

-Hey, you let her talk you into this, no use complaining about it now

He said, not able to completely hide the slight tone of defeat in his own voice.

-I"m actually looking forward to this

I interjected

-Not that I believe this is anything but a scam, but I"d say it"s worth 25 bucks for one evenings worth of entertainment, I"m curious to figure out what kind of tricks she"ll use to try and trick us..

-Alright guys, that"s enough

Alyssa said, looking at us, brow slightly furrowed

-I want to do this with you, but if you"re going to crap all over it before you"ve even tried it you"re just gonna ruin it, for me, for you, for everyone. Just have an open mind

She looked at us pleadingly

-Alright

I looked at her

-The final reason I think this"ll be worth $50 of my own money, is that on the off chance that this is real, I"d pay that sum several times over

Alyssa"s entire being lit up as she smiled at me

-That"s the spirit, we"re almost there

-Simon

-zzt..fffzzZzz -static-

-SIMON

The scream echoed in my ears. My balance is off, the world is shaking. Fred is shaking me, looking me in the eyes.

-Where"d you go buddy?

He asked, looking me in the eyes intensely. I looked to Alyssa, worry written all over her face, rarely seen wrinkles making an appearance on her face, Henri alternating glances at me and the ground, fidgeting with something in his hands.

-I.. I don"t... There was something.. over there.

I said, pointing towards the side of an old, dilapidated house, overgrown weeds all over the lawn and house itself. The dizziness was starting to pass

-There was a shadow. Something moved, I got all dizzy.. It"s gone now.

Fred looked really worried now

-Shadow?

He asked

-It"s fine, just the sleep deprivation doing a number on me, I can handle it

-We can do this another time, if you need to go home and rest

Alyssa chimed in, worry still apparent on her face, she"d been looking forward to this for over a week, she"d always put her friends wellbeing above her own interest, I didn"t want to let her down

-It"s fine, I"m feeling much better already

-Here, take this

Henri reached out a hand with a piece of candy, meant to raise the blood sugar of those with diabetes, I bit down on it and smiled towards the group

-Good as new, let"s do this

They looked unconvinced, but agreed

-This is it

Alyssa said, looking at the very same dilapidated house

-Only one thing left to do then

I said with much more bravado than I felt, a sense of dread growing in me as I marched up towards the overgrown house..."

The group gathered in front of the old, dilapidated house, the air thick with anticipation and unease. Alyssa took a deep breath, her eyes scanning the surroundings one last time before stepping forward.

"This is the place," she said, her voice barely above a whisper. "I found the ad for her on craigslist last week. She said she could communicate with the dead, and I believed her."

Fred and Henri exchanged uneasy glances, while I clutched the candy in my hand, trying to steady my nerves. The overgrown weeds and the crumbling facade of the house only added to the eerie atmosphere.

"Alright, let"s do this," Fred said, trying to mask his apprehension with a confident smile. "Just remember, we're here for fun, and if things get too weird, we leave."

Alyssa knocked on the door, the sound echoing through the empty house. After a few moments, a creaking noise came from inside, and the door slowly opened to reveal a small, elderly woman with a kind face and twinkling eyes.

"Welcome, dear. I've been expecting you," she said, beckoning us inside. The inside of the house was just as old and dilapidated as the outside, but it was filled with an odd warmth that seemed to emanate from the walls.

We followed her into the living room, where she motioned for us to sit on the worn-out couches. Alyssa took out a small notebook and pen, ready to take notes of any messages she might receive.

The woman smiled warmly and began to speak. "I can sense your curiosity and your desire to connect with the other side. But remember, these things come with a price. You must be prepared to face the consequences."

She paused, her eyes glinting with a mysterious light. "Now, let's begin. Close your eyes and think of the person you wish to communicate with. They will come to you."

We all closed our eyes, trying to focus on the person we wanted to reach. I thought of my grandmother, who had passed away a few years ago. I remembered her warm smile and her love for gardening.

As I concentrated on her image, a sense of peace washed over me. I felt her presence, and for a moment, it was like she was right there with me. I could almost hear her voice, but it faded just as quickly as it appeared.

The rest of the group shared similar experiences, some more vivid than others. Alyssa wrote down every message and feeling she experienced, her face a mix of awe and confusion.

When we opened our eyes, the woman was still smiling, her eyes twinkling with satisfaction. "You have all done well tonight. Remember, the other side is always near, waiting for you to reach out."

As we left the house, I couldn't help but feel a sense of wonder and sadness. The experience had been both fascinating and unsettling. I still wasn't sure if it was real or not, but it had definitely left an impression on me.

When we got back home, the group gathered around to discuss the night's events. Alyssa shared her notes with us, and we all debated the validity of what we had experienced.

Fred was the first to speak. "I don't know if I believe in all that supernatural stuff, but I have to admit, it was pretty cool. Maybe there's something to it after all."

Henri, still skeptical, shook his head. "It was probably just a clever trick or a combination of suggestion and hypnosis. But I have to admit, it was entertaining."

I nodded in agreement. "I don't know if it was real or not, but it was definitely an experience I won't forget. And if it helps me with my night terrors, I'd say it was worth it."

As we all sat around, sharing our thoughts and feelings, I couldn't help but feel grateful for my friends. They had stuck with me through thick and thin, even when I was struggling with something as personal as my night terrors.

And maybe, just maybe, the night's events had given me a glimmer of hope that I could finally find some peace and relief from the haunting dreams that had been plaguing me for so long.

You should write a continuation of the following story.
[Story]: Once upon a time there was a young boy who had nothing. Truthfully, he had less than nothing. He lived in a small town full of werewolves, witches, and ghosts galore, but he was human, one of the Forsaken. To make matters worse, he was an orphan.


One particularly bad day, he had an idea. On the outskirts of town lived the vampires. And vampires take care of their own. They don't steal food or clothes like desperate orphans do. No, they keep each other well fed and comfortable. And the boy yearned for that.

So, later that night, when all the other orphans were asleep, he crept out of the orphanage and turned towards the hills outside of town. He knew in his gut that this would be his last night alone.

• • •

Once upon a time a vampire ruled atop a lonely throne. She was respected by many, but loved by few, and of those few she trusted even less. She knew the truth, you see. She knew that vampires are not kind, nor are they loyal. It's true that they guard each other from the outside, but they will turn on one another in a heartbeat. So she ruled with an iron fist, fearing that if she loosened her grip, she would lose everything.

This made certain aspects of her unlife hard. After all, she might not care that the blood tribute was a pint short, but if she didn't bring retribution, the others would challenge her power. And when less benign rulers came into power, more than a few pints of blood ran in the streets. Her strict rules made things hard for her at times. The day she discovered a Forsaken in her home was one of those times.

• • •

Celia strode down a hall lit by dim torches. Despite their flames, the hall leading down into the dungeon was cold. Fitting for a place of sorrow and despair. Even though it stayed empty in recent times, the last tenant of the manor used the dank basement liberally, and she suspected that angry ghosts remained nearby. She was only going there now because of a summons from her most loyal servant and friend, Johnny, who supposedly discovered a Forsaken One trying to break in.

She wiped auburn hair from her face and straightened her black dress, then went around a corner into a side room where Johnny was waiting for her. The old man was wiry, and wore a suit that at one time would have been very nice, but time had not been kind to him or the suit.

"Ah, Miss Celia, thank you for coming. Here is the Forsaken One that I caught sneaking into the courtyard. He claims he's here to see you."

Celia looked at the small, skinny boy, tied to a chair. His mouth was pressed into a thin line and his eyes looked nearly feral.

Celia knelt down so she was eye level with the boy. "Untie him. This is no way to treat a guest."

"But, Miss, we still don't know why he was sneaking in, and -"

"He is a child, Johnny. Don't make me ask again."

"Yes, of course."

"Let's cut to the chase, why are you here?" asked Celia.

The boy looked into her blood red eyes for a moment, then fearfully looked away. "I w-want to be-become a vampire."

Celia was taken aback. Sure, some people wanted the life of a vampire, but they were few and far between. None of them had ever been so young.

"Tell me, boy, how old are you?"

The boy looked puzzled. "Thirteen. Why?"

"A thirteen year old boy breaks into my home and says he wants to be a vampire. That's a first. It's also a good way to get yourself killed. Be glad that Johnny found you. A lesser vampire would have drained you there and then."

The boy gulped. "Well, will you make me a vampire?"

"No!" exclaimed Johnny. "Vampirism isn't a jacket you can take on and off whenever you feel like it! It's a curse that you have to live with forever. To turn you at thirteen years old would be cruel! You should have more sense than to ask for this."

Celia examined the boy closer. His clothes were raggedy and patched. Bruises covered just about every surface of his body. As soon as Johnny rose his voice, the boy winced.

Celia lowered her voice to just above a whisper. "Tell me, why do you want to be a vampire?"

The boy rubbed his wrists. "I thought if I became a vampire you might take care of me, then I wouldn't have to go back to the orphanage."

"Why don't you tell me about the orphanage," prompted Celia.

"I don't like it there. Helga is mean to us. She doesn't give us much food, and then the other kids steal mine because they're hungry too. She makes us work all day, and if we don't do enough, she makes us sleep in the floor."

"Do you have a name, boy?" asked Johnny.

The boy nodded. "My name is Cur. Or at least, that's what people call me. Helga says that's my name because no one would ever want me."

She felt for the boy, but years of hardening herself kept any emotions from showing through. "Let me tell you a story, Cur. A long time ago, a young girl lived happily with her family. They lived in fear because they were Forsaken, but she didn't understand that. She was happy.

"One day, a visitor came. What she didn't know was that every month her parents paid a 'protection tax' to the vampire lord. They didn't pay in time, so he came to visit. The little girl, hiding in a closet, heard the sounds of her parents dying. Then he found her.

"He told her that her family broke the rules, and that meant they had to pay the price, even her. She had two options. Become a servant in his house, or die."

Cur was shaking now, and spoke with barely a whisper. "What did she choose?"

Celia leaned in close. "I chose to live."

She backed away, then drew a dagger that was hidden away in her clothes. She held it to Cur's throat, and a small trickle of blood came out.

"You broke the rules, Cur, and everyone must pay the price. Even orphans. So I'll give you the same choice that was given to me. Stay here, in my house, and be my servant, or I'll give you a swift death. It's up to you."

It was the only option. She couldn't let him go, or she would look weak, and weak vampires don't survive. But she knew by the fire in his eyes that this boy would never choose death.

Cur looked at the blood pooling on the gleaming blade. "If I stay here, you won't send me back to the orphanage, right?"

"That's right."

"Then I'll stay. I'll do whatever you want, whenever you want. I swear I'll make you proud."

Celia withdrew the blade. She wiped the blade clean, then stowed it away. Then she turned away, but stopped at the door.

"Johnny, show him to the servant's quarters and get him something to eat. Oh, and Cur, you need to know something."

Cur mindlessly held the cut on his neck, but looked up to Celia expectantly.

"A cur tends to be unwanted, but they are stronger because of it. And they don't hesitate to lash out at anything causing them pain. Make your name a strength, and no one can use it against you."

• • •

Once upon a time there was a wicked woman who ran an orphanage. She was cruel and heartless, and all the kids feared her. One night, a little fiend of a child ran away, but she didn't care about him. She was just angry that one of her little workers had disappeared.

That night, the child rested easy. He had a bed all to himself, and a hot meal made it even better. And while he was dreaming, the wicked woman had an unexpected visitor.

No one knows exactly what happened to her that night. Some say she was paid well to leave town. Others say she had a secret lover and the two of them eloped. But the people on the edge of town have a different theory. For they heard the screams that night, and they found what was left the next morning. But the exact story matters not, for the wicked woman was never seen again."
