### The Boy's Resolve

Cur's heart pounded as he listened to Celia's story. He could hardly believe his ears. The thought of being a servant in a vampire's house was terrifying, but it was a small price to pay for a chance at survival. He had been through so much pain and suffering, and the idea of being under Celia's protection was a beacon of hope in his dark world.

As the boy's eyes met Celia's, he saw a mix of cold determination and something else, something softer, hidden beneath the surface. It was a rare moment of vulnerability, and Cur knew he had to seize it. "I'll stay," he said, his voice steady despite the quiver in his legs. "I'll do whatever you want. I'll make you proud."

Celia studied him for a moment, her eyes narrowing slightly. She had expected fear, but what she saw was resolve. It was a rare quality in a child his age, and it intrigued her. "Very well, Cur," she said finally, her voice as cold as the stone floor beneath them. "But understand this: you will obey my every command without question. There is no room for rebellion here. You will be my servant, and that is all."

Cur nodded, his expression resolute. He knew the risks, but he also knew that this was his only chance. "I understand," he replied, his voice firm. "I'll do whatever it takes to survive."

Celia rose from her kneeling position and turned to Johnny. "Johnny, see to it that he's taken to the servant's quarters. Make sure he gets something to eat. And tell him the rules of this house. He must know exactly what he's gotten himself into."

Johnny nodded, his face a mask of seriousness. "Yes, Miss Celia. I'll make sure he understands."

Cur watched as Johnny untied him and led him out of the room, his heart heavy with the weight of his new reality. But as he followed Johnny down the dimly lit corridor, he couldn't help but feel a spark of hope. For the first time in his life, he had a chance to control his own fate, and he intended to take it.

As he walked through the grand halls of Celia's manor, he couldn't help but marvel at the opulence around him. It was a stark contrast to the squalor of the orphanage, and it filled him with a sense of both awe and trepidation. He knew that this new life would come with its own set of challenges, but he was ready to face them head-on. After all, he had survived worse.

### A New Reality

Cur was led to a small, sparsely furnished room that served as the servant's quarters. The room was modest, with a simple wooden bed, a small table, and a few shelves filled with basic items. Johnny explained the rules of Celia's household in a stern voice, his words cutting through the boy's initial sense of awe.

"Cur, you will rise at dawn and perform your duties without complaint. You will clean the halls, tend to the needs of the vampires, and follow every command without question. Failure to do so will result in punishment, and repeated disobedience will be met with severe consequences."

Cur nodded, absorbing every word. He knew that obedience was essential for survival here. "I understand," he said, his voice steady. "I'll do my best."

Johnny offered a curt nod before leaving the room. Cur sat on the edge of his bed, his mind racing. The contrast between the life he had known and the one he was about to embark on was stark. The orphanage had been a place of hunger, fear, and relentless labor, but this new life, while uncertain, held the promise of protection and perhaps even a chance for a better future.

That night, as Cur lay on the hard bed, he made a silent vow to himself. He would adapt, he would endure, and he would make the most of his situation. The fear of the unknown was overwhelming, but it was also a driving force that pushed him forward. He was no longer just a vulnerable orphan; he was a survivor, and he intended to use that strength to carve out a place for himself in this new world.

The days passed in a blur of chores and tasks. Cur quickly learned the layout of the manor, memorizing the locations of every room and the schedules of the vampires who lived there. He became adept at cleaning, cooking, and even performing minor medical tasks, earning a grudging respect from Johnny, who was tasked with overseeing his training.

Despite the grueling work, Cur found moments of solace in the manor's quiet corners. He would sometimes steal a few moments to sit by the fireplace, the warm flames casting a comforting glow. In those moments, he would think about his mother and father, the family he had lost, and the hope that perhaps, just perhaps, he could find a semblance of happiness here.

Yet, the weight of his new reality never fully lifted. Every command, every demand, served as a constant reminder of his status as a servant. He was not a free agent but a pawn in Celia's game, and the fear of losing his newfound stability kept him grounded. He knew that one misstep could lead to punishment, and he was determined not to make that mistake.

In the depths of his heart, Cur held onto a small flame of hope. He dreamed of a future where he could rise above his circumstances, where he would be more than just a servant. And as he toiled in the shadows of Celia's manor, he silently vowed to make that dream a reality, no matter the cost.

### A Glimpse of the Dark World

One evening, as Cur was tending to the needs of the vampires in the great hall, he overheard a conversation between two of the house's elder vampires. Their voices were hushed, but the words were clear enough for Cur to catch the essence of their discussion.

"Did you hear about the new servant?" one vampire asked, a hint of amusement in their voice.

"The one the master brought in?" the other vampire replied. "Yes, I heard. He's quite the story. An orphan, found sneaking into the courtyard, asking to be turned into a vampire."

Cur's ears perked up at this. He had never heard of anyone so audacious, let alone successful, in their request. "Turned into a vampire?" he thought to himself. "What does that mean?"

As they continued their conversation, Cur learned more about the world he had entered. The vampires spoke of the rituals, the blood sacrifices, and the power that came with being one of them. They mentioned the trials and the transformations that awaited those who sought to join their ranks.

"One would think it's a foolish request, but the boy has spirit," the first vampire said. "It's rare to find someone willing to undergo such a drastic change at such a young age."

The second vampire chuckled. "Spirit is good, but it's not enough. Turning someone requires more than just a desire; it requires power, and we don't have the time or resources for such a risky endeavor."

Cur's heart raced as he listened. He had never imagined that becoming a vampire was such a complex and dangerous process. The idea that he might have to go through something similar filled him with both fear and determination. If he was going to survive and thrive here, he needed to understand more about the world he had entered.

That night, as he lay in his small quarters, Cur's mind was filled with questions. What did it mean to be a vampire? What were the rules and rituals they spoke of? And most importantly, how could he navigate this world without losing himself in the process?

Cur knew that he had to learn more, and he knew that he had to be careful. The vampires around him were powerful, and he was just a servant, a lowly pawn in their game. But he also knew that knowledge was power, and the more he understood, the better equipped he would be to survive and perhaps even thrive in this dark world.

As he drifted off to sleep, Cur made a silent promise to himself. He would learn everything he could about the vampires, their ways, and their secrets. And with that knowledge, he would find a way to make his own path in this new life, no matter how treacherous it might be.

### The Weight of the World

Cur's days grew busier as he continued to learn the ins and outs of Celia's household. The workload was relentless, but he found solace in the routine. It gave him a sense of purpose and a way to focus his mind on something other than his past or the uncertainties of his future. Yet, the weight of his new reality never truly lifted.

One evening, as he was cleaning the great hall, Cur noticed a small, worn book tucked away in a corner. His curiosity piqued, he quietly retrieved it and brought it to his room. He knew that reading was a dangerous endeavor for a servant, but he was desperate for knowledge. As he leafed through the pages, he discovered it was an old tome on vampire lore and rituals.

His heart raced as he read about the different ceremonies and the significance of each step in the transformation process. He learned about the blood sacrifices, the rituals of passage, and the trials that awaited those who sought to become vampires. The more he read, the more he realized just how profound a change he had requested, and the more he feared that he might not be prepared for what lay ahead.

That night, as he lay in his small bed, the weight of his decision pressed heavily upon him. He had left the orphanage in search of a better life, but had he truly understood the cost of that life? The idea of becoming a vampire was more terrifying than he had ever imagined, and he wondered if he had made a mistake.

As he stared at the ceiling, his mind raced with questions. What if he couldn't handle the pain of the transformation? What if he lost himself in the process? And most importantly, what if he couldn't live up to the expectations of the vampires who now held his fate in their hands?

Tears welled up in his eyes as he clutched the book to his chest. He had taken a great risk, and now he was left to face the consequences alone. He felt a deep sense of loneliness, as if the weight of the world had finally pressed down upon his shoulders.

But as he sat there in the dark, feeling the weight of his fears, he also felt a flicker of determination. He had come this far, and he couldn't let his doubts and fears define him. He had to find a way to make this work, to survive and perhaps even thrive in this new life.

With a deep breath, Cur closed the book and set it aside. He knew that he couldn't change his decision now, and he couldn't afford to let his fears control him. He had to face his challenges head-on, no matter how daunting they might seem.

As he lay back down, he made a silent vow to himself. He would learn everything he could, adapt to his new circumstances, and find a way to make his place in this dark world. And with that resolve, he finally drifted off to sleep, ready to face whatever tomorrow might bring.

### The Turning Point

Cur's life at Celia's manor continued in much the same rhythm, with the grueling tasks and the ever-present fear of punishment. But one evening, an unexpected event changed the course of his existence forever. As he was tending to the needs of one of the elder vampires, he overheard a hushed conversation between Celia and Johnny.

"Johnny, I've been thinking," Celia said, her voice low and measured. "Cur has proven himself to be more resilient than I expected. He's shown a level of determination and intelligence that's rare for a servant, let alone a Forsaken One."

Johnny nodded, his expression contemplative. "Yes, Miss Celia. He's adapted well to his duties and has even managed to earn a small measure of respect from the others. But turning him into a vampire... that's still a risk."

Celia's eyes gleamed with a mixture of determination and cunning. "I agree. But what if we took a different approach? Instead of turning him, what if we gave him a chance to prove himself? A trial of sorts, to demonstrate his worthiness."

Johnny raised an eyebrow, intrigued. "A trial, you say? And what would this trial entail?"

"Simple," Celia replied with a smirk. "He will be given a task that only a vampire could accomplish. If he succeeds, we'll know he has the potential to become one of us. If he fails, well, he'll be no worse off than he is now."

Johnny's eyes widened slightly. "And what task might that be?"

Celia's lips curled into a sinister smile. "I have a special request from a vampire lord in a neighboring town. He seeks a rare and powerful artifact, one that could tip the balance of power in our favor. The problem is, the artifact is hidden in a fortress guarded by a fearsome beast. I believe Cur has the potential to be the one to retrieve it."

Johnny's eyes narrowed in thought. "A beast in a fortress? That's a dangerous mission, even for a vampire."

"True," Celia conceded, "but Cur isn't a vampire yet. This will be his chance to prove his worth. If he succeeds, he'll earn the respect of the entire household and prove his potential as a vampire. If he fails... well, he'll still be here, serving us in whatever capacity he's capable of."

Johnny considered the proposal for a moment before nodding. "Very well, Miss Celia. I'll inform Cur of the task. But I must warn you, this is a significant risk. If he fails, he could be killed."

Celia shrugged, her expression cold and unyielding. "That's the nature of the game, Johnny. We don't get everything we want without paying a price. If he succeeds, we'll have a powerful new ally. If he fails, we'll have no regrets."

With the plan set in motion, Johnny found Cur and delivered the news. Cur's heart raced at the prospect of such a dangerous mission, but also at the possibility of proving himself. He knew the risks were high, but the chance to prove his worth and perhaps earn his place as a vampire was too great to pass up.

As he prepared for the mission, Cur's mind was a whirlwind of thoughts and emotions. He had come a long way from the orphanage, and this was his chance to turn his life around. With a deep breath, he steeled himself for the challenges ahead, determined to seize this opportunity and make his name a strength in the world of the undead.

### The Mission Begins

The dawn broke with an eerie silence, casting long shadows over the manor as Cur prepared for his perilous journey. He had spent the night gathering supplies and planning every detail of his mission, his mind a whirlwind of thoughts and fears. The artifact Celia sought was said to be hidden in the heart of a fortress, guarded by a beast of legendary strength and cunning. The journey ahead would be fraught with danger at every turn, but Cur knew he had to succeed. His fate now hung in the balance.

Johnny handed Cur a small satchel filled with provisions, a dagger, and a map of the surrounding territory. "Remember, Cur," Johnny warned, his voice low and serious. "This mission is crucial. Failure is not an option."

Cur nodded, his resolve unwavering. "I understand, Johnny. I won't let you down."

With a final nod of approval, Johnny watched as Cur left the manor, heading into the unknown. The road to the fortress was treacherous, winding through dense forests and rugged terrain. Cur's heart pounded with each step, his mind a mix of anticipation and fear.

As he ventured deeper into the forest, Cur encountered his first obstacle: a river swollen with recent rains. The water roared, its current strong and unforgiving. He considered crossing, but the risk was too great. Instead, he followed the river's path, hoping to find a safer crossing point.

Hours passed, and the forest grew darker and more ominous. The trees seemed to close in around him, their gnarled branches reaching out like twisted fingers. Cur's nerves were on edge, and he could feel the eyes of the forest watching him. He knew he had to stay alert, for danger could lurk anywhere.

Eventually, he found a narrow path that led him to a shallow part of the river. Carefully, he waded through the murky water, his boots sinking into the cold, muddy bottom. The current tugged at him, trying to pull him under, but Cur held his ground, his determination fueling his every step.

Emerging on the other side, Cur took a moment to catch his breath. He knew the hardest part of the journey was still ahead. The fortress loomed in the distance, a dark, imposing structure that seemed to blend into the shadows of the forest. He could feel the weight of its presence, a constant reminder of the dangers that lay within.

As he approached the fortress, Cur noticed the guards patrolling the outer walls. They were formidable, their eyes sharp and their weapons ready. He knew he couldn't confront them directly; he would have to find another way inside. Using the map Johnny had given him, Cur began to scout for weaknesses in the fortress's defenses.

After hours of careful observation, Cur discovered a small, hidden entrance near the base of the fortress wall. It was barely wide enough for a person to squeeze through, but it offered a chance to avoid the guards altogether. With a deep breath, Cur slipped through the narrow opening, his heart pounding in his chest.

Inside the fortress, the air was thick with tension. The walls were lined with weapons and armor, and the scent of blood hung in the air. Cur's eyes darted around, searching for any sign of the beast that guarded the artifact. His heart raced as he realized just how close he was to his goal.

He navigated through the labyrinthine corridors, each step taking him deeper into the heart of the fortress. The darkness was almost palpable, and Cur could feel the eyes of the beast watching him from the shadows. He knew he had to be careful, for one wrong move could be fatal.

Finally, he reached a large chamber at the center of the fortress. The artifact was there, resting on a pedestal in the middle of the room. But as he moved closer, he noticed the beast lying in wait, its eyes glowing with a fierce, malevolent light.

Cur knew he had to be swift and silent. He reached for the artifact, but the beast sprang to its feet, its roar shaking the very walls of the chamber. The fight had begun, and Cur had to be ready for anything.

### The Clash with the Beast

The beast's roar reverberated through the fortress, shaking Cur's resolve. He tightened his grip on the dagger Johnny had given him and took a deep breath, preparing for the fight of his life. The creature before him was massive, its scales glinting in the dim light of the chamber. Its eyes burned with a fierce, otherworldly glow, and its claws were sharp enough to rend flesh from bone.

Cur knew he had to be cunning as well as brave. He circled the beast, looking for any weakness. The creature moved with a speed and agility that belied its size, but Cur had studied its movements and knew where to strike. He aimed for its joints, where the scales met, hoping to slow it down.

The beast roared again, lunging at Cur with a speed that seemed almost supernatural. Cur dodged its massive claws, feeling the rush of air as they narrowly missed his face. He parried the next attack with the dagger, the blade ringing against the beast's scales. The impact sent a shockwave through his arm, but he held on.

The creature struck again, this time bringing its massive tail down with a force that could have leveled a building. Cur jumped to the side, narrowly avoiding the deadly swipe. He knew he had to keep it moving, to keep it from finding its footing.

As the fight continued, Cur began to see patterns in the beast's attacks. It would strike with its claws, then follow up with a powerful tail swing, but it would pause for a moment after each attack, giving Cur a brief window of opportunity. He used those moments to his advantage, landing a few well-placed strikes on the beast's joints.

But the creature was relentless, its attacks growing more ferocious with each passing moment. Cur's dagger began to show signs of wear, the blade growing dull from the countless strikes against the beast's scales. He knew he had to be more strategic, to use his environment to his advantage.

He spotted a large boulder near the edge of the chamber and quickly made his way toward it. With a swift movement, he pushed the boulder into the creature's path, creating a temporary barrier. The beast roared in frustration, its tail slamming into the boulder with a force that sent shockwaves through the chamber.

Cur took the opportunity to close the distance between himself and the beast, delivering a series of rapid strikes to its joints. The creature howled in pain, its movements becoming sluggish. Cur knew he had to finish this quickly, before the beast regained its strength.

With one final, desperate push, Cur managed to land a decisive blow to the beast's weak spot, the joint at the base of its tail. The creature let out a final, piercing scream before collapsing to the ground, its movements growing sluggish and then ceasing altogether.

Cur stood there, panting and covered in sweat, his heart pounding in his chest. He had done it. He had defeated the beast and retrieved the artifact. But as he reached for the artifact, a new danger loomed in the shadows.

From the darkness stepped a figure cloaked in darkness, its eyes glowing with a malevolent light. It was another vampire, one who had been guarding the beast. Cur knew he had to be ready for anything. He tightened his grip on the dagger and prepared for the fight of his life.

### The Final Battle

Cur's heart pounded as he faced the new adversary, the figure's presence emanating a chilling aura of power. The vampire's eyes locked onto Cur, and a sinister smile curled its lips. "You've done well, child," it said in a voice like gravel. "But your victory is short-lived."

Without warning, the vampire lunged at Cur, its speed astonishing. Cur barely had time to react, dodging the first attack and parrying the next with the dagger. The blade clanged against the vampire's claws, but Cur could feel the strain on his arm. He knew he had to be faster, more cunning.

The vampire continued its assault, each strike a deadly combination of speed and precision. Cur's mind raced, searching for any advantage. He noticed a crack in the stone wall near the vampire's left hand and saw his chance. He feigned a weak defense, luring the vampire into overextending its reach.

As the vampire's hand swung wide, Cur darted forward, seizing its wrist with both hands. He used all his strength to pull the vampire towards the crack in the wall. The vampire roared in surprise and anger, its claws slashing through the air. But Cur held on, using the momentum to force the vampire into the narrow gap.

The vampire struggled, its claws finding no hold in the stone. With a final, desperate effort, Cur pushed the vampire into the crack and sealed it shut. The vampire's struggles ceased, and silence filled the chamber once more.

Cur collapsed to the ground, his body shaking from the exertion. He had done it. He had defeated the vampire and completed his mission. But as he caught his breath, a new fear began to take root. The vampire had been guarding the beast, and if there were others like it, he was still far from safe.

Cur quickly gathered the artifact and made his way back through the fortress, his senses on high alert. He knew he had to be cautious, for the enemy could be lying in wait at any turn. As he reached the hidden entrance and slipped back into the forest, he felt a wave of relief wash over him. He had survived, and now he had to make it back to Celia.

The journey back was fraught with danger, but Cur pressed on, driven by a mix of determination and fear. He knew that Celia expected success, and he couldn't afford to fail. As he finally reached the manor, he saw Celia standing at the entrance, her eyes narrowed in anticipation.

Cur's heart raced as he approached. He had done it. He had retrieved the artifact and faced the beast and its guardian. But as he held the artifact up, Celia's expression didn't change. Instead, her eyes narrowed even further, and a cold smile spread across her lips.

"Good," she said, her voice like ice. "You've proven your worth. But this is only the beginning. There's much more to come."

Cur's heart sank, but he knew he had to keep going. He had taken the first step, and now he had to face whatever challenges lay ahead. With a deep breath, he steeled himself for the trials that awaited him, determined to make his place in the world of the undead.

### The Price of Victory

As Cur handed the artifact to Celia, his heart pounded with a mix of triumph and trepidation. The journey had been more dangerous than he could have ever imagined, and he had faced horrors that would haunt him for the rest of his days. But he had succeeded, and the weight of his victory was a small comfort against the overwhelming sense of dread that now settled over him.

Celia examined the artifact with a critical eye, her expression inscrutable. "You've done well, Cur," she finally said, her voice a cold, measured tone. "But this was just the beginning. There's much more to come."

Cur's stomach churned at her words. He had expected praise, perhaps even a reward. But instead, he felt a deep sense of foreboding. Celia was a master of manipulation, and he knew she wouldn't rest until she had him exactly where she wanted him.

"Tell me," Celia continued, her eyes locking onto his with an intensity that made him shiver. "What have you learned about the world of the undead?"

Cur hesitated, his mind racing. He had learned a lot during his mission, but he didn't want to reveal too much. "I've learned that it's a dangerous place," he said carefully. "And that there are many who would see me fail."

Celia's smile grew colder. "True, but it's also a place where strength can be found. You've shown resilience and courage, but you must continue to grow if you wish to survive."

Cur nodded, though he wasn't sure what she expected from him. He knew that he had to prove himself again and again, and he was prepared to do whatever it took. But the fear of what lay ahead was a constant shadow, one that he couldn't shake.

Celia's gaze softened slightly, and she reached out to touch his shoulder. "You have potential, Cur. But remember, in this world, potential alone isn't enough. You must be willing to pay the price."

Cur felt a chill run down his spine at her words. He knew that the price of his survival would be high, and he wasn't sure if he was ready to pay it. But he also knew that he had no other choice. He had to continue forward, no matter the cost.

As Celia turned away, her voice faded into the distance, but her words echoed in Cur's mind. He knew that his journey was far from over, and that the challenges ahead would be even greater. But he also knew that he had to face them, for his survival—and perhaps even his redemption—depended on it.

### A New Dawn

The days that followed were a whirlwind of training, trials, and relentless toil for Cur. Celia's expectations were high, and the demands of her tasks seemed never-ending. But Cur met each challenge head-on, his resolve growing stronger with each passing day. He knew that proving his worth was crucial, and he was determined to earn the respect and protection he so desperately needed.

As he toiled in the shadows of Celia's manor, Cur's skills and knowledge began to deepen. He learned the intricacies of vampire society, the secrets of their rituals, and the art of surviving in a world where every shadow held a potential threat. He was no longer just a servant; he was becoming a valuable asset to Celia, and he could feel his status rising within the household.

One evening, as Cur was tending to Celia's needs, she called him to her side. Her expression was soft, a rare sight for someone as formidable as she. "Cur," she began, her voice gentle yet firm. "You've come a long way. You've proven your worth, and I believe you have the potential to become something more."

Cur's heart raced at her words. He had worked tirelessly to earn her approval, and now it seemed he was on the cusp of something great. "What do you mean, Miss Celia?" he asked, his voice trembling with hope.

Celia's eyes locked onto his, and she leaned in close. "I've been considering your request," she said softly. "And I've decided that it's time for you to take the next step. You will be transformed into a vampire, not as a servant, but as an equal."

Cur felt as if the world had stopped spinning. The words hung in the air, a dream that seemed too good to be true. "Are you serious?" he asked, his voice barely a whisper.

Celia nodded, her expression unwavering. "Yes, Cur. You have shown me that you are worthy of this transformation. You will undergo the rites and trials, and when you emerge, you will be a vampire, one of us."

Tears welled up in Cur's eyes as he absorbed her words. He had faced so much pain and hardship, and now he was being given a chance at a new life. "Thank you, Miss Celia," he said, his voice breaking with emotion. "I won't let you down."

Celia's lips curved into a rare smile. "I know you won't, Cur. You have shown me that you have the strength and resilience to face whatever comes your way. Welcome to a new beginning."

As the transformation rituals were prepared, Cur felt a mixture of excitement and trepidation. He knew that becoming a vampire would change him forever, but he was ready for the change. He had faced darkness and emerged stronger, and he believed that this new chapter of his life would be one of hope and possibility.

In the days that followed, Cur's transformation was a profound and painful process. He endured the rites and trials with courage and determination, emerging on the other side as a vampire, his new life filled with both challenges and opportunities.

And so, once upon a time, there was a young boy who had nothing, but through resilience and courage, he found a new path. He became a vampire, not as a servant, but as an equal, ready to face the world with newfound strength and hope.

[Story]: Jogon sat alone in his dimly lit office, immersed in the gentle hum of his data console and the incandescent glow of holographic projections. Images and reports of a peculiar species, known to the Conglomeration of Orthonex Civilizations as Homo Sapiens, flickered across the room. They had officially been a part of the galactic community for barely fifty cycles.


Jogon, recently assigned to their sector, had spent the equivalent of several human years studying them - observing their behavior, assessing their cultural and technological advancements, and - more often than not - grappling with their irrationalities. He marveled at the complexity and sheer audacity of this species, his mandibles chittering in consternation as he mulled over their latest reports.

The Orthonex was currently on the brink of a dire war with the Vorlaxath Hive, a terrifying swarm-like species known for its relentless and insatiable hunger for planetary resources. The Hive was encroaching upon the peaceful territories of the Orthonex, and it was time to call upon all member species to contribute to the defense of the federation.

However, Jogon was about to make a highly controversial recommendation. Staring at his console, he tapped his segmented fingers on the metallic surface, shaping his argument carefully. He was of the belief, one he was about to share with the federation"s military committee, that the humans should not be invited to partake in this war.

"This is a species," he began, recording his statement, "that"s wild and reckless beyond any precedent we"ve previously encountered." He selected a video clip from his database and broadcast it for his audience to see. The clip showed humans "space skiing," an activity where an individual, wearing nothing but a thin suit, was tethered to a spaceship and then dragged through open space at alarming speeds.

Jogon continued, "This reckless act of thrill-seeking, an activity that endangers their lives for mere entertainment, is only one example of their unhinged behavior. Their tendencies for warfare are similar. They are unpredictable, their actions often driven by passion and impulse rather than logic and strategy."

He paused, pondering over his next words, "Their unpredictable nature is a risk we cannot afford to take. If we are to prevail against the Vorlaxath Hive, we need allies we can depend on, not wild cards that could just as easily implode our plans as help execute them."

Closing his arguments, Jogon sent off his recommendation to the committee. He was confident his points were valid, but he was also aware of the Orthonex"s egalitarian principle - every civilization must get a chance to defend the federation. Whether the committee agreed with him or not, one thing was certain - dealing with humans was like playing a game of Xuridian roulette, a game Jogon wasn"t sure they could afford to play.

The Overseers, the ruling council of the Conglomeration of Orthonex Civilizations, convened in their grand hall, a testament to the cooperation and technological prowess of countless star systems. Each Overseer, an emissary of their species, sat encased in individual chambers adapted to their unique biological needs. All attention was on the holographic representation of Jogon, his image flickering amidst them, his report a topic of heated discussion.

Councillor Dremik, a towering silicon-based entity from the rocky world of Qarn, projected a resonating rumble, the universal translator articulating his thoughts. "The humans... they exhibit a peculiar inclination towards danger... almost embracing it. Can we trust them in such a critical situation?"

Contrasting this, Pallaxia, a cloud-like sentience from the nebulous realm of Ethereal Mists, offered a differing viewpoint. "Their fearlessness may be a valuable asset against the Vorlaxath Hive. Do we not value courage in the face of danger? Moreover, our laws are clear; we cannot deny them the opportunity to defend their place in the Orthonex."

"Their war technology is not to be overlooked," murmured Vesto, a telepathic mollusk-like creature from the ocean world of Tydalus, his thoughts pulsating through the council members. "The humans seem particularly adept at it."

The debate raged on, with points made in favor and against the involvement of humans. Ultimately, Jogon"s cautionary tales of human recklessness fell on respectful but unwavering minds. In the spirit of equality and a fair chance, the council decided to extend the call-to-arms to humanity.

An official communique was drafted, a formal request outlining the dire situation and pleading for any military assistance the humans could provide against the Vorlaxath Hive. The document was heavily reviewed, ensuring it was appropriately translated and devoid of any potential miscommunication.

As the communique was dispatched to the humans, Jogon, despite his initial reservations, felt a strange curiosity. Humans were wildly unpredictable, and if their historical data was any indicator, their response to the call-to-arms would be anything but conventional. Even as the council adjourned, one sentiment echoed through the hall: Only time would tell whether they had made a strategic ally or invited further chaos into their well-structured universe.

A solar cycle passed before a response was received from the humans. The Conglomeration of Orthonex Civilizations, with its various species nervously watching, readied its armada against the approaching Vorlaxath Hive. News of the human response reached Jogon"s desk, a mere line of text that belied the monumental nature of its message. The humans had dispatched a single ship in response to the call-to-arms. A single ship? Jogon felt his mandibles tense as he considered the implications.

As the overseers gathered once more to discuss this development, the massive view screen at the council chamber"s front displayed the human ship in question. Compared to the sprawling, intricate structures of the Orthonex fleet, the human vessel looked like a tiny speck of metallic dust. There was an air of incredulity amongst the council. Pallaxia was the first to break the silence, "Have the humans misunderstood our request?"

Vesto, on the other hand, was more thoughtful. "We should not underestimate them. Their technology advances at an unprecedented rate. They might surprise us yet."

A collective sense of anticipation filled the room as the human vessel made its appearance at the meeting coordinates. But something was off. I took a moment before anyone had even noticed their arrival and according to the calculations, the humans should have taken a couple more days to reach the location given their FTL technology. The Overseers exchanged puzzled glances. How did they get here so quickly and without anyone noticing?

One of the senior federation officers, Gavroche, from the highly advanced civilization of Luminary and debatably the most advanced civilization in FTL travel, expressed his disbelief, "It"s almost as if they...teleported. But that"s impossible." The humans were known to push the limits of technology, but instantaneous space travel was a frontier not even the most advanced civilizations in the Orthonex had crossed.

As the overseers grappled with this mystery, a communication request came through from the human ship. The council fell silent as the message was broadcasted. "We apologize for the delay," a human voice echoed in the council chamber, their tone surprisingly casual, "According to the rules we"re still customizing ourselves to, our presence is required on the battlefield. Otherwise, we would have just teleported the bomb."

Jogon felt his multi-faceted eyes widen, his antennae twitching anxiously. "Teleported the...bomb?" The council echoed, confusion and dread filling the room as the full implications of the human"s words hung in the air, a harbinger of a storm yet to come. In the following moments, time seemed to stretch and dilate, as though the universe itself was holding its breath.

The silence in the grand hall of the Conglomeration of Orthonex Civilizations was so profound that one could almost hear the pulsations of the distant stars."Yes," the human voice broke the silence once more, its tone starkly contrasting with the tension that had encapsulated the hall. "Our antimatter singularity bomb."Before the stunned council members could react, a blinding light blossomed on the massive viewscreen.

As they shielded their visual sensors from the radiant explosion, every conversation, every thought was dwarfed by the spectacle unfolding before them. The display struggled to compensate for the intense light before finally settling down to show the aftermath. And then, as the light receded, there was... nothing.

Just the emptiness of space where once a horde of Vorlaxath Hive ships had swarmed. In what seemed to be an instant, the dire threat to the Orthonex was obliterated, reduced to cosmic dust.The human ship was also gone, leaving no trace behind. No heat signature, no warp trail, just a void where it had once hovered. "Did they... Did they teleport away?" murmured a stunned Gavroche, disbelief audible in his voice.

"There was no engine engagement, no displacement. It"s as though they just... vanished."The council was left staring at the emptiness of space, their thoughts echoing Gavroche"s disbelief. The magnitude of what the humans had just demonstrated was difficult to grasp. They had not only displayed the capability to annihilate a vast fleet with a single bomb but also hinted at a form of travel that seemed to defy the known laws of physics.

Jogon felt a chill running down his exoskeleton, his antennae twitching in the charged atmosphere of the council chamber. His earlier reports about human recklessness and unpredictability suddenly seemed like a grave understatement.As shockwaves of realization swept through the Conglomeration, one question resonated across the galactic federation, a question that carried with it an undercurrent of fear and awe, "What exactly have we welcomed into our galactic community?""

### The Council's Reaction

The blinding light on the viewscreen was a stark reminder of the enormity of what had just transpired. The Conglomeration of Orthonex Civilizations had never witnessed such an event; their collective minds struggled to comprehend the implications. The silence in the grand hall was broken only by the faint hum of the chamber's advanced climate control systems, which now felt insufficient to alleviate the tension gripping the room.

Councillor Dremik, his usually calm demeanor now marred by visible distress, was the first to voice the collective confusion. "This... this defies logic. How could a single ship, with a single weapon, annihilate an entire fleet of the Vorlaxath Hive?" His resonating voice echoed, amplifying the uncertainty that permeated the hall.

Pallaxia, who had initially advocated for human inclusion, now looked visibly shaken. Her once serene form was now a cloud of swirling doubts. "This... this is beyond our understanding. If their technology is this advanced, what else do they possess that we have yet to see?"

Vesto, the telepathic mollusk from Tydalus, his thoughts still pulsating through the chamber, seemed to be grappling with a similar turmoil. "Their capabilities are... staggering. We underestimated them. What if they possess other weapons, other technologies that we are completely unaware of?"

The room fell into a heavy silence, each Overseer lost in their own reverie, trying to process the unprecedented event. Gavroche, the expert in FTL travel from Luminary, finally broke the silence, his voice tinged with a mix of disbelief and apprehension. "We need to understand their technology. We need to assess the full extent of their capabilities. This could change everything we know about the balance of power in the federation."

Jogon, observing the unfolding drama from his station, felt a deep sense of unease. His earlier concerns about human unpredictability now seemed trivial in comparison to the reality they faced. He could see the flicker of fear in the eyes of his fellow Overseers, a fear that mirrored his own. The humans had not only changed the battlefield but had also rewritten the rules of engagement in a way no one could have anticipated.

As the council members began to murmur amongst themselves, the gravity of the situation became even more apparent. The Conglomeration had always prided itself on its technological prowess and strategic acumen, but now it faced a reality that defied their deepest assumptions. The future of the federation, it seemed, was hanging in the balance, teetering on the edge of an unknown precipice.

### The Council's Decision

In the wake of this unprecedented event, the council convened in an emergency session, their previous debates now dwarfed by the sheer magnitude of what had transpired. The air was thick with tension and uncertainty as each Overseer struggled to process the implications of the humans' actions. The grand hall, typically a place of calm deliberation, now buzzed with a frenetic energy, as the Overseers exchanged hushed but urgent whispers.

Councillor Dremik, his silicon-based form tense and rigid, was the first to propose a course of action. "We must send an immediate delegation to the humans. We need to understand their technology, their intentions, and the full scope of their capabilities. This cannot be left unexplored." His resonating voice echoed through the chamber, drawing immediate support from several other Overseers.

Pallaxia, though still visibly shaken, nodded in agreement. "Agreed. Their display of power is undeniable. We must engage with them, not out of fear, but out of necessity. We need to ensure that they align with our values and our strategic goals."

Vesto, his thoughts still pulsating through the chamber, added his voice to the growing consensus. "We must also consider the possibility that their technology could be of immense benefit to us. If they can annihilate an entire fleet with a single weapon, imagine what they could achieve with collaboration."

The council members nodded, their collective minds now aligned on the need for immediate action. Gavroche, the expert in FTL travel, proposed a specific plan. "We should dispatch a fleet to intercept the human vessel. It's clear they have advanced capabilities, but we cannot afford to let them operate in secrecy. We need to establish diplomatic channels and secure an understanding of their intentions."

After much debate, the council reached a unanimous decision. A delegation, consisting of representatives from various Orthonex civilizations, would be dispatched to the human vessel. This mission was critical; the fate of the federation now rested on their ability to negotiate and understand the humans.

As the council members prepared to address their fleets and initiate the diplomatic mission, a sense of grim determination settled over the chamber. The Conglomeration had always prided itself on its unity and strategic foresight, but this new development tested those principles in ways they had never imagined. The humans had introduced an element of chaos that was both unpredictable and potentially transformative.

Jogon, watching the proceedings with a mixture of anxiety and curiosity, felt a renewed sense of purpose. The humans had shown that they were a force to be reckoned with, and it was now up to the Conglomeration to navigate this new reality and secure their place in the galactic community. The future was uncertain, but one thing was clear: the Conglomeration of Orthonex Civilizations was ready to face whatever challenges lay ahead.

### Diplomatic Encounter

The diplomatic delegation, a diverse assembly of Orthonex species, prepared for the momentous encounter with the humans. Each representative, encased in their individual chambers, brought unique insights and perspectives to the table. As the fleet approached the designated coordinates, the anticipation in the chamber was palpable. The humans' unprecedented display of power had left the Conglomeration both intrigued and wary, and the upcoming conversation would set the tone for future interactions.

The human vessel, now the center of attention, loomed large on the viewscreen. Its sleek design and unfamiliar technologies were a stark contrast to the intricate and ornate structures of the Orthonex fleet. The moment the communication link was established, a calm yet authoritative voice echoed through the chamber. "Greetings from the Earth Alliance. We are ready to discuss the terms of our engagement."

The lead representative of the Orthonex delegation, Councillor Zethran, a towering, reptilian entity from the arid world of Xerath, stepped forward. "We extend our gratitude for your timely intervention against the Vorlaxath Hive. Your capabilities have shown us a new frontier of technological advancement. We seek to understand the nature of your technology and establish a mutual alliance."

The human response was measured and deliberate. "We thank you for your words. Our intervention was driven by the shared goal of preserving the integrity of the galaxy. We understand the importance of unity against common threats. However, we must first address the matter of trust. Our technologies, while advanced, are also highly sensitive. We cannot risk them falling into the wrong hands."

The room fell silent, the humans' caution evident in their words. Councillor Dremik, from the rocky world of Qarn, interjected. "We understand your concerns. The Conglomeration is committed to the principles of mutual respect and cooperation. We assure you that our intentions are peaceful and our commitment to the federation's stability is unwavering."

The human representative, a tall, stoic figure with a visor that obscured their eyes, nodded. "We appreciate your assurance. But words alone cannot bridge the gap of mistrust. We propose a series of steps to build confidence between our civilizations. These include the establishment of a joint scientific exchange program, the sharing of technological blueprints under strict security protocols, and the deployment of joint military exercises to test our capabilities together."

The proposal was ambitious, and it left the Orthonex delegates both impressed and apprehensive. Pallaxia, from the nebulous realm of Ethereal Mists, voiced the collective sentiment. "Their proposal is both intriguing and challenging. It offers the potential for significant advancements, but it also requires a degree of vulnerability on our part. We must proceed with caution."

Vesto, the telepathic mollusk from Tydalus, added his perspective. "Their proposal aligns with our interests. If we can harness their technology while maintaining our autonomy, it could be a game-changer for the federation. But we must ensure that our values and principles are not compromised."

After much deliberation, the council reached a tentative agreement. The joint scientific exchange program would begin immediately, with a select group of Orthonex scientists and human counterparts working together to understand and develop new technologies. The sharing of blueprints would be limited to specific areas, with strict security measures in place to prevent any unauthorized access. Joint military exercises would also be scheduled, aimed at enhancing coordination and readiness against future threats.

As the initial terms of the agreement were established, a sense of cautious optimism began to take hold. The humans had proven their capabilities, and the Conglomeration was ready to explore the potential benefits of this newfound alliance. However, the road ahead was fraught with challenges, and the true extent of the collaboration would only be realized through time and mutual understanding.

Jogon, observing the proceedings, felt a mixture of relief and trepidation. The humans were unpredictable, and their technology was a double-edged sword. But as he looked around the chamber, he saw a shared determination among the Orthonex delegates. They were ready to face this new reality and navigate the complexities of this unprecedented alliance.

The future of the galaxy now hung in a delicate balance, poised between the promise of technological advancement and the uncertainty of human unpredictability. The Conglomeration of Orthonex Civilizations and the Earth Alliance were on the brink of a new chapter, one that would test the limits of their cooperation and redefine the boundaries of their shared universe.

### The New Reality

In the weeks that followed the diplomatic encounter, the Conglomeration of Orthonex Civilizations and the Earth Alliance embarked on a cautious yet ambitious journey toward mutual understanding and collaboration. The joint scientific exchange program began to take shape, with teams from both civilizations working tirelessly to bridge the vast technological gap between them. The initial meetings were marked by a blend of awe and skepticism, as each side sought to unravel the mysteries of the other's advancements.

The Orthonex, with their centuries of refined scientific knowledge and intricate technologies, brought a wealth of experience to the table. They shared insights into advanced materials, energy systems, and communication technologies that were unparalleled in human history. In return, the humans, with their audacious approach to innovation and their rapid technological growth, introduced the Orthonex to groundbreaking concepts such as quantum computing, artificial intelligence, and advanced propulsion systems.

This exchange of knowledge was not without its challenges. The Orthonex, with their highly structured and hierarchical societies, often found the human approach to be both unpredictable and unorthodox. They struggled to comprehend the human drive for exploration and experimentation, which sometimes led to hasty decisions and risky ventures. Conversely, the humans were often puzzled by the Orthonex's meticulous attention to detail and their adherence to established protocols, which sometimes appeared to stifle innovation.

Despite these initial hurdles, the collaboration began to bear fruit. The joint scientific teams made significant breakthroughs in areas such as renewable energy, medical treatments, and space exploration. The fusion of Orthonex precision with human ingenuity led to the development of new technologies that exceeded the expectations of both civilizations. This period of discovery and innovation fostered a growing sense of camaraderie and mutual respect between the Orthonex and the humans.

However, as the collaboration deepened, the true complexity of the alliance began to emerge. The humans, with their unpredictable nature and penchant for taking risks, introduced a new dynamic into the federation. Their actions, often driven by passion and a desire to push the boundaries of what was possible, sometimes clashed with the more conservative and calculated approaches of the Orthonex. This tension was most evident in the joint military exercises, where the humans' willingness to experiment with new tactics and strategies occasionally led to disagreements with the more traditional Orthonex commanders.

Jogon, who had been closely monitoring the developments, found himself both impressed and concerned by the humans' impact on the federation. On one hand, their technological advancements and innovative thinking had brought about significant improvements and new possibilities. On the other hand, their unpredictable behavior and sometimes reckless actions posed a constant challenge to the established order and strategic stability of the Orthonex.

The humans' influence was also felt in the political arena. Their egalitarian values and emphasis on individual rights began to resonate with certain factions within the Orthonex societies, leading to debates and discussions about the potential benefits of adopting a more open and inclusive approach. This shift in ideology was both a testament to the power of human influence and a potential threat to the long-standing principles of the Conglomeration.

As the alliance continued to evolve, it became clear that the future of the galaxy would be shaped by the complex interplay between the Orthonex's structured order and the humans' audacious spirit. The Conglomeration, once confident in its own technological and strategic prowess, now found itself navigating a new reality where the boundaries between friend and foe, ally and competitor, were increasingly blurred.

In this new reality, the Orthonex and the humans would have to learn to balance their differences and find common ground. The challenges they faced were numerous, but so were the opportunities. The future of the galaxy, it seemed, would be determined not by the strength of their technologies or the depth of their knowledge, but by their ability to adapt, to innovate, and to forge a path forward together.

Jogon, reflecting on the journey thus far, felt a mix of hope and trepidation. The humans had proven to be a force of change, one that could both transform and disrupt the established order. Whether this new alliance would lead to a brighter future or a path fraught with uncertainty remained to be seen. One thing was certain, though—the Conglomeration of Orthonex Civilizations would have to be ready to face whatever challenges lay ahead, for the humans had forever altered the course of their shared destiny.

The dry eaves blew along the autumn wind

Singing the ocean's song to the ears in the land locked hollow.

The tops of the hills shaded the lane occasionally giving way to glimpses of a sunset as the funeral procession poured toward the family plot nestled in the back of the homestead between two limestone cliffs.

Duke was waiting with his fathers casket. The preacher stood, casting a shadow over the 6 foot hole that would soon hold the memories of the old man's bones. The preacher's wife stood by duke knowing that words could not penetrate the spell of grief that silenced the young man. Nor could her own losses teach her anything about his future.

Duke stood. Though his eyes were gazing down the lane, he was nowhere to be found in them.

In the blackness of his mind stood a rocky bluff, beaten by waves

"We're free, but we're in hell," whispered a thought.

The procession gathered in the borrowed church chairs. The indiscrete tones filled the hollow as each person clung to the edges of their mind. Not wanting to consider the haunting vision of their future. The loss was enough, though nobody knew the deceases past his steadfast oars through which he steered the generational family, donations to the church, and sparse involvement in town events. Time was this man's god, and other people were it's cost.

Next to the open grave lay Duke's mother. Her headstone was clean and polished like the love that she brought Duke's heart. She was seen and known for her sacrifices to her husband and to her hands. The world had swallowed her 3 years prior. Decades too early for Duke.

Duke took his seat and the preacher's wife next to him. The preacher stood with his head bowed over the casket mumbling to himself while he slowly turned to face the congregation.

"Today we honor a man

Who lived his life to the letter of the law, who gave his blood to his farm, his friends, and his kin. He walked among us like an omen

He stood Collected, Kind and Disciplined.

A teacher in the spirit of nature"

The preacher opened his bible to the gospel of John and spoke a sermon about light and the old man's life. He spoke about the passage of death. That it was indefinite and celebratory. That it was indeed both an end and a beginning.

The preacher did not care for any of his words. He had stopped caring years before when the world started to change and the mirror that greeted him every morning stopped staring so kindly. His words had no answers in them anymore. They were merely shorelines for his people and he was the one tasked with saying them.

Everybody was there for Duke, not for his father whose mountainous behavior left him isolated. The old man was a remnant of a fire that was dying out taking with it the emptiness of living for oneself.

The preacher's words came to a close. The sun was setting behind a cloud shrouding the grove in dark blue shadows. Duke stood from his chair and shook the preachers hand, thanking him in a rasped panicked voice. He touched the casket and placed his father's hat on it.

Not knowing what to do next, he awkwardly turned around and eyed the preacher and his wife.

Turning his back, he knocked on the casket and whispered

"Bye dad"

Falling out of him like a breath.

He could hear the preacher's wife directing the seated audience- a reception at the house. Duke could feel hands patting his back in comfort and murmurs of condolences. Filling in the space around him. Squeezing his chest.

The eruption of people broke the levee that Duke had created, forcing him to look up.

"I need you all to go on ahead," bellowing as his knees shook but he wouldn't budge. Just pressed his hands harder and harder onto the casket,

"Back to the house ya'll, I'll meet you there."

The preacher and his wife began corralling the procession toward the lane, as the townsfolk retrieved their chairs and loaded them into the pickup truck.

The preacher's sons had been standing at the edge of the clearing leaning on their shovels, next to the pickup truck that had brought the casket out. They stood like crows, above it and unindoctrinated in grief. Only waiting for their father's voice to command them to the task of lowering and burying Duke's father.

Duke could feel a heat rapture his face as he fought back tears and a place somewhere in his lungs began to tremor begging for breath. The air was a cool liquid that he felt behind his chest and this breath had carried every other breath in his lungs. His face was enveloped in heat as his salt stung his eyes. He wiped them as he turned - nodding toward the waiting preacher and walked toward the shovel to bury his father.

# The Drought

There was no rain that summer but Duke's farm had remained operational. The local reservoir had not completely run dry but it would not last as there had been many summers like this over the preceding decades. Pressed, the local farmers traded in their families heirloom properties for mansions, allowing the chain of progress to fill in behind them. What had once been thousands of acres of orchards, golden fields of wheat and corn, waves of furrows of green alfalfa, lay giant boxes placed end to end – homes for everybody from the nearby city and for all people pulled by the gravity of lower real estate costs and new lives in this suburb.

The county was becoming *that* despite the proximity to the largest city nearby being more than an hours drive. Though this once village had no association to that city, it was becoming a pre-fix to be never spoken of in its own history.

Duke knew this. His father had begun witnessing it before his death several years prior. They had watched as nearby communities became absorbed by the looming monolith to industry. There were new stores and new people. The dusty shadows that had camouflaged the townsfolk had become tapestried with new shades of colors each more vibrant than the last.

The old timers hated this emergence. They would hold court at local diners and glare at every visitor that would pass through their doors.

Standoffish men became bitter

Bitter men became silent.

Duke was not among either – though his father had become the silent type. Duke had no reason for lament- the community was changing in proportion to his curiosity. At times, he thought it was his young age, but he was not much younger than most bitter ranchers left. This farm had been the anchor of his family's heart for 4 generations. The trees and rocks had become the song that his life breathed through. The farm was the only hearth that he had known. Playing in it as a respite, then ultimately knowing it as his own personal clock.

This year, the ground was dustier and dying. He pulled only 3 out of 5 cuttings. 1 less then the year prior. There would be no profit this year. The few cattle that he ran could not diminish like his crops but no profit meant no feed and seed. No feed and seed meant that his farm might take the inevitable passage that had pulled his cohorts.

-----

The August sun bore down on Duke's shoulders as he walked the lane to the family cemetery. The leaves from the bordering trees gave his skin intermittent relief and a quiet breeze dried his sweat. The cottonwoods swallowed Duke's eyes and the old knots and hallowed trunks warmed his chest with the feeling that a part of him was cocooned in their bark.

He fumbled in his pocket for the handkerchief to wipe his brow. He arrived at the family plot to see first his fathers grave, covered in grass and prairie flower. Adjacent his mothers tombstone lay prominently marking his loss 6 years prior. They were both from this county, though his mother was an only child and her family's line had come to a close with her. He never imagined their bodies to mingle in decay. They were separate and distinct from each other in their marriage and would be apart even through death, until the earth claimed their coffins too.

There were 4 generations of men, women, and some children in this cemetery. The bones of Duke's family stretched across the historical divide from homesteader to rancher. Though parcels had been sold off over the century, this land had seen the Great Depression and the advent of million dollar tractors. Duke wasn't sentimental but the farm was the only thing he knew. The cold cement echoed against his face as his cheeks tingled underneath his beard.

"Dad, I don't know if this land is gunna make it. The water's gone, the sun's got hotter, the feed's doubled in price and there's no sign of it lettin' up. I know you said stick with it. That this farm is bigger than me or you. But I think God's got other plans. Buck next door is selling. He's got a nice price for it. Nothing like the offers that you got. The dirt's dust. I don't see it getting wetter. I don't feel the end.

I know what your gunna say, 'don't let the city get you. Don't be swallowed by the swarm.

But you know, it's only a matter of time with no rain.

Momma, I know you never much cared for this place. I know you'd itch to leave as soon as a door opened."

The sun was soft but still warm. The clouds were dispersing in the distance and the grove held nothing but silence. Duke could hear his own searching. He felt embarrassed that he even had to ask. Duke felt like he was performing. Somehow he believed that he was supposed to already know the answer. Already know how to navigate this changing tide. He knew there was no one there to answer and the emptiness that his words fell against made him feel like a fool.

With frustration, he turned around and started marching his way back to the house. What answers had his father? He was dead. What good were his bones but a memory of his forms inevitable end? The hubris of his father to think that he could out last the great machine. His own hubris for even considering that he was an exception to the rule.

Capable of selling or not, this land had shaped him and his very mind. He did not know himself apart from it. Every fiber of his being resisted the claim to be separate from the land. To be an individual pressing into the monolithic new age and bouncing off the new curiosities that modern industry had to offer. Duke knew that he was at a threshold and there was no exit that his heart could conjure to depart from his ever growing anguish – there was only suffocation.

The sun was beginning to set as Duke made it to the porch steps. There was nothing waiting for him inside except a few beers and a roast he cooked the night before. Wandering around his yard, he picked up the loose pieces of trash that had blown in from other parts of the property. Bringing the refuse to his garbage can, he went inside knowing there was no way to ease his consternation. There was no way out of his binding blade.

# The Echo

Duke drained the rocks of their energy. The land no longer harnessed the power of the soul. The fields became barren and void. The cows mingled slower to the troughs and the limits of Duke's hopes shown unearthed. The trees lived like they always had, bordering the homestead. The green that used to illuminate the center of the farm transformed itself into a papyrus brown as life from that spring that had fed the land so generously emptied without replenishment – the rocks drying out.

Light pressed through the blinds into Dukes room. The pools of dust whirled in the rays of sunlight at the foot of his bed. Duke stared, absorbed in its clou,d watching the space between the dust. Watching currents move while the light remained stationary. He was already late to feed the cattle, but they had become accustomed to a daylit breakfast, adjusting for their caretakers evening habits.

Staggering out of bed he found his irrigation boots and made his way to the barn to load his ATV with hay. The hungry herd was waiting, singing to each other in their semicircle. Duke broke apart the bale and splayed the flakes for the beasts. His head was booming and swirling as his stomach felt like it was sucked into his spine. His hands were tremoring as he took off his gloves – he reminded himself that he only needed to keep them alive until the next season. Grabbing the truck keys, he trudged to the drive-way and hopped into his silver truck.

Nobody was on the road this Sunday morning. They were either in church or away- looking to rediscover their foothold in nature. Nobody was there to witness Duke wrestle with the strongest motivation to pull his car into each passing power pole, every ditch, every large boulder. It would take nothing but a swift jerk of the wheel to the left or the right, to find a home in the immediate compression as his truck flung him to his timely death. He had watched it happen over and over in his head. This was his landscape to his journey townward. This was the road that Duke feared every time he stepped into that truck since his father's passing. He could feel the water in him asking for a way out but every day he kept driving, his hands becoming tighter and tighter against the steering wheel as the weeks turned into months, his hands becoming tighter as his negotiation set deeper into his jaw, then into his chest, then to his lungs where a small pocket of air carried the rest of him.

Duke passed the city limits sign slowing his resolve while he anticipated the path to his gas station. The lot was empty but for the owner's car. He parked his truck and walked in through the glass door; nodding at the man behind the counter reading his newspaper. These two needed no words, the owner had known Duke since he had purchased the timeless store. Duke grabbed his 12 pack from the cooler, a sandwich from the heater, a pack of gum, cup of coffee, and walked up to the register.

"Now you know its dry today, I tell you every Sunday. The law don't let me sell on Sundays. You want your beer, drive the 20 minutes to the next county"

Duke stood blankly, though the sleep was out of his eyes, he still felt the weight of it holding down his eyelids.

"You know days don't work like that out here"

The shopkeeper said nothing

Duke shrugged

Putting the daily provisions down he walked up to the register. He tossed his sandwich on the counter. I'll take 50 on pump 2

The shopkeeper nodded

"You want your tickets?"

Duke Shook his head

He walked out making his way to the bed of his truck. Sitting and drinking his morning cup while his tank fueled.

A green crossover rolled into the station's parking lot filled with a family. 2 little brown boys, a girl, and their parents. Duke eyed them inquisitively – there had been new people coming into town for the last couple of decades but this family pulled his attention. Their presence forced air down his chest and a small tremor sang from a space behind his ribs. Duke could feel his bones for the first time since his father died. They quivered and ached against the bed of his truck.

He watched as the family filed out of the car- the father exhausted but smiling, the mother resting in her own enchantment, like she had won herself over. The children reminded him of his school days. One was quietly watching while the other two played a slapping game as the family swirled into the gas station. The parents waved and Duke returned the gesture with barely enough time for them to see before they approached the door.

Duke's tank finished fueling

He took a sip of coffee and slipped off the back of his truck.

------

He drove homeward meandering from back road to back road, not knowing who was driving. He found the road to the highway that led south to the nearest county. In the years preceding, there were no events that marked his days nor an inner will to admit that he had lost contact with his sense of time. The highway took him 10 minutes to the adjacent county that wasn't dry on Sundays. Pulling into the first gas station, he sat in the moment between the truck halting and the release of his key in the ignition – his lips pursed and his fingers tapping the steering wheel. Traffic had picked up picked up carrying church goes home creating a wall of noise. Duke was met with a lull in the flow revealing the sounds of shifting metal creak in his ears while his truck settled.

A glint in his eye and a glimmer of a sneer marked his descent from the truck. Duke marched through the gas station door. Entranced as he opened the door, he made his way to the gas cans on the bottom shelf. Grabbing 4, he waltzed to the counter.

# The Passage

*Bottled Tempests*

*Scorching the summers weave*

*Ashes to Ashes*

*Dust to Dust*

Dukes blood pulsed with each step. With each step his face became tighter and tighter. He shut the curtains in his parents bedroom, preserved as it had been since nobody slept there these days. The dust didn't bother him, but this day he could see just how much had gathered on the linens. His boots echoed across the wood floors as he went from window to window, yanking the cloth shut. Grabbing one of the gas cans, he flung the petrol across the mattress that his parents had rested their limbs on for decades.

He tipped the container over at the doorway and watched the puddle spread between the floor boards. Duke barreled to the guest room and did the same thing. He spied the pictures on the wall that were a testament to his mother's interior decorating. Taking them off the wall and tossing them on the floor he emptied the second container over the glass and wood.

He trudged to his room and flipped his bed over . The mattress slammed into the window sending shards of glass to the backyard, 2 stories below. He cleared the clothes out of the closet and dumped them on the bed. Dukes hands started to shake as he emptied the third container. The fumes burned the inside of his nose.

The smell was not transitive, it neither carried him to any memory nor even attracted his attention at all. In truth, Duke was intoxicated by the fumes and drank them in, feeling the touch and timbre in his throat.

He finished dousing the third room and set out to finish the rest of the house. At this point the bottoms of his boots were wet and the floor had become slick. He leaped down the stairs with the fourth and last container of fuel. Drenching the front room of his family's farmhouse. The shadows from the already closed curtains danced around the center of the room. His home was unrecognizable. The couches that he had slept on sat motionless and stale. There was no one there. There was nothing left living in that old home.

Duke took the final container and removed the cap. He timidly made his way to the front door that he had entered and exited thousands of times. His boots getting wetter and wetter. The door warred with him. His eyes became absorbed in the seams of the wood. The knots and rings pulling him into them. The brass hinges, made by his great grandfather, reflected the sepia light in the room. He felt his face getting tighter and tighter and pressure in his lips became unbearable as he reached forward.

-----

The door flew open as he fell to his feet

The earth took his wound and he gave it his life.

He walked onto the dirt in front of him

Letting the light fall on his face and the air became pregnant fire.

The earth bore it and moved him to his car

He stepped into the cab and drove away."

### The Turning Point
