[Story]: I have a ghost.


In my house. I think.

My husband.

I think.

I'm tapping loudly on my computer. I do everything loudly now. I bang open cabinets, slam drawers, pound my fuzzy slippers heavily on the ground. To let the ghost know I'm here. To warn him of my presence. Because it's when I'm sneaking… that he finds me.

This house aches. I ache - that kind of … rich people ache. A clean, hollow, Hitchcockian ache. A whistling ache. The wind rips right through you. I know because I've been both. A poor person's ache feels damp. Heavy. Waterlogged. The wind can't rip it. Nothing can.

I inherited this house. And ghosts aren't the only things I've inherited with it. Brown widows (me?). Brown recluses (also me). Spindly creepy crawly heat-seeking things, determined to share my life. To take refuge from the doldrums of our island's winter tantrums. I've been alone here for a year and a half, but still, every time I flip on a light switch to reveal a fat centipede skitter under my bed, or a gilt edged silver fish looking up at me from the clawfoot tub - hot terror catches me.

All creatures I somehow never remember seeing while my husband was alive. Sometimes I wonder if the house is really mine, or if it was always theirs. With the ringing absence of my late husband's stewardship, it is changing hands, being returned back to the land. And the original owners are finding their way in through the cracks. Foundations loosening. Spirits and bugs welcome.

Looking at me, you wouldn't think I'm the type to be haunted by the ghost of a husband who can't move on. And yet, I fear, that is exactly what is happening.

It's a little flattering, really. At 38, I've kept up pretty good. Mainly, my hair. It's a little brassy from decades of blonde bottle dye, the ends crispy and straw-like, but I have not yet succumbed to that short haircut women fall victim to at my age. The haircut of a woman disappearing. A certain time of year I sport a rich, golden tan. But a lifetime of beach bumming with no sunscreen has taken its toll. My face dotted with faint patches and lines, settlers upon this land, seizing it and claiming it as their own. I've got the skinny legs of a teenager. Of a sand piper's, nearly invisible, scurrying away from the crash of the shore. But my top half resembles that of a dumpling. Storing all my softness at my center, with heaving breasts like overripe fruit. My thinness radiating out, trying its best to stretch away, to defy the pull of a centrifugal dough ball force. I have small brown eyes. Almond shaped and light, like watery coffee with shiny hazel flecks. Big full lips, and a flat ass. A few tattoos. From over the years. Maybe a few more than I'd like. But, they prove good conversation starters anyway. I'm regular white, but don't always look it, no one knows why. A Portuguese grandad on my mom's side, I've heard? But like most family lore… probably meaningless.

I pad my way down the spiral staircase that dizzyingly dumps me at the door.

"Coming down!" I elongate the syllables like I'm trying them out for the first time.

—

March on the coast is unnerving.

Block Island has abandonment issues.

She shivers and creaks and forces you to love her. Once the tourists and second-homers pack up at the end of summer, she gives her chosen ones sixty days of pure pleasure, reigniting their shaken faith. Devilishly drawing them in, captivating them … until they become captive. Blinded by her piercing beauty, her golden September afternoons, her sweet loganberry harvest, the best of her treasures saved for the most loyal. Her October plenty. Her blazing red leaves and edible purple skies. Her bright salty mornings and crab boil nights. She wraps you in her arms so tight that come November - you can't breathe. You're being - choked. Her thrashing waters, a bride in hysterics. She cries "Why does everyone leave me?" "Why can't they stay when I need them most?" The storm of her petulance tiring even herself out. Then, her loneliness turns punishing. "I love you, don't leave me". "Prove that you love me. Prove you won't ever leave. If you truly love me, take my choppy seas and caustic winds. Take my blistering freeze, my cavernous hallows. Can you take it? My shrouded mourning gown, my grey forever."

So we do. Until summer, when growing fat off the adoration of mere strangers, she turns her sun gaze away from the ones who steadied her in her bleak fit of winter. Bitterly, we blame the trampling tourist - you know the kind, throwing his money around and leaving. But deep down, every New Shoreham resident understands, if we sit still within ourselves, our ire is misplaced. That our woman chose someone else to shine on. We are back in competition with the handsome drifter.

So, March. March on the island is as sapless as it is serpentine. As dull as it is aching. Call it cabin fever. Call it winter blues. Call it anything other than what it is. A desire to leave.

—

My marriage to Jordan was fine. Really! We loved each other in a way that is truly underrated: A love balanced on the scales of "You don't acknowledge my flaws, and I won't acknowledge yours." We supported each other and stayed out of each others way. The sort of love that has fallen out of fashion now. The kind where I didn't work and I was fine with that. The kind where you both get what you asked for, then realize you both asked for the wrong thing, but you stick with it anyway. The kind where we never wanted kids because we never wanted to rouse such strong feelings. Even for each other. We did have a dog named Chester. And we loved him a medium amount. So it's… strange that… now that Jordan's dead… he wants me so bad.

I swipe my keys off the hook and zip my coat. A big puffy one I found in the attic. Forest green with a khaki collar. I smooth balm from the pocket over my chapping lips. I feel like he's watching me. Even now.

"I'm going out" I yell, into the stagnant air.

—

The door chimes as I slink from the pitiless, ashen afternoon into the dark bar. Warm and humming - the belly of the whale. I sidle up and in the mirror, catch myself flipping my hair to one side and over my shoulder with wanton flair.

I had been a waitress all my life. Well, my previous life. My pre-Jordan life. Since I was 14, I worked the Rhode Inn every summer, wearing white t-shirts that read "Rhode Hard and Put Away Wet". That's where we met, actually. He was a city boy. Boston. Invested some capital in a few of our local dives along the coast. Degree in Finance, the whole bit. Did a good job, really. Not overbearing, not trying to "class it up", corporatize us. They were popular little joints, so he wasn't trying to fix what wasn't broke.

"Want some oysters, Kat? Boat just came in." Trish stood comfortably, some rags in hand, her red hair gelled back into one severe ponytail.

"Nah, I'm OK."

"Ky's out back." She says, her back to me.

Her knees crack as she squats down, pulling sharpie-dated quart containers of soupy, red cocktail sauce out of a low boy. I try to sound casual, like I'm not quite sure why she'd be telling me where Ky is.

"Oh. OK."

Ky was my weakness. Is now, and always will be forever, amen. The broad, thick chest of a working man. Sea grey eyes, and the touch of someone whose presence is so crushing he had to learn, the hard way, how to handle the delicate things he loomed over. Hapless and unpolished, but careful. A hearty grin when he'd give it.

I fidget with my wallet while Trish slides me a Sam Adams.

"Put that away!" she scolds.

"Thanks." I smile sheepishly.

I put a coaster over my beer after the first sip and fish a pack of cigarettes out of my pocket.

—

Behind the restaurant, I hover. My plan is to wait for him to say something first. To happen upon me.

"Kat! Heads up!"

It's Tony. My favorite pint-sized maniac, unloading ingredients from the back of a box truck with feverish irregularity. I look in the direction of his voice, and he lobs an industrial bag of sea salt at my head. I dodge it just in time. It puts out my cigarette.

"What the FUCK Tony!" I yelp.

"You'll live!" He responds brightly, as I fumble with my lighter.

"Havin' a drink?" He asks, candy-coated in envy. He slaps one commercial kitchen sized vacuum sealed pork loin over each shoulder and hops off the truck, his knees buckling ever-so-slightly.

I nod, taking a long drag.

"You can have that, by the way. It's expired." His "i's" wide and throaty, an old-school New England accent stuck around his tonsils.

"Whatdoyathink I'm gonna need a five pound bag of expired salt for?"

"Your drive way!" Tony yells forcefully, rolling his eyes.

"Always tryin' ta provide for the helpless widow…" I jab back, with over-measured precision and pitch perfect volume, aimed just-so at the back of the truck. Hoping Ky can hear.

Just then, Ky emerges, hauling clams, headed for the walk-in.

"I could think of something else to do with a helpless widow…" He breathes, brushing my coat with his crooked elbow.

The air between us sharpens.

And my unfortunate first thought is: Jordan.

Dammit. I might need this salt after all.

—

Amid the dregs of winter, having no job and a dead husband, I found I left the house less and less— which meant I rarely saw it from this angle. I pull into the driveway and idle, craning my neck up.

It's impressive. Built in 1888, it's a classic example of the Victorian style of architecture known as Queen Anne. Nantucket blue with white trim and cranberry stained accents. Three sweeping stories embraced by a wrap-around porch with turned posts, decorative brackets, and spindlework.

Its asymmetrical facade gives it the character of a person. Multifaceted, tiresome. Showing some things off with a flourish of Dutch gables—and concealing others, the way we do. Its most prominent features on display like stories we tell over and over at parties. Its second-story balcony almost pouts with disuse, sagging slightly under a proud polygonal turret, dramatically built on a series of bay windows—a final, trumpeting declaration. "I used to be someone, something".

Not sure Jordan's parents were too thrilled when he left the house solely to me. But they retained the Boston assets, washed me out of their Supper Club hair, and I got to stay. Here. At home. The island of my teenaged summers.

And so did Jordan. Apparently.

—

"I'm home!" I bang and crash through the foyer. "It's fucking freezing in here." I say aloud, the door slamming behind me.

It is then that I see it— four french doors helplessly thrashing against their frames in the wind. Cabinets in the kitchen all open. Whisks and muddlers violently askew on the floor. Umbrellas spilled from a shattered standing vase.

Then a side-splitting howl, as an angry gust of sea wind whips through the naked, open channel that is now my house. Suddenly, I kneel to the ground and weep. I give up. Why is he doing this to me?

—

It didn't make sense. One, he didn't die here. In the house. He died in a car accident. A little over a year ago. In Providence, on his way home from a lunch meeting. If people are going to haunt, they're usually going to do it at the *site* of their death. Stuck there. Unwilling to move on, but unable to exist outside a loop, playing out their death over and over, trying to get it right this time. I know because I've done my research. Had a psychic over in November. A local woman with soft white hair piled on her head, an excess of earrings, and virtually non-stop chatter about angels. She refused to step beyond the porch, claiming she felt she wasn't "invited" by the house, until I reminded her *I'm the one* "inviting" her to make that $100/hour she insisted on.

So. She tells me. If your loved one turns into a ghost, a haunting, a spirit caught between planes, it's either because:



1. Their death was untimely
2. Their death was horrifically violent.

OK. Jordan was 49 when he died. So yes, too young. But not exceedingly young. Not "he had his whole life ahead of him" young. I mean, not two generations ago, that was a perfectly reasonable age to forever etch on a tombstone. His car accident, as tragic as it was, wasn't exceptionally horrific either. Just your average death. Pretty symbolic of a lot in Jordan's life.

But *even if* those two criteria were met, the psychic assured me that spirits of the departed are *still* likely to haunt the place they died in.

But he's not haunting a busy stretch of I-95… He's haunting me.

He died in me.

Somehow.

"And one more thing" she said. Stopping me, as her glasses fogged, one foot out the door, her pale eyes growing paler. "It could be unfinished business. That's c." The ABCs of haunting.

Unfinished business. The unfinished business of what exactly? I loved him—I want to make that one thing clear. I did love him. I smile when I think about his jet dark hair, perfect in that boxy, side-parted Republican way. His brooding countenance - the sort of etched severity that promises trouble below. Except with Jordan, there was no darkness. He had no demons. That was just how his face looked.

I miss his big vocabulary, that phone voice he reserved for "business calls", the fake laugh he used on demanding restaurant patrons, or that easy way he fell asleep, every limb draped over mine.

He was never vindictive. Never looking for ways people could hurt him, the way I do. Sure, maybe… maybe we'd've been better off as friends, but we also *wanted* the same things: Comfort. This beach. Cold beer. This house. Using Chester-the-unruly-dog as an alibi to never visit his parents or sister. A medium sized boat.

He was never this passionate in life. He wasn't even particularly stubborn. Unfinished business felt so uncharacteristically romantic by comparison. My throat itches as I wonder if the unfinished business we had was in never loving each other recklessly. Totally. Always skating through life unannounced. Never asking ourselves "Isn't it supposed to be more beautiful than this?"

Now, I sweep up the broken vase and put the kitchen back together. It's the best I can do."

**Haunted Reflections**

As the storm outside crescendos, I can't help but feel a strange sense of relief. The tumultuous wind and rain are a stark contrast to the eerie silence that usually fills the house. It’s as if the natural chaos is a distraction, a temporary shield from the unseen forces that torment me. I stand in the middle of the living room, the remnants of the broken vase scattered at my feet, and let the cold air seep through my clothes. My mind races, trying to grasp any semblance of logic or reason for what’s happening.

I know I'm not crazy. At least, that's what I tell myself. Jordan's parents never believed in ghosts. They were practical people, always reminding me that there are rational explanations for everything. But they were also the ones who would call me every other day to check in, even after Jordan’s death. They knew something was off. They knew I was struggling.

My fingers trace the rough wood of the mantle, my eyes fixed on the portrait of Jordan and me from our honeymoon. We look so happy then, so full of life. But that was before everything changed. Before the house started feeling colder, darker. Before the whispers at night and the feeling of being watched. I close my eyes and try to summon the memory of Jordan’s laugh, the sound that used to make my heart soar. But all I get is an empty void, a silence that is deafening.

"Maybe it's just the house," I whisper to myself. "Maybe it's just the house and the memories. It's not really him." But even as I say it, I know it's not true. I know that the house is just a vessel, a place where Jordan's essence has become trapped, unable to move on. And I'm trapped too, caught in a cycle of fear and uncertainty.

I glance around the room, my eyes landing on the empty chair that used to be Jordan's. It's been sitting there, untouched, for over a year now. I remember how he used to sprawl in it, reading a book or watching TV, his feet up on the coffee table. Now it's just a ghost of what was, a reminder of what I've lost. And I wonder if that's what he's doing too—trapped in some form of limbo, stuck between this world and the next.

The wind howls outside, and I shiver, pulling my coat tighter around me. I know I need to face my fear, to try and make peace with whatever is haunting me. But the thought of confronting Jordan, of actually talking to him, terrifies me. What if he's angry? What if he's hurt? What if he's still in pain?

I take a deep breath, trying to steady myself. I know I have to move forward, even if it means facing the things I'm most afraid of. Because if I don't, I'll be trapped here forever, just like him.

With a heavy heart, I start picking up the pieces of the vase, one fragment at a time. It's a small step, but it's a step in the right direction. Maybe if I can fix this, if I can mend the broken pieces of the vase, I can mend the broken pieces of my life too.

But as I stand there, cleaning up the shattered remnants, I can't shake the feeling that no matter how hard I try, some things are beyond repair. And that's a thought that haunts me more than any ghost could.

**Unfinished Business**

I sit back down on the couch, the last piece of the vase cradled in my hands. The storm outside seems to have quieted, leaving a hushed silence that amplifies the unease in the room. I take a deep breath and let it out slowly, trying to center myself. I know I need to confront the unfinished business between Jordan and me, but the fear of what that might reveal paralyzes me.

I remember the last time we had a serious conversation, just weeks before his accident. We were sitting on the porch, the sun setting over the ocean, casting a golden glow over everything. We talked about our future, about the things we wanted to do, the places we wanted to go. But we never got past the surface. We avoided the deeper questions, the ones that required vulnerability and honesty.

"What if we're just too different?" Jordan had said, his voice soft but tinged with frustration. "What if we're too comfortable with each other to really be happy?"

I had looked at him, confused. "What do you mean? We're happy now."

He shook his head. "No, I mean... what if we're too settled? Too content to change?"

I had no answer for him then, and I have no answer now. Was our love too stagnant? Too predictable? Or was it just a reflection of the comfort we found in each other?

The more I think about it, the more I realize that our relationship was built on a foundation of unspoken words and unexplored territories. We were always too afraid to truly confront our feelings, to dive deep into the complexities of our emotions. We were content to skate over the surface, avoiding the potential for conflict and pain.

And now, with Jordan gone, I'm left to grapple with those unspoken words and unexplored territories. What if he's still grappling with the same questions? What if he's still searching for the answers we never found?

I close my eyes and try to summon Jordan's voice, his smile, the way he used to hold me when I was scared. But all I get is an empty silence, a void that seems to swallow me whole. I know I need to face this fear, to confront the unfinished business between us. But the thought of doing so terrifies me. What if I find out something I'm not ready to face?

I take another deep breath, trying to steady myself. I know I can't avoid this any longer. I have to confront the things that haunt me, even if they're the most terrifying ones. Because if I don't, I'll be trapped in this cycle of fear and uncertainty forever.

With a heavy heart, I stand up and walk over to the window, looking out at the stormy sea. The waves crash against the shore, relentless and unforgiving. Just like my emotions, I think. Unyielding and unrelenting. And I know that I have to face them, no matter how scary they might be.

Because if I don't, I'll never find the peace I so desperately need.

**Facing the Unseen**

The decision to confront Jordan, to bridge the unspoken words and unexplored territories of our relationship, weighs heavily on my mind. I know it's the right thing to do, but the fear of what might happen paralyzes me. What if he's still angry? What if he's still in pain? What if he's already moved on, leaving me to deal with the remnants of our past?

I sit on the edge of the bed, staring at the ceiling, trying to find the strength to take this next step. I know I can't do it alone. I need some guidance, some reassurance that I'm not facing this battle in the dark. And then it hits me—writing. Writing has always been my escape, my way of making sense of the world. Maybe it can be my guide now, my tool to confront Jordan and the unfinished business between us.

I grab a notebook and a pen from the drawer and sit down at the dining room table. I start writing, my hand moving across the paper with a kind of urgency that surprises me. I write about Jordan, about our relationship, about the fears and uncertainties that haunt me. As I write, I start to feel a strange sense of clarity. The words on the page become a mirror, reflecting the truths I've been avoiding.

I write about the last time we talked, about the things we never said. I write about the fear of change, the fear of losing what we had. And as I write, I realize that those fears are what's been haunting me. They're the unspoken words, the unexplored territories, that have left us both stuck in limbo.

I write about how much I miss him, how much I wish I could tell him the things I never had the courage to say. I write about the pain of losing him, the emptiness that has filled the void he left behind. And as I write, I start to feel a strange sense of peace. The words on the page become a healing balm, soothing the wounds of my heart.

I write about the storm outside, about how it mirrors the storm inside me. I write about the fear of facing Jordan, the fear of what might happen if I do. And as I write, I start to understand that facing my fear is the only way to find peace. That confronting Jordan, even if it's painful, is the only way to move forward.

I write until my hand aches, until my eyes are dry and sore. I write until I've poured out every last drop of my fear and uncertainty. And when I'm done, I look at the page and see not just my words, but the truth of my heart.

I know now that I have to face Jordan, that I have to confront the unfinished business between us. It won't be easy, and it might be painful, but it's the only way to find the peace I so desperately need.

With a heavy heart, but a determined spirit, I stand up and walk towards the window. I look out at the stormy sea, and I take a deep breath. I know the journey ahead won't be easy, but I'm ready to face it. Because if I don't, I'll never find the peace I so desperately need.

**A Chance Encounter**

The following morning, the sun rises over Block Island, casting a warm glow over the desolate streets. I decide to take a walk, hoping the fresh air might clear my mind. The island is eerily quiet, the aftermath of the storm leaving it in a state of fragile calm. As I walk, I replay the words I wrote last night in my head, trying to make sense of them. I know I need to face Jordan, but the fear of what that might entail lingers in the back of my mind.

As I turn a corner, I nearly run into a tall man with salt-and-pepper hair and kind, sea-green eyes. He's carrying a basket of fresh produce, his face lighting up when he sees me.

"Hey there, Kat. Got a minute?" he says, his voice warm and inviting.

I nod, slightly taken aback by his sudden appearance. "Sure," I reply, trying to mask my surprise.

He sets the basket down on the ground and looks me in the eyes. "I'm Ky," he introduces himself, extending his hand. "I saw you writing by the window last night. Thought I'd check in on you."

I shake his hand, feeling a strange sense of comfort despite my initial apprehension. "Thanks for the concern, Ky. I'm just trying to get through the day, you know?"

Ky looks at me thoughtfully for a moment before speaking. "You know, sometimes facing our fears is the only way to find peace. Are you ready to face yours?"

I hesitate, the words hanging in the air between us. "I don't know," I finally admit. "It's just... it's been so long since Jordan died. I don't know if I can confront him, let alone what he might say."

Ky's eyes soften with understanding. "I get that. But sometimes, we have to take that first step, no matter how hard it might be. And sometimes, we find the strength we need in the most unexpected places."

I take a deep breath, feeling a mixture of hope and fear. "I appreciate that, Ky. But what if I can't handle it? What if facing Jordan just makes things worse?"

Ky smiles gently. "You'll never know unless you try. And if it does get too much, you have me. I'm here for you, Kat. No matter what."

His words provide a sense of solace, a reminder that I'm not alone in this. For the first time since Jordan's death, I feel a glimmer of hope. Maybe facing my fear isn't as impossible as I thought. Maybe with Ky's support, I can find the strength to confront Jordan and the unfinished business between us.

With a newfound sense of determination, I look at Ky and thank him. "I think I'm ready to take that first step," I say, my voice steady.

Ky smiles, giving me a reassuring nod. "That's the spirit, Kat. Just remember, you don't have to do this alone."

As I walk away, the sun begins to set over the ocean, casting a golden hue over the horizon. I take one last look at Ky, feeling a sense of peace I hadn't felt in a long time. And with that peace, I know I'm ready to face whatever comes next.

**A Heartfelt Confrontation**

The evening air is crisp as I stand at the edge of the porch, looking out at the ocean. The waves crash against the shore, their rhythmic sound providing a comforting backdrop for the conversation I'm about to have. I take a deep breath, steadying myself as I turn to face the silhouette of Ky standing by the garden gate. His presence is reassuring, a reminder that I'm not alone in this.

"Ky," I begin, my voice trembling slightly. "I think it's time. I need to face Jordan, to confront the unfinished business between us."

Ky looks at me, his eyes filled with understanding and encouragement. "I know this isn't easy, Kat. But you have the strength to do this. I believe in you."

With a nod, I take another deep breath and step forward. "I've been writing a lot lately," I start, my voice gaining confidence as I speak. "And I realized that there are things I need to say to Jordan. Things I never had the courage to say while he was alive."

Ky listens intently, his eyes never leaving mine. "I'm here with you, Kat. You don't have to do this alone."

I continue, my voice steady now. "I wrote about the fear of change, the fear of losing what we had. I wrote about the things we never said, the questions we never answered. And I realized that confronting these fears, facing these unspoken words, is the only way to find peace."

Ky's eyes soften as he listens. "You're braver than you know, Kat. Taking this step is a testament to your strength and determination."

I pause, taking a moment to collect my thoughts. "I need you to promise me something," I say, looking Ky straight in the eyes. "No matter what happens, no matter what Jordan says, you'll be here for me. You'll help me through this, okay?"

Ky's eyes fill with compassion. "I promise, Kat. I'll be here with you every step of the way."

With a final deep breath, I turn and walk towards the house. The memories of Jordan flood my mind, each step a reminder of the life we shared and the love we once had. As I reach the front door, I take a moment to steady myself, feeling the weight of my emotions.

I open the door slowly, the soft creak of the hinges echoing through the empty hallway. The house is silent, the only sound the distant waves crashing against the shore. I make my way to the living room, my heart pounding in my chest. I sit down on the couch, feeling the emptiness that has filled the space since Jordan's death.

And then I see him. Jordan, sitting in the chair where he used to sit, his presence as palpable as it was when he was alive. My breath catches in my throat as I look at him, feeling a mixture of fear and longing. I know this is the moment I've been dreading, but also the moment I've been waiting for.

"Jordan," I whisper, my voice breaking. "I need to tell you something."

He looks at me, his eyes filled with a mix of confusion and sadness. "Kat, what are you doing here?"

I stand up, taking a step towards him. "I need to confront the unfinished business between us. I need to say the things I never had the courage to say while you were alive."

Jordan's eyes search mine, his expression softening as he listens. "I understand, Kat. I've been thinking about this too."

The silence between us feels heavy, filled with unspoken words and unexplored emotions. I take another deep breath, steadying myself as I speak. "I wrote about the fear of change, the fear of losing what we had. I wrote about the things we never said, the questions we never answered. And I realized that confronting these fears, facing these unspoken words, is the only way to find peace."

Jordan's eyes fill with understanding. "I know, Kat. I've been thinking about the same things. Maybe we were too afraid to change, too afraid to lose what we had."

I nod, feeling a sense of relief wash over me. "I think that's why I've been so haunted by your presence. I needed to confront these fears, to find the peace we both needed."

Jordan's eyes soften, and he takes a step towards me. "Kat, I'm sorry. I never meant to hurt you. I just... I was scared too."

I reach out, taking his hand in mine. "I know, Jordan. And I'm sorry too. I should have been more open with you, more willing to face our fears together."

We stand there, holding hands, the silence between us filled with a newfound understanding. The fear and pain that once haunted me seem to dissipate, replaced by a sense of peace and closure. I know that facing Jordan, confronting the unfinished business between us, has been the hardest thing I've ever done. But it's also been the most important.

**Finding Peace**

As the night deepens, the house seems to settle into a quiet calm, the storm outside long since passed. I sit beside Jordan on the couch, feeling a sense of peace I haven't known in a long time. The fear and uncertainty that once haunted me have finally been laid to rest, replaced by a profound understanding and acceptance of the past.

Jordan's hand is warm in mine, a reminder of the love and connection we once shared. I look at him, my eyes filled with gratitude. "Thank you, Jordan. For giving me the strength to face my fears, to confront the unfinished business between us."

He smiles, his eyes shining with a gentle warmth. "You were always strong, Kat. You just needed the courage to see it."

We sit there, wrapped in the comforting silence of the moment, the bond between us stronger than ever. I know that facing our fears has been the hardest thing I've ever done, but it's also been the most important. By confronting the unspoken words and unexplored territories of our relationship, I've found the peace I so desperately needed.

The door creaks softly, and Ky steps into the room, his eyes filled with concern. "I heard you two were talking," he says, his voice gentle. "I just wanted to make sure you were okay."

I look at Ky, feeling a deep sense of gratitude. "We're fine, Ky. Thank you for being here for me. For believing in me."

Ky smiles, his eyes twinkling with understanding. "That's what friends are for, Kat. And I'm always here for you."

As Ky leaves the room, Jordan and I sit there, holding hands, the bond between us stronger than ever. I know that, no matter what the future holds, we'll face it together. And I know that, finally, I've found the peace I've been searching for.

And with that peace, the house seems to breathe a sigh of relief. The echoes of the past fade into the background, replaced by a sense of calm and tranquility. The ghost of Jordan, once a source of fear and uncertainty, has now become a symbol of love and understanding. And I know, deep in my heart, that I'm finally home.

You should write a continuation of the following story.
[Story]: It had been decided that the machine must go. I didn"t find myself agreeing with Major Milic very much these days. His methods were harsh, brutal and he had become a fanatic. I"d call him more of a terrorist than a freedom fighter. But he was right, the machine had to go. I didn"t have any confidence we could do it, however.


The resistance had changed in the last couple years. The Emperor"s personal secret project was brought online. Though it was round, it wasn"t like it the "Death Star." This Empire was real, and it made smarter decisions. It spent its time and money on a brain. CyCLOPS- Cybernetic, Control, Law-enforcement, and Online Policing System- changed the rules of human nature more and more every day. It make it possible for a few people to effectively watch the entire human populace at once. It watched, it learned, it analyzed, it predicted, and it remembered with perfect clarity all at a single time.

I had been surprised at first when Major Milic rescued me from my prison, but not when I figured out what he planned to do. He needed me for two reasons. One- I could fly helicopters, the old ones without autopilot. Two- I knew where CyCLOPS was. And I suppose a third reason too; I would never turn him into the Imperial Union.

I agreed to help, not that I had a lot of choice when everything I knew was lost and there was a gun in my face. I left the prison behind, but all the while knowing I would die with them instead.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

CyCLOPS is not easy to get near. It was secret to begin with, but they knew better than to rely on that alone. Through torture, Major Milic"s loyal team discovered a lot information about the facility. Though most work with it is done remotely, it has over 500 that work directly with the machine on-site. These are mostly fat technicians and overpaid civilians, not that Milic recognized civilians anymore. They wouldn"t put up much of a fight when push came to shove.

The security came from a reinforced, mixed-guard company made up of Sentinels and Assault Forces. One company of three platoons. Each platoon covered a 12-hour shift. One was on days, one on nights, one on recovery cycle at all times. They had six guard towers with heavy machine guns on the walled perimeter. The walls were made of carbonized concrete, the gate was heavy metal and automatic, and there was electrified razor wire across the top. Four roving patrols covered the exterior of the facility, rejecting any trespassers onto the "Navajo Sanctuary Reservation." At least one large armored vehicle was ready at all times for a quick reaction force. The rest of the on-shift platoon patrolled the inside of the compound and checked key points.

If at any point the guards caught wind of our approach and intentions, the other platoons would be woken and activated as reserves. An entire company of heavily armed and armored Sentinels would be vastly too much to deal with, and we"d be slaughtered. We had to 1- approach undetected, 2- blind the guard towers so they could not shoot down our helicopters, 3- secure the barracks and take the reserves hostage before they could get to their arms room, 4- deal with the existing guards in the compound, 5- lock the gate to prevent the roving patrols from returning with more firepower, 6- break into and make our way into the facility, and at last, 7- blow CyCLOPS to high hell. None of the major processor banks can survive. No one knows the extent of its capabilities for certain, besides the Emperor and his chosen team, but it may likely begin to back up its data to external servers outside of the facility. The more we can destroy, the more we"ve set back the Empire, and the more time we've bought for a larger resistance to mobilize.

They are dependent on the machine now. They will be weaker than they were before it"s installation. But first, we had to get there. And I had a bad feeling. So many things could go wrong.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

I listened as intently as I could to Milic"s briefing. He"d thought of everything. Even from his little bunker hidden away from the world, he"d managed to gather a lot of intelligence. From his position at the top of the map, he could point out every section of the base, where we would land, where the satellite communications were, where the barracks and arms rooms were, where we would enter the facility, and more. I wasn"t sure how he knew all of this. I think I didn"t want to know.

"Sam, are you fuckin" paying attention!?" His eyes seemed to glow from the light reflected off the map in the otherwise dark bunker.

"What? Yes. I know where to land." Truthfully I"d never been the same since that prison. I couldn"t focus on anything too long.

"But after that?"

"What... what am I doing after that? That wasn"t... I didn"t agree to-"

"I don"t give a shit. You"re with me. I"m not letting you out of my sight."

"Who"s going to stay with the helicopter?"

"Jacob will keep it running." He pointed to Powell, next to me. Anyone who knew him called him Powell. Only people who pretended to know him called him Jake or Jacob. They"d had a long history, but that told me how close they weren"t. Powell"s eyes locked with mine for a moment then looked away. He was a hostage here, too. He was the man that taught me to fly. He was old now. So was I.

"I"m not shooting anyone."

"That"s fine. You"ll help carry explosives. You"ve got no problem blowing this thing up. That"s what we agreed on, right?"

"Okay... right. I"m with you."

"You"re attached to my hip. You go where I fuckin" tell you and nowhere else. Is that understood?"

"I"m with you." I growled.

"3rd squad, alpha-team"s goals are the communications array..." he continued. But again, I already wasn"t listening. A faint whining grew in my ears, and I faded out into one of my blackout spells. After coming all this way, and everything I"ve worked for- everything I did to fight the Empire- it was probably Milic that was going to kill me.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

During pre-flight checks with Powell, we talked a little bit. It was nice. I climbed up on top of the back of the bird to give the yoke a good look.

"This piece of shit is not gonna fly." I interjected, looked at the rust near the blade hub.

"It"ll fly. I flew it yesterday."

"The rotors are going to fall off before we get there."

"No... but we"re in for a bumpy ride. She definitely handles like a... heh heh, Sammy, you remember that old two-seater we flew up to that Appalachian relay station?"

"Oh dear god, we almost died. On three separate occasions." I grinned.

"We"ve been through tougher spots." Powell grinned too and climbed up the other side. His entire bald head wrinkled when he smiled.

"Yeah... but we were younger men. And the Empire didn"t rule the world yet."

"Nothing lasts forever. Not youth, and not this crummy empire. They all fall down eventually. We"re just giving it a good shove."

"You really think we"re going to win?" my grin faded. That old feeling returned.

"I think so. Major Milic"s got his plan down tight. He"s resourced everything he needs. We have our opening. You don"t think we can?"

The yoke, despite several conditions I would normally reject, appeared okay. The blades were in surprisingly good condition. It would fly all the way to the scene of the crash. "I don"t think so."

"You need to give the guy more credit. I know you don"t agree with his methods, but he"s a warrior. This is what he was built for. You have that prison mindset still. The walls are all closed in around you."

"Oh I don"t think it"s the prison that got to me," I looked out into the setting sun of the evening. The scenery from up here was incredible.

"Is this about Lindsey?"

"No. Lindsey"s gone. This is about us. Now. Though I admit, it"s hard to forget her face with a bullet in it. I"m glad she"s not here to see this. This is going to be... a mess."

Powell reached up and grabbed my hand and held it in both of his. "You"ve gotta have a little faith in this team. They know what they"re doing."

"I know. But this team never met the Emperor. I"ve met him, and... No one on earth knows what they"re doing compared to him. He sees everything coming."

"Sam, you have to believe we can win."

"I know... there"s a chance we can win. But we need to be ready. If it"s not a trap now, it will be by the time we get there." The sun slipped from view, and we were left standing in the dark."

### Preparing for the Mission

As the helicopter rumbled to life, I felt a strange mixture of fear and determination. The whir of the blades was a familiar sound, yet it carried a new weight this time. Powell and I climbed into the cockpit, the familiar controls feeling both comforting and foreign. I adjusted my grip on the yoke, feeling the vibration through my hands as we taxied towards the launch pad. The ground crew stood back, their expressions a mix of apprehension and resolve.

"Remember, we only have one shot at this," Powell said, his voice steady but laced with an undercurrent of urgency. "We have to be precise."

I nodded, though my mind was a whirlwind of doubts and fears. The plan was meticulous, but that didn't mean it would go off without a hitch. The weight of the mission pressed down on me, making it hard to breathe. I glanced at Powell, his eyes reflecting the same tension. He gave me a reassuring squeeze on the shoulder, a silent promise that we would face this together.

As we lifted off, the ground fell away beneath us, and the horizon expanded before us. The sun was setting, casting long shadows over the landscape below. The air was cool against my skin, and the noise of the helicopter's engines drowned out all other sounds. For a moment, I felt a semblance of peace, a brief escape from the chaos that awaited us.

But the peace was short-lived. The closer we got to the facility, the more the reality of our mission settled in. The ground below was a maze of security checkpoints and guard towers, each one a potential threat. I could see the roving patrols moving back and forth, their eyes scanning the horizon for any sign of intrusion.

"Keep your head down," Powell murmured as we flew lower, skimming the treetops to avoid detection. "We have to stay under their radar."

I gripped the yoke tighter, my knuckles turning white. The weight of the explosives I was carrying felt like a leaden shroud around my body. Each second felt like an eternity as we inched closer to our target. I couldn't shake the feeling that something was off, that we were walking into a trap.

"Can you feel it?" Powell asked, his voice barely above a whisper.

I shook my head, trying to mask my unease. "No. I just feel like I've done this a million times before."

He chuckled softly, though his eyes were still sharp with focus. "Yeah, well, this time it's for real. No more practice runs."

The facility came into view, a sprawling complex surrounded by a high, fortified wall. Guard towers dotted the perimeter, their searchlights sweeping back and forth in a relentless pattern. The main building was a towering monstrosity, its sleek design a stark contrast to the brutal efficiency of the guards patrolling outside.

"Alright, here we go," Powell said, his voice taking on a determined edge. "We've got to hit them hard and fast. No room for mistakes."

I nodded, taking a deep breath to steady my nerves. We were on a suicide mission, but we had to try. For all of us who had suffered under the Empire's iron fist, for all those who had lost their lives, we had to make a stand.

As we approached the drop zone, I could see the outline of the facility more clearly. The helicopters were our only advantage, and we had to use them to the fullest. I adjusted the throttle, bringing us in for a low pass over the compound. The ground felt like it was rushing up to meet us, and for a moment, I felt a rush of adrenaline that pushed aside my fears.

"Ready?" Powell asked, his eyes meeting mine with a steely resolve.

"Ready," I replied, though my voice wavered. "Let's do this."

### The First Phase: Overcoming Obstacles

As the helicopter descended, I could see the details of the compound with unsettling clarity. The walls, composed of carbonized concrete, gleamed under the fading sunlight, their thickness and durability a testament to the Empire's resources. The razor-wire-topped perimeter was a stark reminder of the deadly defenses we would have to breach.

"Keep your eyes on the target," Powell whispered, his voice barely audible over the roar of the engines. "We need to hit them hard and fast."

I nodded, my hands steady on the yoke. The plan was simple in theory but fraught with danger in execution. We had to fly low and fast, using the cover of the terrain to avoid the guard towers' searchlights. As we approached the first tower, I saw a sentinel moving within its confines, scanning the horizon with a weapon trained on anything that moved.

"Two minutes," I murmured, counting down the time we had before we were within range of the tower's guns.

"Alright, here it comes," Powell said, his voice tense. "We'll need to hit them with everything we've got."

As we crossed over the first tower, I pulled back on the yoke, lifting the helicopter into a steep dive. Powell released a burst of flares from the side of the helicopter, causing a distraction that momentarily blinded the sentinel. The guard turned his weapon towards the flares, missing our approach.

"We're through the first one," I said, my voice tight with relief. "But there are four more."

The second tower was closer, and its searchlight was already sweeping towards us. I knew we had to make this quick. I pushed the helicopter into another dive, and Powell launched another burst of flares. The guards turned their attention back to the lights, giving us a few precious seconds to fly beneath their reach.

"Alright, one more to go," I said, my voice a strained whisper. "And then we're in."

The third tower was almost upon us, its searchlight a menacing beam that seemed to stretch out and reach for us. I could feel the weight of every second ticking by. We were running out of time. Powell released the final burst of flares, and I pulled the helicopter up just in time to avoid the tower's beam.

"We're through," I said, my voice trembling with a mix of fear and exhilaration. "We've done it."

But as we lifted back up to a safer altitude, I saw the final obstacle: the main gate. It was heavily fortified, with heavy metal bars and an automatic locking mechanism that would make it difficult to breach. We had to disable it before the roving patrols could reach us.

"Alright, we've got one final challenge," Powell said, his voice calm but urgent. "We need to get through that gate and secure the compound."

I nodded, gripping the yoke with both hands. We were close, but the hardest part was still ahead of us. The helicopter descended once more, this time aiming directly for the gate. As we approached, I could see the automated systems whirring to life, preparing to close the gate and trap us outside.

"Engage the system," I said, my voice a steady command. "We can't let them close us out."

Powell reached into his pack and pulled out a small device, a specially designed jammer. He held it up to the side of the helicopter and activated it, sending a pulse through the gate's systems. The locking mechanism froze, and the gate remained open.

"We're in," he said, a triumphant grin spreading across his face. "Let's do this."

As the helicopter touched down on the compound grounds, I felt a surge of adrenaline course through my veins. We had made it through the first phase of our mission, but the real challenge was just beginning. The compound was secure for now, but we had to act fast if we were to have any chance of succeeding.

"Alright, let's move," I said, stepping out of the helicopter and onto the compound grounds. "We've got to take out the guards and secure the barracks before the roving patrols realize what's happening."

Powell nodded, his eyes focused on the task ahead. We had come this far; we couldn't afford to falter now.

### The Next Phase: Engaging the Guards

As we set foot on the compound grounds, the weight of our mission pressed heavily on our shoulders. The air was thick with tension, every step we took a calculated risk. Powell and I moved with the precision of soldiers who had been through countless battles, our eyes scanning for any sign of guards.

"Stay close," I whispered, my voice barely audible. "We don't want to give them a chance to react."

We approached the first guard post, a pair of sentinels standing at attention with their weapons at the ready. Their eyes were sharp, their ears attuned to any sound out of place. I could see the way they shifted their positions, always aware of their surroundings. Powell and I exchanged a quick glance, a silent communication that we had to move fast.

"Ready?" I asked, my voice a strained whisper.

"Always," Powell replied, his eyes never leaving the sentinels.

I took a deep breath, steadying my nerves. We had to be quick. I stepped forward, my hand reaching into my pack to pull out the first of the tranquilizer darts. Powell followed my lead, his dart gun at the ready. We moved in unison, each step synchronized to avoid drawing unnecessary attention.

As I approached the first sentinel, I saw his eyes flicker towards me, a suspicion brewing in his gaze. I knew I had to act fast. I fired the dart, watching it sail through the air and embed itself into the sentinel's shoulder. The man let out a yelp of surprise before collapsing to the ground, unconscious but alive.

Powell moved in quickly, taking out the second sentinel with a well-placed shot. We moved on, our pace quick but controlled, each step bringing us closer to our goal. The compound was a labyrinth of buildings and pathways, each corner potentially hiding a threat.

We reached the barracks, a large structure that housed the on-duty guards. The doors were secured with a combination lock, and I could see the guards patrolling outside, their weapons trained on the entrance. We had to take them by surprise if we wanted any chance of success.

"Wait here," I said to Powell, my voice a hushed command. "I'll handle the lock."

I pulled out a small device, a lock-picking tool designed specifically for this kind of situation. I worked quickly, my hands moving with practiced precision. The lock clicked open, and the door swung wide. Powell stepped inside, his dart gun at the ready.

"Clear," he whispered, his voice a relief that washed over me.

We moved through the barracks, taking out the guards one by one. Each sentinel fell quickly, their weapons useless against our surprise attack. We reached the armory, a secure room that held the reserves' weapons and ammunition. The door was locked, and I could see the guards outside, their expressions tense as they scanned the area for intruders.

"Alright, this is it," I said, my voice steady but urgent. "We need to take them out fast."

Powell nodded, his dart gun already in hand. We moved towards the guards, our steps silent but deliberate. I fired the first dart, watching it sail through the air and hit its mark. The guard let out a shout of pain before collapsing to the ground. Powell followed suit, taking out the second guard with a swift, precise shot.

We were in, the armory before us filled with rows of weapons and ammunition. We grabbed what we needed, stuffing the gear into our packs. The sound of footsteps approaching made us freeze, our eyes scanning the area for any threats.

"Move fast," I whispered to Powell, my voice a strained whisper. "We don't have much time."

We moved through the armory, securing the weapons and ammunition we needed. The guards outside were still unaware of what had happened, their attention focused on the compound's perimeter. We had to take advantage of that.

As we made our way back to the main building, I could feel the weight of the mission pressing down on me. We had taken out the guards, secured the armory, but the hardest part was still ahead. We had to make our way into the facility and disable CyCLOPS before the Empire could react.

"Let's go," I said, my voice a command that echoed through the compound. "We're almost there."

Powell nodded, his eyes focused on the path ahead. We moved with purpose, each step bringing us closer to our goal. The compound was now ours, but the real challenge was just beginning. We had to get inside and shut down the machine that controlled the Empire before it was too late.

### The Final Phase: Breaching the Facility

The facility's main entrance loomed ahead, a towering edifice of sleek, metallic design that exuded an air of cold, unyielding power. Powell and I paused, taking a moment to assess our surroundings. The entrance was guarded by an imposing set of double doors, secured with heavy-duty locks and reinforced with steel plates. Beyond them, we knew, lay the heart of the Empire's control—CyCLOPS.

"We need to get through these doors," I said, my voice a hushed whisper. "And fast."

Powell nodded, his eyes scanning the area for any additional threats. "I've got a charge. We can blow the locks, but we need to be careful. If we set off any alarms, we're dead."

I pulled out a small, cylindrical device from my pack, a high-explosive charge designed to penetrate the toughest barriers. "Alright, let's do this."

We positioned ourselves on either side of the door, taking careful aim with the charge. Powell handed me a detonator, and we worked in unison, planting the charge and connecting it to the detonator. The seconds ticked by, each one a weight on our shoulders. If we miscalculated even slightly, the explosion could alert the entire facility to our presence.

"Ready?" Powell asked, his voice steady but tense.

"Ready," I replied, my heart pounding in my chest.

We both pressed the triggers simultaneously, the sound of the detonation echoing through the compound. The explosion was powerful, tearing through the steel and concrete with a force that sent shockwaves through the ground. The locks burst open, the doors swinging wide with a thunderous crash.

We rushed inside, the interior of the facility a labyrinth of corridors and control rooms. The air was thick with the hum of machinery, the sound of countless processors and servers whirring to life. Powell and I moved with purpose, our eyes scanning for the main control center where CyCLOPS resided.

As we navigated through the maze of hallways, I could feel the weight of the mission pressing down on me. The stakes had never been higher, and the consequences of failure were unthinkable. I had to focus, had to stay calm.

"Over here," Powell called out, his voice a beacon in the darkness. He was pointing towards a large, glass-enclosed room, the heart of the facility. Inside, I could see rows of servers, banks of monitors, and a central console where CyCLOPS operated.

"Get ready," I said, my voice a strained whisper. "We have to shut this thing down."

Powell nodded, his eyes focused on the task at hand. I pulled out a pair of EMP grenades, devices designed to emit a powerful electromagnetic pulse that would disable electronic systems. "We need to get close. These things are lethal."

We moved cautiously, our steps silent but deliberate. As we approached the control room, I could see the main console, the heart of CyCLOPS. It was a marvel of technology, a machine that had the potential to control the entire Empire. I knew that if we could disable it, we could cripple their power and buy time for the resistance.

"Alright, this is it," I said, my voice a hushed command. "We're going to blow this thing to hell."

Powell and I positioned ourselves on either side of the console, ready to throw the grenades. The seconds felt like an eternity as we moved into position. I could see the monitors flickering, the screens displaying streams of data that were being processed by the machine.

"Now," I said, my voice a steady command. "Throw them both."

We threw the grenades, the explosions shaking the room as the electromagnetic pulse spread through the facility. The monitors flickered, then went dark. The servers powered down, the hum of machinery dying down to a quiet hum. CyCLOPS was offline, its control over the Empire severed.

"We did it," Powell said, his voice a mixture of relief and triumph. "We shut it down."

I nodded, my heart pounding in my chest. We had done it. We had taken down the machine that controlled the Empire, at least for now. The future was uncertain, but we had taken a significant step towards freedom.

As we stood there, watching the facility go dark, I felt a sense of accomplishment wash over me. We had faced impossible odds, and we had won. For the first time in a long time, I felt hope.

"We did it," I said, my voice a whisper of triumph. "We did it."

Powell nodded, his eyes reflecting the same feeling. "We did it."

We stood there, watching the facility fall silent, knowing that we had made a difference. The fight was far from over, but for now, we had won a crucial victory.

### Reflections and Regrets

As the facility fell into silence, a heavy sense of exhaustion settled over me. The adrenaline that had fueled us through the mission began to ebb away, leaving behind a profound weariness that I couldn't shake. Powell and I stood in the control room, the once-busy hub of the Empire now a cold, dark void. The screens were dark, the servers still, and the hum of machinery had ceased, replaced by an eerie quiet.

"We did it," I murmured, more to myself than to Powell. The words felt hollow, almost surreal. Had we really just brought down the machine that controlled the Empire? The enormity of what we had accomplished was almost too much to comprehend.

"Are you alright?" Powell's voice broke through my thoughts, a gentle inquiry laced with concern.

I looked at him, his face etched with worry. "I don't know," I admitted. "It feels like we're standing on the edge of something huge, and I don't know if I'm ready for what comes next."

Powell nodded, understanding the weight of my words. "It's a lot to take in. But we did it. We've made a difference."

I sighed, the reality of our victory mingling with the lingering dread of the future. "I know. But what now? We've crippled their control, but we haven't won the war. There's still the Emperor, and he's not going to give up easily."

"Nothing lasts forever," Powell said, his voice a calm contrast to my turmoil. "Empires rise and fall. Ours will too."

I looked at him, his words resonating with a truth I had long forgotten. "You really believe that, don't you?"

He gave a small, reassuring smile. "I do. And I believe in us. We've come this far. We can keep going."

I took a deep breath, the weight of our mission pressing down on me once more. The future was uncertain, and the path ahead was fraught with danger. But for the first time in a long time, I felt a glimmer of hope. We had taken the first step, and however long the road ahead, we would walk it together.

"Alright," I said, my voice steadier than it had been. "Let's keep moving. We've still got a fight ahead."

Powell nodded, his eyes reflecting the same resolve. "Together," he said, and with that, we set off into the unknown, ready to face whatever challenges lay ahead.

[Story]: My name is Kristin Renee Saunders, and my life has become crazy in a big fucking way. And the shit part is I can't even tell anyone about it. Forget talking to my therapist, she'd have me locked up and the key thrown away if I attempted to unload any of my problems and experiences. After all, who would believe anyone who said they were involved in a murderous power-grab between witches, vampires, werewolves and other supernatural races?


Not one damn person, that's who.

But if I don't get this off my chest, I might lock me up and throw away the key. If only not to get killed by something that doesn't have a box next to it on a coroner's report.

It all started a few months back, while I was waiting tables at the Whistle Stop. The Whistle is a small little restaurant in Glendale, Kentucky that serves up the best southern dishes and desserts in the area. Folks travel everywhere from Louisville to out of state, and I've even served folks from as far away as Cali and Alaska. We have many regulars, but it's not uncommon to see strange folks here, even if Glendale is literally a one-stop-sign kinda place.

The two women at table ten made me strangely uneasy from the beginning, requesting a table as far away from any of the others as possible. When Hailey, the hostess, sat them at table ten , I felt an inside groan. Table ten- the haunted table. Not that anyone had actually seen a ghost, but unexplainable things always seem to happen there. Drinks will unexplainably topple over or dishes will slip out of even the most experienced servers' hands. No matter who is sitting at table ten, you just know something is going to happen.

I smiled my most winning smile at the two ladies. One of the women looked to be in her mid-thirties, with dark hair and eyes. She was well-dressed in a pair of slacks with a form-fitting shirt that made it clear she was in excellent shape, and a jacket that matched her sensibly-low heels. In short, she was dressed like Beckett in an episode of Castle, or any other female cop in a prime-time, murder-porn TV show.

The other looked to be in her mid-twenties, with long, wild sandy blonde hair that fell in waves past her shoulders. It looked like it had not been brushed in several days. She was wearing faded jeans and sneakers, and a faded black Realtree sweatshirt with cammo lettering.

In short, these women could not have appeared less likely to be dining together. But whatever. I'm not here to ask questions, right?

The well-dressed woman said she had eaten earlier and simply ordered water with a slight English accent. The younger woman ordered country-style steak, two orders of fried chicken, and two slices of Kentucky pie. I wondered how someone could possibly put away that much food , but hey… big bill, big tip. Who am I to question? Maybe she had a tapeworm.

I had just finished scrubbing the tea urns after promising my manager Tess that I would lock up. The women were the last two people other than myself in the building and I had already cleared the dishes and was waiting for them to pay and leave. I finished closing work in the kitchen and headed out the back door that lead to the dining area and around to the front of the building to check that the lights were off. I was about to round the corner into their section when I first caught wind of their conversation . I should have just delivered the bill and minded my own fucking business. But I've never been good at being sensible. I slipped silently into the next dining room area to listen as pieces of their conversation floated towards me.

"….. Can't kill him, he holds too much power…"

"Even the witches would not dare ."

"….Can't control the pack for much longer."

"Vampires have not had a council outside what the Vatican controls in centuries,"

What the fuck? Murder? Witches? Vampires in the Vatican?

Actually having been raised Catholic, that last part I could believe.

I was still hiding in the next dining room when they went silent. Could they hear me? Did they know I was back there? I crawled my way to the doorway that connected the two dining room, hoping to covertly peek around the corner. I prayed the damn ancient saloon-style double doors wouldn't squeak too much when I opened them. Then again, I wasn't exactly able crawl all that silently, either. The building is over 120 years old and has all the original flooring. It groans and squeaks with just about every movement. I cursed all the times I chose tacos over going to the gym as I gingerly tried to make my way to the doors.

When I got there, I decided not to risk trying to open the doors. Instead, I stuck my head under them only far enough to look under the booths to double check that the two ladies were still there. I briefly praised my own foresight in having already throughly swept and mopped the floor. Maybe Grandpa's half-eaten biscuits and gravy wouldn't end up in my hair.

Table ten was empty.

I was so shocked I went to stand up so quickly I forgot I was under the doors, and cracked my head. I rubbed the rising knot on my scalp and looked around, but there was no sign of the two women. I rushed around the restaurant seeing if maybe they had gone to use the restroom before paying their bill. No dice. I even checked the kitchen. Nothing.

I heaved a sigh. Great. Now not only am I the last one here, my last table was two crazy ladies who dined and dashed on me. Assholes.

I finished my last duties and stepped out the back door into the cool autumn evening. We were already busy when I arrived at work earlier, so I had to park clear down Railroad Avenue , and I had a fairly long walk in the dark ahead of me. The streetlights had gone out a while back but Glendale prides itself on being a "community" rather than an actual town. The result was nobody had gotten around to fixing the lights. The median age of the residents being somewhere between 75 and death, everyone was well inside and likely already asleep by the time dark fell. Fixing the streetlights wasn't on anyone's priority list.

I walked past the antique mall and shuddered at the eerie sight of porcelain dolls staring at me in the darkened window display. As I walked down Railroad the houses stopped and there was nothing but cornfield on either side of the little road. I always hate walking by myself simply because it always feels as if someone, something is out there. This night was no different and I tried to walk faster but I could not shake the feeling that I was being watched. Stalked.

When I finally reached my car my hands were clammy and shaking as I dug around my purse for my key fob. I heaved a sigh of relief when my hand found the fob, and went to pull it out when a black blur whizzed beside me.

Before I could blink, I was on my back in a small grassy patch in front of the cornfield, staring into the eyes of the English-accented well-dressed woman. I gasped for breath, the force of her take-down having knocked the wind out of me. I stared into her eyes, continuing to gasp for breath and not piss myself. Her eyes seemed different. Feral. They caught and reflected the moonlight the way animals' eyes do. She bared her teeth at me, revealing canine teeth that were… well, canine-like. It was like staring into the face of someone who had just stepped away from filming a scene for True Blood. I mentally counted down the weeks until Halloween. It seemed far too early to be attending a Halloween costume party.

It sounded like someone else's voice as I gasped out "wha..wha..what do you want?!"

I had hoped to sound defiant. Fearless. Instead, I sounded like an asthmatic mouse with an anxiety disorder. Fabulous.

"What did you hear?" Her voice sounded like a growl.

"Huh? N-n-nothing!" I squeaked.

"Bollocks. I can smell the lies on you. Now is not the time to bullshit. I have other ways of getting the truth from you." Shit. I'm gonna die.

The younger woman's face suddenly loomed over me. She spoke with a thick southern accent, but it wasn't local. "Just kill her and let's go before one of these blue hairs decides to talk a late-night stroll. We have to get going. This little bitch isn't going to fuck up us finding my father or talk shit to the wrong people. She's a loose end. Get rid of her."

I started to scream, hoping one of "those blue hairs" would actually be on a stroll, but the well-dressed woman quickly put her hand over my mouth. She looked up at the younger woman and sneered. "Bloodshed isn't necessary here. This one might be useful. If nothing else, she might know something." She looked down at me. " I suggest you stay quiet. I may be reasonable but my associate here would rip your throat out with her teeth and not think twice. She's rather rash, that one. So be a good girl, hmmm? Now, look at me."

I squeezed my eyes shut. I didn't want to look into those strange, feral eyes. She shook me hard.

"Look at me or I swear, they'll never find what's left of you. Genevieve? Perhaps you might emphasize my point? Let's let our little waitress know this is no idle threat."

My eyes were still glued shut when I heard what sounded like the growl of a very large animal. It was deeper and more menacing than any animal I had ever encountered. At the sound of it my eyes snapped open. The well-dressed woman smiled, revealing those horribly pointed teeth.

"Very good. Now, look at me.There's a good girl."

I stared into those fearsome, strange eyes and they seemed to start to glow. I felt myself become strangely calm. The glow of her eyes seemed to intensify, and I felt my body becoming heavy. I felt myself falling…falling. I was falling into blackness when I heard her faintly say "Good. Now we are going go for a bit of a ride….."

The world went black."
