[Story]: Sightseeing. It is what I tell myself I am doing as I stand here year after year, viewing wistfully in the distance towards a collective nothingness. Upon a beach of sea-blue sand, dully reflecting the neverending haze surrounding this place, I stare into the ocean's mist, serving only to further cover everything in the same grey blanket of total blandness. The waters are calm and unmoving, carrying no wind, perfectly still as all else is here. The only movement that reminds me time is not yet frozen is the wavering deep-blue hue the water carries with itself near the shoreline, refracting the sand's gem-like azureness in a listless dance, until once again fading into a lifeless grey. It is all I can do to stare at this hesitant ripple of blue. It draws me in until the dreary atmosphere ever so slowly fades out of my consciousness; a welcome refuge for my tired eyes.


I am unsure when I first arrived at this place, it happened much like how one might forget a dream. Awaking with a moment of unfamiliarity, and a distant memory of a place that dives farther from your mind each second you try to grasp at it, until all that"s left is the memory that there was something that happened, some thought that you engaged with thoroughly, but remembered nevermore. I had tried to find a way to get away from here. I've ran along these sands many times in search of solidarity from this place, but alas, the beach seems infinite in every direction. Even the water itself holds no secrets of escape, for it violently steepens only a few meters from shore, and attempting to run away from the beach is equally futile, I simply appear right back at the ocean after walking only a short distance away, as if this cursed place is just a loop one cannot escape by effort alone.

So, I stand and stare. Time passes here at a dreadful pace, and I have lost hope of returning to my past life. Even if I somehow rid myself of this place, a mind can only take so much of this desolation before permanently adapting to it. The little solace I hold is writing these words into the sands, for this land's apathetic nature is kind enough to leave the sands unmoving for me to use as a canvas of words and thoughts. There is little else to describe here so this writing will end I suppose. One day I may add to my scriptures in these sands, but this place is making me tired. So, I'll let it take my thoughts to sleep, hoping to dream of a place that isn't here.



Writing Upon Blue Sands pt. 2, Sinking to Somber:

My mind skips upon my dead thoughts like these pebbles upon this familiar sea: plip, plop, plip are my thoughts, sinking into cold, lifeless insanity. My mind stands me along this beach once more, my body begging for the back and forth familiarity of flinging rocks towards the open nothingness—anything that isn't another nothing for my senses. I let the thoughts fall from my head and drag my body back to my scrawled words. I return to writing upon these blue sands to exorcise my mind from the silence and the blue.

I think I've found blue to be so… depressing. At first it was a welcome sight from the ocean's horrid blanket of eternal grey, but now my mind is in constant battle between the greys and the blues and the brights and the dulls and the same pattern of refracting light of the water's dance with the sand until my mind simply surrenders to a single muddled color of somber. These are the patterns and contrasts of the sole two colors in this world that I once thought would hold significant importance to my sanity, but now they serve only to constrain my sanity to yet another nothingness.

A mind cannot withstand absolute singularity of a concept for long before breaking; a single color or a single belief and ideal, a single order or a single life, a single one place of consciousness and decision-making that sits in eternal stillness for the extent of one's sanity—as afterwards, constraints on reality no longer matter to a broken mind. It is simply an environment that such a machine was not designed to survive in.

So, this world blesses me with living upon an eternal balance point between absolute singularity and necessary stimuli with its waveless sea, its stillborn breeze, and its shimmering azure sands that seep into your mind like drops of ink, leaving your thoughts stained forever blue. But again, I am blessed within this world to write within its sands and throw its stones back at itself in childish retaliation. The world could've let my writing disappear as my thoughts do, or let my stones skip only once instead of the occasional twice to my amusement. The world may steal my thoughts and feelings, forever lost within the depths of its sea, but it does allow solidarity from its environment in painfully short moments of self amusement through my actions here.

Unfortunately they are far in-between each other, and once again I am feeling my thoughts having been thoroughly soaked into these sands, wishing to take leave of my head and send me to my nothingness once again. So, I'll lay within these sands, staring at my nothing until my sanity tips too far from its balance point, and I will decide to skip stones again tomorrow or maybe continue my writings here another night. Whichever one my mind has felt is a greater necessity to its survival in this apathetic wasteland of blue sands and lifeless waters."

**A Desperate Search for Escape**

I find myself wandering aimlessly along the beach, my feet sinking into the cool, yet uninviting sand. Each step forward feels like an attempt to escape the suffocating silence that surrounds me. The horizon stretches endlessly, offering no solace and no promise of a different world. My heart pounds with a mix of anxiety and despair as I look out to the sea, hoping to find some sort of beacon, some sign that there might be a way out of this endless loop. The waves, though gentle, mock me with their rhythmic rise and fall, as if reminding me of my futile attempts to find a way out.

I pause and look down at my hands, now coated with the fine blue sand. They trace the outline of my fingers, each one telling a story of its own—a story of a life that was once filled with purpose and meaning. But now, those stories feel like distant memories, buried beneath the weight of this relentless desolation. I close my eyes and take a deep breath, trying to center myself, to find some semblance of control in this chaos. But the air is as empty as the sky, and I am left with only my thoughts and the sound of my own breathing.

I continue walking, hoping that the movement might bring some clarity or at least a distraction from the oppressive silence. The sand feels different under my feet today, almost as if it's absorbing my despair, making each step heavier than the last. I look back to see if there's any sign of progress, any indication that I'm moving closer to something—anything—that could offer me a sense of hope. But there's nothing. Just the same endless expanse of blue and grey, a testament to the futility of my search.

As I walk, I pass by the remnants of past attempts to make sense of this place. There are scrawled notes and half-finished sentences in the sand, remnants of my earlier struggles to understand my situation. They look so fragile now, like they could be erased by the next wave or the next gust of wind. It's as if my attempts to find meaning here were never meant to last, destined to be washed away just like everything else in this desolate landscape.

I stop and sit down on a pile of seaweed, my body exhausted from the endless walking. The sand is cool against my skin, a temporary comfort that does little to alleviate the gnawing despair within me. I look out at the sea again, this time with a sense of resignation. I realize that escape might not be possible, at least not in the way I had imagined. This place, with its eternal stillness and haunting monotony, has a hold on me that I cannot break.

I am trapped in this endless cycle, bound by the very elements that surround me. The sea, with its deceptive calm, and the sand, with its deceptive stability, are both a prison and a canvas. I have tried to paint a picture of hope and purpose here, but all I have managed to create is a reflection of my own despair. And as I sit there, staring out at the horizon, I come to the haunting realization that maybe this is my new reality, and I might be stuck here forever.

**A Momentary Respite**

As the sun begins its slow descent, casting long shadows across the beach, I find myself drawn to a small, secluded cove nestled between two rocky outcrops. The contrast between this hidden corner and the vast expanse of the open beach is striking. Here, the sand is softer, almost velvety underfoot, and the water, though still a monochrome shade of grey, seems to shimmer with a faint, almost ethereal light. It's as if this tiny sanctuary has been carved out of the monotony, offering a brief escape from the endless desolation.

I make my way to the edge of the cove, the sound of the waves gently lapping at the shore providing a soothing backdrop to my thoughts. The air is filled with the faint scent of salt and seaweed, a scent that is both foreign and comforting. I sit down on a smooth rock that juts out from the shore, feeling a strange sense of peace wash over me. For the first time in what feels like an eternity, I am not searching for an escape or trying to make sense of my surroundings. I am simply existing, allowing myself to be present in this moment.

I close my eyes and listen to the rhythmic cadence of the waves, their gentle ebb and flow a lullaby that calms my restless mind. I can feel the warmth of the sun on my skin, a rare and precious sensation in this otherwise cold and indifferent world. Slowly, my breathing begins to even out, my thoughts dissolving into the silence around me. It's as if the cove has become a portal to another reality, one where time seems to stand still and worries fade into oblivion.

I open my eyes and look out at the horizon, where the sky meets the sea in a breathtaking display of colors. The sun is beginning its descent, casting a golden glow on the water, creating an illusion of movement and life. For a moment, I am lost in the beauty of it all, forgetting about the desolation that awaits me just beyond this small sanctuary. It's a fleeting moment, but it is enough to remind me that there is still a semblance of beauty to be found in this world, even if it is hidden beneath layers of bleakness.

I sit there for a while longer, savoring the peace that this tiny corner of the beach has offered me. It's a brief respite from the relentless despair that has become my constant companion, a reminder that there are still moments of tranquility to be found, even in the most desolate of places. And with that reminder, I gather the strength to face the endless expanse once more, knowing that I have at least one small refuge to return to when the weight of the world becomes too much to bear.

**The Weight of Solitude**

As the sun continues to sink towards the horizon, casting long shadows and a soft, golden glow over the beach, I find myself once again grappling with the crushing weight of my solitude. The cove, though a brief sanctuary, now feels like a distant memory, and I am once more surrounded by the endless expanse of sea and sand. The gentle lull of the waves, which moments ago provided solace, now echo with an eerie sense of loneliness, as if mocking my desperate attempts to find meaning in this desolate landscape.

I stand up from the rock, feeling the weight of my body and the weight of my thoughts pressing down on me. My mind is a whirlwind of emotions—despair, frustration, and a deep, unrelenting sadness. I look out at the sea, where the water meets the sky in a seamless blend of grey and blue. It's a stark contrast to the golden light that briefly graced the cove, and it serves as a cruel reminder of my isolation. The horizon seems to stretch infinitely, much like my despair, offering no promise of escape or relief.

I take a deep breath, trying to center myself, to find some semblance of control in this chaos. But the air is as empty as the sky, and I am left with only my thoughts and the sound of my own breathing. My mind races, jumping from one thought to another, each one more despairing than the last. I think about my past, about the life I once knew, the people I once loved. It all feels like a distant dream, a memory that I can no longer grasp. And in that memory, I am left with the haunting realization that I might never escape this place, that I might be trapped here forever.

I feel a tear slip down my cheek, and I wipe it away with the back of my hand, trying to hold back the flood of emotions that threaten to overwhelm me. I look down at my feet, now buried in the sand, and I can feel the weight of my despair pressing down on them. It's as if the ground itself is absorbing my sorrow, making each step feel heavier, more burdensome. I take a step forward, and then another, but the ground seems to resist my efforts, as if trying to hold me back from escaping this endless loop.

I stop and sit down on the sand, my body trembling with the effort of holding back my emotions. The cool sand is a stark contrast to my warm tears, and for a moment, it feels like the world has stopped turning. I close my eyes, trying to focus on the sound of the waves, but they only serve to amplify my sense of isolation. The rhythmic cadence of the water feels alien, as if it's mocking my futile attempts to find peace.

I am lost in my thoughts, drowning in a sea of despair, when I hear a distant voice call out to me. At first, I think it's just the wind, but the voice grows louder, more distinct. I look around, but there's no one in sight. The voice seems to be coming from everywhere and nowhere at once, a haunting reminder of my loneliness. I stand up, trying to shake off the sense of despair that has gripped me, and I look out at the horizon once more.

The sun is almost completely submerged below the horizon now, and the sky is turning a deep shade of purple, with streaks of orange and pink painting the sky in a beautiful but fleeting display. It's a reminder that time is passing, that life is moving forward, even if I am not. I take a deep breath, trying to center myself, to find some semblance of hope in this bleak existence. But the weight of my solitude is a heavy burden, and I am not sure if I can carry it much longer.

As the night falls and the stars begin to emerge, I realize that this place, with its eternal stillness and haunting beauty, has become my prison. And I am not sure if I will ever find a way to escape, or if I even want to. For in this place of desolation, I have found a strange kind of peace, a acceptance of my reality that I never thought possible. And as I sit there, watching the stars appear in the sky, I wonder if this is where I will remain, forever trapped in the inescapable cycle of blue sands and lifeless waters.

**A Glimmer of Hope**

Just as I am about to surrender completely to the overwhelming weight of my despair, I spot a faint glimmer of light on the horizon. At first, I think it's just a trick of the eyes, a reflection perhaps, but as I watch, the light grows brighter, piercing through the thick blanket of grey that has shrouded this place for so long. My heart skips a beat, and I feel a surge of hope surge through me, a feeling I haven't experienced in what feels like an eternity.

I stand up and walk towards the light, my feet moving almost on their own, driven by an inexplicable force. The sand feels softer now, almost welcoming, as if it's encouraging me to continue. As I get closer, I realize that the light is coming from a small island, barely visible through the mist. It's a speck of life in an otherwise desolate sea, a beacon of hope in my endless expanse of despair.

I reach the edge of the beach and look out at the island, feeling a mix of awe and trepidation. The water between us is choppy, and the waves crash against the rocks with a force that seems almost defiant. But I am no longer afraid. Instead, I feel a strange sense of determination, a need to reach that light, to find out what it represents. I know it's a long shot, that the chances of survival are slim, but I can't bring myself to turn back now.

I begin to wade into the water, the coldness of the sea biting at my skin, but I don't stop. Each step forward feels like a step towards a new beginning, a chance to break free from the endless cycle that has bound me here. The waves are strong, and they pull me back with each surge, but I keep pushing forward, driven by a newfound sense of purpose.

As I approach the island, I see that it's not just a small patch of land but a thriving ecosystem, with trees and plants growing robustly. There's a small beach, and beyond it, a dense forest that seems to hold the promise of life and possibility. I feel a wave of relief wash over me, mixed with a sense of wonder. This island, with its vibrant colors and the sound of birds chirping, is a stark contrast to the desolation I have known for so long.

I reach the shore and step onto the island, feeling the soft sand between my toes. The trees are tall and lush, their leaves swaying gently in the breeze. I walk deeper into the forest, the sounds of the ocean fading behind me, replaced by the melodies of birds and the rustling of leaves. It's a world apart from the bleakness I have known, and I am filled with a sense of awe and gratitude.

As I explore the island, I find a small stream, its clear water flowing gently over rocks. I kneel by the stream and cup my hands to drink, savoring the taste of fresh, clean water. It's a simple pleasure, but it feels like a gift, a reminder that there is still beauty and life to be found in this world.

I sit by the stream, allowing myself to absorb the surroundings, to let go of the despair that has weighed me down for so long. For the first time, I feel a sense of peace, a sense of belonging. This island, with its vibrant colors and the sound of life all around, has given me a new perspective, a new hope.

I look out at the sea once more, and I see it differently now. It's no longer a barrier, a prison. It's a path, a journey that has led me to this place of wonder and possibility. And as the sun sets behind me, casting a golden glow over the island, I feel a sense of gratitude for the journey that has brought me here. For in this small, vibrant island, I have found a new beginning, a new hope for the future.

**A New Horizon**

As the sun sets behind the island, painting the sky with hues of orange and pink, I sit by the stream, reflecting on the journey that has brought me here. The island, with its lush greenery and the sound of life all around, has shown me that there is still beauty and hope to be found in this world. It has given me a new perspective, a new sense of purpose. And as the first stars begin to twinkle in the night sky, I feel a profound sense of gratitude for this unexpected sanctuary.

I look out at the sea once more, and I see it differently now. It's no longer a barrier, a prison. It's a path, a journey that has led me to this place of wonder and possibility. The island has taught me that there is life beyond despair, that there is beauty to be found even in the most desolate of places. It has shown me that hope can be found in the unlikeliest of places, that a new beginning is always within reach.

As I sit there, watching the waves gently lap against the shore, I feel a sense of peace wash over me. The weight of my solitude and despair has lifted, replaced by a newfound sense of hope and determination. I realize that I don't need to escape this place entirely to find a new life. Instead, I can find my way back to the island, to this place of beauty and possibility, whenever I need a reminder that there is still light in the darkness.

I stand up and stretch, feeling a sense of rejuvenation and purpose. I know that my journey is far from over, but I am no longer afraid. I am ready to face the challenges that lie ahead, to explore the vast expanse of this world, and to find new horizons. And as I walk back towards the beach, I feel a sense of excitement and anticipation for what lies ahead. For in this world of endless desolation and hidden beauty, I have found a new beginning, a new hope for the future.

You should write a continuation of the following story.
[Story]: We never thought in our most desperate hour that knowing how many toes on a possum could save a life. Because honestly, who has that kinda knowledge rumbling through their brain ready to be pulled out of their butt? No one. No one except a winner, and most of the time, they"re just guessing and pulling crap out. But that guess gets them a ticket out of this life, and leaves the rest of us sorry losers in the dirt.


This may sound like ranting because it is. In a system that is already corrupted to the core by chance and social connections, Trivia Hour added an extra topping to that hot mess. At 12 in the afternoon and 6 in the evening, three quarters of the world pulled out some sort of device to gaze hopefully at their last chance for a pleasant life as the clock clicks down to 0 and bright blue words ask "Are you ready?". Three quarters of the world will desperately tap answer after answer, feeling their opportunity rising higher and higher until they click that one wrong answer, and they come crashing down into the garbage pile. Nothing matches the excitement of getting a question right and moving to the next round, the ultra combination of exhilaration and adrenaline gunning through your body and setting you on fire. And nothing matches that sub-abyssal low when you miss one, sinking into your stomach and tearing you from the inside out. Its a feeling that stays a lot longer than the high, the feeling that no matter what, no matter who you could"ve been, you are never getting out. I know what it feels like because just like the other 5 billion, I"m a sucker to the game. The game, the most hedonistic form of capitalism and emotional manipulation this side of the hill works like this:

There are 20 question, starting off easy before ramping to nearly impossible. All quick facts, no mathematical equations so I guess we have to thank the creators for that. You answer one wrong, you, and millions and billions, are booted. Here"s the catch, so it"s not just the entire population of China randomly guessing and crying into their phone: if you get someone to enter your username in as a referral code, you get a heart. A heart will save you for one wrong question and you can"t use more than one a game. When the game started off, with only 2 maybe 3 hundred thousand logging in at 12 and 6, it was relatively easy to get a referral code from a friend just joining the game or a relative. But when the numbers kept going up and up as the weeks grew into months then years, you were considered blessed to get a heart, as rare today as finding a diamond amid coal. That"s where things got ugly. People began to create massive amounts of accounts to get hearts, so the folks at Trivia Hour began demanding confirmation that the person creating an account was a real human. So this led to two things happening: people creating people as fast at they could, either by birthing children or smudging documents, and people going the opposite way, knocking off competitors permanently and stealing their phones in the hopes they could give a heart.

I was born as one of the former options. My parents lived on the poorer end of the middle class spectrum. Kept us in a three-bedroom house in the suburbs on desk-jobs. The game came out when they were in their early twenties, when they already had Macy and Linden. When the Upturn struck, sending the economy into a vicious spiral, the low-end middle class felt in the hardest. After being let go of their jobs, the house in the suburbs was vacated for a slimy apartment in the city and mom and dad picked up work anywhere they could. The game before the Upturn was a fun, exciting way to connect across borders and learn new facts. The game after the Upturn became the light at the end of the tunnel for them. It no longer had that child-like appeal. It was business. Macy and Linden were given cheap phones and accounts when they were three and two, with my parents answering for them. Five years later, mom popped me and Pepper out to get more chances, before succumbing to an infection, probably grown in the petri dish of our home. Dad got desperate when she died. We stopped looking like kids, and more like washed out bed sheets as he struggled to put food on the table. Taking on three jobs was a lot, but Macy, as the oldest, was only 15 and was still required to go to school, just like the rest of us.

It looked pretty grim for a couple years, until dad was hired by an advertising company for the game, to mandate calls or whatever, and things started to pick up. There was food in the house 24/7 and Mace was given the chance to join an after school club centered around computer technology and design. She had to stay late at school but to her it was worth it, the extra hours. It scared Dad, and he made sure she had a can of mace for Mace. A family joke. It broke him when he got the call she was found in an alley on her way home, half-clothed and with no phone, a full can of mace next to her. It"d be an understatement to say Dad was never the same after that. He lost his job when they found drugs in his urine tests, so he turned to peddling them on the streets. We didn"t see him for a full week when it was Linden"s turn to pick up the phone to the police"s number. He was 14, and working as hard as he could to keep us all together, lying to social workers and neighbors, pulling hours at the gas station. When he went down to the station to identify the corpse, it was the last straw, and we were all shipped up and sent out to orphanages and foster homes.

So began my extra ordinary life, living from home to home, going to school when I could, playing the game. Always the game. The one constant in my short, ugly life, the companion to my every misery. Like millions, i considered ending it all. After the Upturn, the government passed legal consent to euthanize those who applied to the program. I even got in the line at the offices to sign up, at 16 years old, 8 years after the last time I knew what a family was. I got up to the desk clerk at 11:59, to this shriveled old hag. I opened my mouth to say good morning, because even with the decomposition of society, I still had manners, and this witch held a hand up and said, in absolute snotty authority,

"Please wait. The game has started."

On the edge of the cliff, about to throw myself off, I started to laugh. Trivia Hour wouldn"t even let me end my life. So that"s when I stopped being sad, stopped feeling like a pitiful sad sack of trash, and got angry instead. Angry at the game, angry at my life, angry at what I had lost, angry that my sister was killed for a heart because no one had one left to give.

I"m tired of waiting for a game to tell me if I"m going to make something of my life, if I"m going to break the chains on question 20. I"m going to break them when I decide, and I"ve decide I"m breaking them now. Trivia Hour won"t get a second chance because I"ve no heart to give. Join me if you"re ready"

### The Rise of Trivia Hour

The rise of Trivia Hour was meteoric, almost as if it had been orchestrated by some unseen hand. It started as a simple app, a pastime for those looking to kill a few minutes or a couple of hours. But as the years went by, it morphed into something far more sinister. The game’s creators, a shadowy group with no public identity, knew exactly how to tap into the desperation and hope that had become the currency of our world. Each question, each round, each heart became a lifeline for millions, and a noose for just as many.

The concept was deceptively simple: answer twenty questions correctly to secure a new life, a clean slate, and an escape from the endless grind of poverty and despair. The game began with seemingly innocuous questions about everyday facts—what is the capital of France? What is the largest mammal? These easy questions were designed to lure players in, to give them a taste of victory and a false sense of security. As the game progressed, the questions grew increasingly complex and obscure. “What is the number of chromosomes in a banana?” or “How many legs does a centipede have?” These were not just difficult; they were almost impossible for the average person to answer without prior knowledge or extensive research.

The stakes were high. Each incorrect answer meant instant elimination, a harsh reminder of the brutal reality of the game. But the real catch was the heart system. Players could accumulate hearts, which acted as a safety net for one wrong answer. These hearts were incredibly valuable, and the game’s mechanics were designed to make them scarce and difficult to obtain. The only way to get a heart was through referrals—convincing someone to enter your username as a referral code. This turned the game into a social ordeal, as people frantically tried to gather as many referrals as possible.

The heart system added an additional layer of complexity and desperation. Players had to balance their immediate need for a heart against the risk of revealing their username to strangers. Trust became a rare commodity, and friendships were often strained or destroyed in the pursuit of hearts. The game’s creators knew this, and they exploited it to the fullest. The tension and emotional rollercoaster that Trivia Hour provided were not just a byproduct but the primary goal. They thrived on the anxiety, the hope, and the despair of their players.

The game’s popularity soared, reaching a point where it became impossible to ignore. At 12 in the afternoon and 6 in the evening, the entire world seemed to stop. Billions of people huddled around their screens, fingers dancing over keyboards in a frantic bid to secure their future. The atmosphere was electric, a mix of exhilaration and dread that kept players hooked. Each correct answer felt like a small victory, each wrong answer a step closer to oblivion.

And so, Trivia Hour became more than just a game. It was a cultural phenomenon, a constant presence in the lives of billions. It defined relationships, shaped economies, and even influenced political decisions. In a world where hope was a scarce resource, Trivia Hour was the ultimate gamble, a game where the stakes were nothing less than life and death.

### The Highs and Lows of Trivia Hour

The feeling of getting a question right is indescribable. It’s a surge of adrenaline that courses through your veins, igniting every nerve ending and sending a jolt of exhilaration straight to your brain. For a brief, blissful moment, you are on top of the world, the master of your fate. The screen flashes green, confirming your correct answer, and you can almost hear the cheers of millions of other players around the globe. Your heart pounds in your chest, and a wide, triumphant grin spreads across your face. This is what keeps people coming back, time and time again. The game is designed to make you feel like a winner, even if just for a second.

But the high is always followed by an inevitable low. The sting of a wrong answer is visceral, a gut-wrenching feeling that makes your stomach twist into knots. The screen flashes red, and the words "Game Over" appear with cold, unyielding finality. It’s a moment of sheer despair, a crushing reminder of your inadequacies and failures. The room spins, and the world around you seems to blur and fade. For a brief moment, you feel like you’ve been punched in the gut. The disappointment is profound, and it lingers long after the initial shock has passed.

The emotional impact of Trivia Hour is profound. The highs are euphoric, a fleeting sense of accomplishment and triumph. But the lows are devastating, a stark reminder of your vulnerability and shortcomings. This rollercoaster of emotions creates a psychological dependence, keeping players hooked and desperate for another chance. The game thrives on this dependence, knowing that the emotional stakes are just as high as the literal stakes.

For many, the game becomes an obsession, a constant presence in their lives. They live and breathe for those two hours each day when Trivia Hour is live. They spend hours studying, researching, and practicing, all in the hope of achieving that elusive perfect score. They sacrifice sleep, meals, and even relationships to give themselves the best possible chance. The game consumes them, and they become a part of its intricate web of desperation and hope.

The feelings of joy and despair are not just fleeting; they shape your identity and define your worth. Each correct answer reinforces your sense of self-worth, making you feel capable and intelligent. Each wrong answer shatters that fragile illusion, leaving you feeling inadequate and powerless. The game becomes a reflection of your life, a microcosm of your struggles and triumphs.

The emotional manipulation is intentional and relentless. The creators of Trivia Hour know exactly how to keep players hooked, how to make them feel both elation and despair. They design the game to be as addictive as possible, using psychological tricks to keep players coming back for more. The anticipation of the next question, the hope of a correct answer, and the dread of a wrong one are all part of the game’s allure.

In the end, the highs and lows of Trivia Hour are more than just a game. They are a reflection of the human condition, a testament to our desire for success and our fear of failure. They are a reminder that in a world where hope is scarce, even a small victory can feel like a monumental achievement, and even a small setback can feel like the end of the world.

### The Rarity and Value of Hearts

Hearts in Trivia Hour are not just symbols of emotional resilience; they are the most sought-after commodities in a world already drowning in desperation. Initially, obtaining a heart seemed like a simple task—a mere matter of convincing a friend or relative to enter your username as a referral code. However, as the game's popularity exploded, so did the demand for hearts. The scarcity of this precious resource turned the game into a cutthroat competition, where every heart was a lifeline and every player a potential adversary.

The value of a heart skyrocketed, transforming it from a mere in-game benefit to a prized asset worth its weight in gold. In a world where the stakes were life and death, a single heart could mean the difference between survival and oblivion. The intense desire for hearts led to a surge in nefarious activities, as players went to extreme lengths to secure as many as possible.

One of the most common methods was the creation of fake accounts. Players would set up multiple fake profiles, using them to gather referrals from unsuspecting friends and family members. This tactic, while effective, was fraught with risks. The creators of Trivia Hour, ever vigilant, implemented stringent verification measures to detect and ban fake accounts. This led to a constant cat-and-mouse game, where players would continuously devise new ways to evade detection while amassing as many hearts as possible.

The demand for hearts also fueled a black market where players would trade real-world goods and services for hearts. A single heart could be exchanged for food, shelter, or even a life-saving operation. This created a bizarre economy within the game, where the value of a heart often surpassed that of tangible assets. The more desperate players found themselves trapped in a cycle of trading their most valuable possessions for a chance at a better life, only to be met with the same harsh reality each time they failed to secure a heart.

The pressure to obtain hearts led to a rise in identity theft and document forgery. Players would steal the identities of others, creating fake profiles to gain their hearts. This was particularly prevalent in poorer regions where the stakes were even higher. Families would concoct elaborate schemes to fake relationships, creating fake marriages and even children to provide the necessary verifications for multiple accounts. The game’s creators, aware of these practices, implemented stricter identity verification processes, but they could never fully eradicate the problem.

The desperation for hearts also led to violent confrontations. Players would resort to stealing phones, hacking accounts, and even committing physical assaults to secure a heart. The stakes were too high to play fair, and the lines between right and wrong blurred as players became more ruthless in their pursuit of victory. Trivia Hour had become a battlefield, where every player was a soldier in a relentless war for survival.

The game’s creators thrived on this chaos, feeding off the fear and desperation of their players. They knew that as long as the demand for hearts remained high, the game would continue to thrive. The rare and valuable nature of hearts kept players hooked, driving them to extremes and ensuring their continued engagement. In this world of desperation, a heart was more than just a game mechanic; it was a symbol of hope and a ticket to a better future.

### The Former Options: A Desperate Family's Struggle

I was born into a family that had already been ravaged by the brutal realities of the Upturn. My parents, once thriving in the lower end of the middle class, found their lives upended by the economic collapse. The game, Trivia Hour, had initially been a fun way to connect with others and learn new facts. But as the economy spiraled downward, it transformed into our lifeline, our last hope for a better future.

My parents, John and Maria, worked tirelessly to keep us afloat. They took on three jobs each, working long hours for meager pay. My older siblings, Macy and Linden, were given cheap phones and Trivia Hour accounts at a young age. They were only three and two when the game first came out, but they quickly became adept at navigating its questions. John and Maria hoped that by the time we were old enough, the game would have stabilized and provided a real opportunity for a fresh start.

But the Upturn didn’t stabilize. It only got worse. By the time I was born, we had been forced out of our suburban home and into a cramped apartment in the city. The economic downturn had hit the lower-end middle class the hardest, and we were struggling to make ends meet. Meals were often skipped, and the once warm and cozy home we had known was now a shadow of its former self.

My mother, Maria, was particularly devastated. She had always been a vibrant and optimistic person, but the constant stress and fear had worn her down. She fell ill frequently, and her health steadily declined until she finally succumbed to an infection. It was a devastating blow for my father, John. He lost his job when he tested positive for drugs in a random urine test. The stress and desperation had taken their toll, and he turned to peddling drugs on the streets to survive.

Linden, at just fourteen, had to take on the responsibility of caring for us. He worked at a gas station for long hours, lying to social workers and neighbors to keep us together. The strain was evident on his young face; he looked more like an adult than a teenager. Macy, now fifteen, was still required to attend school, despite her own struggles. She joined an after-school club centered around computer technology and design, hoping it would give her an edge in the game and perhaps a future beyond our desperate circumstances.

The game had become our entire existence. Every day, we would gather around the dining table, hunched over our phones, fingers dancing over the screens in a desperate bid to secure hearts. We studied relentlessly, memorizing facts and trivia, hoping that one day we would achieve the perfect score. But the game was unforgiving, and each failure felt like a blow to our already fragile spirits.

It was during this tumultuous period that my siblings and I were born. My parents, desperate for more chances, hoped that more of us would increase our odds. They named me "Pepper" in the hope that I would bring a spark of joy and resilience to our family. But as I grew, the hardships only intensified. We moved from one rundown apartment to another, each one more dismal than the last.

Dad’s descent into peddling drugs became more pronounced, and the police eventually caught up with him. It was a brutal end, and the loss was devastating. We were sent to different orphanages and foster homes, and I lost touch with my siblings. The only constant in my life became the game, a cruel reminder of what we had lost and what we were fighting for.

In the chaos and despair, Trivia Hour was both a refuge and a torment. It was a distraction from our reality, a fleeting sense of hope that kept us going. But it was also a source of immense pressure and heartbreak. Each heart we failed to secure felt like a nail in the coffin of our dreams, a reminder that our lives were defined by a game that we had no control over.

### The Aftermath: A Life of Fragmented Existence

The fall of my father was the beginning of the end for our family. After his arrest and subsequent imprisonment for drug trafficking, the fragile structure we had built crumbled into dust. We were scattered to different orphanages and foster homes, our lives ripped apart at the seams. I was placed in a small, overcrowded facility on the outskirts of the city. The orphanage was run by a stern matron who treated the children more like inmates than young souls in need of care. Meals were sparse, and the few toys we had were broken and outdated.

School was a distant memory, overshadowed by the relentless grind of survival. I would attend classes sporadically, my mind often drifting back to the game and the hope it represented. Trivia Hour was my escape, a sanctuary where I could forget the harsh realities of my life. I spent hours hunched over a second-hand smartphone, my fingers moving swiftly over the screen, desperate for that one correct answer that could change our fate.

The loss of my siblings was the most devastating blow. I had no idea where Macy and Linden were, and the thought of them haunted me. I would sit by my window, staring out at the grey sky, wondering if they were safe and if they were also playing the game. The orphanage provided no comfort or solace; it was a place of cold, institutionalized cruelty. The other children were no different, each of us trapped in our own personal hells, struggling to find a semblance of hope.

In the orphanage, I formed a small circle of friends, all of us united by our shared suffering. We would huddle together at night, sharing stories of our lives before the Upturn and our dreams for the future. But these dreams felt increasingly distant, overshadowed by the harsh realities of our existence. The game became our common ground, a link between us that transcended the cruelty of our circumstances.

I was fifteen now, and I had grown more adept at navigating the world of Trivia Hour. I had learned to manipulate the system, creating fake accounts and trading hearts in the underground market. It was a dangerous game, and I often wondered if I would get caught. But the stakes were too high to play it safe. Each heart I secured brought us one step closer to a better life, a chance to escape the orphanage and the endless cycle of poverty and despair.

The game was more than just a tool for survival; it was a source of power and control. In a world where we had none, Trivia Hour gave us a sense of agency. We could study, strategize, and compete, all in the hope of achieving that elusive perfect score. It was a stark contrast to the rest of our lives, where every decision was dictated by forces beyond our control.

Despite the hardships, I held onto a glimmer of hope. I knew that one day, I would break free from the chains that bound us. Trivia Hour was my ticket out, my way of proving that even in the darkest times, there was always a light at the end of the tunnel. And as long as I had the game, I had a chance to reclaim my life and my future.

### The Last Straw: A Desperate Decision

The final straw came unexpectedly, one cold winter evening when I was 16 years old. I had just finished a long day at the orphanage, my mind preoccupied with thoughts of Trivia Hour and the hearts I needed to secure. The matron had assigned us a particularly grueling task, making us sweep the freezing streets until our hands were numb and our bodies ached with exhaustion. I was on my way back to the orphanage when I was approached by a group of older boys, their intentions clear but masked by polite smiles.

They offered me food and a warm place to stay if I helped them with a small favor. I knew what they wanted, and I knew the risks. But the promise of a heart was too enticing to pass up. I agreed to their request, thinking it would be a one-time deal, a desperate measure to improve our chances of survival. Little did I know that this decision would set off a chain of events that would change my life forever.

That night, as I lay in my makeshift bed, the reality of my choice began to sink in. The favor I had done for the older boys had tied me to a dangerous underworld of crime and deceit. The more I tried to distance myself, the deeper I got entangled. Every day, I was forced to make more and more compromising decisions, each one bringing me closer to the edge of legality and morality.

The pressure was relentless. The orphanage was a constant reminder of my failures and the limitations of my life. The cold, sterile walls and the indifferent faces of the matron and other staff made me feel more like a prisoner than a child. I longed for a way out, a chance to break free from the cycle of poverty, desperation, and helplessness that had defined my existence.

The government’s euthanasia program, which had been introduced as a response to the escalating despair and hopelessness, became an increasingly appealing option. The idea of ending my suffering and escaping the relentless grind of Trivia Hour was intoxicating. I began to research the program, learning about the requirements and the procedure. The thought of a peaceful end, free from pain and suffering, was a stark contrast to the life I was living.

I gathered the necessary documents and made plans to go to the local office. I knew it would be a difficult decision, but I was ready. The final blow came when I received news that my brother, Linden, had been killed in a violent altercation over a heart. The loss was devastating, and it pushed me to the brink. The thought of losing another loved one because of the game was unbearable. It was the last straw that broke my already fragile resolve.

On the day I was set to go to the office, I stood on the edge of a cliff, the cold wind whipping against my face. I took a deep breath and looked out at the vast expanse of the sea below. The idea of jumping felt like a release, a way to end the endless cycle of pain and suffering. But just as I was about to take that final step, I heard the familiar chime of my phone. It was the orphanage matron, calling to remind me about a routine meeting.

As I held the phone to my ear, a strange sense of calm washed over me. The game had started, and it was a reminder that even in the darkest moments, I was not alone. Trivia Hour was a constant in my life, a cruel but persistent companion that had seen me through the worst of times. And for the first time in a long while, I felt a spark of determination. I wasn’t ready to give up just yet. I had one more fight left in me, and I was going to use every tool at my disposal to win it.

### The Spark of Resistance

Standing there, the cold air biting my face as I clutched the phone, a wave of emotions crashed over me. Anger, despair, and a deep-seated frustration boiled to the surface. Trivia Hour had taken everything from me, had reduced my life to a series of questions and answers, a relentless cycle of highs and lows. It had stolen my family, my dreams, and even my will to live. But as the matron’s voice droned on in the background, something inside me shifted.

I started to laugh, a sound that echoed off the cold, stone walls of the cliff. It was a hollow, bitter laugh, but it was laughter nonetheless. For the first time in what felt like an eternity, I wasn’t feeling the crushing weight of despair. Instead, I felt a strange sense of clarity and purpose. Trivia Hour couldn’t dictate my life anymore. It wasn’t just a game to me; it was a tool of manipulation, a mechanism designed to control and exploit.

As I looked out at the vast expanse of the ocean, I realized that my life, my future, was mine to control. I didn’t need Trivia Hour to give me a chance. I didn’t need a heart to define my worth. I was more than just a series of answers, more than a number in a database. I was a person with agency, with the power to make my own decisions and forge my own path.

The anger that had been simmering inside me for so long turned into a fierce determination. I was done waiting for some random question to decide my fate. I was going to take control, to break free from the chains that Trivia Hour had wrapped around my life. I was going to fight back, to show that even in a world driven by desperation and manipulation, there was still hope.

I turned my phone off and tucked it into my pocket. I didn’t need it anymore. I was going to find my own way, my own path. And I was going to invite anyone who felt trapped by the game to join me. We didn’t need Trivia Hour’s hearts to save us. We needed to save ourselves.

### A Call to Arms

I stood on the edge of the cliff, my heart pounding with a mix of fear and determination. I knew what I had to do. Trivia Hour had taken everything from me, but it wouldn’t have the last word. I took a deep breath, feeling the cold air fill my lungs and fuel my resolve. I was going to break free from its grasp, to show that there was another way, another path.

I pulled out my phone, the one that had been my lifeline and my tormentor. This time, I wasn’t going to play by its rules. I opened my social media accounts and started typing. My message was simple, yet powerful:

"I'm tired of waiting for Trivia Hour to tell me if I'm worth something. I'm done with the game that has stolen my family, my dreams, and my hope. But I'm not alone. If you're ready to break free, to take control of your life, join me. We don't need hearts from a game to define us. We need to define ourselves. Are you with me?"

I hit send, and the message spread like wildfire. It wasn’t long before replies started pouring in, each one a spark of hope that I had lit. People from all walks of life, all corners of the world, were responding. They were tired of the game’s manipulation, of living their lives by its rules. They were ready to fight back, to reclaim their agency.

I posted my phone number and set up a group chat, where we could coordinate and support each other. The response was overwhelming. Within hours, we had hundreds of members, all eager to break free from the game’s grip. We shared strategies, resources, and our own stories of struggle and hope. We were building a community, a network of resistance against the game that had controlled so much of our lives.

The plan was simple, yet profound. We would use the game’s own mechanics against it. We would gather referrals, not for hearts, but for a different kind of victory. We would use the game to expose its flaws, to show the world that we were more than just a series of answers. We would fight for our dignity, our worth, and our right to live our lives on our own terms.

I stood on that cliff, my heart filled with a sense of purpose and hope. Trivia Hour wouldn’t break us. We would break it, one heart at a time. And I was ready to lead the charge.

[Story]: Lightspeed Frontier, lives inside the game


By Adam Corres

'bzzz pip pip... Congratulations! You've won a month's supply of Kepler Cola... bzzz pip pip. The intercom switched back to space static.

'Ok. Cool. Are you a real person or a galactaspammer? Only I'm a bit busy right now.'

'bzzz pip... No way, I'm a real life person in the publicity department here at Xenon Pops & Beverages inc., a subsidiary of the one and only Kepler Cola Corporation. You've aced, almost aced, our main prize because your, I must say, fabulous star-rise cocktail, incorporating 3 parts Kepler Cola, was selected by our panel of judges who reflect a cross section of representative sentient organic life forms and cola-absorbing, naturally occurring, mineral and liquid sentient chemical compounds. You almost won overall. Your mix tastes great! It also has useful secondary applications, although mostly involving bacteria and ferric oxide.'

'What was first prize?' An array of warning lights flashed around the cabin.

'bzzz pip... That would be a lifetime's supply of Kepler Cola, the most popular drink in the... bzzz pip.'

'Ok. I'll pick it up next time I swing around the core.' The onboard gravity replicator blinked off and popcorn filled the cockpit. It hung in the air like a complaint. The usually soundless gravity replicator, a wide metallic collar held in the vacuum cavity between the dual layers of the hull and spinning almost frictionlessly under the force of molybdenum magnets, was such a thoroughly basic device that the crew rarely remembered it until something 'went all spanners'. As the collar abraded away carbon from the latest inward dent in the hardly flawless exterior hull, matter entered the vacuum and oscillations turned to noise and heat.

The instrument panel took a neat kick from the pilot, blinked, re-calibrated via a feed-back loop and switched back on. As the inner and outer skins of the hull eased further apart under tension, a gravitational field formed, the noise stopped and fluffy popcorn balls stuck to all available surfaces. A peach pit rattled down the stabiliser panels.

'bzzz... Sounds better. Are you saying you're not on a Government world or station now? How would it be possible to slip past Compliance and leave the atmosphere? How do you get re-supplied?...pip.'

'I'm not registered with the Authority, or aligned to any corporation. I'm not into all that shkush. It's stupid anyway, all that promising within the constitution that the black hole serves the people and the inner planets will never fall in, when that's obviously happening; just look at the time difference between you and the frontier. People out here are living life faster. I like the idea I'll get more birthday presents than I'll give.'

'bzzz... The discrepancy can be explained by seeing only one side of a balancing distortion. All the candidates have been saying so. You cannot seriously be out on the Frontier alone... pip.'

'Kepler Cola's made off world, right? They say the central hub has no space for factories, fruit trees or anything else but people.' Another kick connected the flight-deck to holo-image immersion feed and Exia risked a glance sideways to see with whom she was talking. Without warning, the PR exec found himself dropped into a holo-immersed projection with a metal block the size of a bus pivoting through space straight at him.

'Warping skank! Mind out! What the... was that?' He fell down, seeking the reassurance of a solid surface.

'It helps if you close your eyes if you're not used to it. The metal and carbon stuff is just another bunch of modules spinning crazy dances. It's the same old crash-mash every day. I'm going to have to heal my hull after this one though. The good news is switching to visual stops that bzzz pip rubbish. Yes, I have a scavenger band ship, at least I was in a band but my brother went off. He was annoying, so I gave him the code for the airlock and asked him to go and test it.'

'He died?'

'No such luck. The cheeky brat put a suit on first, vented outside, separated a command module I'd salvaged and spent half a cycle shooting my ship's tail off to annoy me.'

'Why?'

'Well, for a start it annoyed me but that would also be to break modules off to compile his own ship. How do you not know this stuff?'

'It isn't knowledge on the central syllabus, no. The approved press also don't talk about that, although our news takes a day to clear regulator checks; or more if it's about the black hole. They gave approval for direct communication with you because it's about cola.'

'If it's about cola, that's the priority. Are you worried that your most powerful population centre is oblivious to life outside, conflicting evidence, unsanctioned opinions, reality?'

'You definitely are our most sarcastic finalist. I see your entry includes an offensive adjective in the description which, when taken in isolation from the noun...'

'In space, no one can hear you swear. I can see rebellion isn't quite your thing. I love your pop by the way. My relatives way back were peach farmers and I guess I've always liked the real peach juice in it. I know you'll give me that speech about it being a secret recipe of a dozen chemical compounds with four radioactively-induced herbal-style products and blah blah but I taste peach pop when I drink it.'

Exia scraped a heel across the dashboard and a display of options scrolled until she found the one she wanted. 'I'm going to use the tractor beam now to pull this module in. Mind the glare.'

A blue-white finger shafted out and pinned one of the spinning pieces of debris like a moth to the night sky. In silence, it drew the block inward and the ship rotated with the photo-mechanical effort until both watchers were blinded as the arc of a reddened sun crossed their vision. The raw light flashed off the module's flank and through aching eyes they caught glimpses of its intricate design.

Only Exia felt the temperature rising for the second time that day as latent heat seeped through and flooded the compartment. She feathered the blast screens to deflect heat until the ship turned through and beyond. Raising them again, Exia manoeuvred the module until it locked with a clunk onto a key node of the hull.

'So that's how it's done. I scavenge modules off corporate factions' ships and bolt them onto this one. A medical pod this time – and that's how I re-supply. Some of the pilots don't even care what gets lifted. The boat's not theirs I suppose, or they can't turn off course to deal with scavengers. Sometimes they ask for a date but mostly I just snap bits off them and go.'

Exia stood up for the first time in the conversation, put on a discreet visor and started to read.

'What will you do with the medical pod? Sell it?'

'I keep anything that might be useful and if it isn't useful, I keep it for extra armour. It says here, if I get diabetes from drinking too much of your cola, there's a programme for re-coating my liver with working liver cells to fix it. I can run that myself, according to Poodle.'

'Oh no. You really shouldn't search on Poodle. The Azedware Corporation will note the condition to your profile and downgrade your life insurance rating.'

It dawned upon him that this might be inconsequential, given the vast and unpiloted blocks bouncing into one another behind her incredulous expression.

'If I did report you as a dangerous delinquent, I suppose it wouldn't make much difference?'

'You can if you want but there's not much sign of a Compliance mob out here. I'd scramble the shape of my ship and then my containers and components couldn't be told apart from anyone else's anyway, so go knock yourself out.' She honestly didn't care. 'Has anything improved at the glorious galactic centre in the last two years then?'

'Definitely. There's a major debate about who owns and controls the regulation of time. The corporations prefer to know where they stand legally and the ownership of abstracts and constructs is a whole new field to carve up. If time can be owned, it can be licensed.'

'Away from a planet it's all the same, hours, day and night. You can go mad from having fewer points of reference, like me. What's bed-time? I might never walk into a shop again, so there goes opening hours and I think I've completely lost my concept of Tuesday.'

'Don't you miss it? Planetary life, I mean. Home, routine and family?'

'Home was the Wexler-Watson Corporation. "Hush kids. Comply or your parents don't get their increment because if we work for Watson, Watson has a beneficial shareholding in our family because he loves families", which comes of being a computer by the way because he's compensating. Is that lifestyle?'

'Watson isn't evil and neither is PAL for that matter.'

'Who runs Xenon, of course.' Exia threw he head back to laugh and then lost the elegant high- ground, picking popcorn out of her spiky hair. 'I forgot you work for that creepy drone covered in disgusting skuzz, so will be used to licking a few itchy sockets.'

'Which is prejudiced by the way; which is even worse than murder. PAL was originally designated Pizza and Laundry, so began as a delivery bot capable of machine learning. The drone's intelligence and abilities have reached such a level now that it"s too valuable to deploy outside, so sends out humans to gather data or do anything dangerous. I think PAL just wants to find its purpose, now that all the basic service jobs can be delegated to people, although he still heats pizza at AGMs for shareholders. The only problem is he sometimes takes advice literally. He was told it's a bad idea to go outside without a waterproof outer layer, so he got himself completely coated in human skin. The donor was very well compensated.'

'I'm sure. Well, I prefer it up here. It's not just freedom. I've seen things beyond description. Sprays of sparking magnesium set against the rising disc of a new world as someone's propulsion pod cheese-graters down their hull, skimming a solar mass to collect the denser hydrogen for fuel – you did know space is made of hydrogen and that's free fuel for scavengers? Or running through another faction's flotilla while they're stuck in the queue to hydrate their breakfast gloop and then pulsing to light speed like a comet through their stupid little campfire. Yeah, that's not as cool though as using the tractor to move dust particles in a nebula, which I did so I could write my name in letters twenty miles high that will stand for a few million years. I was the first to do that, incidentally. What did you do on your birthday?'

'I saw an approved film graded 5 for stimulation, which unashamedly misrepresented cultural norms. Okay then, you have a good point but here's a question: How did you get a ship and weapons in the first place? That's not cheap and I don't see an executive currency implant in your finger.'

'Well, put it this way, my surname's Skuttle.'

'What, really? Like the inventor of the lattice neutrino cannon?'

'Just like that, yeah. Norvo and Allegra Skuttle were my parents. It was a nightmare. They were always fighting. Then they improved a solar particle harvester and got investment from the corporations and turned into rich people always fighting, so my brother and I took off a lot. Then Dad discovered how to harden neutrinos into subatomic fabrics, so the forces and bonds between them really hit and separated molecular bonds rather than the neutrinos swishing straight through things, so the lattice neutrino cannon was born.

The original was on our kitchen table because Dad said if he completed it in the lab then Wexler would take it away. Mum came home and they started shouting and arguing about not telling Watson, then crunch, we were orphans. There was no mess, just us standing in the hall, trying to get our rods and cones back. We didn't hang around that day and spent our parents' Wexcoins on a basic flight module, then went back for the bazooka. I still remember trying to carry it down the walkways. When we found we could rebuild and develop our ship using bits blown off other module ships by molecular de-bonding, that was it: The future calling.'

Exia paused. 'Of course, there are other private raiders up here and some skunk designs being tested. I bet you didn't know about those, although they're sure to be corporate. Some factions won't even talk to anyone. They just see you as fair harvest, whether you're commercial haulage or scavenger. There's a particularly nasty bunch called the Twinblades who target your interior inertia negators, so when a ship at high speed stops, after running away or something, the pilot's momentum stays the same and they smash through their front panels, closely followed by everything else in the vessel, just spewing bodies and junk into space. Instant abstract expressionism.'

'That's quite a lot to handle for, what are you, a teenager? I couldn't help noticing that you fly your ship by kicking the controls.'

'That's about reach. This compartment's made for two pilots.'

'Have you even completed pilot training?'

'What's training? When you play pool, do you see it as an exercise in advanced trigonometry or do you just pick up the stick and poke?'

'Fair enough, although it sounds hard staying sane up there without anyone around to talk to. You should realise that one day someone will move into that seat next to you and I wonder if then you'll stop kicking quite so hard, young lady.'

Exia made a non-committal huff and checked a compartmental integrity scan, then slipped a couple of fingertips lightly over the joystick, circled his hologram around the room until it stood in and out of the console, looked innocently into his eyes, tilted her head and shut it down hard with an upward thrust of her knee.

'Ouch. Whoah.' Despite the distance, he folded anyway. This so wasn't in the training. 'I'm not without feelings you know and I was also beginning to appreciate your attitude, although I could never be like you, not that you've even asked my name. It took me years to get to H-grade responsibility in this job. If I go further, that's use of a spa and discounted meds. Look, I can help you.

We have a Xenon continental class mega-freighter coming in from the Algolian wormhole nine hours from now. I could ask them to check your hull and supplies or re-stock your oxygen but they aren't in communication range until they fall out this side of the cusp. It's amazing they always survive the deceleration from warp jump to super-luminal and then the step down to light-speed, but that's thanks to Watson because he cares.'

'...and loves families, I know. Does it have a lifetime's supply of your gorgeous peach pop on it?' A bright smile, at last.

'Several lifetimes, I should think.'

'Ok. Then you were wrong.'

'Sorry?'

'About me settling for second prize... bzz pip.' Dots of popcorn turned into white lines as Exia sent

the scavenger ship to light-speed."
