### Mei's Escape

Mei's eyes widened in horror as the flames enveloped them. The intense heat hit her face immediately, causing her to scream. Her hands flew up to shield her head, but the flames licked through her fingers. She struggled, kicking and twisting, trying to break free from Tobi's grip. But his hold was firm, almost as if he were afraid she would change her mind and stop.

"Let me go!" she cried, her voice tinged with desperation. "This isn't what I agreed to!"

Tobi's face remained impassive, his eyes still fixed on the flames. "It's the only way," he said, his voice calm and detached. "Trust me."

Mei's heart pounded in her chest as she stared into his eyes. There was something almost mesmerizing about them, something that made her want to obey. But she also felt a surge of fear, a fear that she was about to do something incredibly foolish.

The flames grew brighter, and the heat intensified. Mei could feel the skin on her arms and legs beginning to burn. She tried to take a breath, but the smoke was thick and filling her lungs. She felt herself losing consciousness, her body weakening with each passing second.

Just as she was about to give in to the overwhelming heat, something snapped inside her. With a final, desperate effort, she twisted her body and managed to break free from Tobi's grip. She rolled away from the fire, hitting the cold ground with a thud. Pain shot through her, but she didn't stop. She scrambled to her feet and ran as fast as she could, her legs pumping hard to put as much distance between herself and the fire as possible.

Behind her, she could still hear Tobi's voice, calling out to her, but she didn't stop. She didn't dare to stop. Every step took her further away from the flames, away from Tobi, and away from whatever terrible fate awaited her in that fire.

She ran through the narrow streets of New York, her breath coming in short, ragged gasps. The city seemed empty and silent, as if it was watching her run. She didn't stop to think about where she was going or what she would do next. All she knew was that she had to keep running, keep away from the fire and from Tobi.

As she ran, Mei's mind raced. She couldn't understand why Tobi had tried to drag her into the flames. Was he trying to help her? Or was he trying to harm her? She didn't know, and that uncertainty filled her with a deep, gnawing fear. She had trusted him, and now she was more lost and afraid than ever.

But Mei was determined. She would find her brother, and she would find a way to stop whatever was chasing her. Even if it meant running forever, she would never stop until she had answers.

### Tobi's Revelation

Tobi watched Mei run from the fireplace, his expression a mixture of concern and amusement. He had expected her to be curious, but not to outright reject his plan so violently. He shook his head slightly, a small chuckle escaping his lips as he watched her figure disappear into the distance.

"Alright, Mei," he muttered to himself, "if you want to play it that way, we'll do this another way."

Tobi walked over to the fireplace, his small frame almost blending into the shadows cast by the flickering flames. He reached into the fire with his bare hands, causing the flames to hiss and retreat. From the ashes, he pulled out a small, intricately carved jade pendant. The jade was cool to the touch, and Tobi held it up to examine it closely.

"This is your brother's," he said softly, as if speaking to a pet. "It's the only way he can communicate with you. But it's also the key to his location."

Tobi's eyes narrowed as he studied the pendant. He turned it over in his hands, feeling the smooth surface and the subtle etchings. "Your brother is in danger, Mei. And if you want to find him, you'll have to come back."

Tobi placed the jade pendant back into the fire, where it disappeared into the glowing embers. He then turned and walked towards the door, leaving the fireplace and the remaining ashes behind.

"Think about it, Mei," he called out as he stepped into the hallway. "This isn't just about finding your brother. It's about understanding the magic that binds you both. And that magic, it's stronger than you might think."

Tobi's footsteps echoed down the empty hallway as he made his way towards the front door. Mei was still running, still afraid, but Tobi knew that she would come back. She had no other choice.

As he opened the door and stepped outside, Tobi couldn't help but smile. The girl was brave, stronger than he had given her credit for. And that was exactly what he needed.

### Mei's Reflection

Mei slowed her frantic pace as she reached a quieter part of the city. Her breath came in ragged gasps, and her legs felt like they were made of lead. She leaned against a brick wall, trying to catch her breath. Her heart was still pounding in her chest, and she could still feel the heat of the flames from moments ago. But as the adrenaline wore off, a deep sense of fear took its place.

She thought back to Tobi and the jade pendant he had shown her. His words echoed in her mind, and she couldn't shake the feeling that he was telling the truth. Her brother was in danger, and the pendant was the only clue she had. But why would Tobi help her? And why would he lead her into such a dangerous situation?

Mei's thoughts were interrupted by the sound of footsteps approaching. She looked up to see a group of teenagers her own age, their faces twisted in curiosity. They stared at her, their eyes wide with a mixture of fear and excitement. She knew she couldn't stay here. They might recognize her, or worse, they might think she was dangerous.

Mei pushed herself away from the wall and started to walk quickly, but not too quickly. She needed to stay hidden, but she also needed to get as far away from the Magic Detective's office as possible. She turned a corner and found herself in an alley, the perfect place to hide.

She leaned against the cold, brick wall once more, her mind racing. She had to find her brother, and she had to do it soon. But how? Tobi had said the magic that bound her and her brother was strong, but she had no idea how to use it. And she had no idea if Tobi was really on her side.

Mei closed her eyes, taking a deep breath. She needed to think, to figure out a plan. She couldn't keep running forever. She had to face her fears and find a way to save her brother.

As she stood there, lost in thought, a small, green light caught her eye. It was faint, but it was there. Mei's heart skipped a beat. Could it be her brother? She reached out, her hand trembling, and the light disappeared. She opened her eyes to see a small, golden Buddha statue on the other side of the alley. The light must have come from it.

Mei felt a small smile creep onto her face. Maybe magic wasn't as mysterious or dangerous as she thought. Maybe it was just another tool she could use to find her brother. She took one last look at the Buddha statue before turning and heading back in the direction of the Magic Detective's office.

She had to talk to Tobi again. She had to find out more about the magic that connected her and her brother. And she had to find a way to use it to save him.

### Tobi's Decision

Back at the Magic Detective's office, Tobi sat at his cluttered desk, the jade pendant still glowing faintly in his hand. He looked at it for a long time, lost in thought. The pendant was more than just a key to finding Mei's brother; it was a connection to a power that was as dangerous as it was powerful. Tobi had always been fascinated by such forces, but he had never encountered anything quite like this before.

He knew that Mei was running scared, and he couldn't blame her. The idea of being dragged into a roaring fire was enough to make anyone run. But Tobi also knew that Mei was brave, stronger than most people he had ever met. He needed her help, but he couldn't force her. He needed to find a way to make her understand the importance of their mission.

Tobi decided that he would give Mei some space. He needed to show her that he was on her side, that he was willing to help her in any way he could. He stood up from his desk, his small frame almost disappearing in the cluttered room. He walked over to a shelf filled with old books and pulled out one that caught his eye. It was a thick, leather-bound volume, filled with strange symbols and ancient texts.

Tobi opened the book to a specific page and began to read. His eyes scanned the text quickly, his mind absorbing the information. He had been studying magic for as long as he could remember, but this was different. This was a power that was beyond anything he had ever encountered.

Tobi closed the book and stood up. He knew what he had to do. He needed to prepare himself, to be ready for whatever might come. He walked over to the fireplace and added more wood to the dwindling fire, stoking the flames until they roared back to life. He then reached into his desk drawer and pulled out a small vial of blue liquid. He uncorked it and poured a small amount into a cup, mixing it with a few drops of red liquid. The mixture turned a deep purple, shimmering with an almost magical glow.

Tobi took a deep breath, feeling a sense of determination fill him. He had made a decision. He would protect Mei, guide her, and help her find her brother. But he also knew that this mission would be dangerous, and he would need to be prepared for anything.

Tobi looked at the potion in the cup, then at the jade pendant. He knew that he would need both to face whatever challenges lay ahead. He placed the pendant around his neck and the cup of potion on the desk. He was ready.

As Tobi stood there, the door to the office opened, and Mei walked in. She was still wary, her eyes scanning the room cautiously. Tobi noticed her and smiled, a warm, reassuring smile that seemed to reach her heart despite her fears.

"Welcome back, Mei," he said softly. "I think we have a lot to discuss."

### Mei's Return

Mei hesitated at the doorway, her heart pounding in her chest. The last time she was in this room, she had almost been dragged into a fiery death trap by a strange boy who claimed to understand magic. But something inside her urged her to come back. She needed answers, and she was out of options.

Taking a deep breath, she stepped into the cluttered room. The air was thick with the smell of old paper and chemicals. Tobi was waiting for her at his desk, the jade pendant still around his neck. His eyes met hers with a calm, reassuring expression that made her feel a little less afraid.

"Are you ready to talk?" Tobi asked, his voice gentle but firm.

Mei nodded, though she still felt a knot of anxiety in her stomach. She walked over to the desk, her eyes never leaving Tobi's. "I need to find my brother," she said, her voice steady but low. "You said the jade pendant could help me. But why did you try to drag me into the fire?"

Tobi sighed, running a hand through his tousled brown hair. "I'm sorry, Mei. I didn't mean to scare you. I just wanted to show you the power of the pendant. It's a way to communicate with your brother, but it's also a key to finding him."

Mei's eyes widened as she listened. "You mean he's here in America?"

Tobi nodded. "Yes. But he's in danger, and he needs your help. The magic that binds you two is powerful, but it's also fragile. If we don't use it correctly, we could lose everything."

Mei felt a rush of determination. She couldn't lose her brother. "What do we need to do?"

Tobi leaned back in his chair, his expression serious. "First, we need to understand the magic. It's not just about casting spells or controlling forces. It's about understanding the connections between people, between objects. The jade pendant is a part of that connection. But it's not just the pendant. You have to learn to trust it, to feel its power."

Mei nodded, her mind racing. "I can try," she said. "But I need to know more. How do I use the pendant? How do I find my brother?"

Tobi reached into his desk and pulled out a small notebook filled with strange symbols and drawings. He handed it to Mei. "This is a guide to understanding the magic. It's not an easy task, and it won't happen overnight. But if you're willing to learn, we can find your brother."

Mei took the notebook, her fingers trembling slightly. She looked up at Tobi, her eyes filled with a mix of hope and fear. "I want to find him," she said. "I need to find him. Can you help me?"

Tobi's eyes softened as he looked at her. "I will help you, Mei. But we have to be careful. This magic is powerful, and it's dangerous. We can't make any mistakes."

Mei nodded, her determination stronger than ever. She had faced danger before, and she would face it again. She just needed to find her brother. "I'm ready," she said. "Let's start learning."

Tobi smiled, a warm, reassuring smile that made Mei feel a little less afraid. "Then let's begin," he said. "The journey to find your brother has just started."

### The Journey Begins

With the notebook in hand, Mei and Tobi began their quest to understand the magic that connected them to Mei's brother. Tobi explained that the jade pendant was not just a symbol of their bond but also a conduit for the magic. He showed her how to hold the pendant correctly, how to breathe and focus her thoughts to tap into the power it held.

"Think of your brother," Tobi instructed. "Imagine the two of you standing side by side, connected by the pendant. Feel the warmth, the energy that flows between you. This is how you will communicate with him, and how you will find him."

Mei closed her eyes, trying to follow Tobi's instructions. She thought of her brother, his face, his smile. She could almost feel the warmth of his presence. She opened her eyes and looked at Tobi, who was watching her with a mixture of pride and concern.

"It's not easy," Tobi said. "Using magic requires a lot of focus and patience. But with practice, you'll get better."

Over the next few days, Mei practiced with the pendant, trying to tune into the magic. Tobi taught her how to interpret the signs and symbols in the notebook, and how to use them to navigate the world of magic. Mei's determination was unwavering, and she was determined to master this new skill.

One evening, as they sat by the fireplace, Tobi asked Mei if she felt ready to try communicating with her brother again. Mei nodded, her eyes filled with hope. She held the pendant tightly in her hand and focused on the warmth she had felt before.

"Think of Li," Tobi said softly. "Imagine the pendant connecting you to him. Send him a message."

Mei closed her eyes and concentrated. She could feel the pendant responding to her thoughts, the energy flowing between them. Suddenly, she felt a surge of warmth and a familiar voice in her mind.

"Mei?" It was her brother's voice, clear and distinct.

Mei's eyes filled with tears of joy. "Li! Is that really you?"

"Of course, Mei. I've been trying to reach you," Li's voice replied. "I'm in danger. I need your help."

Mei's heart raced with fear and determination. "I'm coming for you, Li. I'll find you and we'll get out of this together."

Tobi smiled, a sense of satisfaction in his eyes. "You did it, Mei. You've made the first step in finding your brother."

Mei nodded, her eyes still glistening with tears. "We'll find him, Tobi. I promise."

And with that, Mei's journey to save her brother truly began. The magic was a powerful force, and with Tobi's guidance, she was ready to face whatever challenges lay ahead.

### The Hidden Magic

As Mei and Tobi delved deeper into their study of the magic, they discovered that the pendant was not just a simple tool for communication. It was a key to a hidden world, one that lay hidden within the fabric of reality itself. Tobi explained that the magic they were dealing with was not the ordinary kind found in spells and enchantments, but a more fundamental force that intertwined the physical and spiritual realms.

"The jade pendant is more than just a symbol," Tobi said one evening, as they sat by the fireplace, the flames casting a warm glow on their faces. "It's a bridge between our world and the world of spirits. Your brother, Li, has tapped into this power, and now he's trapped in a place between the two worlds."

Mei's eyes widened in horror. "What do you mean? Is he stuck in some kind of spirit realm?"

Tobi nodded. "Yes, but it's not as dangerous as it sounds. The world between our own and the spirit realm is called the Astral Plane. It's a place where the rules of our world don't apply. Time moves differently there, and the physical laws are more flexible. Li has found a way to survive there, but he's not safe."

Mei felt a surge of fear and determination. "We have to get him out. How do we do it?"

Tobi reached into his desk and pulled out another book, even older and more worn than the first. He opened it to a specific page and showed Mei a drawing of a complex symbol made up of intertwined lines and circles.

"This is a portal spell," Tobi explained. "It will allow us to travel to the Astral Plane and find Li. But it's not just about casting the spell. We need to prepare ourselves, to attune our minds and bodies to the magic."

Mei studied the symbol carefully. "It looks difficult," she said, her voice tinged with worry.

"It is," Tobi replied. "But with practice and focus, we can do it. The key is to stay calm and focused. Any hesitation or doubt will weaken the spell."

Mei nodded, feeling a mix of fear and determination. She knew that this was their only chance to save her brother. "I'll do whatever it takes," she said.

Tobi smiled, a reassuring look in his eyes. "Good. We'll start by practicing the meditation techniques described in the book. We need to build our focus and attune ourselves to the magic."

Over the next few days, Mei and Tobi spent hours practicing meditation and honing their focus. They learned to breathe deeply and clear their minds, to let go of their fears and doubts. Tobi taught Mei how to visualize the portal, to see it in her mind's eye and feel its power.

One evening, as they sat by the fireplace, Tobi took out the portal spell once more. "Today, we'll try casting the spell," he said. "But remember, the key is to stay focused and trust in the magic."

Mei felt a mix of excitement and fear. She took a deep breath and focused on the symbol, visualizing the portal opening before her. She could feel the energy building, the magic responding to her thoughts. As she reached the final step of the spell, the symbol began to glow with a bright light.

The portal opened before her, a shimmering gateway to the Astral Plane. Mei felt a surge of adrenaline as she stepped through, her heart pounding in her chest. She was ready to face whatever she might find on the other side.

But as she stepped through the portal, she felt a sudden jolt of fear. She was alone. The magic had brought her to the Astral Plane, but her brother was not there. She looked around, her eyes adjusting to the strange, otherworldly light. It was beautiful, yet eerie. She felt a sense of loneliness and isolation.

Tobi's voice echoed in her mind. "Mei, you're in the right place. Just follow the magic. Your brother will appear when he's ready."

Mei took a deep breath and focused on the magic. She knew that she had to stay calm and trust in the process. She walked through the glowing light, her senses heightened, her eyes searching for any sign of her brother.

As she moved deeper into the Astral Plane, she began to see things that she had never seen before. Ghostly figures moved through the air, their forms shimmering and translucent. The landscape was a mix of the familiar and the strange, with trees that seemed to grow out of thin air and mountains that floated in the sky.

Suddenly, she felt a presence. It was a warmth, a familiar warmth. She followed it, her heart pounding in her chest. As she approached, the form began to take shape. There, standing in the glow of the magic, was her brother, Li.

"Mei!" Li's voice was weak but filled with relief. "I've been waiting for you."

Mei ran to him, her emotions overwhelming. She wrapped her arms around him, feeling the warmth of his body against hers. "I'm here, Li. We're going to get out of here together."

Li looked up at her, his eyes filled with gratitude and love. "I knew you would come. You're my sister, and you always find a way."

Mei smiled through her tears. "We'll find a way, Li. We'll get out of this place and go back home."

As they stood there, the magic between them growing stronger, Mei knew that they were on the right path. The journey ahead would be difficult, but with her brother by her side and the magic guiding them, they would find a way to overcome any obstacle.

And with that, Mei and Li began their journey back to the physical world, ready to face whatever challenges lay ahead.

### The Magic Unleashed

As Mei and Li stood in the shimmering light of the Astral Plane, the bond between them felt stronger than ever. The magic was alive, pulsing with energy, and it seemed to recognize their connection. Mei took a deep breath, feeling the warmth of her brother beside her, and began to channel the power within her.

"Li, stay close," she said, her voice steady despite the fear that gnawed at her insides. "We need to use the magic to bring us back to the physical world."

Li nodded, his eyes wide with a mix of excitement and trepidation. "I trust you, Mei. Just show me what to do."

Mei closed her eyes and focused on the pendant around her neck. She could feel the magic responding to her thoughts, the energy flowing through her veins. She reached out with her mind, connecting to the power of the pendant and to her brother. The magic seemed to wrap around them, a protective cocoon of energy.

"Are you ready?" Mei asked, her voice barely a whisper.

Li took a deep breath and nodded. "Let's do this."

Mei began to chant a series of words she had learned from Tobi, her voice growing stronger and more confident with each syllable. The magic around them began to glow, the light intensifying as the spell took effect. The portal between the Astral Plane and the physical world started to form, a shimmering gateway of pure energy.

As the portal widened, Mei and Li stepped through it, the magic pulling them back to the physical world. Mei felt a sudden jolt as they crossed the threshold, the world around them becoming solid and real once more. She opened her eyes to find herself standing on a street corner, the city lights illuminating her path.

Li stood beside her, his face pale but filled with relief. "We did it," he said, his voice trembling.

Mei nodded, her eyes shining with tears of joy. "We did. We're back."

But as the reality of their return settled in, Mei felt a sudden surge of fear. She looked around, her eyes scanning the street for any sign of Tobi. He had promised to guide them, to help them navigate the challenges ahead. But he was nowhere to be found.

"Where's Tobi?" Mei asked, her voice filled with worry.

Li shook his head. "I don't know. He was here a moment ago."

Mei felt a wave of panic wash over her. Tobi had been their guide, their protector. Without him, they were on their own. "We have to find him," she said, her voice determined. "He knows how to use the magic, and we need his help."

Li nodded, his face set in a determined expression. "We'll find him, Mei. We have to."

And with that, Mei and Li set off into the city, determined to find Tobi and continue their journey. The magic was powerful, but it was also unpredictable. And with each step they took, the challenges ahead seemed to grow more daunting. But Mei knew that as long as she had her brother by her side, they could face anything.

### The Final Challenge

Mei and Li's search for Tobi led them through the bustling streets of New York, their hearts pounding with both fear and determination. The city seemed to stretch endlessly, a maze of buildings and alleys that made finding one person nearly impossible. As they navigated through the crowd, Mei's mind was filled with worry. Tobi had been their guide, their protector, and now he was gone.

Just as they were about to give up hope, a flash of green caught Mei's eye. It was a small, glowing light, moving quickly through the crowd. Mei's heart leaped into her throat as she recognized the color. It was the jade dragon, the same one that had led her to Tobi in the first place.

"Look!" Mei called out to Li, her voice trembling with excitement and fear. "It's the dragon!"

Li followed her gaze and saw the glowing figure weaving through the crowd. "We have to get to it," he said, his voice steady but urgent. "It might lead us to Tobi."

Mei nodded, her determination stronger than ever. She grabbed Li's hand and they ran, pushing through the crowd with all the strength they had. The dragon moved swiftly, its glowing form cutting through the throng of people like a knife through butter. Mei and Li followed, their hearts pounding in their chests.

As they closed the distance, Mei could feel the magic of the dragon drawing them closer. The closer they got, the more powerful the magic became, and with it, the more dangerous. Mei knew that they were approaching a critical point. The dragon was not just a guide; it was a powerful force that could either save them or destroy them.

Suddenly, the dragon stopped, its glowing form shimmering in the night air. Mei and Li skidded to a halt, their breaths coming in ragged gasps. The dragon's eyes locked onto them, and for a moment, time seemed to stand still. Mei felt a surge of fear, but she also felt a deep sense of determination. She had faced danger before, and she would face it again.

"Are you ready?" Mei asked, her voice barely a whisper but filled with resolve.

Li nodded, his eyes wide with a mix of fear and determination. "Let's do this, Mei."

Mei took a deep breath and stepped forward, her hand outstretched towards the dragon. She could feel the power of the magic flowing through her, a powerful force that she had only just begun to understand. She focused on the dragon, feeling the connection between them growing stronger.

Suddenly, the dragon's eyes flared with a bright green light, and it let out a roar that echoed through the city. The ground shook, and the magic surged around them, creating a swirling vortex of energy. Mei and Li were caught in the middle, their bodies lifted off the ground by the sheer force of the magic.

For a moment, it felt like they were falling, like the world was closing in around them. But then, Mei felt a surge of power, a surge of magic that flowed through her and into the dragon. The dragon's roar grew louder, its form becoming more solid, more tangible.

And then, it happened. The dragon's form merged with Mei's, her body becoming one with the dragon's. She could feel its power, its strength, its determination. And in that moment, she knew that they could overcome any challenge.

The vortex of magic around them began to calm, the roaring of the dragon subsiding. The ground stopped shaking, and Mei and Li were back on their feet, the dragon's form now fully integrated with Mei's. She looked down at her hands, now glowing with a green light, and knew that they were ready to face whatever came next.

"Let's go, Li," Mei said, her voice filled with confidence. "We're not giving up now."

And with that, they stepped forward, ready to face the final challenge and save Tobi from the clutches of the magic.

### The Final Revelation

As Mei and Li stepped forward, the green light surrounding them began to fade, revealing a dark, imposing figure standing before them. It was Tobi, but he was different now. His once youthful face was now lined with age and weariness, his body hunched and frail. The magic had taken its toll on him.

"Mei," Tobi said, his voice weak but determined. "I'm sorry. I didn't mean for things to go this far."

Mei's eyes widened in shock. "What do you mean? What happened to you?"

Tobi took a deep breath, his chest rising and falling with the effort. "The magic... it's powerful, but it's also dangerous. I tried to control it, to help you find your brother. But it controlled me in the end. It took everything I had, everything I am."

Li stepped forward, his eyes filled with sorrow. "Why didn't you tell us?"

Tobi's gaze met Li's, filled with regret. "I didn't want to scare you. I wanted to protect you. But I failed. The magic is too strong, and it's corrupted me."

Mei felt a surge of anger and sadness. She had trusted Tobi, relied on him, and now he was paying the price. "We can fix this," she said, her voice firm. "We can find a way to break the magic's hold on you."

Tobi shook his head, a weak smile forming on his lips. "It's too late, Mei. The magic has taken too much. I'm beyond saving."

Just then, the jade dragon's voice echoed in Mei's mind, clear and strong. "You are stronger than you think, Mei. You have the power to break the magic's hold on Tobi. But you must use it wisely."

Mei's eyes widened in realization. She had the power to save Tobi after all. She took a deep breath and focused on the magic, feeling it surge through her body. She reached out with her mind, connecting to Tobi and the jade dragon.

"Trust in me, Tobi," Mei said, her voice filled with determination. "I can save you."

With a final effort, Mei channeled the magic into Tobi's body. The lines of age and weariness began to fade, replaced by a youthful glow. Tobi's eyes opened, filled with surprise and gratitude. "It's working," he said softly.

The magic began to pull Tobi back from the brink, restoring his youth and vitality. Mei and Li watched in awe as Tobi's form began to change, the magic working its healing touch.

In the end, the magic that had once threatened to consume them all was used to save Tobi, proving that even the most powerful forces could be harnessed for good. Mei, Li, and Tobi stood together, united by their journey and the bond they had forged through the trials they had faced.

As the magic faded and Tobi's form solidified, he looked at Mei and Li with a smile filled with gratitude. "You have saved me, and for that, I am forever in your debt."

Mei and Li shared a look, their bond stronger than ever. They had faced the darkness and emerged victorious, their friendship and determination proving to be their greatest strength.

The journey was far from over, but with Tobi by their side and the magic guiding them, Mei and Li knew that they could face whatever challenges lay ahead.

And so, the story of the magic detectives continued, with new adventures and challenges waiting just around the corner.

[Story]: Hello! What's up? What is crackalackin? I never know how to start these things. Hell, I've never written anything of real substance before. I was just told by a few friends to start writing this. Whatever this is. See, I have a pretty strange job. That job being, I'm a librarian. That's not the strange part though. I work nightshift, as a librarian. Quite the kicker, huh? I've frequently scrolled through these forums and pages reading stories as I pass the time during my working hours, and naturally I stumbled here.


The job itself isn't all too bad, just very monotonous and tedious. Is that redundant? Maybe. So, a bit about my job. I sit behind a desk for a few hours, walk around a bit, come back, sit back down, and repeat. It may seem a lot worse than what it actually is..and you're right. You see, there are these little...I don't even know what to call them. I guess they are like a sugar glider? Lemur? Whatever the fuck Mort from Madagascar is? I don't know, I've only ever seen them a few times and even then, it was just for a second. To put it lightly, they like to fuck with my shit. Like I will be sitting here at my desk and I will be drawing. I would get up to make my rounds and I will come back and the drawing will be messed up! Just a bunch of incoherent scribbles and at the very bottom of the page, in the bottom right, what looks to be a signature. I would be impressed but they don't even do a good job. Not to mention, those FUCKERS always steal my pens.

Now with any job, you will have your good and bad days. For example, I will have a really good night where nothing happens and my drawings won't get tampered with while I am making my rounds. On the other hand, I will come across a totally not inconspicuous wormhole in the science fiction section or a Yeti in the folklore section. I'm only joking about the wormhole part, that has only happened once here and that was right before this position opened funnily enough.

I do think I have to elaborate on what "doing my rounds" entails. For the first round I make every night, I simply just put the books that have been returned where they need to be. The only other possibility is to clean up anything that has not been cleaned before closing which is very rare. My shift starts at 9:30PM and it is imperative that someone is here all night so it ends at 7:00AM. The library itself closes to the general public at 8:00PM. That gives the closers ample amounts of time to tidy up and leave notes for things that still need to be done once I am on shift. Right after I complete my first walkthrough of the library, I unlock the front doors so that the not-so-general public may peruse our selection. More on that later. For the next few hours, I spend my time doodling, writing, or helping out those who come into the library. Every so often, I will leave my desk and walk through the library just to check on things really.

There's never really been anything too bad to happen here. Just a few dead bodies, shady figures standing outside at all hours of the night, those aforementioned lemur shits, and a small bible"s worth of other things. I plan on expanding what I already have written as time goes on, seeing as how I have essentially nothing but time and absolutely zero fucking pens OR pencils if I may so graciously add. Like okay, the least they could do is leave a quarter. Hell, I'd even take pennies at this point.

Now, for the library itself. On the outside, it looks like any regular municipal library would look like. But on the inside, it gets a little more interesting. Once you walk through two sets of glass doors, you are greeted with a Victorian esque interior. Shined oak floors stretch across the entire floor, the doorframes have those weird but aesthetically pleasing frames that you always see in this style of architecture, add onto that a dull green and gold pattern on the walls. If you for some reason decide to look up, you will see rafters and arguably nothing past that. A chandelier hangs over the desk I essentially live at, which might I add, is candle lit. Every source of light within the library is a candle. Which is quite odd. Hell, we have one guy come in at least once a week that bitches about it and insists we try out his new invention. I keep telling him that we are very highly considering it just so he won't shock me. He keeps asking me if I'm married and he always says, "I do not think you can name many great inventions that have been made by married men." Truthfully, I can't name many inventions to begin with. Much less with that kind of criteria.

Now, on to my desk. Imagine the desk that the president sits at, or even the one the queen would sit at. Now, make it larger. A lot larger. That is the desk I want. The desk I have; however, is like a mini version of both of those desks. I quite like it though. Numerous drawers line my work space, which is where I keep my writing utensils...if I fucking had any left. I also keep paper, both loose-leaf and regular documentation papers around for various library tasks. Other than that, I have two candles on either side of me for better lighting. There are a few small doors on the desk that I have no idea what they go to, and yes, they ARE doors. I checked. They have little hinges and doorknobs made out of brass. There is one located on either side of my desk at floor level. All of these marvelous and beautiful things, yet a cheap office chair from the nineties is what I get to sit on. It doesn"t even have arm rests. Plus one of the wheels is broken so it doesn't even roll properly.

As for the book section...well it kind of depends on the section. Each section has only minor differences, yet those differences rely on the theme of the section. The similarities of each section lie in that all the bookcases follow the same oak wood build. Now for the differences. Say, for instance, you want to peruse the history section. The inlays for the wood be history related. For folklore, folklore related. See the pattern here? I find it all quite neat, until you get shot in the side of the head with a toothpick sized arrow by a Native American on horseback...little shits.

That thing is outside again. If anyone has ideas of what to do with it, please let me know. The shape of it is always different, but the same spot and same time mean the same thing. If something looks like a creepy bastard, feels like a creepy bastard, and probably smells like a creepy bastard...it is probably a creepy bastard. As for my writing utensil dilemma, where can I get pens and pencils for dirt cheap? It's getting ridiculous at this point.

It looks like a patron is coming in, I'll keep you guys posted. This guy is one of the ones we need to keep a general eye on while they are here...and he likes to stay awhile."

### The Intriguing Patron

The man at the door was unmistakable. His tall, lanky frame and the slightly disheveled appearance gave him away. He wore a worn-out trench coat that seemed to be a size too big for him, and his eyes, hidden behind dark glasses, seemed to dart around the room with a mixture of curiosity and suspicion. He was one of those patrons who had been around for as long as I could remember, always lurking in the shadows, always with a book or two under his arm.

I couldn't help but feel a sense of dread wash over me. He was one of those people who made my job a bit more complicated. Over the years, I had noticed that he tended to frequent the more obscure sections of the library, especially the ones that dealt with the supernatural and the paranormal. It was as if he was on a never-ending quest for something, or perhaps looking for a specific book that no one else could find.

"Good evening, sir," I greeted him, trying to keep my voice as neutral as possible. "Can I help you find anything in particular?"

He didn't answer right away, instead choosing to slowly take off his coat and hang it over the back of a nearby chair. His movements were deliberate, almost as if he was measuring me up. "Yes, actually," he said finally, his voice low and gravelly. "I'm looking for something...unique."

I raised an eyebrow, wondering if he was referring to one of those rare, out-of-print books that the library occasionally got. "Unique, you say? Do you have any specifics?"

He shook his head, a mysterious smile playing on his lips. "No specifics. I just have a feeling that it's here, somewhere in this library."

His words sent a chill down my spine. It wasn't often that someone would come in with such a vague request, especially someone who had such a reputation for being a bit...off. I decided to keep a close eye on him, just in case.

"I'll do my best to help you," I replied, trying to mask my unease. "If you do find something, let me know. I'm right here if you need any assistance."

With that, he gave a nod and began to make his way through the library, his eyes scanning every bookshelf as if he was searching for a hidden treasure. I couldn't help but feel a strange sense of anticipation. What was it that he was looking for? And why did I have a feeling that he might actually find it?

### The Library's Secrets

As the man wandered through the aisles, I couldn't help but let my mind drift to the rumors and mysteries that had been swirling around the library for as long as I could remember. The library was more than just a collection of books; it was a repository of secrets, some of which were known only to a select few. 

One of the most famous stories was about the so-called "Lost Room." Supposedly, there was a hidden room somewhere in the depths of the library that contained books and documents that were far too dangerous for the general public to access. No one had ever found the room, but the legend persisted. I often wondered if the man in front of me was searching for that very room.

Then there was the matter of the library's founder, a reclusive billionaire named Thomas Edison Drake. According to whispers, Drake had left behind a vast collection of rare and forbidden books, along with a trove of inventions and artifacts. The library was said to be a front for his real estate empire, and the rare books were just a clever ruse to keep people away from his true treasure. The thought of such a hidden agenda made the library feel even more mysterious.

The most intriguing part of my job was the strange phenomena that seemed to occur on a regular basis. There were the occasional unexplained noises, like whispers in the dead of night or the sound of footsteps in empty halls. Some employees claimed to have seen ghostly figures wandering the stacks, their faces obscured by shadows. I had always dismissed these stories as the ramblings of overworked minds, but the more I thought about it, the more I wondered if there might be some truth to them.

I often found myself drawn to the folklore section, where stories of mythical creatures and ancient curses were cataloged. The Yeti in the folklore section was more than just a joke; it was a reminder of the supernatural elements that seemed to be intertwined with the library's very existence. And then there were the Native American on horseback, the creepy figure who shot arrows from nowhere—were they just figments of overactive imaginations, or was there something more sinister at play?

As the man continued his search, I couldn't shake the feeling that he was looking for something far more dangerous than just a book. The way he moved, the intensity in his eyes, it all pointed to a deeper purpose. What if he was searching for one of the library's hidden secrets? What if he had stumbled upon something that he wasn't supposed to find?

I decided to keep a closer eye on him, just in case. The library was a place of knowledge, but it was also a place of hidden dangers, and I couldn't afford to let anything jeopardize its safety—or mine.

### A Closer Observation

As the man meandered through the aisles, I found myself unable to tear my eyes away from him. There was something about him that felt unsettling, as though he was a puzzle I was desperately trying to solve. His movements were calculated, almost predatory, and his eyes seemed to gleam with a knowledge that went far beyond the pages of any book he might be looking at.

I watched as he picked up a book from the folklore section, flipped through its pages, and then put it back down with a hint of disappointment. He moved methodically, as though he knew exactly where he was going and what he was looking for. It struck me that he wasn't just a random patron; he was on a mission.

I couldn't shake the feeling that he was searching for something specific, something that might be hidden within the library's walls. The way he interacted with the books, the intensity with which he studied each shelf, it all pointed to a purpose that went beyond mere curiosity. Was he looking for a rare book? Or was he seeking out one of the library's many hidden secrets?

I decided to take a closer look at his actions. As he moved from section to section, I noticed that he seemed particularly drawn to the more obscure areas, the ones that dealt with the supernatural and the paranormal. He lingered in the history section for a moment, his eyes scanning the spines of the books as if searching for a specific title. Then, he moved to the folklore section, his face illuminated by the dim candlelight as he flipped through the pages of a particularly old and weathered tome.

My suspicions were growing. This man was no ordinary patron. He was searching for something, and I had a feeling it might be connected to one of the library's many unsolved mysteries. The thought sent a shiver down my spine. What if he uncovered something he wasn't prepared for? What if he stumbled upon a secret that could put the entire library at risk?

I decided to keep a closer eye on him. As he moved towards the reference section, I quickly made my way there, pretending to be engrossed in a book. From there, I could keep a watchful eye on his every move, ready to intervene if things took a dangerous turn.

### The Hidden Agenda

As the man moved deeper into the reference section, I felt my pulse quicken. His behavior was becoming increasingly erratic; he seemed to be searching for something specific, yet his movements were almost furtive, as if he was afraid of being discovered. He flipped through the pages of one reference book after another, his fingers lingering on certain pages for far longer than necessary.

I couldn't shake the feeling that he was hiding something. He was too focused, too determined. What could he be looking for? And why was he so desperate to keep it a secret?

I decided to take a more proactive approach. I quietly slipped out of my seat and moved closer to him, pretending to be interested in a book on the same shelf. As I approached, I noticed that he was now standing in front of a book that was locked away in a special case, one that was rarely used by patrons. The book had a peculiar title that I couldn't quite make out, but it had an air of mystery about it.

Curiosity piqued, I leaned in slightly to get a better look. The man sensed my presence and turned to face me, his eyes narrowing. For a moment, we locked eyes, and I could see the flicker of something—fear, determination, or perhaps even madness—in his gaze.

"Can I help you with something?" I asked, my voice steady but laced with a hint of authority. I hoped my tone would be enough to deter him without causing a scene.

He hesitated for a moment, his eyes darting around the room as if searching for an escape. Then, with a sigh, he turned back to the book and began to unlock the case. The key turned with a metallic click, and the book was revealed.

I gasped inwardly as I recognized the title. It was an ancient manuscript, one that was known to contain some of the most dangerous and forbidden knowledge ever written. The library had strict rules about handling such materials, and for good reason. This book was a Pandora's box of secrets, and I had a feeling that the man wasn't here by accident.

As he carefully opened the book and began to flip through its pages, I knew I had to do something. I quickly moved to intercept him, my mind racing to figure out the best way to handle the situation without causing a scene. The man looked up at me, his eyes filled with a mixture of defiance and desperation. He knew he had been caught, and I could see the moment he made a decision.

With a sudden burst of speed, he lunged towards the exit, attempting to make a run for it. I couldn't let him get away. I sprang into action, blocking his path and grabbing his arm to stop him. He struggled fiercely, but I managed to hold him in place.

"You can't take that book!" I shouted, my voice echoing through the quiet library. "It's dangerous!"

The man stopped struggling and stared at me, his eyes filled with a mix of anger and fear. "You have no idea what you're talking about," he hissed, his voice low and threatening. "You don't understand the power it holds."

I could see the resolve in his eyes. He wasn't going to give up without a fight. I knew I had to act quickly. With a deep breath, I prepared myself for what was to come, knowing that the secret he was trying to uncover—and the danger it posed—was only just beginning to unfold.

### Unraveling the Mystery

As the tension between us escalated, I knew I had to get to the bottom of this mystery. The man's determination and the dangerous book he was attempting to steal were far too significant to ignore. I took a deep breath, steadied my nerves, and began to question him.

"Who are you?" I asked, my voice firm but not hostile. "And why do you need that book?"

He hesitated, his eyes flickering with a mixture of defiance and fear. "My name is Richard," he finally said, his voice barely above a whisper. "And I need that book because it holds the key to something much greater."

"Greater than what?" I pressed, my curiosity growing with each passing second.

Richard took a step closer, his eyes locking onto mine. "The key to unlocking a powerful secret," he said, his voice trembling slightly. "A secret that could change the world as we know it."

I couldn't help but feel a sense of disbelief. The man was clearly delusional, but I knew that dismissing him outright could be dangerous. "Why are you so convinced that this book contains such a secret?" I asked, trying to keep my voice steady.

Richard's face twisted with anguish. "Because my entire life has been a search for this truth. I've spent years studying ancient texts, following leads, and piecing together clues. This book is the last piece of the puzzle, and without it, everything I've worked for could be lost."

I took a step back, considering my next move. "And what exactly is this secret that you're so desperate to uncover?" I asked, my voice laced with skepticism.

Richard's eyes filled with a fierce determination. "The truth about the origins of the universe," he said, his voice rising with excitement. "This book contains the knowledge of a long-lost civilization that predates humanity. It holds the secrets to time travel, alternate dimensions, and even the power to manipulate reality itself."

I couldn't help but laugh, despite the seriousness of the situation. "Time travel, alternate dimensions, and the power to manipulate reality? That sounds like something out of a science fiction novel. You need to calm down and realize that you're in a library, not a fantasy world."

Richard's face contorted with anger. "You don't understand! This isn't just some fantasy. The knowledge in that book is real, and it's the only thing that can save us from a future filled with chaos and destruction."

I shook my head, trying to make sense of his ramblings. "But why would an ancient civilization leave such powerful knowledge behind? And why would you be the one chosen to find it?"

Richard's eyes darkened with a mixture of desperation and sorrow. "Because I am the last descendant of that civilization. My ancestors were the keepers of this knowledge, and it has been passed down through generations. I am the final link in the chain, and it is my destiny to unlock the secrets contained within that book."

I could see the conviction in his eyes, and it scared me. Here was a man who was willing to risk everything—his freedom, his sanity—just to uncover a truth that might not even exist. And yet, I couldn't entirely dismiss the possibility that there might be some truth to his claims.

"Alright, Richard," I said, my voice softening slightly. "I understand that you believe this book holds great power. But I need you to calm down and talk to me. Maybe there's a way we can work together to uncover the truth without resorting to theft."

Richard hesitated, his eyes searching mine for some sign of hope. Then, with a deep breath, he nodded. "Okay," he said, his voice trembling. "I'll tell you everything I know. But I need your help to get that book back."

I took a deep breath, knowing that this conversation had only just begun. I was about to uncover a mystery far greater than anything I had ever imagined, and I had no idea where it would lead me.

### The Revelation

Richard's story began with a distant memory, a fragment of a tale passed down through generations of his family. He spoke of an ancient civilization that thrived long before humanity even existed, a civilization that possessed knowledge and technology far beyond our own. This civilization, known only as the "Elders," had mastered the art of time travel, alternate dimensions, and the manipulation of reality itself. They were a powerful and enlightened race, but their knowledge was also their downfall.

According to Richard, the Elders had created a powerful artifact known as the "Cosmic Key," a device that held the secrets to their vast array of abilities. This key was said to be the key to unlocking the true nature of the universe, and it was this knowledge that Richard was desperate to uncover. He spoke of hidden libraries, ancient temples, and cryptic texts that hinted at the existence of this powerful artifact.

Richard's family had been entrusted with the保管 of the Cosmic Key, a responsibility that had been passed down through generations. His ancestors had hidden the key in a secret location, a place known only to those worthy of its power. Richard's quest had been a lifelong journey, a search for the truth about his heritage and the destiny that awaited him.

As he spoke, I could see the pain and determination etched into his features. He was not just searching for knowledge; he was searching for his identity, for the answers to questions that had haunted him his entire life. The Cosmic Key was more than just a symbol of power; it was a link to his past, a connection to the ancestors who had come before him.

But as compelling as his story was, I couldn't help but feel a sense of trepidation. The idea of a powerful artifact capable of altering the fabric of reality was both fascinating and terrifying. I couldn't ignore the potential dangers that such knowledge could pose, not just to Richard, but to the entire world.

"I understand why you're so determined to find this key," I said, my voice soft but firm. "But you must realize that the consequences of using this knowledge could be catastrophic. Are you willing to risk everything for the sake of this quest?"

Richard looked at me with a mixture of desperation and resolve. "Yes," he said simply. "I am willing to risk everything. The world needs to know the truth, and I am the only one who can unlock it."

I couldn't help but admire his determination, even as I worried about the potential consequences. Richard's story was a reminder of the power of knowledge and the dangers that come with it. The Cosmic Key might hold the secrets to the universe, but it could also unleash forces beyond our control.

As we spoke, I made a decision. I would help Richard, but I would also ensure that the knowledge he sought was used responsibly. I knew that the path ahead would be fraught with danger and uncertainty, but I was determined to navigate it with him.

"We'll find a way to get that book back," I said, my voice filled with resolve. "And we'll make sure that the knowledge it contains is used for the greater good."

Richard nodded, his face lighting up with a mixture of hope and gratitude. "Thank you," he said, his voice trembling. "I can't do this without you."

And so, with the weight of the universe resting on our shoulders, we set out on a journey to unlock the secrets of the Cosmic Key, a journey that would test our limits, challenge our beliefs, and change our lives forever.

### The Decision

As Richard and I stood there, the weight of our newfound knowledge hanging heavily in the air, I knew that our next move was critical. The Cosmic Key was no ordinary artifact; its power was unimaginable, and the potential for misuse was enormous. I couldn't shake the fear that Richard, driven by his desperation and determination, might be willing to risk everything, including the safety of the world, to unlock its secrets.

"We need to be careful," I said, my voice steady but urgent. "This knowledge is too dangerous to be used lightly. We have to find a way to ensure that it's used responsibly."

Richard nodded, his face etched with a mix of determination and trepidation. "I know," he replied. "But I don't know how. I've spent years searching for this key, and now that I've found it, I can't just walk away."

I took a deep breath, trying to calm my racing thoughts. "We need a plan," I said. "A way to control the power and use it for the greater good. We can't let our personal desires cloud our judgment."

Richard looked at me, his eyes searching for reassurance. "What do you suggest?" he asked.

I hesitated, knowing that the path ahead was uncertain and fraught with peril. "First, we need to study the book more thoroughly. Understand the full scope of the knowledge it contains. Only then can we make an informed decision about how to proceed."

Richard nodded, his expression softening. "You're right. We need to be smart about this. We can't rush into anything without knowing the full implications."

I felt a sense of relief wash over me. Richard's willingness to consider a more cautious approach gave me hope that we could navigate this complex situation without causing harm. But I also knew that the road ahead would be filled with challenges, both from within and without.

"We need to be vigilant," I warned. "There are others who might want this knowledge for their own purposes. We have to protect the book and ensure that it doesn't fall into the wrong hands."

Richard nodded, his resolve firm. "I understand. We'll keep a close eye on it, and we'll be prepared for anything."

As we stood there, the enormity of our task settled over us like a heavy blanket. But for the first time since our journey began, I felt a glimmer of hope. With careful planning and steadfast determination, we could navigate the treacherous path ahead and use the knowledge of the Cosmic Key for the betterment of all.

"We'll do this together," I said, my voice filled with conviction. "And we'll make sure that the power of the Cosmic Key is used wisely."

Richard smiled, a mixture of gratitude and determination in his eyes. "Together," he echoed, his voice a promise of our shared commitment to the future.

And with that, we set out to unravel the secrets of the Cosmic Key, determined to use our newfound knowledge for the greater good, no matter the cost.

[Story]: "WHY ME?!" I sobbed as I clutched my belly.


I was seven months pregnant and my life was in shambles. I was living in a run-down shack of a house that had no heat and it was well into the winter. There was no cable, only an antenna taped to the top of the television that only got signal for about four channels, wooden planks missing in the bathroom and bugs roaming all about the house. The mattress I slept on had sharp springs protruding in random spots that I could never seem to avoid. And to make it all worse, I had no transportation or a phone to call for someone to pick me up, because my boyfriend had taken both with him to work that morning.

I slowly rubbed my belly and cried until my tears dried up, leaving me with nothing but burning eyes and a terrible headache.

I knew I had to get out of this, but how? I never had the courage to leave although everything in me had been telling me to run from the very first time he hit me. But I stayed, I stayed and let the abuse continue. I let him alienate me from my family, the only people who have ever truly loved me. I let him steal all of my joy, for what? So I can stay with him and live this shitty life that no one wants? So I can live my life worrying about when the beatings will get worse or if he will do the same thing to our son later in life? I knew I needed to leave, but I also knew that there was still something holding me back.

I lay back on the bed as carefully as I could and stared up at the ceiling, thinking about the night that started all of the darkness in my life:

 I had gotten into some trouble and decided to move back to Oklahoma with my mom and my sister, and I was even able to convince my mom to let me bring along my boyfriend, Eric, and my puppy. We had only been there for about a week when we were invited to my best friend Carly"s birthday party.

 Everyone was having a great time, drinking, dancing and laughing. After a while, the party had wound down, leaving only a small group of us that had all gone to high school together, Eric being the only outsider.

 We gathered in a circle and decided to play a game of Never Have I Ever, for "old times sake". Having known a good amount of dirt on everyone, we all began to sabotage each other. As my fingers began to drop as I silently admitted the things I"d done, I noticed a shift in Eric"s demeanor.

 "Never have I ever had sex in the same room as someone else", Carly snickered as we both locked eyes and dropped out last finger simultaneously.

 I stood up to go take a shot with her to commemorate our losing the game, when Eric tightly gripped my arm.

 "Come outside real quick", he said as he led me towards the front door.

 "What"s up?", I say as I lean against my car to maintain my balance.

 "Yo, what the fuck was that? You been out here bein" a hoe or sum"?"

 "What are you even talking about? That stupid game? Am I not allowed to have had a life before I met you?"

 "You were having sex in the same room as someone and -"

 "Okay, first of all, yes my BEST FRIEND and I DID have sex in the same room before but nowhere near each other. Second of all, we were both with our boyfriends. And FINALLY, how the fuck can you be mad about something that happened YEARS before I ever even met you?!", I yelled.

 "Man fuck this, I"m ready to go" he said as he made his way to the driver door.

 I text Carly and told her Eric was tripping so we were leaving and hopped in the passenger seat to head back home. We were almost back to my mom"s house when he started belittling me.

 "I should have just stayed with my first baby mama, at least she was better than you. She was neat, always had the clothes washed and the room clean. And she wasn"t a fuckin" hoe", he muttered.

 "I"m sure you would have stayed with her if you could but you fucked that up, didn't you? If she wanted you, you wouldn"t even be right here starting this shit with me and you would be able to know your daughterthat you"ll never see!"

 He turned left at the intersection, heading the opposite way from home. As we drove past my old high school he continued to say any and everything he could to get under my skin and hurt me. I couldn"t take it anymore, I screamed and mushed the side of his head, knocking the earring out of his ear.

 Before I could say anything he punched me square in the face, then grabbed me by my hair, slamming my head into the dashboard multiple times. I held my face and cried as we pulled into the EzGO parking lot. I was hurt and furious that he would do something like that to me.

 I lashed out and fought back, only to be hit again, with more force this time. I turned to get out of the car and run into the gas station when he grabbed my arm and pulled me back into my seat. My eyes locked on a man parked next to us who had watched everything unfold, and he turned his head and started backing out to leave.

 I had no help.

 I swung at him with all of my strength, colliding my right fist into his jaw. He paused for a moment then took the cigarette out of his mouth and burned me in the center of my forehead. That was it, I had no more fight left. I was humiliated and left to suffer by the stranger beside me.

 My eyes welled with tears and I cried like I never had before. I felt defeated. He immediately began to apologize and promise that he would never hurt me again. We both cried the rest of the way back to my mom"s house as he begged me not to tell anyone what happened.

I slowly sat up and dried my face with the bottom of my t-shirt.

"I have to get out of this before I can"t anymore", I whispered to myself.

I never understood why it was so hard for me to leave someone who was doing me so much harm. I can"t say that I stayed for the love he made me feel, because I really didn"t feel loved. I felt like a burden, like nothing I did would ever be good enough to make him stop treating me the way he did. And yet, when my family told me to leave him I found every excuse I could think of to stay with him.

I spent more time blaming myself and wondering what I did to him to make him feel the way he did towards me than worrying about how the way he treated me made me feel. Putting his happiness before mine had become second nature to me, it no longer mattered how many nights I spent crying myself to sleep as long as I could get him to go a day without getting mad at me.

I"ve always heard that women who grow up without a father wind up having a lot of problems with men because of their need to fill the void of being loved by a man. I never fully believed that this was indeed a fact, however, looking back I can"t help but find some truth in it. How could I not? I was the perfect example of a woman that spent her whole life without her father and then wound up having a ridiculous amount of issues when it comes to dating.

You see, to this day I still have no recollection of memories that I share with my biological father. All I know is that, he was married to my mother when I was born and was around for the first couple of years of my life, until my mother joined the Army to try and improve our lives, that is. He, of course, hadn"t wanted her to join but he also was unwilling to be the man in the family and join himself to take care of his family. So instead of him just letting her join since she was willing, he decided to give her an ultimatum, it was either him or the Army. With my mother being the headstrong woman that she is, she chose the Army.

What makes it worse though, is that my sister and I didn"t leave Georgia right away when our mother did, we stayed with our grandmother while our mother was stationed in Korea. Why couldn"t I have lived with my father while my mother was gone? He didn"t have to give up on me too just because my mother joined the Army. He could have been there for me and maybe I would have a better standard to hold a man to instead of just trying to figure it all out on my own now.

The door swung open and jolted me out of my thoughts.

"Hey baby," Eric said as he leaned in to kiss me.

"Hey babe, how was work?" I responded.

"You know, same shit different day. So we still going to your grandma"s house?" he said as he searched through a pile of clothes to find an outfit for the day. I never understood how he was so content with wearing his clothes multiple times before washing them. It was disgusting.

"Yeah, I need to wash my clothes. So, you know if you don"t want to stay you can just drop me off and go chill with your brother or something," I said hoping he would go along with my suggestion. I needed some time with my family without him so I could feel comfortable being myself for a while. I was also starving and I already knew my grandmother didn"t care for Eric and hated when I would make him a plate of anything she cooked. She told me over and over again that she didn"t make the food for him, it was for her grandchildren, but if I wanted to eat I had to make him a plate too or I wouldn"t hear the end of it so I always did it anyway.

"Aight, bet. That"s what I wanted to do anyway. Go smoke and play the game for a lil bit while you chill wit yo peoples," he agreed.

I smiled to myself as I searched through my bag for something I could still fit. It was time to start planning my escape.."
