You should write a story on the topic "horror" in the style of the following story.
[Reference Story]: In order to move on, I need to grieve the lost years of my life and find a way to win the years to come. I think there is still time for me to undo the damage that has been done. I may not like doctors and nurses for what they did to me, but I have to put it aside and submit to the system again. It has gotten out of hand with this thing… I'm writing this to hopefully heal from the past and put these experiences behind me, even with him.


To put this into perspective, I want to briefly mention the bouts of psychosis I have dealt with in the past. This way it's clear that the thing I talk about later is a result of my mind deteriorating and nothing more.

It began with auditory hallucinations. Nothing big. I would be working and suddenly ‘someone' would ‘scream' in my ear. It was always one or two words, but so loud that I'd jump and look for the source. I don't remember most of the words but they were always derogatory. Sometimes it would yell my name right into my ear like I was in trouble. A few times it was a very loud ‘Bang!'

This gradually evolved into things like hearing TV static in the other room, people talking just out of sight, firecrackers off in the distance… but these were all things I could easily disprove to myself by investigating the sound.

It got more serious as I aged. More delusions began to pop up. I ‘knew' someone was in the corner of the room. I'd turn to check. No one. I'd get back to work, but feel something was there. Turn to check. Nothing. It never felt malicious only that I was being observed, that's why I didn't think it was a big deal, before my diagnosis.

There are more but I don't know about their relevance. I was convinced I was being assaulted in my sleep, that there were demons in me, bugs were under my skin… There were shadow people following me and sometimes I'd talk out loud to try and get them to go away… A lot of my delusions and hallucinations are too traumatic to bring up. I'll cry if I linger on those memories too much.

The only positive thing I did have growing up, and still now, is an overactive imagination. As a child, I delved into maladaptive daydreaming. Without getting into the trauma that occurred, I was completely isolated and left unattended most days. The imaginary worlds I created were all I had and so I welcomed anything my mind would provide to me as entertainment. While ‘daydreaming' and dissociating separated my reality from the abuse, it also exacerbated my delusions and hallucinations.

Once I was made aware that these things were not ‘normal' for everyone, and that the disorder I had was progressive, my life's mission was to do everything I could to keep my mind and body healthy. Reduce the symptoms by changing my lifestyle alongside the taking the medication.

I know it sounds ridiculous. ‘How could you think everyone deals with that?!' But when someone says ‘I'm depressed' most people respond with ‘Oh yeah, I feel that.' I'd tell someone I hear voices that say awful things and the response would be ‘Ah, yeah, intrusive thoughts. I get those too.' In hindsight all of it seems obvious, but when the world is constantly reassuring you that you're ‘normal', you begin to think the ‘shadow people' in the basement is just the normal fear of the dark most people have… up until your mind snaps and suddenly it's ‘How could you not seek help?! You're so stupid! How did you not know?!'

That began my horrid journey through the healthcare system.

I've been on many different medications to try and quell my symptoms and those medications have caused physical side effects that I am still living with. I gave so much trust to doctors, doing my best to be understanding and patient. Doctors and nurses are people too. However, I've only ever met dismissive medical staff in all my years.

Before inpatient, I always got the following:
It's just stress and anxiety.
Take a self-care day.
Get more Vitamin D.
Are you sure you aren't thinking about it too much?
Get more sleep.
Drink less caffeine.

I. Do. It. All.

I lost the weight they told me would ‘help'. I ate the food they told me would ‘help'. I do the exercise they told me would ‘help'. So, how much extra work do I have to do, in order to get my life to the ‘normal baseline' that everyone else is at?

Once I grabbed the recommended vitamins out of my bag and shook it in a neurologist's face, after he told me that I was probably hormonal, on my period, and needed more vitamins – he didn't even look at my chart. I went in because I was rapidly losing weight for no reason and my hair was falling out.

"How many of these do I need to take and for how long?!" I shoved the bottle at him. "It's been years! How many more hoops do I need to jump through, before you people finally do something besides tell me that you don't know what it could be and send me home with nothing?!"

I paid for the appointment and went home empty-handed with a migraine, feeling nauseous and exhausted as my hair fell out in clumps. Doctors don't care.

I went into the hospital once, telling them I was suicidal and slipping into delusions. My knick-knacks were ‘talking to me'. But because I didn't think they were influencing me or moving things in my home, I didn't get sent to inpatient. They locked me away in a glass room with an officer outside it. They did nothing but come back in occasionally and ask if I changed my mind. When I said I wasn't suicidal anymore, they let me go, alone, to drive home, and be alone at home. I was still delusional, they didn't give me anything no matter how much I asked because it was ‘drug seeking behavior, and that night I had the worst psychotic episode of my life.

That's a full-blown story for another day. I do sometimes wonder if he had anything to do with it...

All this to say, my faith in the medical field has slipped and I no longer want to communicate my issues to them beyond what I have already. That trust has been drained like my bank account. They got to take their frustrations out on me while I paid them to do it. They said things to my face that I'd never say to another human being, let alone to someone scared of themselves and everything around them.

There actually was a 2 month period of relief; I finally had found a medication cocktail that worked for me. The ‘thing' by the door was gone and the mirrors were safe to walk past was beautiful!

I was living for first time in my life! I had spent thousands hopping from psychiatrist to psychiatrist, therapist to therapist, doctor to doctor. I got bloodwork done here, evaluations done there. Try this anti-psychotic, try that one. I was so miserable for so long, a guinea pig for them to mix medications together without thinking about how they'd interact in my system.

It nearly destroyed my physical health… This was why my hair was falling out, my teeth were wearing down from gastrointestinal issues, the vertigo was intense, my vision had failed for a few weeks on one prescription, another had given me such bad insomnia I was up for five days and my doctor still refused to take me off it…

But it finally felt like I was seeing the light at the end of the tunnel. I cried over the years that were wasted. For the first time in my life, I had the sanity to realize just how bad it had gotten.

It didn't matter anymore, I could work on my physical health; the peace I had in my mind was worth the suffering.

...Then it started again.

Years ago, the intense stare of the ‘thing' by the door returned. Hearing people that weren't there when I would lay down in bed, seeing shadow people who wanted to do disgusting things to my body...

The cycle was going to have to start all over again. After knowing what life truly could be, the thought of regressing back into my old mindset was beyond devastating and overwhelming.

In a fit of mania, my wrist was slashed so deep I almost cut the nerves in my arm. There was blood splatter all around the room and it kept squirting out in bursts from my arm as my heart beat. The blood loss made me dizzy and nauseous, my vision blurred until all I saw were lights and shadows. My eyes closed and I was ready for everything to be over.

After all these years, all the fear and suffering, this was what my brain truly wanted and I was going to give it that. I know he was there and saw me do it. I could feel him. The thing by the doorway… It was a delusion, but I indulged in the idea that he could be real as I succumbed to the bloodloss. I liked to believe that he took pity on me.

There were sirens off in the distance.

I lived alone and hadn't called for help.

Waking up in the ER, I was voluntold to go to inpatient for an indefinite amount of time.

They took pictures of my body to document any injuries or identifying marks and gave me an assessment. With hair that had thinned tremendously, eyes with dark purple bags, a stomach a bit distended from IBS, and fingers turned white from the cold of the ER, I was filthy from not taking care of myself. I must have smelled and looked pathetic.

I had failed. Years of trying to be good and doing all the right things, I followed all the rules and put up with anything that was thrown my way and failed anyway.

I was in the psychiatric ward.

When I said I didn't like the medical system earlier… I was discussing dismissive doctors which was nothing compared to the inpatient staff. Those people not only made me feel like a burden to the system, but that I was disgusting and rotten. The staff would scoff, roll their eyes, or make fun of my memory issues. A few times the night shift staff would role play as us behind the front counter, poking fun of our symptoms or saying they'd ‘rather be dead'.

They would drug me to the point of passing out and seeing stars and then get aggravated when I couldn't get up for their check-ins. Edward, a friend I had made, got the same treatment. I could go on all day about that guy, he and Rosaline were my two buddies. They both are schizoaffective too for similar reasons and it was a relief to casually talk about our lives together without the judgment. Maybe I'll write about those guys later, but things got weird with them towards the end and I feel a little bad about it.

Anyway, the ER had told my inpatient nurse to put a bandage over my cut when she cleaned and dressed it, in the morning and at night. ‘Why do you need this to be dressed like this?' She always complained. If she had read my file, she'd know why because I'm lucky I still have control over my left hand.

I was ‘uncooperative' because I yanked my hand back when she tried putting the bandage down, but she was going to put the sticky part on my cut. I was scolded and she put the sticky edges over the cut out of spite. It pulled on the stitches and the goo from the bandage got into the crevasse of the cut.

That night, sobbing in my bed, the paper thin hospital clothes did nothing to keep me from freezing. My entire forearm was itchy and red; I realized she had never cleaned the wound with saline. It would turn bright white when poked, there was a burning sensation as it turned red again. I had tried to get help earlier but was told ‘come back when you can't move your wrist'. Not wanting to be written up again, I was trying to stick it out until morning. My other arm was covered in goosebumps and I trembled with no way to warm myself. The blanket was useless, as thin as my ‘clothes', but I still pulled it over my lower half.

I felt something by the door but expected to see nothing as usual. That was the first time I saw him. Eyes swollen and filled with tears, my vision was blurry, but I could still make out a figure, hunched over and peering into my room. I frantically wiped my face with my hands, hoping it was just a trick of the light.

Off-white skin glistened in the fluorescent overhead lighting from the hallway. Tinged pink in some places, yellow or green in others, deep purples resembling bruises were scattered over his body. It was as if someone had poorly sculpted a human figure from pure-white clay with messy hands, colors bleeding into the white as he was molded. There were even little dents, impressions on his skin, that resembled hundreds of little fingerprints. His limbs were curved or bent in a slightly unusual way, but not enough that it looked wrong. The off-white color of his lanky arms bled into a muddy red on his spider-like hands. His splotchy white legs were similar, leading to large, red feet.

The facial features were rudimentary, as if someone had taken a sculpting tool and sliced off what made him look human, leaving a flat surface. Large, black, marble-like eyes protruded from his face, thick pinkish-purple eyelids framed them. His large, red ears made me paranoid, like he could listen in on my thoughts as I analyzed him.

He had a shadow.

If he didn't, I could confirm it was my brain playing tricks on me, but his shadow grounded him in reality.

Frozen in place, I didn't scream, telling myself over and over that I'd finally fallen off the edge. My mind had unraveled. I was shivering uncontrollably, doing my best to try and stay still but it only made me more tense. My hands and feet were like ice.

I didn't know the best course of action and I was in awe at what my mind had created – because I knew, I knew this wasn't real.

I was not going to close my eyes. Even blinking was scaring me, but I didn't want to keep my eyes open so long they'd dry out and I'd have to close them for longer… better for short and quick blinks, right?

A quick blink. He was still, but tilted his head curiously.

A quick blink. He seemed to be relaxing into his crouched position by the door.

I started to relax, a little empowered that I was sticking it out and not becoming the problematic screaming patient like my poor friend Edward had a few nights ago. They'd sedated him so badly he didn't wake up for an entire day. I didn't want that to be me. I felt strong.

A quick blink, and he still didn't make any sudden movements. I smiled to myself and decided the best course of action was to ignore him and go to bed. Before settling in, I tried to fluff the flat, stiff pillow. Collapsing with a sigh, I vowed to not open my eyes again and delve into my imagination instead. I wanted to ‘watch' something calm and comforting that night. Slowing my breathing, I heard a very light sound of sticky footsteps making their way to me and then there was a warmth.

The mattress dipped slightly, as if someone was leaning against the edge of the bed near my face. I was doing a good job of ignoring him, valiantly escaping into my own Wonderland, until it felt like something was prying its way into my skull.

Play the one about ‘The Willful Child'.

Unable to resist any longer, I opened my eyes to see his face inches from my own.

"Ffff-!" I instantly sat up and he pushed himself up slightly to continue to stay eye-level. There was a hollow pressure in my chest. Tears welled up in my eyes again.

The day had worn me down. My arm was screaming for attention. I tried to move my wrist and it was swollen in place.

This wasn't fair!

"Please... I'm so tired," was all I could muster with a sigh. I was unable to look him in the eyes, those black marbles. I opted to stare in the middle of his face where I finally noticed two little slits in the bruise-like pink splot there, like the remains of nose. He really did look like he was handmade. Smooth, dirty, white clay.

"I've never had a strong visual hallucination like this before." It felt like I had to say something. He leaned in slightly, as if trying to hear the words I was thinking rather than speaking.

There were so many things I could say, my mind was racing with thoughts but I couldn't grab a single one. I wasn't sure if I wanted to know more about where it came from or what it was… but I was scared of being hurt.

"Are you mad at me?"

Giving me a closed smile, he leaned back slightly. I nervously smiled back, ready to accept insanity until the morning. As I tried to even out my breathing, I blinked a few times and tears fell down my cheeks. The thing reached up to poke at them harshly, his nail pressed into my cheek, making me scrunch my face up. They were as clammy as they looked and his fingernails were pointed like little claws with dirt in the crevices.

It was annoying until I realized that he was tactile. Feeling his fingers prodding my face, I broke out in a cold sweat, shaking like a leaf.

What level of crazy is it when you can start feeling things? I thought.

The room was starting to get blurry because the medication was starting to kick in, nausea hitting me.

He looked at his wet fingers, rubbing them together in thought, then he reached up again. That was my breaking point.

I tried to scramble backwards on the bed and make space between us, convinced he was going to poke my eyes in. When I put pressure on my cut arm, heat surged from my arm to my brain like an electric shock, causing black and white spots to dot my vision. It was swollen, pulsing, and itchy, looking more like a stage prop than my forearm. I hissed and nearly fell backwards, off the other side of the bed.

Either he moved too fast for me to get away or I was officially succumbing to the medication cocktail, a misshapen hand latched onto my bad arm and yanked me back towards him. I yelped, slapping my other hand over my mouth.

He inspected it. Putting his thumb on the bandage and pressing down hard, he cocked his head curiously and listened to me cry out in pain.

"Stop it. Stop. Please," I tried to reason with him. "I'm so tired. I - I made a mistake coming here and thinking I'd get better. I need sleep." I swallowed the snot that was running down the back of my throat. "Let me get better. Please."

His head swung up to stare straight into my eyes and lips parted to reveal its dull yet pointy teeth. Any confidence I had of it being a hallucination was long gone. I fully believed he was in front of me.

A clammy hand snapped up to grab my face, it was big enough to wrap around my head. He shoved me back down onto my bed, my legs failed and I tried to grab at his arm to free myself. It didn't do much, he was too strong. My head was forced to rest against the flat pillow and I pulled my arms to my chest as a last ditch effort to protect myself from nothing.

Through the gaps in his fingers, I scanned the room searching for a clock, words on a poster, pamphlet, anything. I knew in dreams those things could be wonky. My vision was already bad, head aching, eyes stinging, and a dizzy spell was coming over me, so my efforts were futile. Removing his hand, he leaned over to fill my field of vision.

Shaking, I swallowed and stared back. He smiled warmly, taking enjoyment in my inebriated state, but sympathizing with it in a strange way. Unable to handle his vacant stare, I tried to make out what his skin could be made of.

His middle and index fingers were placed above my eyes and then he pushed my lids down. Eyes closed, I accepted whatever was going to happen but nothing did. His presence remained, the warmth he radiated eased the chill of the room more than the paper thin blanket ever could.

I didn't want to picture him. So, I delved deep back into my own little world to keep my mind occupied until I fell asleep. He let out a pleased hum, as if that was what he wanted.

The next day, I bounced out of bed. It was the best sleep I had gotten in years. Years. In inpatient, I had the worst hallucination of my life but also got the best sleep I've ever had? Leaving the room and going into the common area for my medication, I saw my nurse. She was the same nurse from the day prior and I readied myself for her to roughly grab my arm and tear the bandage off of the stitches she pressed it into.

I found her with her cart, engrossed in drawing on her clipboard. There was a chair positioned next to her, which was odd because everything had always been done standing up somewhere random in the ward. This was a comfortable corner by the window, undisturbed by the other patients and nurses, and the morning light was shining through to warm the area. The cart that carried her medical supplies and patients' medication was stationed next to her.

I could still be dreaming… and could cry because this is is so… nice... I stepped into the warm and sighed in relief, rubbing my shoulders to rid myself of the excess cold.

"I, um, like your nail color today," I tried to be as polite as possible. "It's pretty."

"Thank you, I wanted to try something new for a change," she raised her hand, as if she just noticed her freshly manicured nails herself. A lovely gradient of purples and reds. "Sit down."

I obediently sat down next to her, taking a peek at her clipboard. They weren't notes, just seemingly random doodles.

Typical. I thought.

She chuckled and set the clipboard down.

My arm was gingerly taken by my wrist and turned over to view the cut. My jaw dropped. The redness and swelling was gone, the relief I had gotten from a good night's sleep made me forget how much pain I had been in. The bandage was also fixed, placed down diagonal so none of the edges touched the cut.

Eyes wide, my breath caught in my throat; it had been a dream. When the realization seeped in, I exhaled loudly and any tension in my body dissipated. Just a dream.

She gently peeled the bandaid off, discarding it in a small garbage bin kept on the lower level of her cart.

"Thank you," I smiled slightly.

"Your welcome." The nursed tilted her head up at me. Her eyes were completely black, bulging slightly, with purple bruising around them.

My jaw was stuck parted, drying my mouth and throat out. I knew it wasn't possible. She was being gentle and kind, the black eyes, the good night's sleep… maybe I had died?!

"No, silly," she chuckled, bringing out a syringe filled with saline and applied the liquid to my cut. "I couldn't let that happen."

I didn't know how to respond to that. ...Did I almost die?

She tutted. "Strong will. Such a small little person, trying again and again. Willful little child. They're not kind to you, are they?"

My heart was beating erratically causing my breathing to falter. "I'm well past being a child."

"Aw, sweetie, don't be like that."

"What does it matter how staff treats me? ...Can you call Dr. Kasley? I'm seeing things again... and it's... worse."

She clicked her tongue against the roof of her mouth. "Do you think she'd care?"

There was nothing I could say because my ‘nurse' was right. My doctor was the same one who over medicated me to the point of drooling in bed like a lobotomized patient last week, and they refused to ease up the dosage. A patient had tried to take advantage of me in my inebriated state and I was only saved by Rosaline, who came to get me for dinner.

I didn't want to be a vegetable in bed again for the whole day.

"I can help with that for a price."

"I need something though," I genuinely needed some sort of medication – I wasn't stupid enough to forego what brought me sanity at one point in my life. As much as I hated the doctors, I still held out hope they cared somehow.

"Why," she spat. Holding the bandage over my cut, she turned it so it'd stick to my stitches.

"The-." I licked my chapped lips, and then whispered, "the voices… I see and hear things."

She cocked her head. "Only for the fake ones?"

"...The fake ones?" I wanted to run, something primal in me was screaming.

With a huff and an eye roll, she turned the bandage back so it'd avoid my stitches. "I can be patient." She leaned back and pulled out a tiny clear cup with my pills in it. Before she handed them to me, she plucked out my anti-psychotic and broke it in half. I couldn't stop myself from reaching out to stop her, but her dead spherical eyes made me recoil. The mood stabilizer was also broken in half.

She offered me my reduced prescription. "This is what you get."

Licking my lips, I decided to press my luck. "The anxiety one, the green one, it makes me feel nauseous. They give it to me just to put me to sleep and it doesn't help. Do I have to take it?"

The ‘nurse' beamed and plucked the green pill from the clear container and popped it in her own mouth. Gasping, a raised a hand to stop her but the damage was done.

"I didn't like the one you played last night," she casually said, packing up her things on the cart.

"The… the what?"

"You didn't play your usual story. I was disappointed."

I spent the day trying to draw him, as best as I could. I wanted to capture how terrified I was at the time, but the longer I spent on it the more calming and comforting the image got. Nostalgic.

Edward had come over to see what I was doing, but took one of my drawings and tore it up. It was so out-of-character for him I stood up and backed away, gathering my other drawings and retreating into my room.

That night I felt silly, sitting cross-legged in bed and facing the door. My nurse had returned to her old self and given me my anxiety medication so I was dozing off. Eventually it became too difficult to stay awake and I situated myself for sleep.

The bed grew warm and comfortable, it was so wonderful I wanted to cry in relief to be free from the cold again. ‘The Willful Child'. I like that one.

Afraid of the consequences, yet eager to please the one ray of light I had, I began to visualize the story in my head. It's one I always liked to make my own little visuals for…A Grimm's Fairytale that I relate to heavily.

And… and...I actually don't think this helped at all. I'm ashamed that, after revisiting this again, I only feel sentimental and more confident I my decision. Even if he's not real, he's the nicest thing that's happened to me in years, the nicest delusion or hallucination I've ever had… I know he's not real though, so there's still sanity left in me. As long as I know he's not, he can stay."

**A Descent into Darkness**

In the dimly lit room, I sit hunched over, my pen scratching across the page as if it's trying to carve words from my soul. The room is suffocatingly quiet, save for the distant hum of the heating system and the occasional creak of the floorboards. It's as if the walls themselves are breathing, watching my every move with an unseen, malevolent eye.

I began writing this journal not as a means of catharsis, but as a desperate attempt to make sense of the horrors that have seeped into my reality. The stories I'm about to recount are not for the faint of heart, nor are they meant to be pretty or palatable. They are the raw, unfiltered account of a mind unraveling, a soul in torment.

My descent into madness started subtly, like the creeping tendrils of a parasitic plant, slowly taking root in my psyche. At first, it was just fleeting moments of disorientation, as if I had momentarily stepped out of my own body. I would look down to see my hands moving without my control, or feel my legs stiffen as if some invisible force had seized them. These episodes were brief and isolated, easily dismissed as mere quirks of my imagination.

But as the days turned into weeks, the episodes grew more frequent and intense. I began to see things that weren't there. Shadows that seemed to dance just out of the corner of my eye, and whispers that echoed in the empty rooms of my home. I would catch glimpses of a figure out of the corner of my eye, only to turn and find nothing but a blank wall. The whispers grew louder, more insistent, as if they were trying to communicate with me, to pull me into a world of darkness.

My behavior became erratic, my thoughts fragmented. I would stare at the same spot on the wall for hours, trying to decipher the faces that seemed to flicker in and out of existence. I started to question my own sanity, wondering if I was going mad. The more I tried to convince myself these were just figments of my imagination, the stronger they became.

The first real sign that something was terribly wrong came one night when I awoke to find my room bathed in an eerie green light. I bolted upright in my bed, my heart pounding in my chest. In the center of the room stood a figure, its face obscured by a shadowy halo. I couldn't make out any details, only that it was there, watching me. I screamed, my voice echoing through the silence, but the figure remained motionless. Terrified, I reached for the light switch, my fingers trembling as I flipped it. The room plunged into darkness, but the figure disappeared just as quickly as it had appeared.

That night marked the beginning of my nightmare. The green light became a constant presence, haunting my every waking moment. It would appear in the most unexpected places—behind me as I walked down the hallway, in the reflection of the bathroom mirror, even in the darkness of my own mind. I was trapped in a never-ending cycle of fear and confusion, my sanity slipping through my fingers like sand.

I tried to keep my panic under control, to maintain some semblance of normalcy. I would go to work, put on a brave face, and pretend that everything was fine. But at night, when I was alone with my thoughts, the fear would overwhelm me. I would lie in bed, staring at the ceiling, willing the green light to disappear, praying that I hadn't lost my mind entirely.

But the green light was just the beginning. As my sanity deteriorated, I began to experience more vivid and disturbing hallucinations. I saw creatures that seemed to be made of smoke and shadow, creatures that moved with a life of their own. They would circle me, whispering dark secrets and mocking my fears. I could feel their presence, a cold, clammy sensation that made my skin crawl. They were always just out of reach, just beyond the edge of my vision, but they were there, lurking in the corners of my mind.

One night, as I lay in bed, I heard a noise that sent chills down my spine. It sounded like someone was walking across my ceiling, their feet making a soft, rhythmic thud. I sat up, my heart pounding in my chest, and listened intently. The noise stopped, leaving me in a state of suspended terror. I couldn't tell if it was real or imagined, but the fear it instilled in me was all too real.

I started to lose touch with reality. I would have conversations with myself, trying to make sense of the chaos in my mind. I would argue with the shadows, trying to convince them to leave me alone. But they wouldn't listen, they were relentless, a constant reminder of my slipping sanity.

I knew I needed help, but I was terrified to seek it. I was afraid that if I told anyone about what I was experiencing, they would think I was crazy. I was afraid that I would be locked away, labeled as a danger to myself and others. But the fear of being labeled was nothing compared to the fear of the unknown, of the creatures that seemed to be stalking me in the darkness.

So I continued to suffer in silence, writing in my journal to try and make sense of it all. The words on the page were a lifeline, a connection to the part of me that was still in control. But even as I wrote, I knew that my grip on reality was slipping, that I was on the brink of losing myself entirely.

And now, here I am, sitting in the dimly lit room, my pen scratching across the page, trying to capture the horrors that have become my reality. I know that my words will never do them justice, that they can only scratch the surface of the darkness that has engulfed me. But I write them anyway, in the hopes that one day, I will be able to look back and understand the madness that consumed me.

**The Desperation for Help**

But as I spoke, I could see the skepticism in their eyes. They asked questions, tried to probe for rational explanations, but I knew there were none. And so, I continued to struggle, to fight against the darkness that seemed to consume me. Each day was a battle, each moment a struggle to keep my mind from completely unraveling. I was trapped in a relentless cycle of fear and despair, but I refused to give up. I would keep writing, keep fighting, until I found a way to reclaim my life from the shadows.

**The Breakdown and the Night of the Scream**

The relentless torment reached a fever pitch one harrowing night, when the creatures in the shadow world seemed to close in around me, their whispers becoming a cacophony of madness. I was lying in bed, my heart racing, my breath coming in short, ragged gasps. The room was dark, the only light coming from the dim glow of the nightstand clock. It read 3:07 AM, a stark reminder of the isolation and terror that had become my reality.

Suddenly, a cold hand gripped my shoulder, sending a jolt of fear through my already frazzled nerves. I bolted upright, my eyes wide with terror, searching the room for the source of the touch. The hand was gone, leaving only a chill that seemed to seep into my bones. I reached for the light switch, my fingers trembling as I flipped it. The room erupted into a blinding light, but there was nothing there, just the empty space where the hand had been.

I was about to settle back into the bed when I heard it—a faint, muffled scream, barely audible over the hum of the heating system. It sent a shiver down my spine, my heart leaping into my throat. I listened intently, my ears straining to catch any hint of the source of the scream. It came again, this time louder, more distinct. It was coming from the bathroom, just down the hallway.

My mind raced, a whirlwind of fear and confusion. Who could it be? And why wasn't anyone coming to help? I knew I had to do something, but the fear of what might be waiting for me in the bathroom held me back. I took a deep breath, trying to steady my shaking legs. I had to check on whoever was in there, even if it meant facing the creatures that haunted my every waking moment.

I crept down the hallway, my footsteps silent on the hardwood floor. The door to the bathroom was slightly ajar, and I could see the faint glow of light spilling out into the hallway. I reached out and pushed the door open, my eyes widening in shock at the sight that greeted me.

The bathroom was a scene out of a horror movie. The sink was filled with water, the mirror cracked and reflecting a distorted image of the room. In the center of the bathroom stood my reflection, but it was not my face that stared back at me—it was the face of one of the creatures from the shadow world. Its eyes were wide and hollow, glowing a sickly green, and its mouth was twisted into a grotesque smile.

I screamed, the sound echoing through the empty house. The creature turned towards me, its form shifting and flickering like a wraith. I took a step back, my legs buckling under the weight of my fear. The creature lunged towards me, its shadowy form wrapping around my legs, pulling me towards the floor. I struggled, my hands clawing at the creature's form, trying to break free. But it was too strong, its grip unyielding.

As I was pulled to the ground, I saw the creature's face up close, and I knew then that it was real, that there was no escaping the shadow world. Its eyes locked onto mine, and I felt a cold, clammy sensation seep into my soul. The creature's voice whispered in my ear, a voice that was both familiar and foreign, a voice that echoed the darkest thoughts and fears that I had ever known.

"No escape," it whispered. "You are mine."

I fought until my strength gave out, my body growing numb as the creature's grip tightened. I could feel my consciousness slipping away, the world around me fading into darkness. In that final moment, I knew that I was lost, that I was forever trapped in the shadow world, a prisoner of my own mind.

**The ER and the Inpatient Nightmare**

The night I was pulled into the shadow world, I knew I had to seek help. The creatures had taken control of my mind, and I was desperate for any form of salvation. I stumbled out of the bathroom, my vision blurred and my body weak from the lack of sleep and fear. My legs felt like they were made of lead, and every step was a monumental effort. I could barely keep myself upright, my mind a chaotic swirl of terror and confusion.

I made it to the front door, fumbling with the locks until I finally managed to get it open. The cold night air hit me like a wall, and I gasped, trying to catch my breath. I stumbled down the driveway, my eyes scanning the dark street for any sign of help. I didn't care if I was seen; I just needed someone to save me from the horrors that were consuming me.

After what felt like an eternity, a car pulled up, and the driver's door opened. I collapsed into the seat, my body shaking uncontrollably. The driver was a paramedic, and as soon as I was inside, they began asking questions, their voices calm and reassuring. I could barely muster the strength to respond, my mind a chaotic mess of fear and desperation.

We arrived at the emergency room, and I was quickly wheeled into the trauma bay. The bright lights overhead were blinding, and the sterile smell of antiseptics filled my nostrils. I was poked and prodded, my vitals taken, and then I was placed on a gurney and wheeled into an examination room. A doctor and a nurse entered, their faces professional and unemotional. They asked me questions, trying to determine the cause of my distress, but I couldn't focus. All I could think about was the creature in the bathroom, the cold grip that had pulled me to the ground.

The doctor diagnosed me with severe anxiety and recommended a stay in the psychiatric ward. I agreed, anything to escape the creatures and the constant fear that was consuming me. I was given a tour of the ward, a stark, white, and sterile environment that felt more like a prison than a place of healing. The nurses were polite but distant, their faces mask-like, devoid of any real emotion.

I was assigned a room on the ward, and as I lay on the cold hospital bed, I felt a wave of despair wash over me. I had hoped that the hospital would be a sanctuary, a place where I could find the help I needed. But instead, it felt like I was being locked away, condemned to live in a world of my own making.

The days that followed were a blur of medication, therapy sessions, and endless hours spent staring at the blank walls of my room. The nurses were relentless, their constant check-ins and demands for updates feeling more like an interrogation than a form of care. They would prod and poke at me, asking the same questions over and over, as if trying to shake the creature from my mind.

The therapy sessions were no better. The therapist was well-meaning, but their attempts to help me feel like I was going crazy only served to deepen my sense of despair. They would ask me to confront my fears, to face the creature in the bathroom, but how could I when the creature was real to me? Every time I tried to open up, to share my experiences, I was met with skepticism and dismissal.

The other patients on the ward were no help either. They seemed to view me with a mix of pity and disdain, as if my experiences were too bizarre to be real. They would whisper behind my back, their voices laced with judgment and condescension. I felt more isolated than ever, trapped in a world of my own making, and I knew that I had to find a way to escape.

And so, I continued to struggle, to fight against the darkness that seemed to consume me. I wrote in my journal, hoping that the act of putting my thoughts and experiences down on paper would somehow bring me some clarity. But the words on the page only served to remind me of my isolation, of the loneliness that I felt. I was trapped in a relentless cycle of fear and despair, but I refused to give up. I would keep writing, keep fighting, until I found a way to reclaim my life from the shadows.

**The Torment of Inpatient**

The days in the inpatient ward were a living nightmare. The sterile, white walls seemed to close in on me, the fluorescent lights overhead casting an eerie glow that only heightened my sense of dread. The other patients were no better; they were just as isolated, just as desperate, and just as lost as I was. We were all prisoners in our own minds, locked away in a place that promised help but delivered only more pain.

The staff was a different breed entirely. They were cold, indifferent, and often cruel. They would roll their eyes when we asked for help, dismiss our concerns with a wave of their hands, and treat us like we were children. One nurse in particular, Nurse Carter, made my stay unbearable. She was mean-spirited and condescending, always finding fault with something. She would yell at us for the smallest infractions, her voice dripping with sarcasm and disdain.

One night, I was trying to get some rest when Nurse Carter came into my room, her face twisted in a scowl. "You know, I think you're just attention-seeking," she hissed. "If you really wanted to sleep, you'd try to be quiet."

I tried to explain that I was struggling with the creatures in the shadow world, that the noise was keeping me awake, but she didn't listen. She just shook her head and left, leaving me to stare at the ceiling, my mind a whirlwind of fear and frustration.

The medication only made things worse. They kept changing my dosage, trying different combinations in the hope of finding something that would work. But each new medication brought with it a new set of side effects. Some made me feel heavy and sluggish, others left me feeling jumpy and paranoid. I felt like I was on a roller coaster, my body and mind constantly being thrown into new and unpredictable states.

The worst part was the isolation. I was locked in my room for most of the day, only allowed out for therapy sessions or medication checks. The other patients were just as isolated, and we had no choice but to rely on each other for comfort and support. But even that was taken away from us. Nurse Carter would often deny us visitors, claiming it was for our own good, but it only made us feel more alone and abandoned.

One of the worst nights was when Edward, my friend from the ward, tried to reach out to me. He was in the room next to mine, and we had been talking through the thin walls. He was trying to be comforting, to remind me that I wasn't alone, but the nurse caught wind of it and came bursting into my room, yelling and screaming at both of us. She accused us of "trying to cause a scene" and threatened to put us in solitary confinement if we did it again.

I was devastated. Edward was the only person I felt I could talk to, the only one who understood what I was going through. But now, I was being punished for trying to reach out to him. I felt more isolated than ever, trapped in a world of my own making, with no one to turn to for help.

The days blended into each other, a never-ending cycle of fear, loneliness, and despair. I would sit in my room, staring at the blank walls, trying to find any sense of comfort or hope. But there was none. The ward was a prison, a place where the monsters in my mind were allowed to roam free, unchecked and unchallenged.

And so, I continued to struggle, to fight against the darkness that seemed to consume me. I wrote in my journal, hoping that the act of putting my thoughts and experiences down on paper would somehow bring me some clarity. But the words on the page only served to remind me of my isolation, of the loneliness that I felt. I was trapped in a relentless cycle of fear and despair, but I refused to give up. I would keep writing, keep fighting, until I found a way to reclaim my life from the shadows.

**The Return of the Shadow**

As the days passed in the inpatient ward, the creatures in the shadow world seemed to grow stronger, their presence more insistent and more threatening. I could feel them lurking in the corners of my mind, their whispers growing louder and more insistent. I knew I had to do something, or I would lose myself entirely.

One night, as I lay in bed, trying to get some rest, I heard a faint noise coming from the hallway. It was a soft, rhythmic thud, as if someone was walking across my ceiling. I bolted upright in my bed, my heart pounding in my chest, and listened intently. The noise stopped, leaving me in a state of suspended terror. I reached for the light switch, my fingers trembling as I flipped it. The room plunged into darkness, but the noise had stopped, leaving me in a cold, silent void.

I was about to settle back into the bed when I heard it again—a faint, muffled scream, barely audible over the hum of the heating system. It sent a shiver down my spine, my heart leaping into my throat. I listened intently, my ears straining to catch any hint of the source of the scream. It came again, this time louder, more distinct. It was coming from the bathroom, just down the hallway.

My mind raced, a whirlwind of fear and confusion. Who could it be? And why wasn't anyone coming to help? I knew I had to do something, or I would lose myself entirely. I crept down the hallway, my footsteps silent on the hardwood floor. The door to the bathroom was slightly ajar, and I could see the faint glow of light spilling out into the hallway. I reached out and pushed the door open, my eyes widening in shock at the sight that greeted me.

The bathroom was a scene out of a horror movie. The sink was filled with water, the mirror cracked and reflecting a distorted image of the room. In the center of the bathroom stood a figure, its face obscured by a shadowy halo. It was the creature from the shadow world, its eyes glowing a sickly green, and its mouth twisted into a grotesque smile.

I screamed, the sound echoing through the empty house. The creature turned towards me, its form shifting and flickering like a wraith. I took a step back, my legs buckling under the weight of my fear. The creature lunged towards me, its shadowy form wrapping around my legs, pulling me towards the floor. I struggled, my hands clawing at the creature's form, trying to break free. But it was too strong, its grip unyielding.

As I was pulled to the ground, I saw the creature's face up close, and I knew then that it was real, that there was no escaping the shadow world. Its eyes locked onto mine, and I felt a cold, clammy sensation seep into my soul. The creature's voice whispered in my ear, a voice that was both familiar and foreign, a voice that echoed the darkest thoughts and fears that I had ever known.

"No escape," it whispered. "You are mine."

I fought until my strength gave out, my body growing numb as the creature's grip tightened. I could feel my consciousness slipping away, the world around me fading into darkness. In that final moment, I knew that I was lost, that I was forever trapped in the shadow world, a prisoner of my own mind.

**The Nightmare Unleashed**

The creature's grip was relentless, its cold, clammy fingers wrapping around my legs with a force that seemed to crush the very essence of my being. I struggled, my hands clawing at its form, my fingers digging into its shadowy skin in a desperate attempt to break free. But it was futile; the creature's hold was unyielding, and I was being dragged to the ground, my body helpless against its sinister power.

As I hit the floor, the creature's form seemed to shift and contort, its presence growing more intense and more oppressive. I could feel its eyes burning into my soul, its gaze piercing through the very fabric of my being. The room around me started to blur, the walls and ceiling merging into a twisted, indistinct mass of darkness. The creature's voice echoed in my ears, a haunting melody of despair and madness.

"No escape," it whispered, its voice a chilling reminder of my impending doom. "You are mine."

I screamed, my voice a broken, desperate plea for help that echoed through the empty halls of the inpatient ward. But no one came. The staff was nowhere to be seen, their indifference a cruel testament to my isolation. I was alone, trapped in this nightmare world, with no one to save me from the horrors that were consuming me.

The creature's grip tightened, pulling me closer to its dark, twisted form. I could feel its cold breath on my skin, its presence a living nightmare that seeped into my very bones. I tried to fight, to will myself to break free, but my strength was waning, my body growing weaker with each passing moment.

As the creature's voice whispered in my ear, I felt a cold, clammy sensation seep into my soul. My vision started to fade, the world around me growing darker and more indistinct. I could feel my consciousness slipping away, my mind succumbing to the darkness that had taken hold of me.

"No escape," the creature's voice echoed, a chilling reminder of my impending doom. "You are mine."

And then, everything went black.

**The Escape from Madness**

The darkness was overwhelming, a void that seemed to consume my very essence. I felt as if I were drowning in a sea of shadows, my body and mind succumbing to the relentless grip of the creature. But within this abyss, a spark of resistance flickered, a small ember of hope that refused to be extinguished. I struggled, fighting against the darkness that sought to claim me, my mind a battlefield of fear and determination.

My limbs moved involuntarily, as if my body was trying to escape the grasp of the creature. I could feel its presence, a cold, clammy weight pressing down on me, but I refused to submit. I screamed, my voice a raw, desperate cry that echoed through the darkness. The sound seemed to shake the very walls of the nightmare realm, a testament to my unwillingness to give in.

The creature's grip loosened, its form shifting and contorting as it struggled to maintain control. I seized the opportunity, using every ounce of strength I had left to push myself away. My hands clawed at the darkness, my fingers digging into the floor as I fought to break free. The creature's voice echoed in my ears, a haunting reminder of my impending doom, but I refused to let it defeat me.

With a final burst of energy, I broke free from the creature's grip, my body tumbling away from its dark, twisted form. I landed on the cold, hard floor, my breath coming in ragged gasps. The creature's form seemed to dissipate, its presence fading into the shadows as it retreated back into the depths of my mind. I could still feel its influence, a lingering sense of dread and fear, but I knew I had won this battle.

I struggled to my feet, my body shaking from the exertion. The room around me was still shrouded in darkness, but the creature was gone, at least for now. I took a deep breath, steadying myself as I looked around the room, my heart pounding in my chest. I knew I had to find a way out of this nightmare, to escape the shadows that sought to consume me.

I stumbled towards the door, my hands trembling as I fumbled with the lock. The door opened with a creak, and I stepped out into the hallway, my eyes adjusting to the dim light. The ward was eerily quiet, the other patients still asleep or lost in their own nightmares. I knew I had to find help, to find someone who could understand what I had been through.

I made my way down the hallway, my footsteps echoing in the silence. I passed by the nurses' station, hoping to find someone who would listen to me. But the staff was nowhere to be found, their indifference a cruel reminder of my isolation. I continued down the hallway, my heart racing, my breath coming in short, ragged gasps.

Finally, I reached the exit, my hope renewed as I stepped into the cool night air. I knew I had to find a way to get help, to find someone who could understand what I had been through. I was determined to fight against the darkness, to reclaim my life from the shadows that had once held me captive.

**The Search for Redemption**

Stepping out into the night air was a stark contrast to the oppressive darkness of the inpatient ward. The cool breeze against my skin felt like a balm to my frayed nerves, a reminder that the world outside was still somewhat tethered to reality. I stumbled towards the nearest street, my mind racing with the hope that I could find help, that I could somehow make sense of the madness that had taken over my life.

As I walked, I kept my eyes open for any sign of a safe haven—a café, a store, anything that could be a potential source of help. The night was quiet, the streets mostly deserted, and the shadows seemed to stretch longer and darker as I moved. I was exhausted, both physically and mentally, but the thought of finding redemption kept me moving forward.

My first stop was a small café a few blocks away. I pushed open the door, the sound of chatter and the hum of the coffee machine filling the silence. I approached the counter, my voice trembling as I asked for help. The barista looked at me with a mix of curiosity and concern, but they took my request seriously, asking me questions and offering to call for an ambulance if I needed it.

I explained my situation as best as I could, the words tumbling out in a desperate rush. The barista listened intently, their face showing a mix of sympathy and understanding. They called the hospital, informing them of my situation and asking for assistance. As I waited for the ambulance to arrive, I felt a small sense of relief, a glimmer of hope that maybe, just maybe, I could find a way to reclaim my life.

The ambulance arrived quickly, and I was rushed back to the hospital. This time, the response was different. The staff was more attentive, more compassionate. They listened to my story, believed me, and promised to help. I was admitted to the psychiatric ward again, but this time, it felt different. There was a sense of urgency, a commitment to finding a solution.

I was given a new set of medications, a combination that was supposed to help stabilize my mind. The side effects were intense, but I was willing to endure them if it meant finding a way out of the nightmare. I participated in therapy sessions, both group and individual, sharing my experiences and learning from others who had similar struggles. The support I found in these sessions was invaluable, a lifeline that helped me begin to rebuild my shattered sense of self.

Days turned into weeks, and slowly, I started to regain control of my life. The creatures in the shadow world were still there, lurking in the corners of my mind, but they no longer held the power they once did. I learned to cope with my hallucinations, to find ways to push them aside and focus on the present moment.

The road to recovery was long and challenging, but I refused to give up. I continued to write in my journal, a way to process my experiences and find some semblance of peace. The words on the page were no longer just a means of survival, but a tool for healing, a way to make sense of the chaos that had once consumed me.

And so, I continued to fight, to reclaim my life from the shadows. I knew that the journey would be long and arduous, but I was determined to find redemption, to find a way to live in the light again. The horrors I had faced had left their mark, but they would not define me. I would rise from the ashes, stronger and more resilient than ever before.

**A Glimmer of Hope**

The journey to recovery was fraught with challenges, each step a battle against the lingering shadows of my past. But with each passing day, I found myself gaining strength, my spirit slowly reclaiming its light. The inpatient ward had been a dark chapter, but it also became a crucible, forging resilience in the face of overwhelming odds.

As I left the hospital for the final time, I felt a mix of relief and trepidation. The world outside was vast and uncertain, but it was also filled with possibilities. I knew that my path would be difficult, but I was no longer alone in my struggle. The support of friends, family, and fellow survivors had become my anchor, a constant reminder that I was not defined by my past.

I began attending support groups, finding solace in the shared experiences of others who had faced similar demons. We shared our stories, our fears, and our hopes, creating a network of understanding and compassion. In these groups, I discovered that my struggles were not unique, and that there was strength in numbers, a collective determination to overcome the darkness.

My therapist became an essential part of my recovery, guiding me through the complex landscape of my mind. We worked together to develop coping strategies, to navigate the minefield of my thoughts and emotions. The process was slow and often painful, but it was also transformative. I began to see my experiences not as a curse, but as a testament to my strength and resilience.

I also started to engage in activities that brought me joy and a sense of accomplishment. Art became a powerful outlet for my creativity, a way to express the emotions that words could not capture. I found solace in painting, drawing, and writing, each stroke of the brush or word on the page a step towards healing.

The road ahead was still uncertain, and I knew that the shadows would never completely disappear. But I had learned to face them head-on, to confront my fears and doubts with courage and determination. I had learned that recovery was not a linear journey, but a series of steps forward and occasional setbacks. It was a process of constant growth, a commitment to living fully in the present moment.

And so, I embraced each day with a newfound sense of hope. I was not defined by my past, nor was I afraid of the future. I had survived the horrors that had once consumed me, and I was ready to live—a life filled with light, love, and the endless possibilities that lay ahead.

[Reference Story]: Ding.


Dear Sarah.

I remember the day we got our first microwave. My dad said he bought it at goodwill. For all I know he probably had a line of credit there. They still had lines of credit that were simply kept in a notebook behind the counter. My dad knew everyone, and he helped everyone, so it wouldn't surprise me that his credit was good everywhere in the city.

He was the guy who delivered the milk and other dairy stuff to all the grocery stores, the bodegas, the corner marts and what not. And then he did gumball machines and little trinket machines. When he first started, they were a nickel each. Then ten cents. Then a quarter. Put the coin in, turn the knob, and open the little latch and there's your stuff. Then he started delivering milk to all the schools and and refilling the little candy and trinket machines as well.

Lines of credit turned into layaway, where you could put money down on something and just come in and pay it off slowly over time and pick it up when you were paid off. They just held your thing in a room of things other people put on layaway.

Eventually that got too be too much space being used for layaway, especially because companies didn't charge interest (because it was a free service) and store credit cards became a thing. Now you just buy whatever you want and pay it off over time with a bunch of interest tacked on. It makes stores a ton of money and gives that instant gratification to people willing to pay out the nose in interest for things. It also makes people buy a lot of shit they don't need.

Before my dad made really good money, nothing we ever got was in it's original box or packaging. Not even Christmas and birthday presents. Nothing was ever new, and sometimes we didn't know if it worked until he brought it home. We didn't care. This was the first microwave he ever brought home. I wonder if he found it on the side of the street on the way home from work.

I've probably owned a dozen microwaves since that day, but none of them were like this. To me, this was a behemoth of a box of metal and glass. It probably weighed at least twenty pounds. The first time I opened it up, I pulled the door down and stuck my head in it to see if it fit. I was seven, what else would you expect? Besides, it looked like a regular oven but smaller. Even opened like a regular oven. It was beautiful.

The microwave had a big dial, a little dial, and a button. The big dial went up to thirty minutes. What the heck takes thirty minutes to cook in a microwave? There was a smaller dial for "power" and we never took it off the full power option. Under that was just a little square start button. You had to push it in about half an inch to get it to start. Sometimes you had to press it a couple times.

My mom pulled me gently out of the microwave as I was looking at all the holes inside it and she closed the door. She said this is dangerous and gets hot. I was seven, so I knew what hot meant. I just couldn't figure out how it got hot. I just knew it got hot for only thirty minutes at a time.

That Amana Radaranger moved with my parents to four different apartments. When they moved into their last apartment, my cousin dropped it and it never worked again. We were in such a rush to move that time, my mom didn't even clean it out.

My dad wasn't upset. My mom was a little upset but the next day she got a brand new microwave with buttons on it and a digital clock. It came in it's original box brand new from walmart. I don't remember the brand, and I know it only lasted a couple years. This was just before my dad had started to make a little money. It was a couple months later bought the new trucks and hired a few guys to drive and deliver.

And this is when we met. Right before my dad "hired" me as an adult. Before that, I was with him in his truck every day, meeting the customers and helping him fill the machines and dump the coins into bags. Back then, you could do this and not get jumped or mugged. It was a lot of fun for me.

It was summer, I had just graduated high school and we met at one of the little corner stores my dad had just gotten as a new customer. While he was talking to the owner, I was trying to figure out how to have a conversation with you. It was just us in the store, on a quiet rainy Wednesday morning. Your dad owned the store, and both of them were in the back discussing who knows what. I said hi. You blushed a little and said hi. I said nice shop. I asked you how long the store had been open. You said a couple months. You had just moved from Michigan and your dad bought the building from one of his cousins.

We had a little small talk. I told you my name, you told me your name was Sarah. We talked about the store and my dad's business, and summer time and whether you were going to the town pool on the nice days or to the park or what not. I told you there was a skating rink in town and you hadn't been there long enough to know that. I felt kinda good that I let you know. I also wondered if you thought I was just hitting on you or something, but we were both still kids back then, so did it really matter?

I was just about to ask you if you wanted to go to the skating rink on Friday night and our dad's come out of the back room talking about something. I was leaning over the counter, you were leaning over as well, and there was still a couple feet between us. We stood up straight and both of us blushed. You blushed way more and looked way more beautiful than me, I'm sure. Our dads didn't even notice.

The following Wednesday, which became the day of the week that I got to see you, you were there in your dad's store. Your hair looked different and I swear your lips looked a little pink. You were wearing something pretty. Our dads went in the back room again for about twenty minutes this time and I never thought how odd this was. He never went in the back room with anyone for more than a few minutes at best. And usually never even did that.

This time, I went right into the skating rink and asked you if you wanted to come on Friday. You asked me if this was a date. I said yes, yes it is a date. I'd like to take you on a date. To the skating rink. I heard something drop in the back, or a hand lightly smacking a desk, and a chair scratching the floor, but was unfazed. My eyes were locked on yours, and yours on mine. You had these beautiful brown and golden eyes, and I had these muted grey/blue eyes. I hated my eyes, but I loved them for what they were seeing right then and there.

I borrowed my dad's truck and picked you up at your dad's store. We drove the eight minutes to the rink in near silence. We were both smiling. I came around and opened your door, took your hand, and walked you into the skating rink. We listened to the music and watched the lights shine different colors all over the floor, and the disco ball lights changing colors every few seconds. We stopped for pizza and soda and then went back out. We talked most of the time about everything two almost adult kids talk about. I listened to your stories about back home, and I told you about living here. We stopped again for ice cream and I don't remember letting go of your hand at all that night except when we were eating.

At ten pm sharp I dropped you off at your house. That was your curfew on Friday nights. My dad told me I had better be home at 10:10, which was plenty of time to walk you to and kiss you at your front door. It was a very short and sweet kiss. I held the side of your cheek gently and you smiled.

I said see you Wednesday and you said see you Wednesday. And for the most part, that became our parting words for the next few months. Even when we made plans to go on our dates on the weekends, at the store, it was always see you Wednesday.

I met you on a Wednesday, I asked you out on a Wednesday and I asked you to marry me on a Wednesday. Today's Wednesday and we just signed on our first house. The first thing I did is buy you the most expensive microwave I could find and had it installed over the stove. I just wanted to let you know why I was so giddy about it. I know, sometimes I can be a bit nostalgic and giddy over little silly things. I just wanted to know why it was kind of special to me. And why you're kinda special to me.

I love you."

**A Forgotten Treasure**

Dear Lily,

I remember the day we found the old phonograph. It was tucked away in the dusty corner of a garage sale, almost hidden beneath a stack of old newspapers and a tattered blanket. My grandfather, who had an uncanny knack for finding treasures in the most unexpected places, insisted we buy it. For all I know, he probably paid a fraction of what it was truly worth. Back then, garage sales were more about the thrill of the hunt than the actual value of the items.

My grandfather was the kind of man who lived in the past. He ran a small town record store for decades, where he knew everyone by name and their favorite songs. When that store closed down, he seemed lost. He spent most of his days wandering through flea markets, antique shops, and garage sales, searching for remnants of the music industry he once knew so well.

The phonograph was a relic from the early 20th century. It was a heavy, wooden box with intricate carvings and a glass cover that protected the delicate records. The needle was made of a soft material that had long since worn away, leaving only faint scratches on the surface. My grandfather cleaned it with such care, as if it were a precious gem.

I remember the first time we tried to play a record. My grandfather carefully placed a 78rpm disc on the turntable, adjusted the needle, and turned the large, heavy arm. The music was scratchy and uneven, but it was music nonetheless. It was a song from the 1920s, a time when the world seemed simpler and slower. We listened to it in silence, lost in the melodies of a forgotten era.

Over the years, we played that phonograph countless times. It became a staple in our home, a constant reminder of a time long past. We would often sit in the living room, my grandfather with his pipe and me with my headphones, each lost in our own worlds but connected by the music that filled the room.

Then one day, as we were moving to a new house, my grandfather accidentally dropped the phonograph. The wooden box cracked, the glass cover shattered, and the records scattered across the floor. I remember my grandfather’s sigh of disappointment. He tried to repair it, but it was beyond saving. We couldn’t bring ourselves to throw it away, so it sat in the attic, a silent witness to the passage of time.

I’ve since owned many modern music players and devices. They’re convenient and portable, but they lack the charm and nostalgia of that old phonograph. Every now and then, I’ll think of my grandfather and that garage sale find, and I’ll feel a pang of regret for not having treasured it more when I had the chance.

Last week, I was going through some old boxes in the attic when I came across the remnants of that phonograph. The wooden box was still there, though not in one piece, and a few of the records were intact. I couldn’t resist the urge to bring it back into the house. I set it up in the living room, just as it had been all those years ago.

As I played an old record, I was transported back to those days with my grandfather, when life moved at a slower pace and music was a shared experience. I realized then that the phonograph wasn’t just a piece of furniture or a relic of the past; it was a connection to my grandfather and a part of our shared history.

I hope this little story helps you understand why that phonograph holds such a special place in my heart. It’s not just about the music; it’s about the memories and the love that it represents. And maybe, just maybe, it will inspire you to look for the hidden treasures in your own life, the ones that connect you to your past and bring warmth to your present.

I love you.

**Rediscovering the Magic**

Dear Lily,

You know, sometimes the most cherished memories are the ones that come back to us in the most unexpected ways. It’s been a while since I last saw the old phonograph, but recently, it made a surprise appearance in my life, pulling me back to a time I had almost forgotten.

It started with a phone call from my cousin, who had inherited some of my grandfather’s belongings after his passing. She mentioned she had something that might interest me and asked if I could come over to take a look. I wasn’t quite sure what to expect, but I was curious. After all, my grandfather had a knack for collecting all sorts of oddities, and I had a feeling this would be one of them.

When I arrived at her house, she led me to a small storage room filled with boxes and old furniture. Among the clutter, I spotted it – the old phonograph, its wooden box slightly battered but still recognizable. My heart skipped a beat. I couldn’t believe my eyes. It had been years since I had seen it.

I carefully lifted the phonograph from the pile of boxes and held it in my hands. The weight and texture of the wood brought back memories of my grandfather, who had always treated this piece with such reverence. I remembered him showing me how to handle it, how to clean the records, and the way he would sit by the phonograph, lost in the melodies of a bygone era.

My cousin smiled at my reaction. “I knew you’d be happy to see it,” she said. “Grandpa talked about you a lot. He was always excited to share his treasures with you.”

Tears welled up in my eyes as I gently placed the phonograph on a nearby table. I couldn’t help but think about all the times I had sat by my grandfather, listening to him play records and share stories. It was a connection that went beyond just music; it was a bond that connected us through time and space.

I decided to give the phonograph a proper cleaning and set it up in my living room, just as I had done so many years ago. I carefully replaced the records, one by one, and started playing them. The scratchy sound of the music filled the room, transporting me back to those days spent with my grandfather.

As I listened to the old songs, I began to recall specific moments – the times we would sit in silence, just enjoying the music, or the times we would talk about life, dreams, and everything in between. Each record seemed to hold a story, a piece of our shared history.

I realized that the phonograph was more than just a piece of furniture or a relic; it was a bridge to my past, a way to keep my grandfather’s memory alive. It reminded me of who he was and how much he loved music. It also reminded me of the love and care he had for me, even after he was gone.
