[Reference Story]: Prosopagnosia v. Cotard's Syndrome


My new doctor - a bright and friendly guy named Sarbjit - took the time to explain his diagnosis to me. He told me my condition was mental, not physical, but it was hard to pay attention to everything he said because my left arm was numb and rotting from the inside out. I smiled and nodded and then when I got home I looked up Cotard's Syndrome online. Here is what Wikipedia had to say on it.

"Cotard's syndrome, also known as ‘Cotard's delusion' or ‘Walking Corpse Syndrome', is a rare mental disorder in which the affected person holds the delusional belief that they are dead, do not exist, are putrefying, or have lost their blood or internal organs."

I don't know. Sounded extremely strange to me. I just knew my left arm was dying. Maybe my liver too. I used my right arm, the good one, to open my mail. Most of it was just the normal stuff but when I saw the letter from the Supreme Court of the State of New York I got a little worried. I was here legally - a citizen for almost ten years now - and I knew my rights but being summoned to testify at this criminal trial was a bit unnerving. I didn't like it. I just try to do my best in this life and mind my own business and not cause problems for others.

When my trial appearance date arrived two months later I took the subway downtown and left my assistant, Stavvy, in charge of the office that day. I sat there on a hard wooden bench in the courtroom all morning listening to the testimony of other witnesses but I wasn't called to the stand until sometime after we returned from lunch. Eventually, the lawyer for the defense called my name.

She mispronounced it of course - people here always mispronounce Albanian names - so I wasn't surprised when she called me Mister Shka-Rell-Eee. My surname is Shkreli, after the place where my family comes from, and the proper pronunciation contains only two syllables - Shkrell-Eee. I was trying to hold my left arm in place when she asked her opening question.

Where was I at the time of the murder?

"Well, Miss Anderson" - I pronounced it Ahnd-REE-Sawn, drawing out the first and last syllables while placing too much emphasis on the middle one, intentionally - "I am not entirely certain. That was over a year ago and I travel all around this city on a daily basis for my job. I work in computer repair and IT support and I have customers in all five boroughs." (This wasn't exactly true. I wasn't really willing to travel to Staten Island.) We had spoken four months earlier when she informed me of the questions she intended to ask at trial but I was fairly oblique then and I intended to remain so now. I had bigger problems. Could these people not see that my left arm was rotting away?

She looked at me with a furrowed brow and briskly walked back to the defense table, picked up a leather-bound notepad and opened it.

"Mister Shkreli, when you and I spoke on June 18th you confirmed that you were just leaving a client's office, TRG Commercial Realty, located at 223 Broome Street here in lower Manhattan at approximately 3:30pm that day, shortly before the incident at issue took place less than one block away. Is that not correct?"

I turned up my native eastern European accent a bit and repositioned my left arm in my lap. I could barely feel it at that point. What was wrong with these people?

"If you say so. Like I said, that was over a year ago and it was just another workday for me."

She stared at me for a beat or two longer than necessary and then flashed a quick look towards the jurors before continuing.

"Well yes, Mister Shkreli" - again it was Shka-Rell-Eee - "You did tell me that and I do have a recording of our conversation, which you consented to before we began, if the court would like this to be entered into evidence?"

She looked at the judge and the judge looked at me.

"Mister Shkreli," - he too pronounced it Shka-Rell-Eee - ‘Are you refuting the testimony that Miss Anderson is referencing during your preliminary deposition or can we just move on at this point? If counsel for the defense claims to have this recording I am fairly certain this is true. Will it be necessary to enter this recording into evidence at this time or are you willing to acknowledge Miss Anderson's claim?"

I repositioned my left arm in my lap and nodded.

"That's fine, Your Honor. As I said, it was just another workday for me but if Miss Anderson says that is what we discussed I am sure she is probably right."

The judge nodded back at me. "Very good. Let's proceed then."

Miss Anderson walked back to the defense table and dropped the leather-bound notepad before continuing with her final question for me, looking annoyed.

"Picking up where we left off, Mister Shkreli, can you please describe for the court what happened immediately after you left the offices of TRG Commercial Realty at 223 Broome Street on the date in question, October 22nd of last year?"

I didn't like the way that she was trying to fence me in but I wasn't particularly concerned. I had bigger problems.

"Well, like I said, I don't really remember that day. There was nothing memorable about it. It was just another day."

She stared at me for a few seconds then flashed a quick look at the jury box with her eyebrows raised before returning her attention to the judge. "No more questions, Your Honor."

I was dismissed from the stand but asked to remain in the courtroom as she called her next witness; a small, frail woman from Queens about my same age named Maureen Stewart. She had an odd, twitchy nature about her. I wanted to get home. I wanted to relax.

"Miss Stewart, can you please tell the court where you were on October 22nd of last year at approximately 3:30 in the afternoon?"

The witness looked down for a moment and then glanced towards the judge before removing the slightly confused look from her face and responding in a semi-automated tone.

"Yes, Miss Anderson. At that time, I was just leaving my day shift at the FedEx Office Store (she pronounced it ‘Staw' in her thick New York accent) on Broome Street and I was walking towards the station for the Six Train to begin my ride back home."

The attorney for the defense took a momentary pause and then asked her next question.

"And can you please tell us what happened then?"

The witness looked down again and then looked back at the judge, then the jury and, finally, at me. I didn't like the way she looked at me.

"Yes, as I was leaving my workplace I crossed the street and I remember walking past the entrance to a narrow alleyway where I heard a commotion taking place. It made me stop and look for a second or two but I didn't want to get involved so I just kept on walking towards the subway and I didn't think too much about the whole thing until the Homicide detectives contacted me a few days later after they pulled the security camera videos. I came down to the police station the day after that and gave my statement. That was just over a year ago."

Miss Anderson took a moment to stare at me. I didn't like that either. I adjusted my left arm in my lap. It was completely numb.

"Thank you, Miss Stewart. Can you please be a bit more specific about what you saw occurring in that alleyway?"

Again, the witness looked down at the floor and then her eyes shot all around the courtroom before she responded.

"Well," she said, before taking a brief pause. "At first I thought it was just a little scuffle but when I saw the shorter man in the black jacket punch the tall man in the belly a few times I saw some blood starting to spread on the side of his white button-down shirt and I saw what looked like a small knife or something in the shorter man's hand. The tall thin man looked like he was starting to fall. I remember looking around for a police officer but I certainly wasn't gonna do anything about it by myself. I mean, what could I do? When I didn't see no one who could help I just kept on walking towards the subway. I guess I should have done more but I was scared and I just wanted to get back to Forest Hills to pick up my daughter from daycare before five o'clock."

I glanced at the defendant seated at the table on the left. He looked both hopeful and nervous at the same time, but in a subtle way, like he didn't want to appear to be either. He kept his head down and never once glanced towards the jury box. Miss Anderson asked her final question.

"Thank you, Miss Stewart. And do you see the man in the black jacket who stabbed the victim, Mister Baronston, on that day last October here in the courtroom now?"

Again the witness looked down at the floor between her feet for a moment and then looked back up, right at me. I felt my blood stop flowing through my veins, or at least through my left arm and the top of my right leg, when she raised up her hand and pointed her index finger at me.

"It was that man, there," she said.

Miss Anderson nodded and paused for a moment, satisfied, letting it sink in for the jury members. I was stunned. The stylish defense attorney in the toney, expensive clothing began walking back in my direction and she too pointed an accusatory finger.

"If it pleases the court, let the record show that Miss Stewart has identified Mister Jack Shkreli as the attacker who she witnessed in the-"

Just then the witness on the stand, Miss Stewart, pointed her finger at the judge without really looking at him and suddenly blurted out, "Or him. It might have been him too. I'm not 100% sure..."

Miss Anderson paused, clearly nonplussed, and just stared at her witness. The judge also looked baffled for a second or two and then leaned over and whispered something to his court assistant and the two of them shared a quiet smirk.

Then the witness pointed at one of the jurors, a man in the front row about my size.

"Or him. It could have been him. I'm just not sure..." Then she went silent, as did the rest of the courtroom for a few moments. The State's Attorney, a heavy-set bald man, broke the silence pretty quickly as he rose to his feet.

"Your Honor, the State would like to move to dismiss this witness along with all previous testimony." He paused briefly and took a deep breath, choosing his next words.

"While we appreciate Miss Stewart's willingness to appear at trial today, I think it's clear that her recollection of events is…uncertain at best." He glared at the defense table for a moment, then added "I'd just like to remind the court that Mister Shkreli" - and God bless him, he pronounced my two-syllable surname correctly - "is not on trial here and if this witness cannot distinguish the man she saw that day from yourself or a random member of our jury panel I don't think we can accept this testimony or any further testimony from this witness."

He hung his head respectfully, with the tiniest little smile on his face. He already knew he had won this argument and the judge quickly agreed, telling the jury to disregard what they just heard. Miss Stewart was dismissed from the stand and the defense had no other witnesses left to call. Less than two hours later the jury returned a guilty verdict against the defendant on all counts and the courtroom was cleared. The sentencing hearing would take place at a later date and I was not required to be there. My right leg was starting to feel numb by then but I still managed to get back to the office in time for Stavvy to head home at the end of his shift to make dinner for his kids. His wife was killed in a car accident two years earlier. He was a hard worker and I really liked him.

That night, back at my apartment, I did some research online and learned about a rare mental disorder known as Prosopagnosia. Here is what Wikipedia had to say.

Prosopagnosia, also known as face blindness, is a cognitive disorder of face perception in which the ability to recognize familiar faces, including one's own face (self-recognition), is impaired, while other aspects of visual processing (e.g. object discrimination) and intellectual functioning remain intact.

It all sounded pretty strange to me but if the doctors say it's real who am I to argue? Apparently it is well documented in the DSM-5. I don't know if this is the reason why I was able to walk away from the courtroom without consequence at first but I think it is the most likely explanation. I only know that when I left my client's offices at TRG Commercial Realty on that day just over a year ago and hailed a cab I was stunned and confused when Mister Baronston, a complete stranger with a hostile face, suddenly attacked me, claiming that it was his cab and not mine.

He was bigger than me, tall and thin but strong, and I would have just given up the cab and caught the next one but he was clearly already very angry about something. When he backed me towards the alley, shoving me and then punching me around my head and neck, my backpack tumbled open and I saw my wallet and phone and some other items come crashing out onto the pavement. It was just a stupid and unnecessary altercation, the kind of thing that probably happens on the streets of this city every day, sadly. Too many people, not enough space. I did my best to fight back and protect myself but he was a good deal bigger than me.

Then I was getting punched some more and thrown against the alley wall as people passed by, disinterested, and I just instinctively reached into my jacket pocket and pulled out the pen knife that has been attached to my keychain for years. Before I really knew what was happening it was open and then my right hand was growing warm and red and slick with his blood. Then I was moving again, not looking back.

What an odd thing. I remember seeing Miss Stewart stopping there on the sidewalk to look from the mouth of the alley that day. Of all the passers-by, she was the only one who paused to look at us, at me, right as I desperately punctured Mister Baronston's rib cage for the fifth or sixth time with my little penknife and he began to drop, but she averted her gaze after a few seconds and moved on and then I was rapidly heading in the opposite direction. This is a huge city and I never expected to see her face again. Fortunately, she was apparently never really able to see mine.

Anyway, I have more important problems to worry about at this time. Stavvy received a letter from the Manhattan DA's office yesterday ordering him to appear at a grand jury hearing next month related to my involvement in Mister Baronston's death. He showed it to me. More importantly, my left arm is just about gone now, my right leg is quickly starting to feel the same way and in just the last day or two I have begun feeling that strange tingling sensation in the tips of the fingers on my right hand. I know my liver is failing. It won't be long now.

I scheduled a meeting with my lawyer in the morning to legally put the business and the rest of my assets in Stavvy's name in my will. I have no family here anyway and almost no relatives who I remain close with back in Albania or Montenegro anymore. Stavvy is a good man and he has kids to feed and I have already lived a full life.

So yes, I will just leave it all to him and after that's done I think I will get the old Ford minivan that we sometimes still use for the business and drive it out to the George Washington Bridge while I am still able. I know that when I stop it and get out and leave it there on the center-span I will screw up traffic badly and inconvenience a lot of people but I can't worry about that. I have to do what I have to do. There's no point in waiting for this to get worse. I can barely feel the fingers on my right hand and I don't have much time left.

Maybe I should have told the truth at the trial. I don't know. I think I was just too distracted by all of my health problems. I didn't really have any choice at the time. I don't have any choice now. I'm actually surprised that I lasted this long. I was certain that I would already be gone a few months ago but I feel I have done my best with this life.

As my people back in Albania say, Mos pyet si vdiq, por si rrojti!

"Do not ask how he died, but how he lived!"

THE END"

**A Shadow in the Night**

Dr. Elena Kovac was a woman of few words, her eyes often reflecting the depth of her introspection. Her office, adorned with minimalist decor and soft lighting, was a sanctuary of calm amidst the chaos of her life. Her latest patient, Victor Kane, was a stark contrast. Tanned and muscular, with a rugged face that had seen its share of sun and hardship, Victor exuded an air of self-assuredness that belied the turmoil within him.

Victor sat across from Dr. Kovac, his eyes darting around the room as if searching for something or someone. He was there to discuss a troubling development. For weeks now, Victor had been experiencing vivid nightmares that seemed more real than reality itself. In these dreams, he found himself in a dark, labyrinthine building, pursued by an unseen figure. The entity was always just out of reach, its face obscured by shadows, but its presence was unmistakably malevolent.

Dr. Kovac took a moment to gather her thoughts before speaking. "Victor, these nightmares are distressing, I'm sure. But they could be a sign of something deeper. Have you been under significant stress lately?"

Victor ran a hand through his hair, his face a mask of confusion. "I've been under a lot of pressure, yes. My business has been facing some challenges, and I've been working long hours. But these dreams... they're not just about work. There's something more sinister at play."

Dr. Kovac leaned forward, her gaze intense. "Describe the dreams to me. Pay close attention to details, even the ones that seem insignificant."

Victor took a deep breath, his eyes closing momentarily as he tried to summon the images from his subconscious. "It's always the same place. An old, abandoned building. I can hear the creaking of the floorboards and the distant echo of my own footsteps. The walls are covered in peeling paint, and there's a musty smell in the air. I'm always running, trying to escape something, but I can't see what it is. It's like it's hiding from me, waiting for the perfect moment to strike."

Dr. Kovac nodded, her expression thoughtful. "This could be a manifestation of your subconscious fears. It's not uncommon for the mind to create such vivid dreams when we're under stress or dealing with unresolved issues."

Victor shook his head, his voice tinged with desperation. "It's more than that. I feel like there's a connection. Something real. Like I'm being haunted by something from my past. And it's getting worse. I've started to see shadows in my waking life, as if someone is watching me."

Dr. Kovac's eyes widened slightly. "Victor, this is highly unusual. It's important that we explore this further. Have you considered keeping a journal of these experiences?"

Victor nodded, a mix of relief and anxiety in his eyes. "I have. I've been writing down every detail, every shadow, every feeling. But it's not helping. If anything, it's making it worse."

Dr. Kovac rose from her chair, her voice taking on a gentle, reassuring tone. "Victor, we'll get to the bottom of this. But for now, try to focus on your daily tasks and avoid dwelling on the nightmares. We'll schedule some sessions to delve deeper into this issue and see if we can uncover the root cause."

Victor looked at her, a glimmer of hope in his eyes. "Thank you, Dr. Kovac. I know this is strange, but I feel like you're the only one who can help me."

As Victor left the office, Dr. Kovac couldn't shake the feeling that this case was anything but ordinary. There was a darkness lurking in Victor's dreams, a shadow that threatened to cast a long, sinister reach into his waking life. And as she closed the door behind him, she made a mental note to dig deeper, to uncover the mystery that lay hidden in the shadows.

**The Dark Labyrinth**

That night, Victor returned to his lavish apartment on the Upper East Side, a sanctuary that had once brought him comfort. But tonight, the opulence felt like a cage, and the echoes of his dreams still lingered in the air. He decided to sit by the window and try to clear his mind, hoping the view of the city might offer some solace. The lights of Manhattan danced in the distance, a stark contrast to the darkness that seemed to envelop his own thoughts.

As he gazed out at the bustling city, his mind wandered back to Dr. Kovac's words. There was something unsettling about her calm demeanor and the way she seemed to see right through him. He couldn't shake the feeling that she was hiding something, that there was more to her than met the eye. It was as if she knew more about his nightmares than she let on.

Victor's phone buzzed, pulling him from his thoughts. It was a message from his assistant, alerting him to an urgent email. He quickly checked his phone and found an email from an unknown sender. The subject line read: "What you don't know could hurt you." His curiosity piqued, he opened the email, only to find a single attachment: a photo of the old, abandoned building from his dreams.

Victor's heart skipped a beat. He recognized the place immediately. It was a dilapidated warehouse on the outskirts of the city, a building he had never seen before in his life. His eyes scanned the photo, searching for any clues, any signs that might explain the connection to his dreams. But there was nothing. The photo was grainy and dark, with no visible details to give away its origin.

He tried to shake off the unease, attributing it to the stress of the day. But as he stared at the photo, he couldn't help but feel a growing sense of dread. There was something unsettling about the image, something that felt...off. It was as if the photo was trying to tell him something, but he just couldn't grasp what it was.

As the night wore on, Victor's thoughts continued to spiral. He found himself replaying the events of the day, questioning every detail, every interaction. Had he missed something? Was there something he should have noticed but hadn't? His mind raced with possibilities, each more unsettling than the last.

Finally, exhaustion took over, and Victor decided to call it a night. He set his phone on silent, placed the photo carefully on his bedside table, and climbed into bed. But sleep eluded him. The shadows in the room seemed to grow darker, more menacing, and he couldn't shake the feeling that someone was watching him.

As he lay there, eyes wide open, the memories of his dreams and the mysterious photo from his email began to blend together in his mind. He couldn't tell where one ended and the other began, and the line between reality and nightmare grew increasingly blurred. And in that space, where the boundaries of perception dissolved, Victor felt a chilling realization. He was being watched, not just in his dreams, but in his waking life. And he had no idea who—or what—was behind it.

**A Glimpse into the Past**

As the days passed, Victor found it increasingly difficult to concentrate on his work. The image of the dilapidated warehouse haunted him, and the unsettling feeling that had taken root in his mind grew stronger with each passing hour. He decided it was time to dig deeper into his past, hoping to uncover any hidden connections that might explain these bizarre occurrences.

Victor spent hours pouring over old photographs and documents in his office, searching for any mention of the warehouse or anything that might be related to his dreams. His assistant, Sarah, brought him coffee and checked in on him periodically, her concern evident in her eyes. "You okay, Victor? You've been looking pretty tired lately."

Victor forced a smile. "Just stressed with the business, Sarah. You know how it is."

But deep down, he was worried. The more he looked, the more he realized that he had no memory of ever visiting that warehouse. It was as if it existed outside the realm of his own experiences, a ghostly relic from a life he couldn't recall. The feeling of being watched intensified, and he began to question whether the shadows in his dreams were somehow linked to real-life threats.

Finally, in a box buried in the back of his office closet, Victor found an old newspaper clipping. It was a brief article from ten years ago about a series of mysterious disappearances in the area surrounding the warehouse. The article mentioned that the police had been unable to find any leads or connections between the victims, and the case had since gone cold.

Victor's heart raced as he read the article. The description of the disappearances mirrored the events in his dreams—the dark labyrinthine building, the sense of being pursued by an unseen entity. Could this be the key to understanding his nightmares? He felt a surge of hope mixed with fear. If he could uncover the truth behind these disappearances, he might finally be able to put an end to the haunting dreams and the unsettling feeling that someone was watching him.

He made a mental note to visit the police records and speak to the detective who had worked on the case. For now, he would keep his findings to himself, at least until he had more concrete evidence. He couldn't risk alerting anyone to what he was investigating. The last thing he needed was to attract unwanted attention.

As he closed the newspaper clipping and replaced it in the box, Victor felt a strange sense of determination. He was on the brink of uncovering a mystery that had eluded him for years. And no matter how dangerous the journey ahead might be, he was determined to face it head-on. Because if he didn't, the shadows in his dreams and the ones in his waking life would continue to grow darker, threatening to consume him entirely.

**The Unseen Observer**

Victor's investigation into the mysterious disappearances took him to the city's archives and the local police station. He spent countless hours poring over old case files and speaking to anyone who had any connection to the warehouse or the missing persons reports. Each new piece of information only deepened the enigma surrounding the place.

One evening, as he was about to leave the police station after another fruitless day, a middle-aged detective named Thomas Collins approached him. "Mr. Kane, I see you're looking into the old disappearances case," he said, his eyes sharp and inquisitive. "I was the lead detective on that case back in the day. I thought you might find this interesting."

Victor felt a spark of hope. "That's incredible. I would love to hear anything you remember about it."

Detective Collins led him into a small, dimly lit office and pulled out a folder from a shelf. "Here's what we have. It's not much, but it might help you piece together the puzzle."

Victor opened the folder and found a series of photographs and documents, including a sketch of the warehouse and a list of the missing persons. As he scanned through the papers, he noticed something peculiar. The sketch of the warehouse was eerily similar to the one he had seen in his dreams and the photo he received from his unknown sender. It was as if the building had a life of its own, haunting him across different timelines.

Detective Collins noticed Victor's reaction. "I've always wondered if there was more to that place than just an old warehouse. There were times when I felt like I was being watched, like someone was hiding in the shadows. But I never had any proof."

Victor's eyes met Collins's. "Do you remember any strange occurrences at the warehouse? Anything out of the ordinary?"

Collins thought for a moment. "There was one night when we were investigating, it was late, and we were the only ones there. We heard a strange noise, like someone whispering. We couldn't see anything, but the hairs on the back of our necks stood up. It was unsettling."

Victor's heart pounded in his chest. This was exactly the kind of information he needed. "Did you ever find out who owned the warehouse?"

Collins shook his head. "No. The owner was never identified. The place was abandoned, and it was falling apart. We thought it was just a deserted building until we started finding clues that suggested something more sinister was at play."

The name seemed familiar, but he couldn't place it immediately. He made a mental note to look into the background of this person, hoping it would lead him closer to the truth.

The shadowy figure in his dreams and the whispers he had heard were becoming harder to ignore. He pushed it open, stepping into a room that felt like it had been frozen in time.

The room was small, with peeling paint and dust-covered furniture. But it was the objects scattered around that caught his attention. There were old photographs, newspaper clippings, and a collection of artifacts that seemed out of place. Among them, Victor found a journal belonging to Thomas Blackwood. His heart raced as he flipped through the pages, each entry revealing more about the man and the dark secrets he had kept.

As he read, Victor discovered that Thomas Blackwood had been involved in a series of illegal activities, from smuggling to human trafficking. The more he read, the more he realized that Blackwood had been using the warehouse as a hideout for his operations. But it wasn't just the journal that intrigued Victor; it was the letters attached to it.

The letters were from a woman named Isabella, who claimed to have been Blackwood's accomplice. She described the horrors they had committed together, the fear, and the darkness that had enveloped their lives. Victor felt a chill as he read about the terrible acts they had carried out, and the sense of being watched seemed to intensify.

Victor's mind raced as he pieced together the puzzle. The shadows in his dreams, the whispers, the nightmares—he realized they were all connected to this dark past. Blackwood's journal mentioned a hidden room beneath the warehouse, a place where he had kept his most valuable secrets. Victor knew he had to find it.

He returned to the warehouse, his senses on high alert. He spent hours searching through the rubble, following clues from Blackwood's journal. Finally, he found a hidden trapdoor in the basement. As he lowered himself into the darkness below, he felt a sense of dread. He had no idea what he would find, but he knew he had to face the truth.

The basement was a maze of old pipes, broken beams, and dust-covered debris. Victor navigated the darkness, his flashlight casting eerie shadows on the walls. He followed the clues from the journal, until he reached a locked door. He found a key among the debris and unlocked it, stepping into a hidden room.

The room was small but meticulously organized. It was filled with documents, photographs, and artifacts related to Blackwood's operations. But it was the final item in the room that stopped him in his tracks—a painting of a woman, her eyes filled with fear and sorrow. Victor recognized the woman from the letters—Isabella.

Victor's heart pounded as he studied the painting. It was as if Isabella was looking right at him, pleading for help. He turned to leave, but as he did, he noticed something written on the back of the painting. It was a message from Isabella, warning him about the darkness that still lingered in the warehouse.

Victor's mind raced as he read the message. It spoke of a curse, a malevolent force that had been unleashed and was now haunting the place. He realized that the shadows in his dreams, the whispers, and the sense of being watched were all part of this curse. And now, it was closing in on him.

As Victor made his way back to the surface, he felt a growing sense of urgency. He knew he had to find a way to break the curse and put an end to the nightmares that had been haunting him. He had to confront the darkness that still lingered in the warehouse and free himself from its grasp. Because if he didn't, the shadows would continue to grow darker, threatening to consume him entirely.

**The Final Confrontation**

Victor returned to the warehouse late at night, determined to face the darkness that had been haunting him. He had spent days researching ancient rituals and curses, hoping to find a way to break the malevolent force that seemed to be connected to the place. Armed with his knowledge and a few sacred artifacts, he prepared himself for the confrontation that awaited him.

As he stepped into the dimly lit basement, Victor felt a cold presence surround him. The air was thick with an eerie silence, as if the very walls were holding their breath. He moved cautiously, his senses on high alert. He reached the hidden room where he had found the painting and stood before it, his heart pounding in his chest.

The painting seemed to come to life before his eyes. Isabella's eyes locked onto his, her expression a mixture of fear and determination. Victor took a deep breath, steadying himself as he began the ritual he had learned. He recited the ancient incantations, his voice echoing through the darkness, as he placed the sacred artifacts around the painting.

As he continued, Victor felt a growing sense of power, as if the energy of the artifacts was strengthening his resolve. But the darkness was not willing to give up without a fight. Suddenly, the room began to shake, and shadows seemed to writhe and twist, as if trying to escape the confines of the basement.

Victor pressed on, his voice growing louder and more determined. He felt the power of the ritual growing stronger, the shadows beginning to recede. But just as he thought he was gaining the upper hand, a sudden burst of cold air swept through the room, and a chilling voice echoed in his ears.

"Leave us alone, intruder," the voice hissed, its tone filled with malevolent intent.

Victor's heart raced as he turned to face the source of the voice. In the shadows, he could make out the figure of a man, cloaked in darkness, his face obscured by the shadows. It was Thomas Blackwood, the man who had unleashed the curse and now sought to protect it at all costs.

Blackwood moved towards Victor, his movements slow and deliberate, as if he was savoring the moment. Victor tightened his grip on the artifacts, his resolve unwavering. He knew he couldn't back down now. He had come too far, and he was determined to break the curse once and for all.

As Blackwood advanced, Victor began to chant the final incantation, his voice rising above the roar of the storm. He felt the power of the ritual surge through him, filling him with strength and determination. With a final, defiant shout, Victor hurled the sacred artifacts at Blackwood, the energy of the ritual exploding in a brilliant flash of light.

The room was bathed in the glow of the light, and for a moment, all was silent. Victor turned to find Blackwood standing at the edge of the room, his figure fading into the shadows. The curse had been broken, and the darkness that had haunted him for so long was finally vanquished.

Victor collapsed to his knees, his body shaking from the exertion. He had faced the darkness and emerged victorious. As the light began to fade, he looked back at the painting of Isabella, her eyes still filled with fear but now also with a glimmer of hope. Victor knew that he had freed her spirit, allowing her to finally find peace.

As he climbed to his feet, Victor felt a sense of relief wash over him. The shadows had been lifted, and he was free from their grip. He turned to leave the basement, his heart filled with a newfound sense of purpose. He had faced the darkness and overcome it, and now he was ready to move forward, ready to embrace the light.

With one final glance at the painting, Victor stepped out of the basement, leaving the darkness behind him, forever changed by the confrontation that had tested his courage and resolve.

**A New Beginning**

Victor emerged from the basement, the weight of the past finally lifting from his shoulders. The cold night air felt refreshing against his skin, a stark contrast to the oppressive darkness he had just escaped. He made his way back to the surface, his mind racing with thoughts and emotions. The confrontation with Blackwood had been a battle not just of wills but of spirits, and Victor had emerged victorious.

As he walked away from the warehouse, Victor felt a sense of peace settle over him. The nightmares had ceased, and the shadows that had haunted him for so long had been dispelled. He knew that he had faced his fears and emerged stronger for it. The darkness that had once seemed unbreakable had crumbled in the face of his determination and courage.

Victor's thoughts turned to Isabella. He felt a deep sense of gratitude for the spirit of the woman who had been caught in the web of Blackwood's evil deeds. He hoped that her soul had finally found peace, free from the torment that had plagued her for so long. Her strength and courage had inspired him, and he knew that he would carry her memory with him always.

As he reached the edge of the city, Victor took a deep breath, feeling the weight of his past burdens lift. He was ready to move forward, to embrace a new beginning. The future was uncertain, but he was no longer afraid. He had faced the darkness and emerged victorious, and he knew that he could overcome whatever challenges lay ahead.

With a sense of determination and hope, Victor walked into the dawn, ready to forge his own path and create a future filled with light and possibility. The shadows of the past were behind him, and he was ready to step into the bright, unknown future that awaited him.

[Reference Story]: It's been a long time since I had any people I'd call friends. Who needs them.


People yammer about the most mundane of things. The most boring or unimportant concepts. Nearby shops, food, the annoyances of other people. As if you can talk about the inanity of a conversation with someone without the slightest recognition that you yourself are just as bad. I know I'm as bad as everyone else. I partook in those conversations whenever the necessity arose. But I find myself far more at home consuming knowledge that has actual value. Pouring over various encyclopedia's and old novels. Sure, the information in an encyclopedia from two hundred odd years ago is out of date. It was probably wrong by the objective nature of reality at the time of its writing. But it has stood the test of time far better than any conversation you can hold with the common people of this day and age.

​I'm well known around Deteram Library. The staff don't bother me, they know I prefer my quiet and I always put my books back exactly where they came from. If I didn't have to eat or sleep, I'd likely never leave these walls. The librarians and cleaners have even gotten to the point where they'll simply allow me to go into any area I please. I've walked into the staff room and the janitor's closet at least once each. In my defense the rooms weren't properly marked. I apologized in each case and left but they seemed to hold no problem with my explorations.

A week ago though, I found a new door.

It was technically outside. Near to the car park, there was a small flight of concrete stairs I had not seen before, leading down to a heavy and very old looking door. It was beautiful and very well kept. I wouldn't be surprised if it's a single piece of Ebony given its look and weight. It wasn't locked either. But the hour was late and my stomach demanding, so I left. I've checked on my arrival each day since and the door hasn't been there. The staircase itself was missing every time and to be entirely honest, I had been starting to believe I had dreamed the entire discovery.

​Until today.

As I left the library just after sunset, there it was. Maybe I'd been checking the wrong place? I couldn't go another week of searching fruitlessly for this damnable place. So I opened the door. The bookcases here are actually fairly modern. High quality, very well maintained. I wouldn't even say any of these books are particularly valuable, or controversial. It seems like any other part of the library, I wonder why it's so secreted away?

I found a railing, looks like some kind of balcony. Goes down several floors. I can see at least five other railings, but after that it gets too dark. Can't see the bookcases on the other floors, but now I have to know what are in them! Haven't seen any staff yet, which is good. There's been some movement, the sound of books being put on a shelf or boots scuffing the floor in the next aisle over. So there are definitely other people down here. I'm just glad they're sensible enough to keep to themselves. The books are slightly ratty and yellowed. Is this the damaged pages section? Don't worry, I'll be careful with them, I'm not some kid.

​Took about an hour but I found a staircase down. Haven't found one up yet so it looks like the way I came in is the only entrance. That's really not a good idea. The bookcases are older down here. They probably haven't gotten around to updating them, the contents are still fairly recent though so that's a thing. Not entirely sure how long I've been down here at this rate, but there are so many books I can't help myself. So much knowledge that's going to waste without someone enjoying it. The weirdest part is that I don't remember actually reading any of these books. Sure, I want to read them, and I'll reach for them to check out the covers. But I put them back, none of them are the right book for right now apparently.

How many times have I walked these two aisles?

I have to say I'm starting to hate the other people perusing down here. No-one seems to be any good at putting things back where they got them. I keep finding books out of order, or on the wrong shelf or even the wrong bookcase. It's infuriating! At least they're not stealing them, but it's maddening.

​I'm hearing less noise from downstairs, I could head down? Maybe its more organized down there, I can actually concentrate on reading.

Why are the bookcases here so old? The books aren't even that old, it's just gaudy looking at these new covers sitting on rotting old wooden boards. The bookcases aren't really arranged very well, it's a maze down here. I'm not very far from the staircase back up of course, I could leave if I wanted but at this point I want to know what else I can find.

Why are the bookcases here so old? The books aren't even that bad, it's like looking at fresh prints sitting on the deck of some ancient pirate ship. Why am I holding this book? I didn't take it from a shelf, did someone around here slip it into my hands? How am I supposed to put it back if I don't know where they took it from? I'm being made to look like one of those inconsiderate slobs! I'd try to figure out where it belongs but this place is such a mess, there's no pattern to any of it!

​I want to leave.

I liked the floor above much better.

Where is the staircase up?

Not down, Up.

Why are the aisles so narrow, I can barely walk in them. I need the staircase up.

There's one going down.

Maybe it will lead to another one up?"

**A Solitary Scholar**

It's been a long time since I had any people I'd call friends. Who needs them, I often ponder. People yammer about the most mundane of things—details that would bore anyone with a modicum of intellect. The endless chatter about nearby shops, food, the petty grievances of others—it's as if they believe they can discuss the inanity of a conversation without recognizing their own contributions to the same cycle of triviality. I know I'm not immune to this; I've participated in such conversations when the necessity arose. Yet, I find far greater solace in consuming knowledge that has actual value. I pour over various encyclopedias and old novels, immersing myself in a world where words hold power and meaning. The information in an encyclopedia from two hundred years ago may be outdated, perhaps even factually incorrect by the objective nature of reality at the time of its writing. But it has endured, standing the test of time far better than any fleeting conversation shared by the common folk of today.

The Deteram Library has become my sanctuary. I am well known there, a solitary figure who prefers the quiet and always ensures my books are returned to their rightful places. The staff don't bother me; they understand my need for solitude. If I didn't have to eat or sleep, I might never leave these hallowed walls. The librarians and cleaners have even grown accustomed to my wandering ways, allowing me to explore areas that are typically off-limits. More than once, I have inadvertently entered the staff room or the janitor's closet, though I always apologize profusely when I do. They seem to hold no problem with my explorations, perhaps because they see in me a kindred spirit who values the quiet and the pursuit of knowledge above all else.

**A Mysterious Discovery**

A week ago, I stumbled upon something unusual. It was near sunset, and I was on my way home after another day of perusing the library's vast collection. As I exited through the main doors, my eyes were drawn to a small flight of concrete stairs that I had never noticed before. They led down, down into the shadows of the library's rear, almost as if they were hiding in plain sight. At the bottom was a heavy, old-looking door, its surface marred by time but exuding an air of ancient mystery. The wood was dark and rich, possibly ebony, and the door itself was unlatched, as if inviting me to explore.

My stomach growled, reminding me of the long day I had ahead, and I hesitated. Curiosity tugged at me, but practicality won out. I left, promising myself I would return the next day. Each subsequent visit, I checked the area near the car park, but the staircase and the mysterious door were nowhere to be found. I began to question whether I had dreamed the entire encounter, convinced that I was letting my imagination run wild.

Until today, when as I was leaving the library just after sunset, there it was again—the same staircase, leading down to the same door. My heart raced with a mix of excitement and trepidation. I couldn't let another day pass without investigating. With a deep breath, I opened the door and stepped inside.

**A Hidden World**

The room I entered was dimly lit, the only source of light coming from a single overhead bulb that flickered occasionally. The air was cool, carrying the faint scent of old paper and dust. As my eyes adjusted, I noticed the bookcases that lined the walls, their shelves filled with a collection of modern books. The bindings were sleek and the spines pristine, giving the impression that these volumes were meant for display rather than reading. It struck me as odd that such a hidden section would house books that seemed so ordinary.

I walked towards the railing that ran along the back of the room, from which I could see the other floors of this clandestine library. The railing was sturdy, its dark wood polished to a high sheen. I followed it to a balcony that extended out several floors, offering a view that was both exhilarating and a bit dizzying. Through the gaps in the darkness, I could just make out the silhouettes of other bookcases, hinting at even more hidden spaces beyond my immediate sight.

As I leaned against the railing, I heard the faintest sounds from the adjacent aisles—soft shuffles, the occasional clatter of a book being placed on a shelf, and the distant hum of voices. It was clear that this place was not abandoned or unused, but rather a secret haven for those who appreciated the quiet pursuit of knowledge. I felt a sense of belonging, as if I had discovered a hidden society of like-minded scholars.

Despite the allure of the balcony, my curiosity pulled me back into the main room. I wandered through the aisles, my footsteps echoing softly against the bare floor. The bookcases here were well-maintained, but they seemed disorganized, as if books were placed haphazardly without much regard for their categorization. It was a chaotic beauty, a labyrinth of knowledge waiting to be explored.

I reached out and picked up a book at random, its cover a deep blue with gold lettering that shimmered faintly in the dim light. The title was "The Enchanted Forest: A Tale of Magic and Mystery." It was a children's book, and I couldn't help but smile at its whimsical cover. I turned it over in my hands, pondering the juxtaposition of such a simple story against the complexity of the library that housed it. It seemed almost fitting that a place dedicated to the pursuit of knowledge would also hold stories of imagination and wonder.

As I returned the book to its shelf, I couldn't help but feel a sense of excitement. This hidden world was a testament to the diverse nature of human curiosity, a place where the mundane and the extraordinary coexisted in harmony. And I, solitary and unburdened by the trivialities of everyday life, was about to delve deeper into its mysteries.

**Navigating the Labyrinth**

I wandered deeper into the room, my footsteps echoing softly as I navigated the labyrinth of bookcases. The air grew cooler, and the light dimmed further, creating an almost mystical atmosphere. Each step seemed to bring me closer to a hidden truth, a secret knowledge that lay just beyond my reach. I reached out and touched the spines of the books, their smooth surfaces cool against my fingers. Some were worn and yellowed, while others were pristine, as if untouched by time.

I found a staircase that spiraled downward, its steps worn and creaking under my weight. As I descended, the room became even more secluded, the sounds of the outside world fading into a distant murmur. The walls were lined with rows upon rows of bookcases, their shelves bursting with volumes of every conceivable subject. It was a treasure trove of knowledge, a repository of human thought and experience.

I paused at the base of the staircase, taking a moment to absorb my surroundings. The room was filled with the scent of aged paper and ink, a fragrance that was both familiar and comforting. I inhaled deeply, savoring the feeling of being surrounded by so much knowledge. It was as if I had stepped into a different world, one where time seemed to stand still and the pursuit of understanding was the only goal.

I walked along the base of the bookcases, my eyes scanning the spines of the books. They were arranged seemingly at random, a chaotic display that belied the order within each volume. I reached out and pulled a book from a shelf, its cover a deep red with gold lettering that read "The History of Ancient Civilizations." I opened it, my eyes scanning the pages filled with intricate diagrams and detailed accounts of lost cultures. It was a treasure trove of information, a testament to the wonders of human achievement.

As I continued my exploration, I began to notice a pattern in the chaos. Certain themes seemed to repeat themselves, threads of knowledge that wove together to form a larger tapestry of human understanding. I found myself drawn to these connections, eager to unravel the mysteries they held. Each book I picked up was a puzzle piece, a piece of the larger puzzle that was human history.

I moved from one aisle to another, my curiosity driving me forward. I found books on astronomy, philosophy, literature, and even some that delved into the mysteries of the occult. Each subject was a world unto itself, a realm of knowledge that promised to expand my understanding of the universe. I felt a sense of excitement, a thrill at the prospect of discovering new ideas and insights.

As I walked, I couldn't help but think about the people who had come before me, the scholars and thinkers who had dedicated their lives to the pursuit of knowledge. I imagined them standing in these very aisles, poring over the same books, seeking answers to the same questions. It was a humbling thought, one that reminded me of the long tradition of intellectual curiosity that I was a part of.

I reached the far end of the room and turned back towards the staircase. I had only scratched the surface of this hidden world, and I knew that there was much more to discover. I was eager to continue my exploration, to delve deeper into the mysteries that lay hidden within these walls. And as I climbed the staircase back towards the surface, I couldn't help but feel a sense of anticipation. What new wonders awaited me in this secret library, this sanctuary of human thought and imagination?

**A Chaotic Conundrum**

As I continued my exploration, I found myself growing increasingly frustrated with the disarray of the library. The bookcases were a haphazard collection of old and new volumes, with books seemingly thrown onto shelves without any regard for organization. I stumbled upon several books that were out of place, some even lying on the floor amidst the shadows. My patience wore thin as I attempted to restore order, my fingers brushing against the dust-covered spines as I moved them back into their proper places.

I couldn't help but feel a sense of irritation every time I saw a book that had been carelessly placed on the wrong shelf or left lying open on a table. It was as if the very structure of the library was rebelling against the pursuit of knowledge it was meant to facilitate. I tried to focus on the content of the books, but the chaotic environment was a constant distraction. My mind wandered, imagining the chaos that would ensue if this library were ever to be inspected by the authorities.

I decided to take a break from the disarray and walked towards the sound of the voices I had heard earlier. As I approached, I could make out the faint murmur of conversations and the shuffling of feet. I peeked around the corner to find a small group of people, all engrossed in their own books, yet seemingly oblivious to the disorder around them. They were young, their faces lit by the glow of the overhead lights as they turned pages and made notes.

I watched them for a moment, feeling a mixture of admiration and frustration. They were passionate about their pursuits, but their disregard for the library's organization was palpable. I wanted to approach them and offer my assistance, to help them understand the importance of maintaining order. But I also understood that my presence might disrupt their concentration, so I remained silent, observing from a distance.

As I turned away, I couldn't shake the feeling that this hidden library was a microcosm of the world at large—a place where chaos reigned and order was a distant memory. It was a reminder that even in the pursuit of knowledge, humanity often fell short of its potential. And yet, despite the chaos, there was a certain beauty in the randomness, a reminder that even in disorder, there was a chance to find meaning and understanding.

**The Search for Stability**

I wandered deeper into the labyrinthine depths of the hidden library, my frustration mounting with each misplaced book and each ill-organized shelf. The narrow aisles seemed to close in around me, making it increasingly difficult to navigate. My thoughts grew more turbulent, a reflection of the disarray I found around me. I couldn't help but feel a sense of urgency, a need to bring some semblance of order to this chaotic sanctuary.

As I moved further from the main room, the light grew dimmer, and the air grew colder. The walls, once a simple backdrop, now seemed to close in on me, their aged wood creaking with each step I took. The shadows grew longer, dancing across the floor in an unsettling manner. I began to feel a sense of claustrophobia, as if the library itself was trying to trap me in its endless maze.

I reached a point where the bookcases seemed to merge into one another, their spines blending into a single, indistinguishable mass. It was as if I had entered a different realm, one where logic and reason had no place. My breath came in short, sharp bursts, my heart pounding in my chest. I felt a creeping sense of dread, a fear that I would never find my way back to the surface.

I paused, taking a deep breath to steady myself. I reminded myself that this was a library, a place of knowledge and understanding. It was my duty to navigate this maze and uncover the secrets it held. With renewed determination, I pushed forward, my steps growing firmer as I moved deeper into the unknown.

As I walked, I tried to focus on the patterns I had noticed earlier, the connections between seemingly disparate subjects. I reached out and touched the spines of the books, feeling the weight and texture of each volume. I was searching for a sign, a clue that would guide me back to the surface. And as I continued my journey, I held onto the hope that I would find not only the knowledge I sought but also the path back to the world of light and order that awaited me above.

**A Return to Order**

I finally found a narrow staircase that spiraled upward, its steps worn and familiar. Each step felt like a step closer to the surface, to the light and order that awaited me. As I climbed, the air grew warmer, and the sound of voices and footsteps grew louder, filling the narrow space with a sense of life and purpose. I reached the top and stepped out into the main room, my eyes adjusting to the brighter light.

The room was still chaotic, but the sense of disorder no longer overwhelmed me. I took a moment to gather myself, my mind racing with the knowledge I had gained and the mysteries I had yet to unravel. I realized that this hidden library was a reflection of the world outside—complex, disordered, and yet filled with infinite possibilities.

I walked back to the railing and looked out over the balcony, my heart filled with a sense of wonder. This hidden world had shown me the beauty of chaos and the power of order. I felt a deep connection to the scholars who had come before me, their pursuit of knowledge igniting a spark within me. I knew that this was just the beginning, that there was much more to discover and understand.

As I left the library, the sunlight bathed my face, and I felt a sense of peace. I was no longer a solitary scholar trapped in a world of trivialities. I was a part of something greater, a continuous journey of discovery and understanding. And with that realization, I embraced the chaos, ready to face whatever mysteries the world had in store for me.

I'm sorry to burden you with the letter but I must tell someone, I must write it down, if just to prove to myself I've not gone mad. I have to start from the beginning, again I'm sorry.

A few nights ago after a hard day of pushing the Krauts back out of REDACTED this tiny means nothing village, we settled in for the night and kept watch for any counter attack. We knew where the Germans were and they knew where we were. We were daring them to try something.

I lay in my hide up in the attic of a house, just like dad taught me, lying perfectly still, eye glued to my scope just waiting for some poor soul to pop his head out. Everything was silent, just the light wind and the occasional click of a lighter.

Then they came, all of a sudden this wave of them came charging at us, screaming like madmen. Most of them didn't even fire their rifles, or didn't get the chance. Our response was terrifying dozens of30'sopened up, 50's barking away and even mortars launched flares from somewhere behind the line. They were like lambs to the slaughter, no way they had any hope of getting through, I have no idea why we had so much firepower lined up for some no name village it seemed so out of proportion. But still they came, wave after wave, dozens upon dozens, I admit I've lost count how many lives I took, but I rest easy knowing I'm doing the lord's work, ridding the world one Nazi at a time.

But something didn't sit well, through my scope I saw them, they were all young, their uniforms slightly different to the normal Kraut grey's we'd encountered this past week. I guessed and a few of the guys agreed after it was done, that they must have been reserves from some occupied state, like Poland or Czechoslovakia, sent to die to hold us up while the Germans retreated.

What sick bastards just send men to dielike that Mary? Just to save their own skins for a few more days. They knew that Uncle Sam and the US Army were coming for them and they were rightly scared.

After about 30 mins our guns fell silent, at last they stopped coming. We restocked and reloaded, waiting nervously for a second attack, it never came. As the sun rose we saw the true extent of what had happened, must have been nearly 100 dead, I couldn't quite believe it. I said a prayer for them, that they may repent before the Lord.

Shortly after a voice came over a speaker, in almost perfect English, but with that unmistakable Kraut accent, asking if they may be allowed to retrieve the dead and wounded. We being good Christian folks we gave them that, but warned them any funny business and they'd see a repeat of the previous night.

What must have been nearly a platoons worth of what I assume were medics and stretcher bearers appeared from the ruins of the German lines, all wearing their white helmets and red cross smocks. They began gathering the bodies, but not all of them. They were checking each one and only taking certain ones. I watched one of them through my scope pass over a wounded man, reaching out with one hand and holding in his guts with the other and take a body that was very clearly dead.

I couldn't understand, first they'd sent these boys to die in a pointless attack, and now they were leaving them to die in the field, I laid my cross hairs over him andonlyby the Lord's virtue, resited the urge to send that bastard straight to hell.

After they took some of the dead, they only left those who had suffered massive injuries, missing limbs and a few of the victims of my own head shots, I'm fact I didn't see them take a single body with a head wound.

This is where they really made me sick and a few of us had to be restrained and threatened with a court marshal. They came out and killed the wounded.

Just walked out and bayoneted any who were still alive, those that could have been saved. One kid who it looked like he had taken a round or some shrapnel to his leg, a minor thing, he'd have been fine in a week or two. No.

Those fuckers stood over him as he cried out for help, we could all hear their cries, and stabbed him through the heart.

Only then did they take them away.

I'm sorry my love if this seems too much, but I don't know how I could write what came next without these details, if you get this letter, you need to tell the world what happened, they cant be allowed to get away with this.

All was quiet for the next 2 days, no contacts, no sound. But our orders stayed the same, we were to stay and hold REDACTED until we were relived and taken off the line.

On the third night a fog rolled in, we couldn't see much farther than 50 or 60 yards. We occasionally sent up flares, but this did little to helpbut reminded the Germans we were very much still here

I'd drawn night watch again and so I lay in my hide, waiting. Dougherty had just brought some some coffee to help me stay awake, I couldn't do much, what use is a sniper who cant see and further than the next G.I.?

All of a sudden there were shouts down the line of movement. I figured it was just someone getting skittish, it was so quiet, anything seemed like something and most of the time something was nothing.

I rolled back over and looked down my sight and I that's when I saw them. You have to believe me on this, Mary. I swear this wasn't a trick of the light, or being tired, I saw this, and I'm sure the other guys would say they did too if they still could.

Their eyes Mary, this figure started to emerge from the fog, and the eyes, were glowing, 2 yellow spots piercing the gloom. As they got closer, it looked like one of the conscripted Krauts from a few nights back, same uniform. I figured they has a few more platoons to have use waste ammo on. But this time, there was no screaming, no running.They just shambledsilently through the fog. Theydidn't respond to ID's and soone of the guysput a round through its chest.

Nothing, it didn't react, didn't go down, didn't make a sound, and kept walking. A few more shots rang out until the ping of his clip ejecting echoed through the night, I watched them, every one hit, centre mass. It kept walking, a few seconds later a round went through its skull and it dropped, the eyes faded away as it fell.

No one knew what to think, but I could hear them jostling the poor guy saying he must have missed. One of the other guys boasting he knew how to drop Krauts. He didn't miss Mary, I swear on my mom's grave, I watched them hit its chest,and it didn't drop, just carried on asif being hit with rocks.

The jostling didn'tlast long, a few shout's said more movement. Ashout came for aflareto go up togive us a better look,I almost wish they hadn't. I saw them before the others, dozens of them, their eyes shining through the fog.We opened fireand these things couldn't have cared less. They marched through the fire, their bodies being tornupby multiplehitsand they kept coming.

The odd lucky round hit a head and a body dropped, butno oneseemed to notice. Panic was setting in now, the first one hit our line, dropped over the barricade. I heard the screams over gunfire, soul wrenching shrieks from the guys below.

I know I should have done more, but it didn't seem real Mary. I looked though my scope and tried for headshots where I could,I must have dropped a few. But It wasn't enough, they kept coming.

That's whenI saw him Mary, the young soldier from the first attack, I'm sure it was him, I could see the wound on his leg, and the hole in his chest and his face, despite the eyes, he looked just as scared. I put him to rest, at least I did that.

We had to scramble to pull back from REDACTED, I'm not sure how many of us made it, but we lost more than a few good men last night. We managed to get out, and pull back to REDACTED. But they were coming we could hear them now, dozens of them just groaning in the night.

Now Mary, this isn't going to be easy, but I think this may be the last letter I can send for a while, the10th have been ordered to stay and hold the ground at REDACTED, give the rest of the rear units time to pull back, set up a new line. Ive managed to scribble this down while they load up the trucks and I've given this letter to a Chaplin from the 57th and he's sworn to me he'll get it to you and I pray to god that he has.

Know that I love you, and I pray for the day I can come back home to you. I know the lord will give me strength to carry out his work and that I'm in your thoughts and prayers as you are in mine.

All my Love

Your Edward.

Dear Sarah,

I hope this letter finds you well, but I fear the words I am about to write will be the last you hear from me. I can't shake the feeling that this might be my final letter, and I'm sorry for that. I'm sorry for everything I haven't told you, everything I've kept hidden. I must write this down, if only to remind myself of the truth. I must begin at the beginning, though I'm sorry for the burden it places on you.

It was a seemingly ordinary night, or so I thought. I was working late at the lab, just another night of researching this new project that had the potential to change the world. The building was eerily quiet, the only sounds being the hum of the machines and the occasional beep of the computers. I was on the tenth floor, alone, surrounded by the cold, sterile walls of the laboratory. I had been working on a formula to harness an unknown energy source, one that could revolutionize our understanding of physics.

At first, everything seemed normal. But then, I started to hear it. A faint, distant sound, like a whisper carried by the wind. I dismissed it at first, thinking it was just the air conditioning or one of the machines. But the sound grew louder, more distinct. It was a hum, a low-frequency vibration that seemed to resonate through my bones. I tried to focus on my work, but the noise wouldn't let up.

As the minutes passed, the hum grew stronger, and I noticed a strange light in the corner of my eye. It was a soft, green glow, flickering erratically. I turned to look and saw a portal, a swirling vortex of energy, materializing before me. I froze, my heart pounding in my chest. What was this? Where did it come from? I stood there, paralyzed with fear, as the portal continued to expand, growing larger and more defined.

And then they appeared. Figures, shrouded in the green light, emerging from the portal. They moved with a grace I had never seen before, their forms almost ethereal. But it wasn't their beauty that吓到了我—it was their eyes. Two glowing yellow spots, piercing through the darkness, watching me with a cold, calculating gaze.

I screamed, my voice echoing through the empty lab. I tried to run, but my feet felt like they were glued to the floor. The figures closed in on me, their movements fluid and deliberate. I could see their faces now, and they were not human. Their features were twisted, grotesque, and their eyes... their eyes were filled with a malevolence that sent shivers down my spine.

I reached for the nearest container, hoping to find something that could help me. My fingers brushed against a vial of the experimental formula. Without thinking, I poured it over my hands, hoping it would provide some protection. The liquid sizzled against my skin, causing me to cry out in pain, but it seemed to have no effect on the figures. They continued to advance, their eyes never leaving mine.

In a desperate bid to escape, I turned and ran towards the stairwell, hoping to find a way out of the building. The figures were quick, though, and they were right behind me. I could feel their breath on the back of my neck, their hands grasping at my clothes. I was so close to the stairwell, so close to freedom, but I couldn't move. My legs felt like they were made of lead, and I could barely breathe.

Just as I was about to be caught, I heard a loud explosion. The building shook, and the figures were thrown back, giving me just enough time to reach the stairwell and flee. I didn't stop running until I reached the safety of my apartment. I locked the door behind me, my heart pounding so hard I thought it would break free from my chest.

I tried to explain what had happened to the authorities, but they didn't believe me. They thought I was either delusional or trying to cover up something. But I knew the truth, Sarah. I know what I saw, and I know what those figures were.

I've spent the past few days researching, trying to find any information about this energy source or these creatures. I've come across some disturbing theories, some suggesting that this energy could be linked to an ancient civilization, one that used this power for sinister purposes. Others believe it could be a form of alien technology, left behind as a means of controlling or manipulating us.

Whatever the truth, I know one thing for certain: they're coming back. And this time, they won't be stopped.

If you receive this letter, Sarah, I'm begging you, please investigate this. Don't let them get away with this. Don't let them come for us.

I love you, and I will always pray for your safety.

Your Robert.

[Reference Story]: Ah, look at that. It's a cardboard box, sitting on a hill. A lonely hill, at first glance. The cardboard box was a cardboard color, that off-brown. It was a common color, more common than bark here. But there was only one for a good distance around, so I guess we'll have to settle with this one. Come on. Let's get a closer look!


This box was upside down, so when the smarter critters of this world looked down from their cardboard planes they'd see a cross in its little flaps. Not that the box couldn't be opened on both ends, it's just that the skywards side was taped up and impenetrable.

The box was meant to be carried this direction, though. Whoever had opened it had opened it up from the wrong side. You could tell because this box had two little oval-shaped dotted lines, which could be popped on out to lift the thing. One was still in. The other had disappeared, having turned into the only part of the box for folk like us. Observers, who couldn't do much with cardboard but peak in. The inside of the box was mostly hidden in shadow, like a nest of black fur. Maybe this box was empty! But it most likely wasn't, the box-critter is probably sleeping. Here, let's try to wake it up. A bit of wind would probably do the trick.

woooooooooooshhhhhhhhhhh…

Good job, good job, that's— that's a good wind. A constant breeze, which causes the grass about the hill to flow up and down in hollow V-shapes alongside those who traverse in boats on the opposite side of the dirt. The grass was once again alive, and trading gossip as much as grass ever does. Petty little plants.

Our box was not ready for the wind. It was pushed up into the air just a few inches, before eight-odd triangles covered in static-filled hairs erupted out of the box and clicked into place about the dirt and stone. That little handle-hole, the one which had been popped out by someone some time back, gained two round golden eyes, like lost fireflies who'd soared a bit too high in that night sky. The box-critter spun in a circle, looking about for whoever had spawned this wind. But after not seeing much of anything, it settled on making an annoyed Tik tik! sound, and started off on its way down the hill. Come on, let's follow it. Maybe it'll lead us to something interesting.

You know, I'm surprised this one is alone. They normally travel in groups! Hm? Oh, yeah, I'm sure the groups have an actual name, I just don't know what it is. The box-critter doesn't seem to know quite where it is going. It makes its way down one hill just to go up another. It seems to have a solid goal though, spinning about at the top of every hill before choosing which one it'll go to next. It always seems to choose the tallest one, maybe searching for a good view, or something more useful. Do you think it's lost? Is that why it isn't with a group? How sad.

A sound was added to the music of the landscape. Up until now, the noise was basically just background, not really making for an important Observation. It was just acting out its part in the world because it had to, because it was always there, and because it was nice. The breeze made for a good chorus and the grass added some interesting verses. But it was all disrupted by the sad growling of the box-critters hidden stomach. Tik tik. The box-critter kept wandering. It kept looking for food. The firefly lights in its box's handle-peephole grew dim. I… don't like Observing this. But we've already chosen it as our Narrated, and I don't see any other cardboard critters around to switch it with…

Here's the thing about grass. As I've mentioned, they're petty creatures, but they're also important ones. Grass divides one place from another. Crossing grass has to happen no matter who you are or where you're going. And grass can be very helpful, when they're kind enough to use their role as Bridge to Everywhere to accomplish great things…

And, well, I'd really like to think grass is forgiving, whether or not that's the case is up to you.

The grass didn't react. Then one, tiny strand, one that had just sprouted and couldn't even be really seen by anyone but ants and the smallest of Observers, decided it wanted to be what I'd just Narrated. It decided it wanted to try, even if it didn't really like Observers as a concept. After all, what was the point of being an Observer? Wasn't the world built to be interacted with? Wasn't it a blade of grass so that it could talk with and traverse the dirt? The child blade sunk into the dirt, inverting its small piece of the hill quilt. And the rest of the grass decided to join it, in a rare domino effect. The box-critter fell into a sinkhole, and popped up on the other side of the grass, where a muddy-green sea expanded in all directions. The box-critter was sitting in its cardboard shell as though it were a boat, which meant it was very much exposed for the time being. Box-critters are simple beings. Just black fur, legs, and eyes. It clutched the frontmost wall of its boat-box and watched the waves pass by. It was either confused by how it had gotten here or happy with the view, it's up to you.

Here, let's blow the water, we can push the box-critter along. Create a V-shape in the water. Maybe someone traversing the hills will see it in the grass, and imagine up a story for the specific adventure that we're causing. Who knows! The water passes by. The colors change, from green-brown to a perfect clear, with the roots of the grass rise upwards like seaweed in the water. Actually, some of the grass looks sick. Mushrooms, some fungus or another, was growing along their roots, trying to kill them off where they can't defend themselves. The fungus is of an edible breed, let's help out our box-critter while also aiding the grass that got us here.

We blew the fungus off the grass, so it floated atop the water, off-white islands just within reach of the box-critters' pyramidal legs. It made for a solid meal, though the consistency of soggy mushrooms got dull after a bit I'm sure. The box-critter was creative though, bending the mushrooms in different shapes over the side of its cardboard boat and leaving them out to dry for a bit. Tik tik, it said."
